list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

hom.sense: [The twenty-second letter of the Alphabet, called kaAfN. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap, or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice; and it also belongs to the class called Xajariy-ap. It is a radical letter.]
[As a numeral it denotes twenty.]
[k, as a pronominal suffix, as a preposition, and as a particle of allocution, see Supplement.]
R. Q. 1. kaOokaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kaOokaOapN; (TA;) and takaOokaOa↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also tkEkE; (Ṣ;) He drew back, or retired, and was cowardly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kaOokaOa, inf. n. kaOokaMCN, [respecting the form of which see ZaOoZaOa,] He was very impatiently cowardly. (AA, Ḳ.) [In the CK., in the explanation of the inf. n., Aljabiynu is put for Aljubonu.]
Also, inf. n. as above, He (a thief) ran away. (Ḳ, TA.)
See R. Q. 2.
R. Q. 2. takaOokaOa He was prevented, or hindered. (Lth.)
takaOokaOa fiI kalaAmihi He hesitated in his speech, and was unable to speak. (Ḳ.)
takaOokaOa Ealayohi Aln-aAsu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and kaOokaOa↓, (Ḳ,) The people collected around him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) crowded, or pressed, upon him. (TA.)
And see R. Q. 1.

entry.sense: mutakaOokiYN Short. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

1. kaYiba, aor. _a {yakoOabu}, inf. n. kaOobapN and kaMbapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kaOobN (Ḳ) and kaOobaMCu; (TA;) and AktOb↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He was in an evil state, and broken [in spirit] by grief, or mourning; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he was in grief, unhappy, sorrowful, or sad. (Ḳ.) See also 4.

hom.sense: 4. AkObhu He caused him to grieve, or mourn, or to be unhappy, sorrowful, or sad; (Ḳ;) threw him into grief, or mourning, &c. (TA.)

AkOb He was in grief, or mourning; was unhappy, sorrowful, or sad: (Ḳ:) or he entered upon a state of grief, mourning, unhappiness, sorrow, or sadness; or a state of being changed and broken in spirit by reason of intense anxiety. (TA.) See also 1.
He fell into destruction, or ruin. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. AktOb wajohu AlOaroDi ‡ [The face of the earth, or land, became of sad aspect]. (TA.) See 1.
kaYibN: see kaYiybN.

kaOobaMCu Grief, mourning, unhappiness, sorrow, or sadness: (Ḳ:) [in which sense the inf. n. kaMbapN is more commonly used:] or intense grief, &c.: used both as an inf. n. and as an epithet. (TA.) See kaYiybN.
kuWabapN i. q. tuWabapN, in the following phrase maA bihi kWbpN There is nothing in him for which he should be ashamed. (Ḳ.)

kaYiybN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kaYibN↓ and makotaYibN↓ (Ḳ) A man in an evil state, and broken [in spirit] by grief, or mourning; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) in grief, unhappy, sorrowful, or sad. (Ḳ.) kaYiybapN and kaOobaMCu↓ the same, as applied to a woman. (Ṣ.)
AlArD kaYiybapu Alwajohi ‡ [The earth, or land, is of sad aspect.] (TA.)
mukotaYibN see kaYiybN.
ramaAdN mukotaYibu All-awoni Ashes of a colour inclining to black; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as is the colour of him who is in an evil state, or broken [in spirit] by grief. (Ṣ.)
1. kaOada, aor. _a {yakoOadu}, He was in an evil state, and broken [in spirit] by grief, or mourning; or was in grief, unhappy, sorrowful, or sad, syn. kaYiba. (Ḳ.)
5. takaO-adaniI and takaMCadaniI↓ It (a thing, or an affair,) was difficult to me; it distressed, troubled, fatigued, or wearied, me. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

tkO-d AlX-aIoCa He took, or imposed, upon himself, or undertook, the thing, in spite of difficulty, trouble or inconvenience; he constrained himself to do the thing, notwithstanding it was difficult, troublesome, or inconvenient, to him. (L, Ḳ.) You say takaO-adotu Alc-ahaAba UilaI fulaAnK, meaning, I [constrained myself to go, and] went to such a one, in spite of difficulty, trouble, or inconvenience. (AZ, L.)

He endured the thing; struggled with, or against, it; contended with its difficulty, or severity; underwent difficulties, troubles, or inconveniences, in doing it; endured, or bore, its heat and severity; syn. kaAbadahu, and SaliIa bihi. (IAạr, L, Ḳ.)
6: see 5.
kaOodaMCu Difficulty. (IAạr, L, Ḳ.)
Grief; sorrow; mourning; syn. HuzonN: so accord. to the Ḳ; but accord. to IAạr [and the L] fear; syn. xawofN: (TA:) and caution: (IAạr, L.)
Injustice. (Ḳ.)
A dark night. (IAạr, L, Ḳ.)
See also kaWuwdN.

EaqabapN kaWuwdN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and kaOodaMCu↓, (L, Ḳ,) A mountain-road difficult of ascent. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*) Such a road is also termed [simply] kaOodaMCu, and SuEadaMCu: [in the Ḳ it is said, that kuWadaMCu is syn. with SuEadaMCu:] and kaWuwdN [in like manner, as a subst.,] signifies. a difficult place of ascent: like SaEuwdN. (L, TA.)

kaOosN, (ISk, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and kaAsN, with the C suppressed, is allowable, (Mṣb,) and sometimes occurs, (TA,) A drinking-cup: (A, Ḳ:) or [a cup of wine; i. e.] a cup containing wine; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) or a cup full of wine: (Mṣb:) when not containing wine, it is not thus called; (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb;) being in this case called qadaHN: (TA:) or it has the first and the second of these significations: (TA:) or it signifies wine itself: (Aṣ, AḤát, Ibn-ʼAbbád:) or has this signification also: (Ḳ:) and is of the fem. gender: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OakoWusN and [of mult.] kuWuwsN and kiYaAsN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the last with C, (TA, [but written without C in the CK,]) and, accord. to AḤn, kiyaAsN, without C, which, if correct, is originally kiwaAsN, from kaAsN, with the C changed into A as representing w, (TA,) and kaAsaAtN, (Ḳ,) without C. (TA.)
It is used metaphorically in relation to every kind of disagreeable, hateful, or evil, things. Thus you say, saqaAhu kaOosFA mina Alc-ul-i ‡ [He gave him to drink a cup of abasement]: and mina Alfuroqapi ‡ [of separation]: and mina Almawoti ‡ [of death]: and mina AlHub-i ‡ [of love]. (TA.) You say also, saqaAhu AlkaOosa AlOamar-a ‡ [He gave him to drink the most bitter cup]; meaning death: (A, TA:) and kuWuwsa AlmanaAyaA ‡ [The cups of death; lit., deaths]. (A.) Az. thinks that it may be derived from kaASa fulaAnN mina AlT-aEaAmi waAlX-araAbi, meaning, “Such a one ate and drank much”; because S and s are interchangeable in many words on account of the nearness of their places of utterance. (TA.)
1. kaOana fiI xaloqihi He, (a man) was strong in his make (IAạr, in TA, voce kanata.)
kaOoniI-N A man strong in his make. (IAạr, in TA, voce kanata.)
kaOK and kACK: see kaOaI-K or kaOay-ino in art. OaI-N (p. 134 a.)

hom.sense: 1. kab-ahu, aor. _u {yakobubu}, (inf. n. kab-N, TA;) and kabokabahu; (Ḳ, TA;) He inverted it, or turned it upside-down. (Ḳ.)
kab-a AlUinaMCa, aor _u, inf. n. kab-N, [He inverted, or turned down, the vessel, so as to pour out its contents]: (TA:) he turned the vessel over upon its head. (Mṣb.)
kab-a AlqaSoEapa He turned over the wooden bowl upon its face. (TA.)

kab-ahu, (Ḳ,) or kb-h liwajohihi, (Ṣ,) [or EalaI wajohihi (see 4),] and Akb-h↓ (Ḳ) and kabokabahu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He prostrated him; threw him down upon his face. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [One says,] kab-a Qll-ehu Eaduw-a Almusolimiyna [May God overthrow, or prostrate, the enemy of the Muslims!]: but one should not say Akb-↓. (Ṣ.) See also 4.
He cut, or wounded, a camel in the legs. (TA.)

kab-a,, (aor. _u {yakobubu}, inf. n. kab-u, TA,) ‡ He [convolved, or glomerated, thread, and likewise hair (see faliylN), or he] made thread [&c.] into kubab [or balls]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or into a kub-ap [or ball]. (ISd.) [The verb is used in the present day to signify He wound thread into a ball, or balls.] See 5.
kab-a, [aor., app., _i,] He, or it, was weighty, or heavy. (Ḳ.) See kub-apN
He kindled, or set on fire, kub-, which is [a plant, or tree, of the kind called] HamoD. (AA, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. kb-b, inf. n. takobiybN, ‡ He made kabaAb, or meat cut up, &c. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4: See 1.

Akb-, (Ḳ,) or Akb- EalaI wajohihi, (Ṣ) and Ankb-↓, (TA,) quasi-pass. of kab-a; He fell prostrate or prone; fell upon his face: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the former verb extr. with respect to analogy, (Ṣ,) [as quasi-pass. of kab-a: see OaHojama, and OaHonaja]: [and kab-a↓, aor., app., _i, inf. n. kab-N, he fell, having stumbled: for] kab-N is the contr. of AinotiEaAXN. (Ṣ, art. tEX.)
Akb- lahu (i. e., lilX-aIoCi, TA) i. q. taHaAnaI (as in some copies of the Ḳ) or tajaAnaOa (as in others): the latter [meaning He bent down towards it] is probably the correct reading. (TA.)
Akb- Ealayohi, (i. e., ElI AlX-aIoCi, TA,) and Ankb-↓, † He fell to, or set about, doing it. (Ḳ.) Akb- ElI AlOamori yafoEaluhu, and Ankb-↓, [He fell to, or set about, the thing, to do it]. (Ṣ.)
Akb- Ealayohi, (i. e., ElI EamalK, TA,) and Ankb-↓, ‡ He kept, or adhered, to it; (Ḳ;) i. e., to a work. (TA.)
5. tkb-bt AlUibilu The camels were prostrated by disease (Ṣ, Ḳ) or emaciation. (Ṣ.)

tkb-b ‡ It (sand) became contracted (by reason of its moisture, TA,) into a compact mass: (Ṣ:) or became moist, and, in consequence, compact: whence kub-apu gazolK [a ball of spun thread], as indicated by Z in the A. (TA.)
tkb-b ‡ He wrapped himself up in his garment: (A:) [as also tkbkb↓: ex.] jaACa mutakabokibFA fiI viyaAbihi He came wrapped up in his garment. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 6. tkAb-wA Ealayohi ‡ They pressed together, or crowded together, upon it. (TA.) [See t-akaAt-uwA, in art. kt.]
7. Ankb- It (a jug, or the like) was, or became, inverted, or turned down, so as to pour out its contents. (IB, in TA, voce garabN.)
See 4, in five places.
R. Q. 1. kabokabahu He turned him over, one part upon another: or threw him from the top of a mountain or wall. (TA.) See 1, in two places.

kabokabahu, inf. n. kabokabapN, He threw him into a deep place, or hollow. (Ḳ.) fakubokibuwA fiyhaA [Ḳur, xxvi, 9 4,] And they shall be thrown prostrate therein: [i. e., into the fire of hell:] (Ṣ:) or they shall be collected together and thrown down into it, namely, the abyss of hell-fire: (Lth:) lit., they shall be thrown so as to turn over and over until at length they come to a stop therein: (TA:) or they shall be thrown into it, one upon another: (Zj:) or they shall be collected together therein. (TA.)

kbkb AlmaAla He collected together, and brought or put back, the extremities of what was scattered of the wealth or property: [meaning, he collected the camels, &c. by driving together those that were dispersed:] like kamohalahu and dabokalahu, &c. (L.)
R. Q. 2. takabokabuwA ‡ They collected themselves together. (TA.)
See 5.

kub-N, [coll. gen. n., A plant or tree, of the kind called] HamoD; (Ḳ;) a kind of tree excellent for kindling, the leaves of which make the tails of horses beautiful and long; it has joints and thorns, and grows in fine, or soft, and plain soil: n. un. with p {kub-apN}: or, accord. to some, it is [a plant, or tree,] of the kind called najiylu AlfalaApi: but IAạr says, among the [plants, or trees, called] HamoD, are the njyl and the kb-. (TA.)

hom.sense: kab-apN and kub-apN↓ A charge, an assault, or an onslaught, in war. (Ḳ) [And] kab-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kub-apN↓ (Ḳ) A single impetus [in some copies of the Ṣ, dafoEap; in others, and in my copies of the Ḳ, dufoEap: I prefer the former reading:] in fighting and in running [in the CK, wAljaroIu, which is doubtless a mistake]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and vehemence thereof. (TA.)
kab-apN and kub-apN↓ A collision between two troops of horses: in the Ḳ, biyona Aljabalayoni; but correctly, bayona Alxayolayoni, as in other lexicons. (TA.)

kab-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kub-apN↓ (Ḳ) A letting loose, or setting free, horses, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) upon the race-course, or field, to run, or to charge. (Ṣ.) [This is evidently meant in the Ṣ as an explanation of the words rendered here “a single impetus”, &c.]
kab-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kub-apN↓ (Ḳ) The vehemence and assault [in some copies of the Ṣ, dafoEap: in others, and in my copies of the Ḳ, dufoEap: I prefer the former reading:] of winter. (Ṣ, Ḳ)
kab-apu Aln-aAri A dash, or dashing of the fire [of hell]. (TA.)
kab-apN and kub-apN↓ and kabokabapN↓ and kibokibapN↓ and kibokibN↓ or (accord. to the TA) kabokabN↓, A throwing into a deep place, or hollow. (Ḳ.) See kabokaba.
See also kub-apN.
kub-apN: see kab-apN passim.
Alkb- [a mistranscription for Alkub-apu, as is shown by the next sentence,] What is collected together, of dust, or earth, and of other things. (TA [See also safaApN, voce safFA.])

Hence, (TA,) kub-apN ‡ A jarawohaq (which is not an Arabic word, TA, [but arabicized, from the Persian kuruwhaho guróhah, signifying a ball]) of spun thread: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or such as is collected together, [or convolved, so as to form a ball,] of spun thread: (TA: [see 5:]) pl. kubabN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And it is likewise of hair: see faliylN.]

[Hence,] kub-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kubokubapN↓ (Ṣ) or kabokabapN↓ (Ḳ) ‡ A company, congregated body, or troop, (Ḳ,) of horses, (Ṣ,) or of men. (TA.) kbkbpN mino baniI UisoraAYiyla A company of the Children of Israel. (TA, from a trad.) kub-apu Als-uwqi The company of the market: said in a trad. to be the company of Satan. (TA.) ramaAhumo bikub-atihi [He threw upon them] his troop, or company. (TA.) See also below.

A herd of great camels. (Ḳ.) Uin-aka lakaQlbaAYiEK Alkub-apa biAlhub-api Verily thou art like the seller of a herd of great camels for wind. A proverb, thus related by AZ: but, as related by some, Alkbp bAlhbp, without teshdeed: see arts. kbw and hbw. (TA.)
kub-apu Alxayoli The greater number, or main part, of the troop of horses. (Th.)
I. q. EiyaAlN: so in the phrase Ealayohi kb-pN [He has a family, or household, dependant upon him]. (TA.)
kub-apN (Ḳ) and kab-apN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) ‡ A pressing, or crowding, together. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kub-apN Weight. (Ḳ.) So in the saying ramaAhumo bikub-atihi [He threw upon them his weight]. (TA.) (But see above.) And OaloqaI Ealayohi kub-atahu He threw his weight upon him. (TA.)

entry.sense: kabaAbN i. q. TabaAhajN; (Ṣ;) i. e., (TA,) ‡ Flesh-meat cut up [into small pieces] (Ḳ) and roasted, or broiled; or thrown upon burning coals: (TA:) [small morsels of meat, generally mutton or lamb, roasted on skewers]. Asserted by El-Khafájee to be Persian; and thought to be so by Yaạḳoob. (TA.)

hom.sense: kubaAbN A large number of camels or of sheep or goats. (Ḳ.) Also used as an epithet: ex. naEamN kubaAbN Camels, or camels and sheep or goats, so numerous that one mounts upon another. (TA.) naEamN kubaAkibN Many camels, or camels and sheep or goats. (TA.) See also kuvaAbN
Dust; earth. (Ḳ.)
Adhesive mud; or clay. (Ḳ.)
Moist earth. (Ḳ.)
An abundance of moist, or soft, earth, that cleaves together. (TA.)
Sand that is contracted (by reason of its moisture, TA,) into a compact mass: (Ṣ:) sand that has become moist, and, in consequence, compact. (TA.)

entry.sense: kabaAbapN A certain medicine (Ṣ, Ḳ) of China: (Ḳ:) [cubeb, or piper cubebae.]

hom.sense: kibokibN and kabokabN, see kab-apN
A certain game (Ḳ) of the Arabs. (TA.)

entry.sense: kubokubN and kubaAkibu A man (TA) of compact (and strong, TA,) make: pl. kabaAkibu. (Ḳ.)
kabokabapN and kibokibapN, see kub-apN.
kubokubapN see kubokuwbN.
kabokaAbN An excellent kind of thick dates. (Ḳ.)
kubokuwbN and kubokuwbapN and kubokubapN↓ A closely congregated body of men. (Ḳ.)
kabokaAbapN A fat woman. (Ḳ.)
rajulN Oakab-u A man who is constantly stumbling. (TA.)
mikab-N and mikobaAbN↓ One who looks much towards the ground. (Ḳ.)

mukab-abapN A dust-coloured wheat, with thick ears, (Ḳ,) like small birds, and a thick straw, the eaters of which [namely the straw, a common fodder in Arabia,] do not become brisk, or sprightly. (TA.)
mikobaAbN see mikab-N.

hom.sense: 1. kabatahu, aor. _i {yakobitu}, (inf. n. kabotN, TA,) He threw him down prostrate; (Ḳ;) as also kabatahu liwajohihi: (Ṣ:) he threw him, or it, down upon his, or its face; like kab-ahu: this is the primary signification. (TA.)
kabatahu Qll-ehu liwajohihi May God prostrate him, so that he may not succeed in his enterprise, or may not gain the victory! (TA.)
kabata AlkaAfira He (God) prostrated the unbeliever, and denied him what he desired, or disappointed him, or caused him to fail of attaining his desire. (TA, from a trad.)
kabatahu He repelled him (i. e. an enemy) in his rage, or wrath. (Ḳ.)
I. q. kasarahu [here app. signifying He routed him; or put him to flight.] (Ḳ.)

kabatahu, (inf. n. kabotN, Ṣ,) He turned away, or averted, him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and abased him; debased him; rendered him vile, despicable, or ignominious. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Syn. Oacal-ahu and OaxozaAhu (Ḳ) Ex. kabata Qll-ehu AlEaduw-a God averted and abased the enemy. (Ṣ.)

kubituwA kamaA kubita Al-aciyna mino qabolihimo, in the Ḳur, [lviii, 6,] signifies, They [who oppose God and his Apostle] have been abased, and punished, by their being overcome, like as those who were before them, of such as opposed God, were abased, &c.: (Zj:) or they have been enraged, and grieved, on the occasion of the war of the Moat, like as those who were before them, who fought with the prophets, were enraged and grieved: (Fr:) in favour of which latter interpretation it has been argued, that Alkbt is formed from Alkbd, the liver, by the substitution of t for d, and that the liver is the source of rage and malevolence. (Az.)
kabatahu i. q. kabadahu, He smote, or hurt, his liver. (TA.)

kabata gayoZahu fiI jawofihi ‡ He restrained his rage in his inside [or bosom]. You say, mano kabata gayoZahu fiI jawofihi kabata Qll-ehu Eaduw-ahu mino xawofihi [Whoso restraineth his rage in his bosom, God will avert and abase his enemy, through fear of him]. (A.)

entry.sense: 7. Ankbt He was thrown down, or fell down, prostrate; or, upon his face. (TA.)
kbt [app. kabotN or kibotN or kabitN] i. q. kabidN The liver. Ex. baruda kbtuhu [His liver became cool: i. e., his rage became assuaged]. ('Ináyeh.)
kabotN Rage or wrath; and grief, or sorrow. ('Ináyeh.)
makobuwtN pass. part. n. of 1, q. v.
Also, Affected with violent grief, or sorrow: originally makobuwdN: i. e., having his liver affected by grief, or sorrow. (TA, from a trad.)
mukotabitN Filled with grief, or sorrow; (Ḳ;) or with rage, or wrath. (TA.)
1. kabiva, aor. _a {yakobavu}, It (flesh meat) became altered and stinking. (Ṣ, Ḳ,)
kabava, (aor. _u {yakobuvu}, inf. n. kabovN, TḲ,) He covered over (gam-) flesh-meat, (Ḳ,) so that it became altered and stinking. (TḲ.)
2. kb-v Als-afiynapa, inf. n. takobiyvN, He inclined the ship towards the shore, and transferred what was in it to another ship. (Ḳ.)

kabaAvN [coll. gen. n.] What is ripe of the fruit of the OaraAk; (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) what is unripe thereof being called bariyr: (Ṣ:) or what has become black thereof: (TA in art. brm: [see also marodN:]) or what is unripe thereof: (M:) or, as some say, the fruit of that tree when scattered: n. un. with p {kabaAvapN}: (TA:) the kbAv are, in quantity (miqodaAr), a little above the grains of the coriander, and fill both the hands of a man; being more than a camel takes at once into his mouth. (AḤn.)
laHomN kabiyvN, and makobuwvN↓, Flesh-meat that has been covered, (Ḳ,) [and] become [in consequence] altered and stinking. (TḲ.) AA explains kabiyvN by the words laHomN qado gum-a. (TA.)
kunobuvN and kunobuwvN and kunaAbivN Hard and strong. (Ḳ.)
Also, all the three words, Contracted [in disposition], and niggardly, or stingy. (Ḳ.) Accord. to some, the n is a radical letter. (TA.) [See also art. knbv.]
makobuwvN: see kabiyvN.

1. kabaHa Ald-aAb-apa, (aor. _a {yakobaHu}, inf. n. kaboHN, L,) He pulled in the horse, or the like, by the bridle and bit, (and struck its mouth with the bit, L,) in order that it might stop, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and not run; (Ṣ, L;) as also OakobaHahaA↓; (Yaạḳoob, Ḳ;) or you say AkmHhA and AkfHhA and kbHhA [only]; the last alone without A: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or he (the rider) pulled its head towards him, and prevented its being refractory, and its overcoming him, and going quickly: so in the Nh, the explanation in which is incorrectly given by Mullà ʼAlee Káree: (TA:)
or AkbHh↓ signifies he pulled up his head by the bridle, so as to make it upright, or erect; (Mṣb;) and so kabaHahu. (A.)
kabaHa fulaAnFA Eano HaAjatihi ‡ He turned such a one back from, or made him to revert from, or relinquish, the thing that he wanted. (L, Ḳ.)
kabaHa AlHaAYiTu Als-ahoma ‡ The wall made the arrow, striking it, to turn from its course, without its sticking in it. (L.)
kabaHahu He struck him with a sword, (Ḳ,) upon his flesh, not upon a bone. (Mṣb.)
3. kAbHhu: see qAbHh.
4: see 1, in two places.

kaAbiHN That which presents itself before thee, (Ḳ,) or he who presents himself before thee, (T, L,) of such objects as are of evil omen, (T, L, Ḳ,) as a he-goat, &c.; (L;) because it turns him back from his course: (TA:) pl. kawaAbiHu. (L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. kabadahu, (aor. _i {yakobidu} AZ, L, Ḳ, and _u L, Ḳ, inf. n. kabodN, L,) He, or it, hit, or smote, or hurt, his kabid [or liver]: (AZ, Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, L:) or struck it. (L, Ḳ.)

kabadahumu Albarodu, (aor. _i {yakobidu} and _u {yakobudu} K,) † The cold affected them severely; distressed them; straitened them: (L, Ḳ:) or, smote their livers; which only the most intense cold does. (L, from a trad.)
kabida, aor. _a {yakobadu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. kabadN, (L,) He had a pain in his liver: (L, Ḳ) and (A, L:) or kubida, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kubaAdN, (TA,) he had a complaint of his liver. (L, Ḳ.)
kabida, aor. _a {yakobadu}, (L,) inf. n. kabadN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He was big in the belly, (L, Ḳ,) in its upper part: (L:) he (a man) was bulky in the middle, and therefore slow in his pace. (Ṣ, L.)
It (anything) was big, or large, and thick, in the middle. (L.)
See 5.

entry.sense: 2: See 5.

3. kAbd AlOamora, (inf. n. mukaAbadapN and kibaAdN, L, Ḳ,) ‡ He endured the thing; struggled, or contended, with, or against, it; struggled or contended with, or against, its difficulty, or severity; syn. qaAsaAhu, (L, Ḳ,) or qaAsaI Xid-athu; (Ṣ;) he endured, or struggled, or contended, with or against, its difficulty, trouble, or inconvenience; syn. EaAnaI maXaq-atahu: (L:) he underwent difficulties, troubles, or inconveniences, in doing it. (Mṣb.)

kAbd All-ayola ‡ He (a man) braved (rakiba) the terribleness and difficulty of the night. And kaAbadotu Zulomapa hecihi All-ayolapi mukaAbadapF XadiydapF I braved the darkness of this night with a mighty braving. (Lth, L.)
baEoDuhumo yukaAbidu baEoDFA ‡ [One party of them struggles, contends, or strives, against the opposition of the other]: said of adversaries in a contest, litigation, or the like. (A.)

hom.sense: 5. tkb-dhu ‡ He tended, or betook himself, or directed himself or his course, to, or towards, it, namely, an affair, (L, Ḳ,) and a town or country; syn. qaSadahu; (L, Ḳ;) as also kabadahu↓, aor. _i {yakobidu} and _u {yakobudu}. (Ḳ, TA.)
tkb-d ‡ It (milk) became thick; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) as also any other beverage; (L;) and (the former) became thick like liver, so as to quiver. (L.)

tkb-dt AlX-amosu, (Ṣ, A,) or tkb-dt AlXmsu Als-amaMCa, (L, Ḳ,) ‡ The sun became in the kabid, (Ṣ, L,) or kubayodaMC, (Ḳ,) of the sky; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) became in the middle of the sky; culminated; (A;) as also kb-dt↓, inf. n. takobiydN: (Ḳ:) and kb-d↓ Aln-ajomu Als-amaMCa the star, or asterism, [or the Pleiades,] culminated. (Ṣ, L.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce xaXafa.]
tk-bd AlfalaApa ‡ He directed his course to, or towards, the middle and main part of the desert. (L.)

entry.sense: kabodN and kibodN: see kabidN.

kabadN ‡ Difficulty; distress; affliction; trouble. (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Ex. waqaEa fiI kabadK He fell into difficulty, &c. (A.) So in the words of the Ḳur, [xc, 4,] laqado xalaqonaA QloUinosaAna fiI kabadK Verily we have created man in difficulty, &c., (Ṣ, L, Jel,) in a state in which he has to contend with the afflictions of the present life and the difficulties pertaining to the life to come: (Zj,* Jel:) or fI kbd here signifies, in a right and just state: (Aboo-Tálib, L:) or in an erect state, and in just proportion: (Fr; L:) or in an erect state, and walking upon his two legs; whereas other animals are not erect: or in the belly of his mother, with his head towards her head; in which state the child remains until near the birth, when it becomes inverted. (L.)
And see kaAbidN and kabidN.

kabidN, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) the most chaste and best known form of the word, (TA,) and kibodN↓, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a contraction of the former, (Mṣb,) and kabodN↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) also a contraction of the first, (Ṣ,) [The liver;] a certain black piece of flesh on the right of the lungs: (L:) fem., and sometimes masc.; (Fr, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or fem. only: (Lḥ, ISd, L, Mṣb:) pl. OakobaAdN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kubuwdN; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the latter seldom used. (Mṣb)

Also, [the first,] ‡ The place of the liver, outside: (L;) the side. (Ḳ) It is said in a trad., fawaDaEa yadahu EalaI kabidiI, meaning, And he put his hand upon my side externally; or, upon the external part of my side, next the liver. (L.)
† The inside of an animal, altogether. (Kr, ISd, Ḳ.) Sometimes used in this sense. (Kr, ISd.)
‡ The inside, meaning a cave, or ravine, of a mountain. (L.)

kabidu AlOaroDi ‡ The interior of the earth: (Mṣb:) or the minerals (maEaAdin) of the earth: (A:) or the gold and silver and the like that are in the mines of the earth: (L:) pl. OakobaAdN (A, L) and kubuwdN. (L.) It is said in a trad. wataloqiI AlOaroDu OafolaAca kabidihaA ‡ And the earth shall cast forth what is hidden in her belly, of treasures and minerals. (L.)
‡ The middle of anything, (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and its main part. (L, Ḳ.)
‡ The middle of the sea. (L.)
‡ The middle of a butt for archers. (A, L.)
daAruhu kabida najodK ‡ His house is in the middle of Nejd. (A.)
kabidN; (L;) in the Ḳ, kabadN↓; but none [except F] says so; (MF;) The middle of a tract of sand, (L, Ḳ,) and its main part. (L.)

kabidN; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb;) in the Ḳ, kabadN↓; but none [except F] says so; (MF;) and kabodN↓, and kabodaMCu↓, (Ḳ,) and kubayodaAtN↓, (Ṣ, A, L,) as though they had formed the dim. kubayodapN from kabidN, and then formed the pl.; (Ṣ, L;) in the Ḳ, kubayodaApN; but this is wrong; (TA;) and kubayodaMCu↓, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) dim. of kabidN, contr. to rule, like suwayodaMCu; (Mṣb;) [or dim. of kabodaMCu;] ‡ The middle of the sky, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) and its main part: (L;) or [the meridian of the sky;] the middle of the sky, wherein is the sun at the time of its declining from the meridian: (L:) or the part of the middle of the sky which faces the spectator. (Lth, L, Mṣb.)
kabidN (Lḥ, L; in the Ḳ, kabadN;) † The air; (Lḥ, L, Ḳ;) as also kabodaMCu↓. (L.)

kabidN ‡ of a bow, The handle: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) or the part a little above the handle, (Az, L, Mṣb,) against which the arrow goes: (Az, L:) or the part between the two extremities of the handle, and that along which the arrow runs: (Ṣ, L:) or the part [midway] between the two extremities of its suspensory string or cord or the like: (Aṣ, L, Ḳ:) [see rijolN:] or the space of a cubit from its handle: (L, Ḳ:) or each part where the thong of its suspensory string or the like is tied: (L:) in the bow is its kabid, which is the part [midway] between the two extremities of its suspensory string or the like; then, next to this, the kuloyap; then, next to this, the Oabohar; then, next to this, the TaAYif; then, the siYap, which is the curved part of each extremity. (Aṣ, L.)

suwdN AlOakobaAdi [Black-livered men;] a designation of enemies, (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) similar to Suhobu Als-ibaAli [q. v.]: (Aṣ, Ṣ, L:) they are so called because the effects of rancour, or malevolence, have [as it were] burnt their livers so that they have become black; the liver being the source of enmity. (L.)
kbodaACu: see kabidN, and Oakobadu.

kubaAdN Pain of the liver: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or a disease, or complaint, of the liver. (L.) The only known word, signifying a disease, derived from the name of the member affected, except nukaAfN and qulaAbN. (Kr.)
It is said in a trad. AlkubaAdu mina AlEab-i, (Ṣ, L,) i. e., The pain, or disease, of the liver is from drinking water without sipping. (L.)
kubayodaACu and kubayodaAtN: see kabidN.
kab-aAdN A certain species of the layomuwn; [citrus limon sponginus Ferrari: (Delile, Flor. Aeg. Illustr., no. 748:) a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p {kab-aAdapN}]. (TA.)

kaAbidN ‡ a subst. from kaAbada, (ISd, L, Ḳ,) [in the sense of mukaAbadapN: see 3:] as also kabadN↓. (MF.) Ex. of the former,
walayolapK mina All-ayaAliI mar-ato
bikaAbidK kaAbadotuhaA wajar-ato
[Many a night of nights has passed with a struggling against its severity: I have struggled against its severity; and it was long]. Said by El-ʼAjjáj. jr-t signifies TAlt. (L.)

You also say, of adversaries in a contest, litigation, or the like, Uin-ahumo fiI kabadK↓ mino Oamorihimo ‡ [Verily they are in a state of struggling, contention, or strife, against mutual opposition with respect to their affair]. (A.)

hom.sense: Oakobadu Anything big, or large, and thick, in the middle. (L.)
kabodaMCu A she-camel large in the middle: (L:) and in like manner, a tract of sand, ramolapN. (L, Ḳ.)
Oakobadu Big in the upper part of the belly: (L:) a man bulky in the middle, and therefore slow in his pace: fem. kabodaMCu. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)
Having the place of his liver rising, or prominent. (Ḳ.)
qawosN kabodaMCu ‡ A bow of which the handle fills the hand: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) or, of which the part called the kabid is thick and strong. (L.)
kabodaMCu † A mill that is turned with the hand: (L, Ḳ:) so called because of the difficulty, or trouble, with which it is turned. (L.)
See makobuwdN.
Oakobadu A certain bird. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: makobuwdN Hit, or hurt, in his liver. (Ṣ.) See makobuwtN
Having a complaint of his liver: (TA:) and Oakobadu↓ signifies the same: (A, L:) or this latter, having a pain in his liver. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. kabura, aor. _u {yakoburu}, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. kuborN (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kibarN and kabaArapN, (A, Ḳ,) He, (TA,) or it, (Mṣb,) was, or became, great, [big, or large in body, or corporeal substance: and in years, or age; (when said of a human being, often particularly signifying he attained to puberty;) and in estimation or rank or dignity;] contr. of Dagura; (A, Ḳ;) syn. EaZuma, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and jasuma. (Ḳ.) [In the Ḳ the pret. is twice mentioned: where it is explained as signifying the contr. of Sagura, the above inf. ns. are mentioned, as in the A: where it is explained by EaZuma and jasuma in the Ḳ, no inf. n. is mentioned; but in the TA it is there said that in the sense of EaZuma it relates to an affair or case, and that the inf. n. is kibarN and kabaArapN; and that in the sense of jasuma it relates to anything.]
kabura AlOamoru [The affair, or case, was, or became, of great moment; it was, or became, momentous: or it signifies as in the phrase next following]. (A.)

kabura Ealayohi AlOamoru The affair, or case, was, or became, difficult, hard, severe, grievous, distressing, afflictive, troublesome, or burdensome, to him or in its effect upon him; syn. Xaq-a. (A,* TA.) In this sense the verb is used in the Ḳur, x, 72, (TA,) and xlii, 11. (Bḍ, ii. 42.) And so in the Ḳur again, xvii, 53, Oawo xaloqFA mim-aA yakoburu fiI Sduwrikumo, (TA,) meaning, OawoxaloqFA mim-aA yakoburu Einodakumo Eano qubuwli AlHayaApi [Or a created thing of those which are too difficult in your minds to receive life], as being the thing most remote from capability to receive life. (Bḍ.) [This signification is from the primary application of the verb.]

kabira, aor. _a {yakobaru}, inf. n. kibarN and makobirN, He (a man, Ṣ, a human being, and a beast, TA, and a child, Mṣb,) became full-grown, or old, or advanced in age. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the prov., kabira Eamoruw Eani AlT-awoqi: [see art. Twq.]

[In modern Arabic, and, I believe, sometimes, in classic authors, it also signifies He became big; (said of a boy, or child, in the TA in art. rE, &c.;) i. e. attained to full growth: and to adolescence: and to puberty: see kabiyrN.] This form of the verb and that first mentioned are sometimes erroneously used, each for the other, by persons of distinction as well as by the vulgar. (TA.)
See kaborapN, below.
kaAbarotuhu fakabarotuhu, aor. of the latter, _u: see 3.
kabarahu bisanapK, aor. _u {yakoburu}, He exceeded me in age by a year. (Ḳ.) And maA kabaraniI Uil-aA bisanapK He did not exceed me in age save by a year. (IAạr.)

entry.sense: 2. kb-r, inf. n. tkabiyrN, He made a thing great. (Ḳ.)
He magnified, or honoured; syn. EaZ-ama. (Ṣ)
Also, inf. n. as above, and kib-aArN, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) which latter is of the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab and many of the people of El-Yemen, (Ṣgh,) He said Aall-ehu Oakobar. (Ḳ.) See Oakobaru, below.

3. kaAbarotuhu fakabarotuhu, aor. of the latter _u, [I contended, or disputed, with him for superiority in greatness, and I overcame him therein.] (A.) You say kaAbara fulaAnN fulaAnFA Such a one disputed with such a one for superiority in greatness, and said I am greater than thou. (A.)

kAbrhu, inf. n. mukaAbarapN, He vied with him; or contended with him for superiority; syn. gaAlabahu: and he contended against him; or he contended against him, or disputed with him, not knowing the truth or falsity of what he or his adversary said; syn. EaAnadahu: (Mṣb:) or he contended or disputed with him, knowing that what he himself said was false, and that what his adversary said was true. (Kull, p. 342.)
It is said in a trad., laAtukaAbiruwA AlS-alaApa, meaning, laA tugaAlibuwhaA [app., Contend not ye against prayer.] (TA.)
kuwbira faOabaI [It was contended with, and refused, or would not]: said of what he would utter by a man who had an impediment in his speech. (A.)
kaAbarahu EalaI Haq-ihi He denied, or disacknowledged, to him his right, or due, and contended with him for it; expl. by jaAHadahu wagaAlabahu. (A, TA. [See 1 in art. jHd.])
kuwbira EalaI maAlihi He had his property taken from him by force. (A, TA.)

4. Akbrhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UikobaArN; (Mṣb;) and Astkbrhu↓; (Ḳ;) He deemed it great [or formidable; see an ex., voce faZiEa;] it was great in his estimation; (IJ, Ḳ;) syn. UisotaEoZamahu. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
Akbrt She brought forth a great child, or young one. (IḲṭṭ.)
OaSogarati Aln-aAqapu waOakobarato: see art. Sgr.

5. tkb-r and Astkbr↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and tkAbr↓ (Ḳ) He magnified himself; behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently; (Ḳ;) syn. taEaZ-ama: (Ṣ:) or tkb-r signifies, as used in the Ḳur, vii. 143, he considered himself as of the most excellent of the creation, and as having rights which others have not: (Zj:) or this verb has two significations: one of them, he did really good and great actions, exceeding the good actions of others; and hence Almutakab-iru [applied to God] in the Ḳur, lix. 23: the other, he affected to do such actions, and boasted of great qualities which he did not possess; as do the generality of men; and hence, mutakab-ir in the Ḳur, xl. 37; and the verb itself in the Ḳur, vii. 143: and Astkbr↓ is nearly syn. with tkb-r, and likewise has two significations: one of them, he endeavoured, and sought, to become great; and to do so, when the manner and place and time are such as are requisite, is praiseworthy: the other, he boasted of qualities which he did possess, and feigned such qualities; and to do so is blameable; and in this sense the verb is used in the Ḳur, ii. 32: (El-Basáïr:) and tkAbr↓ signifies he feigned himself great in estimation or rank or dignity, or in age. (A, TA.)
tkb-r EalaI Qll-ehi He magnified himself against God, by refusing to accept the truth. (El-Basáïr.)
[tkb-r Eano kacaA He was disdainful of such a thing; he disdained it; turned from it with disdain; he held himself above it; like taEaZ-ama and taEaAZama and tajaAl-a and taraf-aEa.]
6: see 5, in two places.

hom.sense: see also 5, in two places.
kuborN: see kiborN, in two senses:
and see kiborapN in three places.
kiborN Greatness [in corporeal substance, and in estimation or rank or dignity]. (IḲooṭ, Mṣb.)
Nobility; eminence; highness; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also kuborN↓: (Ḳ:) eminence, or highness, in, or with respect to, nobility; (Ḳ;) as also kuburN↓, with two dammehs. (TA.)

I. q. EaZamapN [which, as an attribute of God, signifies greatness, or majesty, or the like: (see munakab-irN:) and as an attribute of a man, pride]: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a subst. from Alt-akab-uru: (Mṣb:) as also kiboriyaMCu↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) a word, says Kr, of which there is not the like [in measure], except siymiyaMCu and jirobiyaMCu; for, he adds, as to kiymiyaMCu, I think it a foreign word: (TA:) the latter [kiboriyaACu↓] occurs as an attribute of God, in the sense of EaZamapN, (A, Mgh, Jel,) in the Ḳur, xlv. 36: (Jel:) and as an attribute of men, in the Ḳur, x. 79, where it is said to signify proud behaviour towards others, (Bḍ,) or dominion: (IAmb, Bḍ, Jel:) and both signify pride, haughtiness, or insolence: (Ḳ:) or the former, self-admiration, or self-conceit; and the holding one's self greater than others: and ↓the latter, disdain of submission; an attribute to which none but God has a right. (El-Basáïr.)
Unbelief: the association of any other being with God. So in a trad., in which it is said, that he who has in his heart the weight of a grain of mustard-seed of kibor shall not enter paradise. (TA.)
See also kabiyrapN.

The main, or greater, or greatest, part of a thing; (Fr. ISk, Az, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also kuborN↓, (Fr, Mgh, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) like EuZomN; (Fr;) thought by Ibn-El-Yezeedee to be a dial. form; but Az says, that the Arabs used the other form [kiborN]. (TA.) So in the Ḳur, xxiv. 11, waQl-aciI tawal-aI kiborahu (Fr, Ṣ) And he who took upon himself, or undertook, the main part thereof; namely, of the very wicked lie against ʼÁïsheh: (Jel:) thus accord. to the “Seven Readers”: and kuborahu↓, which is an extr. reading, (Mṣb,) the reading of Homeyd Ibn-El-Aaraj, (Fr, Ṣgh,) and of Yaạḳoob. (Ṣgh, Bḍ.) kuboru siyaAsapi Aln-aAsi fiI AlmaAli, [app. signifies The main part of men's management is with respect to property, or camels,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: kabarN [The caper, or capparis of Linnæus;] a certain plant having thorns; (TA;) an arabicized word, from the Persian [kabaro]; (Ṣ;) called in Arabic laSafN, (Mgh,) or OaSafN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the vulgar say kub-aArN↓. (Ḳ.) A beverage is described as made of kabar and barley: kvr is a mistranscription. (Mgh.)
kuburN: see kiborN.
kibarN inf. n. of 1:
see also kaborapN.
kubur-N: see kiborapN.

kaborapN, a subst. from kabira, (Ṣ,) Oldness; age; old age; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) as also kaburapN↓ and makobarapN↓ and makburapN↓ (Ḳ) and makobirN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kibarN↓. (TA.) [The last two, the latter of which is the most common of all, are inf. ns. of kabira.] You say Ealatohu kaburapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and kaburapN, and mukobarapN, and makoburapN, (Ḳ,) and EalaAhu Almakobiru, (Ṣ,) or makobirN, (Ḳ,) and kibarN, (TA,) [Age overcame him;] he became old, or advanced in age. (Mṣb.) Ealatohu kaborapN is also said, tropically, of a sword, and of the iron head or blade of a weapon, when it has become old: (TA:) or of an old iron head or blade of a weapon when spoilt by rust. (M, TA.) And kaborapN is used by AḤn with respect to dates and the like. (L.) [See also an ex. voce HaloqapN.]

hom.sense: kiborapN: see kabiyrapN.

huwa kiboratuhumo, (Ḳ,) and kubur-atuhumo↓, (Az, Ḳ,) so in the handwriting of AHeyth., (TA,) and Uikobir-atuhumo↓, and Oakobir-atuhumo↓, and kuboruhumo↓, and kubur-uhumo↓, (Ḳ,) He is the greatest of them (Ḳ, TA) in age, or in headship: (TA:) or he is the nearest of them in kin to his chief, or oldest, ancestor; (Ḳ, TA;) his intermediate ancestors being fewer in number: (TA:) [but some of these epithets are differently explained, as follows:] hecaA kiborapu Oabiyhi this is the greatest, or oldest, (Oakobaru,) of the children of his father; contr. of Sigorapu Oabiyhi: (A:) and huwa kiborapu waladi Oabawayohi he is the greatest, or oldest, (Akbr,) of the children of his parents: (Ks, Az:) or he is the last of the children of his parents; (Sh, Ṣ;) and the like is said of a female, (Sh, ISk, Ṣ,) and of a pl. number: (ISk, Ṣ:) it is like Eijozapu waladi Oabawayohi: (Sh, AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) or, accord. to Ks and Az, this last phrase has this meaning; but Az says, that kiborap means otherwise, namely, Oakobaru: (TA:) and fulaAnN Uikobir-apu qawomihi such a one is the greatest, or oldest, (Oakobaru,) of his people; and the like is said of a female, and of a pl. number: (Ṣ:) and huwa kuboru↓ qawomihi, (Ṣ,) or Oakobaru↓ qawomihi, and Oukobur-u↓ qawomihi, of the measure of OufoEul-, and applied to a woman as to a man, (TA,) he is the nearest of his people in kin to his chief, or oldest, ancestor; (Ṣ, TA;) in which sense, kaAna kubora↓ qawomihi is said of El-ʼAbbás, in a trad., because there remained not, in his lifetime, any one of the descendants of Háshim more nearly related to him than he: (L:) and in another trad. it is said, AlawlMCu llkubori (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) the right to the inheritance of the property left by an emancipated slave belongs to the nearest in kin [to the emancipater] (Mgh, Mṣb) of the sons of the emancipater; (Mgh;) i. e., when a man [who has emancipated a slave] dies, leaving a son and a grandson, the right to the inheritance of the property left by the emancipated slave belongs to the son, not the grandson. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: kaburapN: see kaborapN.
kubur-apN: see kiborapN.
kiboriyaMCu: see kiborN.
kiboriytN: see art. kbrt.
kubaArN: see kabiyrN.

kabiyrN Great [in body, or corporeal substance, and in estimation or rank or dignity; contr. of SagiyrN, but see EaZiymN]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also kibiyrN, as asserted by En-Nawawee and others, (TA,) and kubaArN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) [in an intensive sense, like EuTaAmN,] and kaAbirN↓ and kub-aArN↓: (Ḳ:) or the last signifies excessively great: (Ṣ, TA:) and kaAbirN is an epithat applied to a man, and signifying great in dignity and nobility; (Ṣ, TA;) or great and noble; (Mṣb;) or one overcoming in greatness; (A;) or a lord, or chief; and the greatest, or oldest, ancestor: (AA:) the fem. [of kabiyrN] is with p {kabiyrapN}: (Ḳ:) and the pl. is kibaArN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kubaraMCu, applied to men, (TA,) and makobuwraMCu, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) [or rather the last is a quasi-pl. n.,] like maXoyuwxaMCu; [see XayoxN;] (TA;) and [of kub-aArN] kub-aAruwna. (Ḳ.) [See also Oakobaru, and mutakab-irN.] You say tawaAravuwA Qlomajoda kaAbirFA Eano kaAbirK↓ They inherited by degrees dignity, or nobility, one great in dignity and nobility from another great in dignity and nobility: (Ṣ:) or one great and noble from another great and noble: (Mṣb:) or Eano is here used in the sense of baEoda [after]: (TA voce TabaqN:) or one overcoming in greatness from another overcoming in greatness. (A.) [In the A and Mṣb, instead of twArvwA, I find warivuwA.]

Great, or advanced, in age; old: (A, Mṣb, TA:) and also big; meaning full-grown; and adolescent: (see kabira:) [occurring in apposition to baAligN in art. brk in the Ṣ; and often, like baAligN, when applied to a human being, signifying one who has attained to puberty; opposed to SagiyrN:] fem. with p {kabiyrapN}: and pl. kibaArN. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] A teacher, and master: so in the Ḳur, xx. 74, and xxvi. 48: (Ks:) and the most knowing, or learned, of a people: so in the Ḳur, xii. 80. (Mujáhid.)

Difficult, severe, grievous, distressing, afflictive, troublesome, or burdensome: (TA:) fem. with p {kabiyrapN}; occurring in this sense in the Ḳur, ii. 42. (Bḍ, TA.) [The fem. is often used in the present day as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates, meaning, An affair, or a matter, that is difficult, severe, grievous,, &c.]
Alkabiyru as an epithet applied to God is syn. with AlEaZiymu [signifying The Incomparably-great]. (TA in art. EZm.)

kabiyrap A foul, or an abominable, sin, or crime, or offence, forbidden by the law, of great magnitude; such as murder and adultery or fornication, and fleeing from an army proceeding against an enemy [of the Muslims], &c.; [contr. of SagiyrapN;] an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: (TA:) and kiborN↓ and kiborapN↓ [in like manner] signify a great sin, or crime, or offence, for which one deserves punishment: (M, Ḳ:) the p is to give intensiveness to the signification: (TA:) or kiborN↓ signifies [simply] a sin, a crime, or an offence, for which one deserves punishment, [as kabiyrapN is said, not well, to signify, in the Mṣb,] and is from kabiyrapN, like xiTo from xaTiyoYapN: (TA:) pl. of the first, kabaAYiru, (Mṣb, TA,) and kabiyraAtN also occurs. (Mṣb.)
And see kabiyrN.

hom.sense: kub-aArN: see kabiyrN:
and see kabarN.

entry.sense: kib-aArN: see 2.
kaAbirN: see kabiyrN.

Oakobaru [Greater, and greatest, in body, or corporeal substance, and in estimation or rank or dignity: and] more, or most, advanced in age; older, and oldest: (Mṣb:) fem. kuboraI: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. masc. OakaAbiru (Ṣ, Mṣb) and Oakobaruwna; but not kuborN, because this is of a form specially appropriated to an epithet such as Oasowadu and OaHomaru, and you do not use Akbr in the manner of such an epithet, for you do not say hecaA rajulN Oakobaru, unless you conjoin it with a following word by mino, or prefix to it the article Al: (Ṣ:) [but see the phrase daEaA bikuborihi, below:] the pl. fem. is kubarN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kuborayaAtN. (Mṣb.)

Oakobaru is also used in the sense of kabiyrN: (Mṣb:) accord. to some, Aall-ehu Oakobar means God is great; (Az, Mgh, Mṣb;) like as huwa Oahowanu Ealayohi [in the Ḳur, xxx. 26,] means huwa hay-inN Ealayohi; (Az, TA;) but this explanation is of weak authority: (Mgh:) accord. to others, the phrase is elliptical, and means God is the greatest great [being]: (Az, TA:) or God is greater than every [other] great [being]: (Mṣb:) or greater than every [other] thing: (Mgh, TA:) or greater than such as that one knows the measure of His majesty: (TA:) [or it may be rendered God is most great, meaning, greater than any other being:] it is considered as elliptical because it is necessary that Akbr should have the article Al, or be followed by a noun in the gen. case [or by the prep. mino]. (TA.) In the phrase Aall-ehu Oakobaru kabiyrAF, the word kbyrA is put in the accus. case [as a corroborative] in the place of the inf. n. takobiyrAF, as though one said Oukab-iru takobiyrFA [I magnify Him greatly, after saying Qll-eh Akbr]. (TA.)
yawomu AlHaj-i AlOakobari [The day of the greater pilgrimage,] means the day of the sacrifice: or, as some say, the day of ʼArafeh: and others say otherwise. (TA.)

In the following words, in a trad. of Mázin, buEiva nabiI-N mino muDara bidiyni Qll-ehi Alkubari, there is an ellipsis, and the meaning is, biXaraYiEi diyni Qll-ehi Alkubari [A prophet of Mudar hath been sent with the greatest, or greater, or great, ordinances of God]. (TA.)

In a trad. respecting burial, wayujoEalu QloOakobaru mim-aA yaliI Qloqibolapa means, And the most excellent shall be placed towards the Kibleh: or, if they be equal [in dignity], the oldest. (TA.) [Agreeably with the former rendering,] Oakobaru, in the Ḳur, xxix. 44, is explained as signifying Better. (TA, art. ckr.) [And agreeably with the second rendering of the above trad.,] you say hecaA Oakobaru mino zayodK, meaning, This is older than Zeyd. (Mṣb.)

In a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, the phrase daEaA bikuborihi means He summoned his sheykhs, and elders, or great men: kubor being here [notwithstanding what has been said above,] pl. of Oakobaru, like as HumorN is pl. of OaHomaru. (TA.)
hecihi AljaAriyapu mino kuboraI banaAti fulaAnK means, [This girl is of those advanced in age of the daughters of such a one,] mino kibaAri banaAtihi. (Ibn-Buzurj.)
huwa Oakobaru qawomihi: see kiborapN.
Oukobur-N: see kiborapN.
Uikobir-apN and Oakobir-apN: see kiborapN; the former, in two places.
makobirN: see kaborapN.
makobarapN and makoburapN: see kabobarpN.
huwa mukaAbarN Ealayohi He has had it (his property) taken from him by force. (A, TA.)

Almutakab-iru, as an epithet applied to God, signifies The Great in majesty: (A:) or the Most Excellent of beings, who has rights which no other has; the Possessor of power and excellence the like of which no other possesses: (TA:) or He whose acts are really good, exceeding the good acts of any other: (El-Basáïr:) or, as also Alkabiyru↓, the Majestic: or He who disdains having the attributes of created beings: or He who magnifies Himself against the proud and exorbitant among his creatures: the t in the former word is to denote individuation, not endeavour. (TA.)

Q. 1. kaborata baEiyrahu He smeared his camel over with kiboriyt [or sulphur], (Ḳ,) mixed with grease, and with xaDaxaAD, which is a kind of nifoT [or naphtha], black, and of a thin consistence; not qaTiraAn; for this is the black, thick, expressed juice of a certain tree. (TṢ.) This is done to cure the scab, for the removal of which it is very efficacious. (TA.)

kiboriytN [Brimstone, or sulphur;] a thing well known; (Ṣ, art. kbr;) one of the kinds of stone with which fire is kindled, or it (red kbryt TA) is a mineral whereof the mine is beyond Et-Tubbat, [or the country of Et-Tibbet, in Tartary,] in the Valley of the Ants, (Ḳ,) by which Solomon passed, (TA,) [as related in the Ḳur, xxvii. 18]: or [the product of] a spring, or source, whereof the water, when it congeals, becomes white, and yellow, and dusky-coloured, kbryt: (Lth, in the T:) MF says, I have seen it in several places; among these, in one which is near El-Maláleeh, between Fás and Miknáseh; by swimming in which, persons are cured of the venereal disease, and other disorders: also in Africa Proper, in the midst of Barkah, in a place called Albrj; and in other places: (TA:) Aristotle says, that, among the different kinds of kbryt are the red, of an excellent colour; and the white, which resembles dust; and the yellow: the source of the red is in the West: it does not appear in its place: the yellow is found near the ocean, a league (or leagues, as in the TA,) from it: it is useful in cases of epilepsy, and apoplexy, and megrim, and palpitation: and it enters into the preparations of gold: the white blackens white substances; and it is sometimes mixed and concealed in the sources of running water, which sources have a fetid odour: the person who plunges into these waters in times when the air is temperate is cured by them of wounds, and swellings, and scab, and wind in the womb, and [the leprosy called] salaE, that arises from black bile: Ibn-Seenà [Avicenna] also says, that kbryt, untouched by fire, is one of the remedies for the leprosy (baraS): that, mixed with the gum of the turpentine-tree, it removes marks on the nails: that, mixed with vinegar, it removes the [leprous-like discolouration of the skin called] bahaq, and the ringworm, or tetter, (quwabaAC,) especially with the gum of the turpentine-tree: that, with natron and water, it is an embrocation for the baraS [or, as in the TA, for the niqoris, or gout]: and that fumigation therewith stops a rheum: and others say, that, if yellow kbryt be powdered, and sprinkled upon a place affected with slEp, it has a good effect: that fumigation therewith whitens the hair: that serpents and fleas flee from the scent of it, especially if [mixed] with an unguent, or with the hoof of an ass; and that the fumigation therewith beneath a citrontree of the kind called Outoruj- causes all the fruits of it to fall. (El-Ḳazweenee.) Several authors say, that the t in kbryt is an augmentative letter, and that the proper place of the word is in art. kbr. IDrd thinks it to be not genuine Arabic. (TA.) [Golius thinks it to be from the Persian kuwkurodo (or kuwkurodo): or rather, he adds, from the Hebrew כָּפְרִית Gen. xix. 24.]

OaEaz-umina Alkiboriyti AlOaHomari [More rare than red brimstone, or sulphur]. A proverb. Some say, that kbryt AHmr [meaning as above] is a thing that does not exist: others, that by it is meant gold. (Meyd.) This phrase is similar to OaEaz-u mino bayoDi AlOanuwqi. (Ṣ, art. kbr.)

kiboriytN also signifies gold: (Ḳ:) [see above:] or red gold: or red [as an epithet applied to gold]: (TA:) or pure, as an epithet applied to gold. (Ṣ, art. kbr.) Ru-beh says,
halo yanofaEan-iI kacibN sixotiytu
Oawo fiD-apN Oawo cahabN kiboriytu
[Will vehement lying profit me, or silver, or pure gold?] (Ṣ, art. kbr.) IAạr says, Ru-beh imagined that kbryt meant gold: upon which MF observes, that the ancient Arabs erred with respect to meanings, though not with respect to words. The latter author, however, supposes kbryt to be fig. used as signifying gold; for they use the expression Alkbryt AlAHmr [as applied to gold] because gold is [said to be] prepared therefrom, and it is used in alchymical processes. (TA.)
kiboriytN also signifies The red jacinth, or ruby; syn. yaAquwtN OaHomaru. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. kabasa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yakobisu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kabosN, (Ṣ,) He filled up with earth a well, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and a river, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and a hollow, or cavity, or pit, dug in the ground. (A, Mgh.)
‡ He covered over, or spread, with earth, and made even, a piece of ground: and in like manner, the roof of a house, before plastering it with mud or clay. (Mgh.)
[And He spread earth upon a roof, &c. (See dak-a.)]

Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, † He pressed, or squeezed, [or kneaded,] a limb with the hand: (TA, art. gmz:) and kb-s↓, inf. n. takobiysN, [signifies the same, accord. to present usage: and] ‡ he suppled the body [by kneading, or pressing, or squeezing it, as is done in the bath,] with the hands. (TA, in the present art.)
And, aor. as above, ‡ Inivit unâ vice feminam. (Ḳ.)

kabasuwA daAra fulaAnK ‡ They made a sudden attack upon the house of such a one, (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ,* Ḳ,) and surrounded it. (Ḳ.) And kabasuwA Ealayohimo, and kb-swA↓, ‡ They threw themselves upon them suddenly and without consideration. (A.) And in like manner, kb-swA↓ EalaI AlX-aIoCi, and tk-bswA↓ Ealayohi, ‡ They threw themselves upon the thing suddenly and without consideration. (TA.)

kabasa raOosahu, [aor. as above,] He put his head within his garments: (Ṣ:) and kabasa raOosahu fiI vawobihi he hid his head in his garment, and put it within it: (Ḳ:) or he put it on in the manner of a qinaAE, (taqan-aEa,) and then covered himself with part of it. (TA.) You say also, kabasa raOosahu fiI jayobi qamiySihi, (A,) or biraOosihi, (TA,) He put his head within the opening at the neck and bosom of his shirt; (A;) and so tkb-s↓ alone. (TA.) And yakobisu Alr-ajulu vawobahu fiI raOosihi [app. meaning, The man puts his garment as a covering over his head.] (Sh, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. kab-asa see 1, in three places.
3. kAbshu, [inf. n. mukaAbasapN, app. syn. with maArasahu, or daAfaEahu: see taAyasa.]

hom.sense: 5. tkb-s [quasi-pass. of 2, It was, or became, pressed, or squeezed].
See also 1, in two places.

entry.sense: 7. Ankbs It (a river, [and a well,] and any hollow, or cavity, or pit, dug in the ground,) became filled up with earth. (Mgh.)
kibosN Earth with which a well, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or river, (Ḳ,) or any hollow, or cavity, or pit, dug in the ground, (TA,) is filled up: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) earth that occupies the place of air. (TA.)

hom.sense: kabiysN A kind of dates, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said to be of the best kind; (Mṣb;) thus called when dry; but when fresh, called Oum-u jirocaAnK, which is also the name of the tree that bears them. (TA.)
A kind of women's ornament, made hollow, (A, L, Ḳ,) and coated with perfume, (A,) or stuffed with perfume, (L, Ḳ,) and then worn; (L;) a necklace being made of ornaments of this kind. (A.)

Als-anapu Alkabiysapu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and EaAmu Alkabiysi, (L, Az, in TA, voce subaATN, q. v.,) [The intercalary year; or leap-year; both in the Syrian, or Julian, reckoning, and in the Coptic;] the year from which, (minohaA,) accord. to the Ṣ and Ḳ, but properly, for which, (lahaA,) as in the work entitled Alqawolu AlmaOonuwsu, a day is stolen (yusotaraqu) [and intercalated]; which is [once] in every four years; as in the Ṣ and Ḳ; for the said day is an addition thereto; (MF, TA;) the year in which the Syrians following the Greeks, add a day to the month subaAT, [which corresponds to February, O. Ṣ.,] making it twentynine days instead of twenty-eight, which they do once in four years; (L;) [and that in which the Copts intercalate, at the end, six epagomenæ instead of five, which, in like manner, they do once in every four years.]

entry.sense: kibaAsapN A raceme, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or large raceme, (TA,) of a palm-tree, (A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) or of dates, like the Eunoquwd of grapes, (Ṣ,) complete, with its XamaAriyx, [or fruit-stalks, pl. of XimoraAxN,] (A, TA,) and its dates: (TA:) pl. kabaAYisu. (A, Mṣb.) [A kbAsp of moderate size has about one hundred XmAryx; the longest XmrAx having about fifty dates, and being about two feet and a half in length; and the shortest having about thirty dates, and being about one foot in length.]
Also applied by AḤn, to ‡ A raceme of [the fruit called] fuwfal. (TA.)

hom.sense: kaAbisN Charging, attacking, or assaulting. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, jaMCa kaAbisFA He came charging, attacking, or assaulting: (Ḳ,* TA:) as also mukab-isFA↓, and mukaAbisFA↓. (TA.)
Throwing himself suddenly and without consideration [upon a person or thing]. (TA.)
A man putting himself within his garment, covering his body with it. (TA.)

entry.sense: kaAbuwsN [Incubus, or nightmare;] what comes upon a man (or rather upon a sleeper, TA,) in the night, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) preventing his moving while it lasts; (Ḳ;) accord. to some, (Ṣ,) the forerunner of epilepsy. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Some think that this is not Arabic, and that the proper word is nayodulaAnN, and baAruwkN, and jaAvuwmN. (TA.) Hence, app., (TA.) ‡ Modus certus coëundi: (Ḳ:) or rather, ‡ coïtus itself. (TA.)
mukab-asu Alr-aOosi Compact in the head. (AHeyth, T in art. Zrb.)
mukab-isN Hanging down his head in his garment: (Ḳ,* TA:) or one who throws himself suddenly and without consideration upon others, and assaults them. (Ḳ.) See also kaAbisN.
mukaAbisN: see kaAbisN.
1. kabaXahu, [aor. _i {yakobiXu}, accord. to present usage,] inf. n. kaboXN, He took it with his hand having the fingers contracted; (TA;) [he took by the handful, so used in the present day.]

kaboXN A ram, or male sheep, whatever be his age: (M, TA:) or a male sheep [that has entered his third year,] when he has cast his central incisors: or when his tooth that is next to the central pair of incisors has come forth: (Lth, Ḳ:) [also applied in the present day to the wild sheep of the Arabian and Egyptian deserts and mountains; ovis tragelaphus:] pl. [of pauc.] OakobuXN and OakobaAXN (Ḳ) and [of mult.] kibaAXN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) [and app. kubuwXN] and kubuwXapN, like SuquwrapN from SaqorN. (TA.) The female is not called kaboXapN, but naEojapN. (IJ. [See raAjilapN.])

[Hence,] ‡ The chief, or lord, of a people, or company of men; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) their leader: (Ḳ:) or their strenuous defender, or protector, and the one of them to whom others look. (TA.) You say, huwa kaboXu Alkatiybapi (A, TA) ‡ He is the leader of the army, or troop: (TA:) and humo kibaAXu AlkataAYibi ‡ [They are the leaders of the armies, or troops]. (A, TA.) And kibaAXN also signifies ‡ Heroes, or brave men. (TA.) And † Aged and learned persons. (TA in art. xrf.)

[Hence also, ‡ A buttress: and a corbel which juts out from a wall to support a superstructure: so in the present day: pl. kubuwXN.] You say, banawoA suwrFA HaSiynFA wawav-aquwhu biAlkubuwXi ‡ [They built a strong town-wall, and made it firm with the buttresses]. (A, TA.) [See also another ex. voce faSiylN.]
kaboXapN [A handful: a heap: so applied in the the present day.]

[And hence, † A gang, or crew: thus, also, applied in the present day. Whence the sayings,] banuw fulaAnK kaboXapu rucalaMCa † [The sons of such a one are a gang of vile persons]: and kaboXapu dunasaMCa † [a gang of dirty, or filthy, persons]: thus they use this word to intimate dispraise: but [SM adds,] I know not how this is. (TA.) [Perhaps SM means that he doubts whether the word thus used be classical or not: for as to its signification, it is well known.]
kab-aAXN An owner, [or a tender] of kibaAX [or rams]. (TA.)
kabaEovaApN The [thing termed] EafalN of a woman: (Ḳ:) a dial. form of qabaEovaApN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. kat-ati Alqidoru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yakotitu}, (TA,) inf. n. katiytN, (Ḳ,) The cooking-pot boiled: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, made a sound in boiling: (Ḳ:) or, made a sound in boiling when the water in it was little; a lower sound than it makes when there is much water boiling in it; as though it said kato kato. (TA.)
Also, kat-ati Aljar-apu Aljadiydu, (Ṣ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, The new jar made a sound (like kato kato, TA) when water was poured into it. (Ṣ.)
kat-a,, aor. _i {yakotitu}, inf. n. kat-N (TA) and katiytN, (Ḳ,) It (nabiyc, Ḳ, or another thing, TA,) made a sound in boiling: (Ḳ:) or began to boil, before it boiled vehemently. (TA.)

kat-a, aor. _i {yakotitu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. katiytN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (a bakor, or young camel,) uttered a cry, or a kind of braying, louder than that which is termed kaXiyXN: (Ṣ:) or began to utter the kind of braying termed hadiyrN: (Ḳ:) Aṣ says, that when a male camel has attained the age when he makes the braying cry termed hdyr, his first kind of braying is termed kXyX; and when it is a little louder, it is termed ktyt: Lth says, that he first makes the kind of braying termed ktyt; then, that termed kXyX; and then, that termed hadiyrN: but Az observes, that the correct saying is that of Aṣ. (TA.)
kat-, aor. _i {yakotitu}, (inf. n. katiytN, Ṣ,) He (a camel, Ṣ, Ḳ, or, as in the L, a bakor, or young camel,) uttered a gentle cry, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) between that termed kXyX and that termed hdyr. (TA.)
He (a calf) lowed. (Nh.)

kat-a, aor. _i {yakotitu}, (inf. n. katiytN, Ḳ,) [He (a man) made a sound like the gentle braying of a camel,] by reason of rage, or wrath: (Ṣ:) or he (a man) made a a sound in his chest like that made by a bakor, or young camel, by reason of vehement rage, or wrath. (Ḳ, TA.)
kat-a AlkalaAma fiI Oucunihi, aor. _u {yakotutu} and Oakat-ahu↓, and Uikotat-ahu↓; He whispered the words in his ear. (Ḳ.)
kut-aniI AlHadiyva, and Oakit-aniyhi↓, Tell me the story as thou heardest it. (TA.)
kat-ahu, [aor. _u {yakotutu},] He angered him; provoked him to anger; syn. Oarogamahu. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
kat-ahu, [aor. _u {yakotutu},] He displeased him; grieved him; did to him what he disliked, or hated; did evil to him. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
faEala bihi maA kat-ahu He did to him what displeased him, or grieved him. (TA.)

kat-a, aor. _u {yakotutu}, inf. n. kat-N, He numbered, counted, or computed, a people. Mostly used in negative phrases. (TA.) You say OataAnaA bijayoXK maA yukat-u He came to us with an army not to be numbered, or counted, (IAạr, Ṣ,) or computed, or of which the number could not be conjectured, and of which the end could not be reached. (IAạr, TA.)
laA takut-uhu Oawo takut-a Aln-ujuwma, [in the CK, erroneously, laA takut-uhu Oawo laA takut-u Aln-ujuwma,] Thou canst not number it, [unless thou canst number the stars]. A proverb. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1.

6. tkAt-w Ealayohi They pressed together, or crowded together, upon it, with crying, or noise: from Alkatiytu. Occurring in a trad., as related and explained by Z; but the word commonly known is tkAb-wA, with b. (TA.)
8. Aktt-, inf. n. UikotitaAtN, He listened; syn. UisotamaEa. (Ḳ.)
Aktt- AlHadiyva min-iI He heard the story from me like as I heard it. (TA.) See 1.

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. katokata, inf. n. katokatapN, (in the Ḳ, katokatN, which is a mistake, TA,) It (a HubaAraI, or bustard,) uttered its cry. (L, Ḳ, &c.)
katokata, inf. n. katokatapN, (Ṣ, &c.,) He laughed gently, or lowly: (Ḳ:) ktktp, in laughing, is less than qahoqahapN: (Ṣ:) or like what is termed HaniynN. (Th, El-Aḥmar.)
katokata fiI DaHikihi He laughed vehemently, immoderately, or excessively; i. q. Oagoraba, q. v. (A.)
See also 1.

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. takatokata: see 1.
kat-N A man or woman having little flesh: you say rajulN kat-N and UimoraOapN kat-N. (TA.)
kat-apN Green produce of land. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
kut-apN The worst, or vilest, of camels, or similar property; syn. rucaAlu AlmaAli. (Fr, Ḳ.)
kat-apF a [gen?] proper name of A bad she-goat. (Fr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: katiytN: see 1.
‡ A niggardly, stingy, man: (Ḳ:) as also katiytu Alyadayoni: (TA:) from katiytu Alqidori: [see 1:] (IJ:) or a niggardly, stingy, man, of bad disposition, and rageful, or wrathful. (T.)

entry.sense: katiytapN i. q. EaSiydapN [q. v.] (TṢ, Ḳ.)
kutokutu and kutokutaI, both imperfectly declinable, A certain game. (TṢ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: katokaAtN ‡ One who walks gently; at a gentle pace: or who walks with short steps, but quickly. (TA.)
A man who talks much (Ḳ) and quickly. (TA.)

entry.sense: Q. Q. 1. kanotaOati All-iHoyapu: see kavaOat.
katoOapN A plant resembling the jirojiyrN, [or rocket], (Ḳ,) which is cooked and eaten. (TA.) But AM says it is kavoOapN, with v; and it is also called nahoqN, accord. to Aboo-Málik and others. (TA.)
kinotaOowu (but accord. to some, this is from knt) A strong rope. (Ḳ.) [But see art. kdO.]
Also, A man having a large and thick, or a handsome, beard. (Ḳ.) Said to be a dial. form of kinovaOowN. (TA.)

hom.sense:
1. katabahu, aor. _u {yakotubu}, inf. n. katobN and kitaAbN and kitaAbapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kitobapN; (Mṣb;) the first of these inf. ns. agreeable with analogy; the second, anomalous; (TA;) or the latter of these two is a subst., like libaAsN; (Lḥ;)
or originally an inf. n., and afterwards used in the senses given below; (MF;) as also kitaAbapN, and kitobapN: (TA:) and kt-bhu↓ (Ḳ) and Akttbhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He wrote it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or katabahu has this signification; and Akttbhu↓, as also Astktbhu↓, signifies he asked [one] to dictate it (UisotamolaAhu): (Ḳ:) UikotatabahaA↓ in the Ḳur, xxv. 6, signifies he hath written them (Ṣ) for himself: (Bḍ:) or he hath asked [one] to write them for him, or to dictate them to him. (TA, Bḍ.)
kataba Eanohu [He wrote what he had heard, or learned from him.] A phrase of common occurrence in biographies.
kataba [He was a writer, or scribe, and a learned man. (Implied in the Ṣ, where we are referred to the Ḳur, lii. 41, and lxviii., 47, in illustration of kaAtibN as signifying “a learned man.”)]

kataba, aor. _u {yakotubu}, inf. n. kitaAbN, q. v., † He (God) prescribed, appointed, or ordained, (TA,) and made obligatory. (Mṣb.) kutiba Ealayokumu AlqiSaASu The law of retaliation is prescribed, appointed, or ordained, as a law of which the observance is incumbent on you. [Ḳur, ii. 173.] kutiba Ealayokumu AlS-iyaAmu Fasting is prescribed as incumbent on you. [Ḳur. ii. 179.] (TA.)

kataba Ealayohi kacaA ‡ He judged, passed sentence, or decreed, against him that he should do such a thing. (A.) ktb AlqaADiI biAln-afaqapi The judge gave sentence that the expenses should be paid. (Mṣb.)
kataba, aor. _u {yakotubu}, inf. n. katobN, He drew together; brought together; conjoined. (Ṣ.)

Hence, kataba Albagolapa, aor. _u {yakotubu} and _i {yakotibu}, inf. n. katobN, He conjoined the oræ of the mule's vulva by means of a ring or a thong; (Ṣ;) as also kataba EalayohaA. (A.) kataba, aor. _u {yakotubu} and _i {yakotibu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. katobN; and kataba EalayohaA; (TA;) He closed the camel's vulva, (Ḳ,) and put a ring upon it: (TA:) or he put a ring of iron or the like upon it, (Ḳ,) conjoining the oræ, in order that she might not be covered. (TA.)

kataba, aor. _u {yakotubu}, inf. n. katobN; (Ṣ;) and Akttb↓; (Ḳ;) He sewed a qirobap, (Ṣ,) or a siqaMC, (Ḳ,) or a mazaAdap, (TA,) with two thongs: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, he closed it at the mouth, by binding it round with a wikaAC, so that nothing [of its contents] should drop from it; (TA;) [as also Aktb↓:] or ktb signifies he sewed a qrbp; and Aktb↓, he bound it with a wkMC, i. e. bound it round the upper part. (Lḥ.)

kataba, aor. _u {yakotubu}, inf. n. katobN; (Ṣ;) and Aktb↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Akttb↓ (TA) ‡ He bound a qirobap with a wikaAC; (Ṣ;) he bound it round the head, or upper part: (Ḳ:) or the first of these verbs signifies he sewed a qrbp. (Lḥ.) See above. IAạr says, I heard an Arab of the desert say, Oakotabotu fama Als-iqaAC falamo yasotakotibo↓ I bound the mouth of the sqAC, but it did not become fast bound, or closed, because of its hardness and thickness. (TA.)

kataba Aln-aAqapa He used art to make the she-camel take a liking to that which was not her own young one, and put something as a ring through her nostrils, lest she should smell the baw-, (in some copies of the Ḳ, bawol; but this is a mistake; TA,) and not have a fondness for it. (TA.)
kataba ‡ He collected a katiybap. (TA.) See also 2.
2: See 1 and 4
kt-b Aln-aAqapa, inf. n. takotiybN, He tied the udder of the camel. (AZ, Ṣ.)
kt-b AlkataAYiba, inf. n. takotiybN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and katabahaA↓; (TA;) ‡ He prepared the troops; (Ḳ;) he disposed the troops in order, troop by troop. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 3. mukaAtabapN and takaAtubN↓ are syn.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) you say, kAtb Sadiyqahu He wrote to his friend: and tkAtbA↓ They wrote, one to the other. (TA.)

kAtbhu, inf. n. mukaAtabapN (Az, Ḳ, Mṣb) and kitaAbN, (Az, Mṣb,) ‡ He (a slave) made a written [or other] contract with him (his master), that he (the former) should pay a certain sum as the price of himself, and on the payment thereof be free: (Ḳ, &c.:) also he (a master) made such a contract with him (his slave): (Az, Mṣb, &c.:) and tkAtbA↓ They two made such a contract, one with the other. (Mṣb.) The slave in this case is called mukaAtabN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and also mukaAtibN; and so is the master; the act being mutual. (Mṣb.) [But the lawyers in the present day call the slave mukaAtabN only; and the master, mukaAtibN.] AlkitaAbapu, signifying “what is written,” is tropically used by the professors of practical law as syn. with AlmukaAtabapu, because the contract above mentioned was generally written; and is so used by them when nothing is written. It was thus called in the age of el-Islám, accord. to Az. These two words are said by Z to be syn.; but it is thought that he may have written the former by mistake for AlkitaAbu, adding the p by a slip of the pen. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 4. Aktb He dictated. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. OakotiboniI hecihi AlqaSiydapa Dictate to me this ode. (Ṣ.)
Aktb and kt-b↓ He taught the art of writing. (Ḳ.)
See also 1, in three places.
5. tkt-b ‡ He girded himself, and drew together his garments upon him. (TA.)
tkt-b ‡ It (an army, Ṣ) collected itself together. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6: see 3.

hom.sense: 8: See 1.
kitobapN [is a quasi-inf. n. of 8; syn. with UikotitaAbN; and is explained as signifying] The writing a book, transcribing it [from another book]: (UikotitaAbuka kitaAbFA tanosaxuhu). (Ḳ.)
It also signifies, [as a quasi-inf. n. of 8,] The writing one's name in [the list of those who receive] stipend and maintenance (AlkttAb fI AlfrD wAlrzq [ASHAb]). (TA.)

Akttb He registered himself in the book of the Sultán's army-list, or stipendiaries. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Uikotatabotu fiI gazowapi kacaA I wrote down my name in the list of the soldiers of such an expedition. (TA, from a trad.)
Akttb kitaAbFA He asked for a book (or the like) to be written for him. (TA.) See also 10.
Akttb ‡ His urine was suppressed. (TA.)
Akttb baTonuhu ‡ He was constipated, or costive; (TA;) his belly was constipated. (Ḳ.)
10. Astktbhu XayoYFA He asked him to write a thing for him. (Ṣ.) See also 1 and 8.
With reference to a siqaAC (or skin), see 1.

entry.sense: kutobapN ‡ A thong with which one sews (Ḳ) a mazaAdap or a qirobap: pl. kutabN. (TA.)
That with which the vulva of a camel (or of a mule, TA,) is closed in order that she may not be covered: (Ḳ:) pl. kutabN. (TA.)

A seam or suture, (KL, PṢ,) in a skin or hide; (KL;) [app. made by sewing together two edges so that one laps over the other;] a xurozapN (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ) whereof the thong conjoins the two faces [or sides]: (Ḳ:) or a xrzp that is joined together with a thong: (Lth:) or that whereof the thong conjoins each of the two faces [or sides]: (ISd, TA:) pl. kutabN. (Ṣ, Mgh.)
kitobapN: see 1 and 8.
[Also, agreeably with analogy, A mode, or manner, of writing.]
[kutubiI-N, meaning A bookseller, is a vulgar term, like SuHufiI-N: by rule it should be kitaAbiI-N.]

hom.sense: kitaAbN [inf. n. of 1, q. v.]

A revealed scripture. (Mṣb.) [Whence Oaholu kitaAbK People having a revealed scripture: and Oaholu AlkitaAbi The people of the Bible. See also OaholN.] AlktAb signifies The taworAp, or Pentateuch, or Mosaic Law: (Ḳ:) and the Gospel, or Book of the Gospels: the Scriptures of the Jews and Christians: (Expositions of the Ḳur, passim:) and the Ḳur-án. (TA.)
See also 3.

kitaAbN [inf. n., or subst.: see 1] Divine prescript, appointment, or ordinance: judgment, or sentence: fatal decree, or predestination. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) laOaqoDiyan-a bayonakumaA bikitaAbi Qll-ehi I will assuredly determine, or judge, between you two according to the judgment, or sentence, of God, which hath been revealed in his book. A trad., not relating to the Ḳur-án. (TA.)
El-Jaadee says,
yaA Qbonapa Eam-iI kitaAbu Qll-ehi OaxorajaniI
Eanokumo wahalo Oamonafan-a Qll-eha maA faEalaA
[O daughter of my paternal uncle! the decree of God hath expelled me from you: and could I indeed forbid God to do what He hath done?] (Ṣ.) [Hence,] AlkitaAbu AlOaw-alu [The first writing; meaning the register of God's decrees]. (M and Ḳ voce maHobalN, q. v.)
A receptacle for ink. (Ḳ).

entry.sense: qirobapN katiybN A skin that is sewed (Ṣ) with two thongs: (TA:) and the same, and mukotabN↓, (Ṣ,) and mukotatabN↓, (TA,) ‡ A skin bound with a wikaAC; (Ṣ;) closed at the mouth, by its being bound with a wikaAC, so that nothing [of its contents] may drop from it. (TA.)
kitaAbapN subst. from 1; signifying The art of writing. (IAạr, Mṣb.)
See also 3.

hom.sense: katiybapN see kitaAbN.

An army; a military force: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a collected portion thereof; (Mṣb;) [a body of troops; a corps:] or a troop: or a troop of horse making a hostile attack or incursion, in number from a hundred to a thousand: (Ḳ:) pl. kataAYibu. (Ṣ.)
kut-aAbN, see makotabN

The same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also kuv-aAbN, q. v., but the former is the more approved: (Ṣ: the reverse, however, is said in the TA; and MF says that some authors altogether reject kt-Ab, with t, in the sense here following:) A kind of small, round-headed, arrow, with which boys learn to shoot. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: kaAtibN [A writer; a scribe; a secretary]: pl. kaAtibuwna and kut-aAbN and katabapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A learned man (Ṣ, Ḳ) was so called by the Arabs, (IAạr,) because, in general, he who knew the art of writing was possessed of science and knowledge; and writers among them were few. (TA.)

makotabN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kut-aAbN↓ (Lth, Ṣ, &c.) A school; a place where the art of writing is taught: (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) accord. to Mbr and F, the assigning this signification to the latter word is an error; it being a pl. of kaAtibN, and signifying, accord. to Mbr, the boys of a school: in the A it is said, this word is said to signify the boys; not the place: but Esh-Shiháb says, in the Sharh esh-Shifa, that it occurs in this sense in the classical language, and is not to be regarded as a post-classical word: it is said to be originally a pl. of kaAtibN, and to be fig. employed to signify a school. (TA.) Pl. of the former makaAtibu; (TA;) and of the latter kataAtiybu. (Ṣ.)
mukotabN: see katiybN.
mukotibN A teacher of the art of writing. (Ṣ.)
bglp makotuwbapN, and makotuwbN EalayohaA, A mule that has the oræ of her vulva conjoined by means of a ring or a thong. (A.) See also 1.
mukat-abN A bunch of grapes and the like of which a part has been eaten. (Ḳ, TA.)
mukotatabN: see katiybN.
mukotawotibN Swollen, and full. (Ḳ.)

katadN and katidN [The upper part of the back, above, or between, the shoulders:] the part where the two shoulder-blades come [or approach] together; in a man and a horse (L, Ḳ) and a lion: (L:) or the part between the base of the neck and the shoulder-blades: (A:) or the part between the kaAhil [app. here signifying the bas of the neck] and the back; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also vabajN: (L:) or the part between the muvab-aj [or place where the pastor puts his stick, or staff, upon his back, putting his arms and hands behind it,] and the middle of the kAhl [which app. here signifies the portion of the back comprising its six upper vertebræ]: or the part from the base of the neck to the bottom of the shoulder-blades, comprising the kaAvibap and vbj and kAhl: (L:) or the kAhl itself: (L, Ḳ:) or the upper part of the shoulder-blade: (L:) pl. OakotaAdN and kutuwdN. (L, Ḳ.)
naHomiluhu EalaI AlOakobaAdi faDolFA Eani AlOakotaAdi [We will carry it upon the livers; much more upon the upper parts of the backs]. (A.)
wal-awohumo OakotaAdahumo They turned their backs upon them, retreating and routed. (A.)
Alkatadu ‡ A certain star, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) [g] in the part called the ktd of the constellation Leo. (L.)

humo OakotaAdN They are companies, or congregated bodies: (L, Ḳ:) or, distinct bodies, or parties, or troops: as also OakodaAdN: (L:) or, like each other; (L, Ḳ:) not differing, one from another: (TA:) or, quick, or swift, one party of them following immediately after another: (L, Ḳ:) AktAd has no sing.: (Ḳ:) it is said to be either OakodaAdN mispronounced, or a dial. form of this latter word. (MF.)
Oakotadu Having the place called the katad prominent. (L, Ḳ.)

dictScrap.title: ktE / ktf / ktl / ktm / ktn
dictScrap.label:
[ktE, ktf, ktl, ktm and ktn
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. kav-a, [aor. _i {yakovivu},] inf. n. kavaAvapN, It (a thing) became thick, or dense. (Ṣ.)
kav-a,, aor. _i {yakovivu}, inf. n. kuvuwvapN and kavaAvapN; and kav-a, originally kaviva, aor. _a {yakovavu}, inf. n. kavavN; It (hair) became thick, or dense, without being long. (Mṣb.)
kav-ati All-iHoyapu, (aor. _i {yakovivu}, TA, or _u A,) inf. n. kavaAvapN and kuvuwvapN and kavavN, (and kav-N, TA,) The beard became thick, or dense; and short and crisp; (Ḳ;) not spreading. (TA.)
kav-a bisaloHihi Alvum dejecit. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4. Akv- and kavokava↓ He became thick, or dense, in the beard. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1: see 4.
kav-N Thick, or dense. (Ḳ.)
liHoyapN kav-apN, (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and kav-aMCu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) A thick, or dense, beard. (IDrd, &c.)

rajulN kav-u All-iHoyapi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and kaviyvu↓ AllHyp, (Ḳ,) and rajulN Oakav-u↓, (Lth,) and kav-N, (Lth, Ḳ,) A man having a thick, or dense, beard; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) not one that is thin or long. (TA.) You say qawomN kuv-N, A thick-bearded people: (Ṣ. Ḳ:) [kuv-N being pl. of kav-N:] like as you say rajulN Sadoqu All-iqaMCi, and qawomN SudoqN: (Ṣ:) [or of Oakav-u:] kivaAvN is also pl. of kavN. (Ḳ.)
UimoraOapN kav-apN, and kav-aMCu↓, A woman having thick, or dense, hair. (IDrd.)
By All-ihama AlkivaAva, occurring in a verse cited in art. Hwv, is meant [The thick, or dense,] plants. (TA.)
Thaalabeh Ibn-ʼObeyd El-'Adawee applies the epithet kav-ap to palm-trees, using the expression kav-apu AlOawobaAri; thus likening them to camels. (TA.)
quduwmuhu EalaI kav-i manoxirihi i. q. EalaI ragomi Oanofihi [His coming is in spite of himself]. (TA.)
kvAv [so in the L and TA: in the former, in a restored portion of a leaf:] Dust: mentioned by El-Khaṭṭábee as being considered by him not of established authority. (TA.)
kavaAvaACu Land (OaroDN) abounding in dust. (Ḳ.)
kaAv-N What grows from that which is scattered, or from that which falls about, of what is reaped. (Ḳ.) [See also zir-iyEN.]
kaAv-K bisaloHihi Alvum dejiciens. (TA.)

kavokavN and kivokivN Crumbled particles of stone; and dust: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like OavolabN and UivolibN: (Ṣ:) or fine dust; and crumbled particles of stone: or dust in general. (TA.) One says bifiyhi Alkvkvu [In his mouth are crumbled particles of stone, and dust: app. meaning he is dead and buried]. (Ṣ.) [See also kvAv.].
kuvokuvaI and kavokavaI A certain game played with dust. (Ḳ.)
Oakav-u: see kav-N.

hom.sense: 1. kavaOa, aor. _a {yakovaOu}, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. kavoCN; (Ṣ;) (as also kavaEa; TA;) and kv-O↓, inf. n. takoviYapN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) It (the milk) rose above the water, and the latter became clear beneath it: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) it (the milk) became thick, or coagulated, and its oily matter floated upon its surface. (TA.)
kavaOati Alqidoru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. kavoCN, (Ṣ,) The pot frothed, or raised a scum, in boiling. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kavaOa Alqidora He skimmed the pot. (Ḳ.)

kavaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kavoCN; (TA;) and kv-O↓, inf. n. takoviYapN; (Ḳ;) It (a plant, Ṣ, Ḳ, and the soft kind of hair called wabar, Ṣ) grew forth, or became dense and thick and long: (Ḳ:) it (standing corn, &c.) became thick and tangled. (TA.)
kavaOati All-iHoyapu, and kv-Ot↓, and kanovaOat↓, (Ḳ,) or, accord. to some, kntOt, (TA,) The beard became long and large (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. kv-O, inf. n. takoviIoCN, He ate what is called kavoOap, (Ḳ,) i. e. what is on the top of milk. (Ṣ, TA.)
And see 1 in three places.
Q. Q. 1: see 1, last sentence.
