kavoCN A kind of OaqiT; what rises (from the milk) above the water, the latter becoming clear beneath it; or what becomes thick, or coagulated, its oily matter floating upon the surface, (yakovaOu,) in the pot, and is poured out; the upper part whereof is gross, or thick. So says AḤát; and he adds, What is termed mSrE [evidently, I think, a mistranscription for muDar-iEN,] is what becomes thick, or coagulated, and almost thoroughly cooked: EAqd is that of which the water has gone, and which is thoroughly cooked: kariyS is that which is cooked with nahoq or HamaSiyS: maSol is a kind of AqT cooked again: and vawor is a great piece of it. (TA.)

hom.sense: kavoOapN and kavoOapN (like kvEp, TA) Oily scum, or floating curd, of milk; or what floats above the water: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) scum of a pot, after boiling. (TA.)
xuco kavOpa qidorika Take the scum of thy pot. (Ṣ.) [See 2.]

kavoOapN and kavaApN (Ḳ) The leek, syn. kur-aAv: or, as some say, the wild carrot, syn. HinozaAb: (TA:) or the rocket, syn. jirojiyr: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to AM, the seed of that plant: (TA:) or wild rocket, syn. jirojiyr bar-iI-; (Ḳ;) not that which is cultivated in gardens. (TA.) Aboo-Málik says, that it is also called nahoq. (TA.) [See also katoOap.]

entry.sense: liHoyapN kanovaOapN A long and large beard. (TA.)
kanovaOu All-iHoyapi Having a long and large beard. (TA.)
kinovaOowN i. q. kinotaOowN, [q. v. in art. ktO]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. kavabahu, aor. _u {yakovubu} and _i {yakovibu}, inf. n. kavobN, He collected it together, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from a near place. (TA.) kuviba bayonanaA [It (referring to a quantity of dates, sent by Moḥammad,) was collected together among us;] meaning, it was left collected together before us. (TA, from a trad.) kavaba Alqawoma He collected together the people. (Mṣb.)
kavabahu, aor. _u {yakovubu} and _i {yakovibu}, inf. n. kavobN, He poured it out, or forth. (Ḳ.) He collected it together from a near place, and poured it out, or forth. (TA.)
He scattered dust, or earth, part over part. (Lth.)
kavaba, aor. _u {yakovubu}, inf. n. kavobN, He scattered corn or other food. (AZ.)
kavaba kinaAnatahu He turned his quiver upside down, and scattered its contents. (Ḳ.) In one copy of the Ḳ, explained by nkvhA; but this is a mistake: the right reading is nakabahaA. (TA.)
kavaba, aor. _u {yakovubu} and _i {yakovibu}, inf. n. kavobN, It (a people, TA,) collected itself together, or congregated. (Ḳ.)
kavabN, aor. _u {yakovubu} and _a {yakovabu}, inf. n. kavobN, He entered. (Ḳ.) Ex. kavabuwA lakumo They entered among you. From [kavabN as signifying] “nearness.” (TA.)
kavaba Ealayohi He charged upon him, and returned against him after retiring from him: (Ḳ:) or he drew near to him, and charged upon him, &c. (TA.) See also 4.
kavaba labanuhaA Her milk became little; (Ḳ;) either in a case of [usual] copiousness or paucity. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. kv-b, inf. n. takoviybN, It [a number of things, or a quantity,] was, or became, few, or little. The inf. n. is explained in the Ḳ by the word qil-ap; but this, says SM, I do not find in the [other] lexicons. (TA.)
3: see 4.

hom.sense: 4. Akvbhu, and Akvb lahu, and minohu, (Ḳ,) and Uilayohi, and kavabahu↓, (TA,) and kAvbhu↓, (Ḳ,) He drew near to, or approached, him or it. (Ḳ.) UicaA kavabuwkumo faQromuwhumo biAln-aboli When they draw near to you, shoot at them with arrows. (TA, from a trad.) [You say] Oakovabaka AlS-ayodu qaQromihi, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) and Oakovaba laka, (TA,) The game hath enabled thee [to shoot it]; (Ṣ;) or made thee to have its kaAvibap within thy power, or reach; (Ḳ;) or drawn near to thee and enabled thee [to take advantage of it]; (TA;) [so shoot at it]. In some copies of the Ḳ, for Akvbk, we read kavabaka; but the former is the right reading, though the two verbs are syn. The phrase is a proverb. (TA.)
Akvbhu He gave him to drink a kuvobap (Ḳ) of milk. (TA.)

entry.sense: 7. Ankvb It (sand) collected. (Ṣ.)
Ankvb fiyhi It (anything) poured out, or forth, or was, or became, poured out, or forth, into it, (Ṣ,) and collected. (TA.)
Ankvb It (dust, or earth,) was, or became, scattered, part over part. (Lth.)

kavabN Nearness [with respect to place]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The b in this word is sometimes changed into m. (Mṣb.) huwa kaXabaka He is near thee. Sb says that it is not used otherwise than as an adverbial noun of place. But you say, huwa yaromiI mino kavabK He shoots, or throws, from a near spot, and from a distance from which he can reach, or hit. (TA.)

hom.sense: kuvobapN A portion, or quantity, of corn or other food, (or of dates, TA,) or dust, or earth, &c., (Ḳ), after it has been little. (TA.)
Anything collected together, (Ḳ,) of corn or other food, &c., after it has been little. (Ṣ.)

A little of milk, &c.: (AʼObeyd) or a little of water and of milk: or a gulp, or draught, remaining in a vessel: (Ḳ:) or the quantity of one milking: (Ṣ:) or the quantity that is contained in a bowl or cup of the kind called qadaH, of milk, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of water: (Ḳ:) pl. kuvabN. (Ṣ.) UiHotalabuwA kuvabFA They milked a little from each ewe. (AḤát.) One says of a man who comes to seek food as a guest under the pretence of demanding a woman in marriage, Uin-ahu layaxoTubu kuvobapF [Verily he sues for a little milk, &c.] (IAạr.)
A depressed tract of land between mountains. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: kavobaACu Dust, or earth, (turaAbN): (Ḳ, as in the Calc. ed. and in a MṢ. copy:) or one of the names of XaraAb [by which, app., is here meant wine]. (So accord. to the TA, which does not mention the former reading in the Ḳ.)
kuvaAbN Many, or much: (Ḳ:) a syn. of kubaAbN, q. v.: you say naEamN kuvaAbN, meaning Many camels, or camels and sheep or goats. (TA.)
kivaAbN: see kuv-aAbN.
kaviybN A thing collected together. (Mṣb.)

A hill, or heap, of sand: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or an oblong and gibbous hill of sand: or an extended gibbous hill [or an elevated expanse] of sand: or what has collected, of sand, and assumed a gibbous shape: (TA:) or what has poured down, of sand, into a place, and collected there: (Ṣ:) [less than what is called EaqanoqalN, q. v.:] pl. kuvobaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kuvubN and OakovibapN: (Ḳ:) [the last a pl. of pauc.].
wkaAnati AljibaAlu kaviybFA muhiylFA [Ḳur, lxxiii. 14,] signifies And the mountains shall be sand, whereof the lower part being shaken, it shall pour down upon thee from above. (Fr.)
valaAvapN EalaI kuvubi Almisoki, or kuvobaAni Almsk, [Three (descriptions of men shall be, on the day of resurrection,) on hills, or heaps, of musk]. (TA, from a trad.)
kav-aAbN: see kuv-aAbN.

kuv-aAbN (Ṣ, art. ktb, and Ḳ) and kat-aAbN↓, (Ḳ,) as also kut-aAbN, q. v., An arrow having neither head nor feathers, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) with which boys play: (Aṣ, TA:) or a common arrow. (TA.) [You say,] maA ramaAhu bikuv-aAbK He did not shoot at him with an arrow: or, as some say, a small arrow is here meant. (L.) A proverb, which is related as above: but accord. to the Ḳ., maA ramaI bikivaAbK↓ He did not shoot, or throw anything; an arrow or other thing. (TA.)
kavonabN and kanovabN: see arts. kvnt and knvb.

kaAvibapN The minosaj (or part below the HaArik, which latter is the withers, or the upper part thereof, &c.,) of a horse: (Ḳ:) or the fore part of the mnsj of a horse, where the hand of the horseman falls [when he mounts]: (Ṣ:) or the elevated part of the mnsj: or the part from the root of the neck to the part between the shoulders: or the place where the shoulders unite, before the saddle; [i. e. the withers]: pl. kawaAvibu (TA) and OakovaAbN: (Ḳ:) but of the latter pl. ISd remarks, I know not how this is. (TA.) yaDaEuwna rimaAHahumo EalaI kawaAvibi xayolihimo [They put their spears upon the withers of their horses]. The last of the above explanations is here assigned to kwAvb. (TA, from a trad.)

hom.sense: 1. kavura, aor. _u {yakovuru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. kavorapN (Mṣb, TA) and kivorapN, or this is erroneous, (Mṣb,) [and perhaps kuvorapN, and kuvorN, or these are simple substs., (see kavorapN, below,)] and kavaArapN, (TA,) It was, or became, much, copious, abundant, many, numerous, great in number or quantity; it multiplied; it accumulated. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) kavuruwA Ealayohi fagalabuwhu [They multiplied against him and overcame him.] (TA in art. grq). [kavura minohu kacaA Such a thing proceeded from him, or was done by him, much, or often.] See also 4.
kaAvaruwhumo fakavaruwhumo: see 3.

entry.sense: 2: see 4.

hom.sense: 3. kaAvaruwhumo fakavaruwhumo, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. of the former, mukaAvarapN, (Ṣ,) [and aor. of the latter, accord. to analogy, _u,] They contended with them for superiority in number, and overcame them therein, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or surpassed, or exceeded, them in number. (TA.)
See also 10.

Oakovarotu mina AlX-aIoCi and Astkvrtu↓ minohu signify the same; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) i. e., Oakovarotu fiEolahu [I did the thing much; lit., I made the doing of it much]: or Oakovarotu mina AlOakoli wanaHowihi [I ate, and the like, much] presents an instance of pleonasm, [being for Oakovarotu AlOakola wanaHowahu,] accord. to the opinion of the Koofees: or it is an instance of explication [of the vague signification of the verb], accord. to the opinion of the Basrees; the objective complement being suppressed, and the complete phrase being Oakovarotu AlfiEola mina AlOakoli: and so in the like cases. (Mṣb.) [You say also Oakovara fiI AlkalaAmi He spoke, or talked, much; was profuse, or immoderate, in speech, or talk. And in like manner, kavura↓ fiI AlOamori He did, acted, or occupied himself, much in the affair.]
Akvr [as an intrans. v.] signifies OataI bikaviyrK [He brought, or he did, or he said, much]. (Ḳ.)
Also, [He became rich; he abounded in property;] his property became much, or abundant. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Akvr It (a palm-tree) produced, or put forth, its TaloE [or spadix], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., its kavar, whence the verb. (TA.)
[maA Oakovara maAlahu How abundant is his wealth! or how numerous are his cattle!]

entry.sense: 5. tkv-r [He endeavoured to acquire much, or abundance, of a thing]. You say tkv-r mina AlEilomi liyaHofaZa [He endeavoured to acquire much knowledge, in order that he might preserve it in his memory]. And takv-r minohu liyafohama [He endeavoured to acquire much thereof in order that he might understand]. (A.) See also 10.

He made a vain, or false, boast of abundance, or riches; or a boast of more than he possessed; and invested himself with that which did not belong to him. (TA, voce taXab-aEa, which signifies the same.) You say tkv-r bimaA layosa Einodahu He made a boast of abundance, or riches, which he did not possess; syn. taXab-aEa. (Mṣb, art. XbE.) And fulaAnN yatakav-aru bimaAli gayorihi [Such a one makes a vain or false show of abundance or riches with the wealth or property of another]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 6. i. q. 3 [but relating to more than two]. (Ṣ.) [You say takaAtaruwA They contended, one with another, for superiority in number.] Alt-akaAvuru in the Ḳur, ci. 1, signifies The contending together for superiority in [the amount or number of] property and children and men. (Jel.)
takaAvarato OamowaAluhu [His riches multiplied by degrees]. (A.)
tkAvr Ealayohi Aln-aAsu faqaharuwhu [The people multiplied by degrees against him, and overcame him, or subdued him]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 10. Astkvr mina AlX-aIoCi He desired, or wished for, much of the thing. (Ḳ.) You say Astkvr mina AlmaAli [He desired, or wished for, much of the property]. (A.)
Astkvrhu AlmaMCi, and kAvrhu↓ AlmaMCa, He desired of him for himself much of the water that he might drink of it: (Ḳ:) and so if the water were little. (TA.)
Astkvr mina AlX-IuCi also signifies i. q. Oakovara minohu, q. v. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
Also Astkvrhu He reckoned it much, abundant, or many. (Mṣb.) You say huwa yasotakoviru Alfaliyla [He reckons little, or few, much, abundant, or many]. (A.)
Q. Q. 2. takawovara It (dust) was, or became, much, or abundant. (Ṣ.) See kuwovarN.

hom.sense: kavorN: see kaviyrN.
See also kavarN.
kuvorN: see kavorapN.
The greater, or greatest, or main, part, of a thing; the most thereof. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: kivorN: see kavorapN.

kavarN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kavorN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) The heart, or pith, (syn. jum-aArN, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and XaHomN, and jacabN, TA,) of a palm-tree: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) of the dial. of the Ansár: (TA:) or its spadix; syn. TaloEN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

kavorapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and kivorapN↓, (Ḳ,) or the latter should not be used, for it is a bad dial. form, (Ṣ,) or it is correct when coupled with qil-apN, for the sake of assimilation, (TA,) and kuvorapN↓, though the first is the best known, (Ibn-'Allán, in his Sharh el-Iktiráh,) or the last is not allowable, (TA,) and kuvorN↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and kivorN↓, (Ṣ,) Muchness; much, as a subst.; copiousness; abundance; a large quantity; numerousness; multiplicity; multitudinousness; a multitude; a plurality; a large number; numbers; and frequency: contr. of qil-apN. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) [See also kavura.] You say maA lahu qul-N walaA kuvorN↓ He has not little nor much of property. (Ṣ.) And AlHamodu lil-ehi EalaI Alqul-N waAlkuvori↓, (Ṣ, A,) and EalaI Alqil-i waAlkivori↓, (Ṣ,) Praise be to God for little and much. (Ṣ,* A.) [kuvorN↓ is explained in the Ṣ by kaviyrN, and so in one place in the TA; but it is a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates.]
kavorapN is also used to signify Richness, or wealthiness; syn. saEapN. (Mgh.)
kuvorapN: see kavorapu.
kivorapN: see kavorapu.

hom.sense: kuvaArN: see kaviyrN.
Also, and kivaArN↓, Companies, or troops, or the like, (Ḳ, TA,) of men or animals only. (TA.) You say fiI Ald-aAri kuvaArN mina Aln-aAsi, and kivaArN, In the house are companies of men. (TA.)

entry.sense: kivaArN: see kuvaArN.

kaviyrN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kuvaArN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kaAvirN↓ and kavorN↓ and kayovarN↓ and kuwovarN↓ (Ḳ) Much; copious; abundant; many; numerous; multitudinous. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
You say xayorN kaviyrN, and kayovarN↓, Much, or abundant, good. (A.) And qawomN kaviyrN A numerous party, or people: and humo kaviyruwna They are many. (Ṣ.) And rijaAlN kaviyrN, and kaviyrapN, Many men: and nisaMCN kaviyrN, and kaviyrapN, Many women. (Yoo, ISh, Mṣb.) And EadadN kaAvirN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and, as some say, kawovarN↓, (Mṣb,) and kaviyrN, (Ḳ in art. bwl, &c.) A large number. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) And gubaArN kuwovarN↓ Much dust: (Ṣ:) or much confused dust (Ḳ, TA) rising and diffusing itself: of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)
[A large quantity, or number, mino maAlK wagayorihi of property, or cattle, &c.]
kaviyrFA, as an adv., Much; often. (The lexicons passim.)
rajulN kvyrN [in the TA kvr: probably the right reading is kayovarN↓, q. v.:] A man whose ancestors are many, and whose high deeds are various. (L.)
See also muT-aridN.
kaviyrapN, with p, [as a subst., signifying Much,] is used only in negative phrases; like [its contr.] qaliylapN, q. v. (AZ, in TA, art. ql.)
kaAvirN: see kaviyrN, in two places.

hom.sense: kuwovarN: see kaviyrN, in three places.
A lord, or master, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) abounding in good: (Ṣ:) a man possessing good, or much good, and who gives much or often; as also kayovarN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
A river. (Kr, Ḳ.)

And Alkawovaru A certain river in paradise, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from which flow all the [other] rivers thereof, (Ḳ,) pertaining specially to the Prophet, described as being whiter than milk and sweeter than honey and as having its margin composed of pavilions of hollowed pearls. (TA.)

entry.sense: kayovarN: see kaviyrN, in two places: and kuwovarN.
Oakovaru More, and most, in quantity, and in number. (The lexicons passim.)
[OakovaziI-N Having relation to the greater number of things or cases.]
mukovirN A man possessing wealth: (Ḳ:) or possessing much wealth. (A, TA.)
makovarapN A cause of rendering abundant, or multiplying; syn. mavoraApN, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ in art. vrw.)
mikovaArN (A, Ḳ, TA) and mikoviyrN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) applied to a man, and to a woman, (A, TA,) Loquacious; talkative; a great talker; (Ḳ, TA;) a great babbler. (A.)
makovuwrN Overcome in number: (Ṣ,* A:) one against whom people have multiplied by degrees (vakaAvaruwA Ealayohi) so that they have overcome or subdued him. (TA.)
makovuwrN Ealayohi [A place thronged].
fulaAnN makovuwrN Ealayohi Such a one has spent what he had, and claims upon him have become numerous: (Ṣ:) or such a one has many seekers of his beneficence. (A.) See also maXofuwfN.
mikoviyrN: see mikovaArN.
kavoEabN (as also kaEovabN, TA,) A woman having a large pubes, (Ḳ,) or pudendum. (TA.)
rakabN kavoEabN (as also kaEovabN, TA,) A large, (and full, and prominent, TA,) pubes, (Ḳ,) or pudendum. (TA.)
kavonabN, as also kanovabN, Hard, and strong, or robust: (Ḳ:) but most of the writers on inflexion consider its n augmentative. (TA.)

kuH-N Anything pure, mere, unadulterated, or genuine; (L;) i. q. quH-N, (L, Ḳ,) of which it is a dial. form: (Ṣ:) [but see what follows, and quH-N]. EarabiI-N kuH-N A pure, or genuine, Arab: fem. Earabiy-apN kuH-apN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OakoHaAHN: you say OaEoraAbN AkHAHN: (L:) [or this is not said: see quH-N:] Yaakoob asserts, that the k in kuH-N is substituted for the q in quH-N: (L:) [and if so, the former is not a dial. form of the latter]. EabodN kuH-N A mere, or genuine, slave; of purely servile race. (L.)

kuHokuHN and kiHokiHN A decrepit old woman: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a she-camel far advanced in age: (Ḳ:) or old and weak: (Ṣ:) or far advanced in age, and having lost her teeth: (T:) a she-camel, and cow, and ewe, or she-goat, old and weak, and unable to retain her slaver: or whose teeth are consumed. (L.)
OakaH-u Toothless. (L.)
kuHuHN Decrepit old women. (Ḳ.)
1. kaHabahu, aor. _a {yakoHabu}, He struck him on his podex. (Ḳ.)

2. kH-b Alkaromu, inf. n. takoHiybN, The vine put forth its unripe, or sour, grapes: (Ḳ:) or its bunches thereof: this is a correct explanation, given on the authority of IAạr: (Az:) or it became abundant in grapes: (Ḳ:) or its grapes became pleasant in flavour. (TA.)

hom.sense: kaHobN The podex: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)
As coll. gen. n. Unripe, or sour, grapes: n. un. with p {kaHobapN}: (Ḳ:) as also kaHomN: a word of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

entry.sense: kaAHibapN, Many, or much. (Ḳ.) daraAhimo kaAHibapN Many dirhems; or much money. (Fr.)
naArN kaAHibapN Fire of which the flame rises high. (Ḳ.)
OakoHatu Short, (Ḳ,) as an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)

1. kaHava lahu mina AlamAli, aor. _a {yakoHavu}, (inf. n. kaHovN and kaHovapN, TA,) He laded out for him with his hands, (or with his hand, as in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the L,) [somewhat] of the property. (L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. kud-a, aor. _u {yakodudu}, (L,) inf. n. kad-N, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He toiled; or was, or became, vehement, or severe, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) in work; (Ṣ, A, L;) he worked laboriously; (TA;) he fatigued himself, and hastened, in his work. (L.) [You say] bijad-ika laA bikad-ika By thy good fortune, not by thy toil, are things attained. A proverb. (L.) And laA tajoEalo EayoXahumaA kad-F Make not the life of them two a toil. (L, from a trad.)
AlmasaAYilu kad-N yakad-u bihaA Alr-ajulu wajohahu Petitions are [a cause of] dispiriting: a man thereby impairs the brightness of his countenance. (L, from a trad.)

kad-ahu, (L, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yakodudu}, inf. n. kad-N, (L,) He required of him toil, or vehemence, or severity in work, or persevering or constant exertion in striving to do a thing or in seeking a thing; as also Aktd-hu↓, and Astkd-hu↓: (L, Ḳ:) he fatigued or wearied or jaded him; (Ṣ,* L;) namely, a beast, and a man, &c.: (L;) [like dak-ahu;] he plied, or pressed him, plied or pressed him hard, or harassed him, in constant work which he imposed upon him, so as to fatigue or weary him. (Az, L.) See also kad-N.
kad-a ‡ He fatigued his tongue with speaking and his heart with thinking. (A, L.)

kad-a, aor. _u {yakodudu}, (L,) inf. n. kad-N, (L, Ḳ,) He exerted himself perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly, (L, Ḳ,) in striving to do, effect, or accomplish, a thing, (L,) or in seeking [a thing]. (Ḳ.)
kad-a, aor. _u {yakodudu}, (L,) inf. n. kad-N, (Ṣ, L,) He sought (Ṣ, L) gain, (Ṣ,) or, sustenance, or the means of subsistence. (L.)

kad-a, aor. _u {yakodudu}, (L,) inf. n. kad-N, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He pointed, or made a sign, with the finger, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) like as the beggar does. (Ṣ.) [It is also trans.] El-Kumeyt says,
ganiytu falamo Oarodudokumu Einoda bigoyapK
waHujotu falamo Oakodudokumu biAlOaSaAbiEi
[I was rich, and I did not repel you on an occasion of exigency; and I was in want, and I did not point at you with the fingers]. (Ṣ, L.)
kud-uwniI faUin-iI mukid-N↓ ‡ Ask ye of me; for I give [only] when asked. Said by Ibn-Hubeyreh. (A [but in my copy of that work, the first word is written kid-uwniI.])
kad-a, [aor. _u {yakodudu}.] ‡ He scratched, or scraped: (L:) he scraped off a soil from a garment: (TA:) he scratched perseveringly his head, and his skin, with his nails. (A.)
kad-a, (TA,) [aor. _u {yakodudu},] inf. n. kad-N, (Ḳ,) † He combed his head. (Ḳ, TA.)
kad-a, [aor. _u {yakodudu},] ‡ He (a beast) trod the ground with his hoofs. (A,* L.)

entry.sense: 2. kd-d He (a man) threw coarsely pounded salt (kadiyd), one portion upon another. (L.)
4. Akd- and Aktd-↓ ‡ He was tenacious, or niggardly. (L, Ḳ.) See also mukid-N.
8: see 1, and 4.
R. Q. 1. kadokada, inf. n. kadokadapN, He ran slowly: (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, L:) he affected a heaviness and slowness in his gait. (Ḳ.)
kadokada EalaI Alkadiydi † He ran upon the dust of the race-course. (L.)
kad-N [inf. n. of 1, q. v.]
[as a subst.] A mortar in which things are pounded, or bruised; like haAwanN, or haAwuwnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kid-apN and kud-apN see kadiydN.
kaduwdN A man who toils, or works, laboriously, so as to fatigue himself. (A.)

‡ A she-camel whose milk is not obtained without labour, or exertion. (A.) biYorN kaduwdN ‡ A well of which the water is not obtained without labour, or exertion, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) and difficulty, or trouble. (TA.)
‡ Tenacious; niggardly: (Ḳ, but omitted in some copies:) one from whom benefits are not obtained without difficulty. (A.)

hom.sense: OaroDN kadiydN ‡ Ground trodden with the hoofs of horses or the like. (Ṣ,* A,* L.)
kadiydN ‡ Fine dust, trodden with the feet: fine dust, which, if trodden, flies about: (L:) dust of a racecourse. (TA.)
Coarsely pounded salt. (L, Ḳ.) [Also,] The sound of coarsely pounded salt when it is poured out, (L, Ḳ,) one portion upon another. (L.)
A low, or depressed, tract of land, (baTonN, Ḳ, or bTyn, L, as from AʼObeyd,) of wide extent, (L, Ḳ,) formed like a valley, or wider than a valley. (AʼObeyd, L.)
A rugged tract of land; (L, Ḳ;) as also kid-apN↓, with kesr, (Ḳ,) or kud-apN↓; (L;) so called because it fatigues him who walks upon it. (L.)

entry.sense: kudaAdapN The cooked food which remains in the bottom of the cooking-pot, and which is drawn out (kud-a) with the fingers: (Az, L:) what remains in the bottom of the cooking-pot, (Aṣ, L, Ḳ,) sticking to it, after the ladling out; (L;) as also kadadapN (L, Ḳ) and kudadapN: (Ḳ:) or the broth, or gravy, remaining in the bottom of the cooking-pot. (Ṣ.)
Also I. q. qiXodapN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) [i. e.] the dregs, or sediment, of clarified butter. (L.)
A little that remains of pasture, or herbage. (L.) See also Oakid-apN.
kadokadapN a word imitative of the sound made by a thing that is struck upon a hard thing. (Ṣ, L.)
Akid-apN The remains in a place of pasture which has already been eaten. (Ḳ.) See also kudaAdapN and OakodaAdN.
qawomN OakodaAdN A quick, or swift, people: (Aṣ, Ṣ, L:) or a people composing distinct bodies, or parties, or troops; (L, art. ktd; and Ḳ;) as also Oakid-apN↓ and OakaAdiydu. (Ḳ.) See also OakotaAdN.
makoduwdN pass. part. n. of kad-a, q. v.
A man overcome. (L.)
mukid-N ‡ One who gives [only] when asked. (A.) See also kaduwdN, and 1, and 4.
mikad-N † A comb. (Ḳ.)
‡ An instrument for scratching or scraping. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. kadaOa and kadiYa, aor. _a {yakodaOu}, inf. n. kadoCN and kuduwoCN, It (a plant) was affected by the cold, and thereby made to stick to the earth: or its growth became slow by reason of want of water. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kadaOa, aor. _a {yakodaOu}; (Ḳ;) and kd-O↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. takodiYapN; (Ṣ;) the former the more common; (TA;) It (cold) cast down the standing corn, &c. upon the earth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kadaOa ‡ It (herbage) was short and bad, (Ḳ,) on account of the badness of the soil. (TA.)
kadiYati AlUibilu, aor. _a {yakodaOu}, inf. n. kadoCN, The camels had little hair. (TA.)
kadiYa, (Ḳ,) or kadaOa, (L.) the former said to be of an uncommon dial., (MF,) aor. _a {yakodaOu}, It (a crow or raven) croaked roughly, as though it were vomiting. (L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
Q. Q. 1. kawodaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kawodaOapN, (TA,) He ran in the manner called Eadow: (Ḳ:) i. e., he hastened in his pace. (TA.) [See daOodaOa.]
OaroDN kaAdiYapN A land that produces plants slowly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
UibilN kaAdiYapu AlOawobaAra Camels having little hair: pl. kawaAdiYu. (TA.)
kinodaOowN dial. form of kinotaOowN. (Ḳ.)

A gross, or bulky, camel. (Ḳ.) [But perhaps jml is here put by a mistake of a copyist in the Ḳ for Hbl, and the meaning is a thick rope; for kntOw is said to signify thick, as an epithet applied to a rope: or the reverse may be the case in the explanation of the latter word.] It occurs again in art. knd. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: kadobN / kadobapN / kadibN / kadibapN / kadabN / kadabapN / kudobN / kudobapN

entry.sense: kadobN and kadibN and kadabN and kudobN [but the second seems to have been written, in MF's copy of the Ḳ, kidobN], coll. gen. ns., also with c for d, The whiteness [or white marks] on the nails of young persons: n. un. (of each of the above words, TA,) with p {kadobapN, kadibapN, kadabapN and kudobapN}: as also kudayobaACu: (Ḳ:) but this last, says SM, I have not found in any other lexicon. (TA.)

jaAWuwA EalaI qamiySihi bidamK kadibK, [Ḳur, xii. 18,] so accord. to the reading of Ibn-ʼAbbás, (Ḳ,) and ʼÁïsheh, and El-Ḥasan El-Basree, (TA,) They brought, upon his shirt, blood inclining in colour to white; as though it were blood that had made marks upon the shirt resembling embroidery or the like: (Ḳ:) or fresh blood: or, contr. dry blood: or blood of a dingy hue: or blood changed [in colour]. (TA.)
makoduwbapN A woman of a pure white complexion. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. kadaHa, aor. _a {yakodaHu}, (inf. n. kadoHN, Ṣ,) He worked or wrought; laboured; employed himself actively; syn. saEaI; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Eamila: (Ṣ:) he wrought for himself good or evil: (Ḳ:) he was eager, and strove, laboured, or exerted himself, and wearied himself, in work, in the affairs relating to the present world and in those relating to the world to come: (Zj:) he toiled, or laboured hard. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) huwa yakodaHu fiI kacaA He toils, or labours hard, in such a thing, or affair. (Ṣ.)
kadaHa liEiyaAlihi, and AktdH↓, He sought, sought after, or sought to gain, sustenance; or he gained, acquired, or earned; for his family, or household; syn. kasaba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Aktsb. (L.)

kadaHa wajohahu It (a thing, Ṣ) scratched, or lacerated, his face: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or did to his face that which disfigured it, or rendered it ugly or unseemly: as also kd-Hhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. takodiyHN: (TA:) or kd-H, inf. n. tkdyH, signifies it scratched, or lacerated, much, or many times, or in many places: (Ṣ:) also [so in the L; but in the Ḳ, or] kadaHa in the phrase kadaHa wajohahu signifies Oafosada; (Ḳ;) you say kadaHa wajoha Oamorihi, meaning he marred his affair. (L.)
kadaHa raOosahu He separated his hair with a comb. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
5. tkd-H It (the skin) became scratched, or lacerated, much, or many times, or in many places. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
waqaEa mina Als-aToHi fatakad-aHa He fell from the flat top, or roof, of the house, and became much broken [in his skin]. (L.)

kadoHN A scratch, or laceration, of the skin; i. q. xadoXN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a kadoH is more (or larger, L) than a xadoX: (Ṣ:) any mark made by scratching or biting: (IAth:) pl. kuduwHN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. bihi kadoHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and kuduwHN, (Ṣ,) He has upon him a scratch, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Uin-aka kaAdiHN UilaI rab-ika, [Ḳur lxxxiv. 6,] Verily thou workest, or labourest, (Ṣ,) or, workest for thyself good or evil, (TA,) or, strivest, or labourest, in thy work until the meeting of thy Lord, i. e., until death. (Jel.)
HimaArN mukad-aHN An ass much lacerated by the bites of other asses. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) A wild ass is termed mkd-H because he is lacerated by the bites of other asses. (AʼObeyd.)

hom.sense: 1. kadira, aor. _a {yakodaru}; and kadura, aor. _u {yakoduru}; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) and kadara; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) but this last is said in the L to be allowable only as signifying “he poured out” water; (TA;) inf. n. kadarN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the first, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or second, (TA,) and kuduwrapN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the second, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and kadaArapN, (Ḳ,) also of the second, (TA,) and kuduwrN, and kudorapN, (Ḳ,) or the last is a simple subst.; (TA;) and tkd-r↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Akdr-↓, inf. n. UikodiraArN; (Ḳ;) and Ankdr↓; (Bḍ lxxxi. 2;) It (water, Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.) was, or became, turbid, thick, or muddy; contr. of SafaA; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) it ceased to be clear: (Mṣb:) or kudorapN relates to colour, (Ḳ,) specially; (TA;) and kuduwrapN, to water, (Ḳ,) and to life, AlEayoX; in the Ḳ, AlEayon, but this is a mistake; (TA;) and kadarN, to all of these. (Ḳ.)

kadira, aor. _a {yakodaru}, (Lḥ, Mṣb,) inf. n. kadarN (Ṣ, Mṣb) [and kudorapN, (see above,)] It (the complexion of a man, Lḥ) and he (a horse, &c., Mṣb) was, or became, of the colour termed kudorapN [i. e. dusky, dingy, or inclining to black and dust-colour]. (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb.)

kadira EayoXu fulaAnK, (Ṣ, A,) [inf. n. kadarN and kuduwrapN; (see above;)] and tkd-r↓, (A,) ‡ [The life of such a one became troublesome, or perturbed, or attended with trouble:] and tkd-rt↓ maEiyXatuhu [signifies the same; or his means of living became attended with trouble]. (Ṣ.)
xuco maA SafaA wadaEo maA kadira, and kadura, and kadara, ‡ [Take thou what is free from trouble, and leave what is attended with trouble.] (IAạr, L, Mṣb.)
kadira EalaI-a fuWaAduhu ‡ [His heart, or mind, became perturbed by displeasure against me]. (A, TA.)
[And in like manner you say] tkd-r↓ macohabuhu fI QlomasoOalapi [‡ His opinion respecting the question became confounded, or perplexed]. (Mgh.)
kadara, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yakoduru}, inf. n. kadorN, (TA,) He poured out, or forth water. (Ḳ, TA.) Said in the L to be the only signification of this form of the verb. (TA.) [But see above.]

entry.sense: 2. kd-rhu, inf. n. takodyrN, He rendered it (namely water, Ṣ, Mṣb) turbid, thick, or muddy. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[kd-r EayoXa fulaAnK ‡ He or it, troubled the life of such a one; rendered it troublesome, or perturbed; caused it to be attended with trouble.]
[kd-r EalaI-a fuWaAda fulaAnK ‡ He, or it, caused the heart, or mind, of such a one to be perturbed by displeasure against me.]
kd-rt AlmasoOalapu Ealayohi macohabahu [‡ The question confounded, or perplexed, his opinion]. (TA.)
SafaA OamoriI fakad-arahu fulaAnN ‡ [My affair, or case, was free from trouble, and such a one caused it to be attended with trouble]. (A.)
kd-r niEomapF [‡ He sullied a favour]. (El-Aạshà, quoted in the Ṣ, art. nXd.)
5: see 1, in four places.
6. tkAdrt AlEayonu fI AlX-aIoCi ‡ The eye continued looking at the thing. (Ṣ, A.)

hom.sense: 7: see 1.

He, or it, darted down. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said of a bird, (A,) or of a hawk, in this sense; (TḲ;) and of a star. (A.) So in the Ḳur lxxxi. 2, waUicaA Aln-ujuwmu Qnokadarato: (Ṣ,* Bḍ:) or this means, And when the stars dart down, and fall, one after another, upon the earth: (Jel:) or when the stars fall and become scattered. (El-Basáïr, Ḳ.*)

Ankdr Elyhm AlEaduw-u ‡ The enemy poured down upon them. (A.) And Ankdr Ealayohi Alqawomu ‡ The people poured upon him: (Ḳ:) or poured down upon him: (TA:) or repaired towards him, scattering themselves upon him. (El-Basáïr.)

Ankdr ‡ He hastened: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he hastened in some measure. (TA.) You say Ankdr fiI sayorihi ‡ He hastened in his pace. (A.) And Ankdr yaEoduw ‡ He hastened in some measure, running; (TA;) accord. to AʼObeyd. (TA, voce AinoSalata.)

entry.sense: 9: see 1.
kadorN: see kadirN.
kadarN [a coll. gen. n., of which the n. of unity is kadarapN] Handfuls of reaped corn: (O, TA:) see EaSofN.

hom.sense: kadirN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kadorN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kadiyrN↓ and Oakodaru↓ (Ḳ) Turbid; thick; muddy: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) applied to water. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)
EayoXN kadirN, and Oakodaru↓ ‡ [Life that is attended with trouble]. (TA.)
huwa kadiru AlfuWaAdi EalaI-a ‡ [He is perturbed in heart, or mind, by displeasure against me]. (A.)

entry.sense: kudorapN Duskiness, or dinginess, of colour; (Ṣ,* Mṣb;) a hue inclining to black and dust-colour. (TA.) See 1.
kadarapN: see kadarN.

kudoriI-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kudaAriI-N↓ (IAạr, TA) A species of the kind of bird called qaTFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) one of three species, whereof the two others are called juwniI-N and gaTaATN; (Ṣ;) the species called kdrI are of a dusty [or dusky] colour, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) short in the legs, (TA,) diversified, or speckled, or marked, with duskiness, or dinginess, and blackness, (ruqoX,) in the backs (Ṣ, Ḳ) and bellies, (Ṣ,) black in the inside of the wing, (TA,) yellow in the throats, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) having in the tail two feathers [in the L and TA ryXAn, but the right reading is riyXataAni,] longer than the rest of the tail; (ISk, TA;) it is smaller than the jwnI, (Ṣ,) and has a clear cry, calling out its own name [qaTaA qaTaA]: (ISd, TA:) it seems to be thus named, kdrI, in relation to the greater number of birds of the kind called qaTFA, which are kudor [in colour]; (Ṣ;) kdrI being, as some assert, a rel. n. from TayorN kudorN, like dubosiI-N from TayorN dubosN: (TA:) the n. un. is kudoriy-apN and kudaAriy-apN. (TA.) [See also gaTaATN, and qaTFA; and De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., ii. 369.]
kadiyrN: see kadirN.
kudaAriI-N: see kudoriI-N.

kudaAyoraMCu, [dim. of kadoraMCu, fem. of OakodarN,] A certain kind of food, accord. to Kr, who does not describe its composition; (TA;) fresh milk in which dates (Ṣ, Ḳ) of the kind called barobiI- (Ḳ) are macerated: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or milk in which dates are steeped and mashed with the hand: (TA:) women are fattened with it: (Ḳ:) so called because of the duskiness (kudorap) of its colour. (Z, TA.)
kunodurN: see art. kndr.
Oakodaru [Dusky, or dingy; of a hue inclining to black and dust-colour;] having kudorap in its colour: (Ṣ, TA:) fem. kadoraMCu: pl. kudorN: and dim. of Akdr, Oukayodiru. (Mṣb.)
banaAtu Oakodara The wild asses: (Ṣ:) the same, (A,) or banaAtu AlOakodari, (Ḳ,) certain wild asses: (A, Ḳ:) so called after a particular stallion (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) or theirs. (Ḳ.)
See also kadirN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. kadasahu, (A, Mṣb, TA,) aor. _i {yakodisu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. kadosN, (Mṣb, TA,) He collected it together; (A, TA;) made it into a kudos, accumulated, heaped, or piled up, one part upon another; (Mṣb;) namely, wheat, (A,) or reaped grain; (Mṣb, TA;) [and in like manner, ‡ money, and clothes, &c.: and so kd-s↓, inf. n. takodiysN; but this has an intensive signification, or applies to many objects: see mukad-asN, below.]

kadasati Alxayolu, (A, Mṣb,) [aor. _i {yakodisu},] inf. n. kadosN, (Mṣb,) ‡ The horses followed closely one upon another: (Mṣb:) or collected themselves together, and followed closely one upon another; as also tkd-st↓: (A:) or kadosN signifies the going quickly of one who is heavily laden: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and kadasati Alxayolu the horses went quickly, being heavily laden: (Ṣ:) and kadasati AlUibilu the camels went quickly, with heaviness, and followed closely one upon another: (TA:) or [simply] went quickly: (Fr:) takad-usN↓ also signifies the walking, or going, quickly: (IAạr, Ḳ:) and tkd-s↓ Alfarasu the horse went as though he were heavily laden: (Ṣ:) or takad-usN↓ signifies the walking, or going, like him who is short and thick: (TA:) and the moving about the shoulder-joints, and erecting the part between the paps, (but instead of wayanoSiba maA bayona vadoyayohi, we find in some copies wayanoSab-u UilaI maA bayona yadayohi [and descending towards the place before him], TA,) when walking, or going along, (Ḳ, TA,) as though one were going away at random; and thus the mountain-goats go: so accord. to IAạr: (TA:) and tkd-s↓ AlUinosaAnu the man was pushed from behind, and fell down. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first part.

hom.sense: 5. tkd-s It (wheat, A, or reaped grain, TA, [&c.,]) became collected together. (A, TA.)
See also 1, in five places.

entry.sense: kudosN Reaped grain collected together; [a heap thereof;] (A, Ḳ;) as also kud-aAsN↓, like rum-aAnN: (Ibn-ʼAbbád and A, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or what is collected together, of wheat, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,) in the place where it is trodden out: (Mṣb:) when trodden out and thrashed, it is called EaramapN and SuborapN: or, as Az says, in one place in the T, on the authority of IAạr, kudosN and bayodarN and EaramapN and XagolapN are all one: and in another place he says, that kudosN signifies a collection of wheat: and in like manner, † what is collected [or heaped] together, of money, and of other things: (Mṣb:) or † of dates, (TA,) and ‡ of money, (A, TA,) and the like, (TA,) and ‡ of clothes: (A, TA:) also, † a large heap of sand, of which one part does not separate from another: (En-Naḍr:) and kudaAsN↓, like guraAbN, what is collected together, or heaped up, of snow: and kudaAsapN↓, what is collected together, and heaped up, one part upon another: (Ḳ:) the pl. of kudosN is OakodaAsN. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)
kudaAsN and kudaAsapN: see kudosN
kud-aAsN: see kudosN

kudosN mukad-asN [What is collected together, of wheat,, &c., heaped up much]. (Mṣb.) You say also Einodahu mino daraAhima waviyaAbK kudosN mukad-asN ‡ [He has, of money, and of clothes, a collection heaped up much]: and OakodaAsN mukad-asapN ‡ [collections heaped up]. (A, TA.)

1. kadaXa liEiyaAlihi, aor. _i {yakodiXu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. kadoXN, (TḲ,) He sought, sought after, or sought to gain, sustenance; or he gained, acquired, or earned; syn. kadaHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and kasaba; (Ḳ;) and collected; and exercised art, cunning, or skill; (TA;) for his family, or household. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

You say also, kadaXotu mino fulaAnK XayoYFA, ('Okbeh Es-Sulamee, TA,) or EaTaMCF, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) I obtained from such a one ('Okbeh, Ṣ, Ḳ) a thing, ('Okbeh,) or a gift; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OakodaXotu↓, (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or UikotadaXotu↓. ('Okbeh, as related by Aboo-Turáb; and so in two copies of the Ṣ.) And maA kadaXa minohu XayoYFA He did not obtain, and did not take, of him anything. (TA.)
4: see 1.
8: see 1.
kudaAXapN [app. Gain, or earnings;] a subst. [from kdX as first explained above, or] from kad-aAXN in the first of the senses explained below. (TA.)
kad-aAXN A man who makes much gain. (TA.)
Also, i. q., mukad-K; (Ḳ;) in the dial. of the people of El-'Irák; meaning An importunate beggar. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: kdm / kdn / kdh / kdI
dictScrap.label:
[kdm, kdn, kdh and kdI
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: 1. kac-a, [aor. _i {yakocicu},] (Ḳ,) inf. n. kac-N, (TA,) It (a thing, TA) was, or became, rough, (Ḳ,) and hard. (TA.)
4. Akc-wA They, (a people, Mṣb,) became among stones such as are termed kac-aAn. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

kac-aAnN Soft stones, (AA, Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also jac-aAnN, (Aṣ, L in art. jc,) like dry pieces of clay, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and foraminous, or pierced with holes, (M, L,) or sometimes pierced with holes: n. un. with p {kac-aAnapN}. (L, Mṣb.) Some say, that the n is a radical letter; (L, Mṣb;) but the form of the verb Oakac-a is against their assertion; for if the n were so, it would appear in the verb. (Mṣb.)
kacokacapN Intense redness. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense:
1. kacaba, aor. _i {yakocibu}, inf. n. kacibN (a strange form of inf. n.; there being, accord. to Ḳz., only fourteen instances of it; as laEibN, and DaHikN, &c.; though there are many substantives of this measure; MF) and kicobN (Ṣ, Ḳ: accord. to Ibn-Es-Seed and others, this latter is formed from the former, by putting the second vowel of the former in the place of the first: MF) and kacibapN (L) or kacobapN (Ḳ) and kicobahN (L, Ḳ) and kicaAbN and kic-aAbN (Ḳ: but this last, which is also assigned to kacaba in the L, is, accord. to the Ṣ, which refers, for proof, to the Ḳur, ch. lxxviii. 28, one of the inf. ns. of kc-b: and Ks says, that the people of El-Yemen make the inf. n. of fE-l of the measure fiE-aAlN, while the other Arabs make it tafoEiylN: TA) and, accord. to some, kucobN and kacobN (TA: but the latter of these two, though agreeable with analogy, is unheard: TA): see also kacibN, below: [He lied; uttered a falsehood; said what was untrue:] he gave an untrue account, or relation, of a thing, whether intentionally or unintentionally. (Mṣb) Alkacibu is of five kinds.
- First, The relater's changing, or altering, what he hears; and his relating; as from others, what he does not know. This is the kind that renders one criminal, and destroys manly virtue. - Second, The saying what resembles a lie, not meaning anything but the truth. Such is meant in the trad., kacaba Uiborehiymu valaAva kacibaAtK Abraham said three sayings resembling lies; he being veracious in the three. - Third, The saying what is untrue by mistake, or unintentionally; making a mistake; erring. This signification is frequent. - Fourth, The finding one's hopes false, or vain. - Fifth, The act of instigating, or inciting. (IAmb.) [See illustrations of these and other significations below; and see more voce Sadaqa.] [You say] yakocibuka mino Oayona jaACa [He will lie to thee even as to the place whence he comes.] (L, art. mH, and in many other places, following the similar phrase laA yaSoduquka Oavarahu, or Oavaruhu.) Lebeed says,
Aikocibi Aln-afosa UicaA Had-avotahaA
Lie to the soul (i. e., to thy soul,) when thou talkest to it: i. e., say not to thy soul, Thou wilt not succeed in thine enterprise; for thy doing so will divert thee, or hinder thee, therefrom. A proverb. (Meyd, &c.)
kuciba, pass., He was told a lie; a falsehood; or an untruth. (Ḳ.)

Aboo-Duwád says,
kacaba AlEayoru waUino kaAna baraHo
The wild ass hath lied, although he hath passed from right to left: [the doing which is esteemed unlucky:] or, [agreeably with explanations of kacaba given below,] hath become languid, and within [the sportsman's] power, or reach, &c.: or keep to the wild ass, and hunt him, &c. A proverb, applied in the case of a thing that is hoped for, though difficult of attainment. (TA.)
kacabato and kc-bt↓ ‡ She (a camel), being covered by the stallion, raised her tail, and then returned without conceiving. (En-Naḍr, Ḳ.)

kacaba is said of other things than men [and animals]: as of lightning, [meaning † It gave a false promise of rain]: of a dream, an opinion, a hope, and a desire, [meaning, in each of these cases, † It proved false]. (TA.)
So also kacabati AlEayonu † The sense [i. e., the sight] of the eye deceived it. (TA.)
kacaba Alr-aOoIu [† The judgment lied]; i. e., he imagined the thing contrary to its real state. (TA.) [See also Sadaqa Zan-iI]
kacabatoka Eayonuka ‡ Thine eye showed thee what had no reality. (TA.)
kacaba labanu Aln-aAqapi, and kc-b↓, (the latter mentioned in the Ṣ,) ‡ The milk of the camel passed away, or failed. (Lḥ.)
kacaba fiI sayorihi ‡ [He (a camel) became slack, or slow, in his pace: see 2]. (TA.)
kacaba AlHar-u ‡ The heat abated. (TA.)

See also 2. kacaba He found his hopes to be false, or vain. (IAmb.) AunoZuro kayofa kacabuwA EalaI Oanofusihimo, [Ḳur vi. 24, lit., See how they lied against themselves,] is said to signify see how their hope hath proved false, or vain. (TA.)

Zan-uwA Oan-ahumo qado kucibuwA, [Ḳur xii. 110,] They (the apostles) thought that they had been disappointed of the fulfilment of the promise made to them. So accord. to one reading. Accord. to another reading, the verb is kuc-ibuwA↓: [in which case, the meaning of the words appears to be, “They knew that they had been pronounced liars” by the people to whom they were sent]. (TA.) There are also two other readings; kac-abuwA↓ and kacabuwA: accord. to the former, the verb refers to the people to whom the apostles were sent; and Zn-wA means “they knew:” accord. to the latter, the words mean, “They (the people above mentioned) thought that they (the apostles) had broken their promise.” (Jel.)
maA kacaba AlfuWaAdu maA raOaI [The mind did not belie what he saw.] (Ḳur liii. 11.)

kacabatohu nafosuhu [His soul lied to him:] his soul made him to desire things, and to conceive hopes, that could scarcely come to pass. (Ḳ.) Hence the soul is called Alkacuwbu. You say in the contr. case, Sacaqatohu nfsh, and Alkacuwbu. (TA.) See kacuwbN, and art. Sdq.
Hence, kacaba Ealayohi signifies It rendered him active, or brisk; animated him; instigated him; incited him; (Ḳ;) as also kacabahu. (Z.)

Hence, kacaba and kacabaka and kacaba Ealayoka have sometimes the same signification, though not always the same government, as Ealayoka, or Ailozamo; Keep to; or take to. The noun following is put in the nom. case accord. to the dial. of El-Yemen; and in the acc. accord. to the dial. of Mudar; or, as some say, is correctly put in the nom. only. (TA.) You say, kacaba Ealayoka kacaA wakacaA, meaning Keep to, or take to, such and such things. It is an extr. phrase. (ISk.) You also say, kacabotu Ealayoka, meaning Keep thou to me: and kcbtu Ealayokumo Keep ye to me. IAạr. cites the following verse of Khidásh Ibn-Zuheyr, [in which he tauntingly compares a people to ticks]:
kacabotu Ealayokumo Oawo EiduwniI waEal-iluwA
biIa AlOaroDa waAlOaqowaAma qirodaAna mawoZabaA
[Keep ye to me: threaten me, and soothe by (the mention of) me the land and the peoples, O ticks of Mowdhab!]: meaning Keep ye to me, and to satirizing me, when ye are on a journey, and traverse the land mentioning me. (TA.) In like manner, yawomu AlOaHadi wAlxamiysi kacabaAka Oawo yawomu AlUivonayoni wAlv-alaAvaACi, in a trad. respecting the proper days for being cupped, signifies Keep thou to Sunday and Thursday, or Monday and Tuesday. (IAth, Z.) The verb is thus used after the manner of a proverb, and is invariable [as to tense], being constantly in the pret. tense, connected [literally or virtually, when explained by Ealayoka followed by the prep. b, or by Uilozamo,] only with the person addressed, and in the sense of the imperative. kcbAk here [lit.] signifies Let them render thee active, or brisk, and animate thee, instigate thee, or incite thee. (Z.). [A trad. of ʼOmar, quoted below, presents another instance to which this signification is said to apply.]

Or kacaba denotes instigation, or incitement, of the person addressed, to keep to the thing that is mentioned; as in the saying of the Arabs, kacaba Ealayoka AlEasalu, meaning Eat thou honey: but the explanation of this is, (The relinquisher of) honey hath erred [to thee; i. e., in his representation of its evil qualites, &c.; which is equivalent to saying, Eat, or keep to, honey]: AlEasalu being put for taAriku AlEasali. [See also 1 in art. Esl.] In like manner, the saying of ʼOmar, kacaba Ealayokumu AlHaj-u, &c., (see below,) signifies Keep ye to the performance of the pilgrimage, &c.: [or (the relinquisher of) the pilgrimage hath erred to thee in his representation of it: therefore it means as above]. (IAmb.) Accord. to IAmb the noun signifying the object of instigation [which may also be called the cause thereof] cannot be rightly put in the acc. case: if so put, the verb is without an agent. (TA.) [But see what is said on this point in the remarks on the trad. of ʼOmar below.]

Or the verb in a case of this kind signifies Oamokana: thus, kacabaka AlHaj-u signifies The performance of the pilgrimage is possible, or practicable, to thee: therefore [it means] Perform thou the pilgrimage. (ISh.)
Or Oamokana is its original signification; and the meaning intended is Keep to; as in the ex. kacaba AlEatiyqu. (Aạl.)

Er-Raḍee [reading AlEtyqa] cites this verse as a proof that kacaba, originally a verb, has become a verbal noun, signifying Ailozamo. (TA.) But he is the only one who asserts it to be a verbal noun. (MF.)

Also, Mo'akkir El-Bárikee says,
wacuboyaAniy-apK OuwoSato baniyhaA
biOano kacaba AlqaraATifu waAlquruwfu
And many a woman of Dhubyán charged her sons by [saying], Keep to the red garments (Aksyp), and the bags (or receptacles) of leather tanned with pomegranate-bark. She charged them to take plenty of these two things as spoil from the tribe of Nemir, if they should prevail over them. (Aboo-ʼObeyd El-Kásim Ibn-Selám.)

kcb is also said to have the same meaning in the words of the trad. kacaba Aln-as-aAbuwna [Keep to those skilled in genealogy:] or Regard is to be had to what is said by those skilled in genealogy: another meaning to which is assigned below. (TA.)

It sometimes signifies It is incumbent, or obligatory. So in the following: (a trad. of ʼOmar: TA:) kacaba Ealayokumu AlHaj-u kacaba Ealayokumu AlEumorapu kacaba Ealayokumu AljihaAdu vlaAvapu OasofaArK kacabona Ealayokumo [The performance of the pilgrimage is incumbent on you: the performance of (the rites called) AlEmrp is incumbent on you: warring (for the sake of religion) is incumbent on you: three expeditions are incumbent on you]: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) or kcb, here, is from kacabatohu nafosuhu, “his soul made him to desire things, and to conceive hopes, that could scarcely come to pass;” and the meaning is let [the expectation of the reward which will follow] the performance of the pilgrimage render thee active, or brisk, and animate thee, instigate thee, or incite thee, to the act: [and so of the rest of the trad.: but here I should observe, that, for liyakocibaka and liyunaX-iTaka and yaboEavaka, in the CK, we should read liyakociboka, &c.:] (Ḳ:)
or, as ISk says, kcb, here, seems to denote instigation, or incitement, meaning Ealayokumo bihi keep ye to it; and is an extr. word with respect to analogy: (Ṣ:)

accord. to Akh., AlHj- is governed in the nom. case by kcb; but as to the meaning, it is in the acc.; because the meaning is a command to perform the pilgrimage; as when you say, Oamokanaka AlS-ayodu [“the game hath become within thy power, or reach”], meaning “shoot it,” or “cast at it:” (Ṣ:) he who puts AlHj- in the acc. case, [agreeably with one relation of the trad., TA,] makes Elyk [or Elykm] a verbal noun; and in kcb is [implied] the pronoun which refers to AlHj- [and which is the agent of the verb]; (Ḳ;) or the agent is implied in kcb, and explained by what follows it; (Sb;) [so that] the meaning is kacaba AlHaj-u Ealayokumu AlHaj-a: (Z:) or, [as shown above,] kcb is a verbal n., meaning Alozamo, and AlHj- is in the acc. case as governed by it: (Er-Raḍee:) though its being in the acc. case, accord. to some, is altogether unknown: (TA:)
[or the meaning is as stated before on the authority of ISh.:]

or the trad. means kacaba Ealayoka AlHaj-u Uino cukira Oan-ahu gayoru kaAfK haAdimK limaA qabolahu mina Alc-unuwbi [(the relinguisher of) the pilgrimage hath erred to thee if it have been spoken of (by him) as not sufficient, (and as not) abolishing the sins, or offences, (committed) before it: agreeably with the explanation by IAmb, given above]. (Ḳ.)

kacaba He said what was false unintentionally; committed a mistake, or error. The verb is used in this sense by the people of El-Ḥijáz, and the rest of the Arabs have followed them in so using it. (Towsheeh.)

kacaba is also said to signify He spoke truth; so as to bear two contr. meanings: and thus, kacaba Aln-as-aAbuwna may signify Those skilled in genealogy have spoken truth: but another explanation of this saying is given in this art. (MF, &c.)
kacabato Eaf-aAqatuka [and the like] Thou brokest wind. (Ṣ in art. Efq.)

2. kc-bh, inf. n. takociybN, (and kic-aAbN, TA, and takocibapN [like tajoribapN, &c.], occurring in the TA, voce lahabapN, &c.) He made, or pronounced, him a liar; an utterer of falsehood; or a sayer of what was untrue: (Ḳ:) he attributed, or ascribed, to him lying, untruth, mendacity, or the speaking untruth: (Mṣb:) and (Mṣb) [accused him of lying:] he gave him the lie; said to him, “Thou hast lied,” &c. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) See also 4.

kc-b biAlOamori, inf. n. takociybN and kic-aAbN (Ḳ: the latter inf. n. of the dial. of El-Yemen: Ks, Fr) and kicaAbN, (TA,) He rejected, disallowed, denied, disacknowledged, disbelieved in, or discredited, the thing; syn. Oanokarahu; (Ḳ;) as also kc-bhu, and kacabahu↓. (Jel, liii. 11.) Ex. wakac-abuwA biMyaAtinaA kic-aAbFA [And they rejected our signs, with rejection: Ḳur, lxxviii. 28]. (Ṣ.) And kac-aba AlfuWaAdu maA raOaI, and kacaba↓: see art. fOd, and see 1.
kc-b Eanohu † He repelled from him, [or defended him]; syn. rad-a Eanohu; namely, a man. (Ḳ.) [See exs. voce Ew-I, in art. Ew.]

Hamala famaA kac-b, inf. n. takociybN, ‡ He charged, and was not cowardly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and did not retreat. (TA.) Hamala vum-a kc-b He charge, and then was cowardly, or did not charge with earnestness, or sincerity: (Ṣ:)

or falsified the opinion formed of him: or made a false charge. (A.) kc-b Eana qironihi He charged, and then retreated from his adversary. (Sh.) kc-b AlqitaAla He was cowardly in fight. Alt-akociybu in fighting is the contr. of AlS-idoqu. (TA.)
kc-b Als-ayora [He slackened his pace, or became slow, after giving promise of being quick;] he did not proceed in his journey with energy. (TA.)

maA kac-aba Oano faEala kacaA (so in the TA, and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ: in the CK, and in two copies of the Ṣ, maA kacaba:) ‡ He did not delay to do so: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he was not cowardly and weak, and did not delay to do so. (TA.)
kc-b Eano OamorK qado OaraAdahu ‡ He abstained, or desisted, or drew back by reason of fear, from a thing that he had desired to do. (Ḳ.)
kc-b (and kacaba↓, TA,) † He (a wild beast) took a run, and then stopped to see what was behind him, (Ḳ,) whether he were pursued or not. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. kaAcabotuhu, inf. n. mukaAcabapN and kicaAbN, I lied, &c., to him, and he to me. (Ḳ,* TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Akcbhu He found him a liar; an utterer of falsehood; or a sayer of what was untrue: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he said to him, “Thou hast lied”: &c.: (TA:) or this verb bears the former of these two significations, and kc-bh↓ signifies the latter: (Ṣ:) or Akcbh signifies he shewed him that he had told a lie, &c.: (Zj:) or Akcbh signifies he announced that he had told, or related, a lie, &c.: and kc-bh↓, he announced his being a liar, &c.: (Ks, Ṣ:) or Akcbh and kc-bh↓ are syn.: but the former sometimes signifies he incited, urged, or induced, him to lie, &c. (a signification assigned to it in the Ḳ): and sometimes, he made manifest, or proved, his lying, &c. (a signification also assigned to it in the Ḳ): and he found him a liar, &c. (Th, Ṣ,* TA.)
Akcb, inf. n. UikocaAbN, ‡ He, being called to, or shouted to, remained silent, feigning to be asleep. (AA, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tkd-b He affected lying: or he lied purposely (takal-afa Alkaciba). (Ṣ, Ḳ.) He told a lie; [like kacab.] (MA, KL.) [See also an instance in which it is trans., meaning He spoke falsely, voce tzE-m.]

tkc-bhu, (Ḳ,) and tkc-b Ealayohi, (TA,) He asserted that he was a liar. (Ḳ.) Aboo-Bekr Es-Siddeek says,
rasuwlN OataAhumo SaAdiqFA fatakac-abuwA
Ealayohi waqaAluwA lasota fiynaA bimaA kivi
[An apostle came to them, speaking truth; but they brought a charge of lying against him, or asserted him to be a liar, and said, Thou shalt not stay among us]. (TA.)
6. tkAcbwA They lied, &c., one to another. (Ṣ.) See also taSaAdaqaA.
kacobN and kacibN and kacabN and kucobN i. q. kadobN, &c. (Ḳ, art. kdb.)

kacibN and OukocuwbapN↓ [pl. OakaAciybu] (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kucobaI↓ and makocuwbN↓ (Ḳ: this last a pass. part. n. used in the sense of an inf. n., as is said to be done in only four other instances: MF) and makocuwbapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ: a fem. pass. part. n. which is less used in this manner than a masc.: TA [or perhaps an inf. n., as its contr. maSoduwqapN is said to be:]) and makocabapN↓ (Ḳ: a meemee inf. n. agreeable with analogy: TA) and mukocubapN↓ (CK: omitted in a MṢ. copy, and in the TA) and kaAcibapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kucobaAnN↓ and kuc-aAbN↓ (Ḳ) and takocaAbN↓ (L, art. msH,) are synonymous: (Ṣ, Ḳ) [all of these are regarded by some as inf. ns., signifying The act of lying; uttering a falsehood; or saying what is untrue: by others, all but the first seem to be regarded as simple substantives, signifying a lie; a falsehood; an untruth; a fiction; a fable: and the first, being an inf. n., is often used as a subst.]
Uin-a baniI numayorK layosa lahumo makocuwbapN↓ [Verily no lying, or lie, is attributable to the sons of Numeyr] is related as a phrase of the Arabs. (Fr.)
Uin-a baniI fulaAnK layosa liHad-ihimN makocuwbapN↓; i. e., kacibN; [Verily no falsity is attributable to the valour of the sons of such a one]. (Ṣ.)

layosa liwaqoEatihaA kaAcibapN↓ [Ḳur lvi. 2,] signifies There shall be no rejecting its happening [as a falsity]: kAcbp being here an inf. n.: (Fr) or kAcbp is here a subst. put in the place of an inf. n., like EaAqibapN and EaAfiypN and baAqiyapN. (Ṣ.)

laA mukocabapa↓, and lA kucobaI↓, and lA kucobaAna↓, I do not accuse thee of lying; or make thee a liar: (TA:) [and in like manner] laA kucoba laka, and lA kucobaI laka, signify lA takociyba There is no accusing thee of lying; or making thee a liar. (Lb.)
takaAciybu↓ AlX-iEori [The lies of poetry]. (TA.)

jaAWuwA EalaI qamiySihi bidamK kacibK, [Ḳur xii. 18, They brought, upon his shirt, false blood]: kcb here means makocuwbK↓: (Fr and Abu-l- ʼAbbás:) or is for ciI kacibK, meaning makocuwbK fiyhi: (Zj:) or the blood is termed kcb because he (Jacob) was told a lie thereby. (Akh.) See another reading in art. kdb.
kucobaI: see kacibN.
kacobaAnN: see kaAcibN.
kucobaAnN: see kacibN.
Alkacuwbu and Alkacuwbapu ‡ Names of the soul. (AZ, Ḳ.) See 1.

Sadaqatohu Alkaduwbu, [The soul (i. e. his soul) told him truth:] the soul diverted him, or hindered him, or held him back, from an undertaking, causing him to imagine himself unable to prosecute it. (TA.) One says so of a man who threatens another, and then belies himself, and is cowardly and weak. (AA.) Fr cites this hemistich:
Hat-aI UicaA maA Sadaqatohu kucubuho
Until, when his souls told him the truth, or diverted him, &c.: the poet assigning souls to the person spoken of because of the several opinions of the soul. (TA.)
kac-aAbN: see kaAcibN.
kuc-aAbN: see kacibN.

kac-aAbapN † A piece of cloth that is dyed of various colours, or figured, as though it were embroidered, and stuck to the ceiling of a chamber: so called because one would imagine that it [meaning what is figured] is upon the ceiling, whereas it is upon a piece of cloth beneath the ceiling. (A, L.)

hom.sense: kaAcibN and kac-aAbN↓ (fem. with p, TA,) and kacuwbN↓ and kucabapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kacuwbapN↓ and tikic-aAbN↓ (like tiSid-aAqN, TA) and kacobaAnN↓ (Ḳ) and kayocubaAnN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kayocabaAnN↓ (Az, Ḳ) and makocabaAnN↓ and makocabaAnapN↓ and kucubocubN↓ and kuc-ubocubN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ; neither of which last two words has its like in measure, IJ) and kucubocubaAnN↓ (Ḳ) epithets, applied to a man, from kacaba “he lied, &c.:” (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) [the first word a simple epithet, signifying Lying, &c.; or a liar: each of the others an intensive epithet, signifying Lying, &c., much; mendacious; or a great, or habitual, liar]. Pl. of the first word [kaAcibuwna and] kuc-abN; and of the third, kucubN: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to some, the last is pl. of kaAcibN, contr. to analogy; or pl. of kicaAbN, which is an inf. n. used as an intensive epithet. (MF.)
naASiyapK kaAcibapK, [in the Ḳur xcvi. 16,] signifies nASypK kAcbpK SaAHibuhaA [By] a forelock whose owner is a liar. (TA.)

Of the same kind is the expression ruWoyaA kacuwbN↓, meaning rWyA SaAHibuhaA kaAcibN [A dream whereof the dreamer finds it to be false, or vain; i. e. a false, or vain, dream]. (TA.) [See also a verse cited voce xayaAlN.]
Uin-a Alkacuwba↓ qado yaSoduqu [Verily the habitual liar in some few instances speaks truth]. A proverb. (TA.)
naAqapN kaAcibN, and mukac-ibN↓, ‡ A she-camel that, being covered by the stallion, raises her tail, and then returns without conceiving. (En-Naḍr, Ḳ.)
HamolapN kaAcibapN, and makocuwbapN↓ [lahaA? (see maSoduwqapN),] ‡ A charge that is followed up with cowardice and retreating. (TA.)
Alkac-aAbaAni An epithet applied to Museylimeh El-Hanafee and El-Aswad El-'Ansee. (Ḳ.) [Each of them is called Alkc-Ab.]

entry.sense: Oakocabu [More and most, lying, or mendacious]: see an ex. voce suhayolap.
OukocuwbapN: see kacibN.
takocaAbN and takaAciybu: see kacibN.
makocabapN: see kacibN.
mukocubapN: see kacibN.
makocuwbN: see kacibN

[One to whom a lie, falsehood, or untruth, is told: see kuciba.] Ex.
kul-u QmoriYK biTawaAli AlEayoXi makocuwbu
Every man, in respect of the length of life, is lied to [by his own soul]. A proverb. (Meyd, &c.)
qawolN makocuwbN [originally makocuwbN fiyhi] A false saying, or lie; [lit.] a saying in which a falsehood, or lie, is told. (M, TA, voce maqotuwtN.)

hom.sense: makocuwbapN: see kacibN.
A weak woman. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
A virtuous woman. (TA.)

entry.sense: makaAcibu [signifying lies, falsehoods, or untruths,] is said to be a word that has no proper sing.: or it is pl. of kacibN, contr. to analogy: or its sing. is makocabN: like as is said of maHaAsinu and macaAkiru, &c. (MF.)

hom.sense: 1. kar-a, [i. e.] kar-a binafosihi, as distinguished from the trans. kar-a, [aor. _u {yakoruru},] (Ṣ, Mgh,) inf. n. kr-N, (Ṣ,) or kuruwrN, (Mgh,) [or both,] He returned. (Ṣ, Mgh.) You say kar-a Ealayohi, (A, Ḳ,) aor, _u, (TA,) inf. n. kar-N and kuruwrN and takoraArN (A, Ḳ) and kariyrN, (CK,) He turned to, or against, him, or it: (A, Ḳ:) he returned to or against, it: (TA:) the primary signification is the turning to, or against, a thing, either in person, or in act. (El-Basáïr.) And Ainohazama vum-a kar-a Ealayohi [He was put to flight: then he returned, or turned back, against him]. (A.) And kar-a AlfaArisu,, aor. _u {yakoruru}, inf. n. kar-N, The horseman [wheeled round, or about, or] fled, to wheel round, or about, and then returned to the fight: (Mṣb:) [or returned to the fight after wheeling round, or about, or retiring, or being put to flight; as is implied in the phrase next preceding, from the A, and in many other examples: and simply, he charged, or assaulted: opposed to far-a: see kar-apN, below.] You say also AljawaAdu yaSoluHu lilokar-i waQlofar-i [The courser is suitable, or fit, for returning to the fight, or for charging, or assaulting, and fleeing]. (Mṣb.) [And kar-a signifies He, or it, returned time after time.] You say OafonaAhu kar-u All-ayoli waAln-ahaAri The returning of night and day time after time caused him to come to an end. (Mṣb.) Also kar-a Eanohu He returned from him, or it. (A, Ḳ.) And takarokara↓ Eano celika He returned from that. (TA.)

kar-a is also trans., as well as intrans.; (Ṣ, TA;) kar-ahu, (aor. _u {yakoruru}, TA,) inf. n. kar-N, signifying He made, or caused, him, or it, to return: (Ṣ, Mgh, TA:) and [in like manner,] karokarahu↓ Eano kacaA, inf. n. karokarapN, he made him to return, or revert, from such a thing. (TA.) You say kar-a Ealayohi rumoHahu, and farasahu, inf. n. kar-N, [He turned back his spear, and his horse, against him]. (A.)

kar-a, aor. _i {yakoriru}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and [see. pers. karirota,] aor. _a {yakoraru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kariyrN, (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,* TA,) He uttered a sound like that of one throttled, or strangled: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or like that of one harassed, or fatigued, or overburdened: (TA:) or he rattled in his throat (HaXuraja) in dying: (AZ, Ṣ:) or he made a sound in his breast like HaXorajapN [or rattling in the throat in dying], (A, TA) but not the same as this latter: and thus do horses, in their breasts. (TA.) [See Xaxara.]
Also, He (a sick man) gave up his spirit, at death. (TA.)
See also kariyrN, below.

entry.sense:
2. kr-rhu, inf. n. takoriyrN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and takoraArN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) or, as AA said to Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer, in reply to a question respecting the difference between the measures tafoEaAlN and tifoEaAlN, the latter is a simple subst., and the former, with fet-ḥ, is an inf. n., (Ṣ, TA,) [but there are two inf. ns. of the measure tifoEaAlN, both of unaugmented verbs, namely tiboyaAnN and tiloqaMCN,]
and takir-apN, (Ibn-Buzurj, Ḳ,) [He repeated it, or reiterated it, either once or more than once:] he repeated it several times; reiterated it: (Mṣb:) or he repeated it one time after another; (Ḳ;) which may mean he tripled it, unless the “other” time be not reckoned as a repetition; (TA;) as also karokarahu↓; (Ḳ; [in the CK, karokarapF is put by mistake for karokarahu;]) either by act or by speech: (MF:) it differs from OaEaAdahu, which signifies only “he repeated it once;” for none but the vulgar say OaEaAdahu mar-aAtK; whereas kar-arahu may signify [not only the same as OaEaAdahu, as it does in many instances, but also] he repeated it time after time: (Aboo-Hilál El-'Askeree:) some explain kar-arahu as signifying he mentioned it twice, and he mentioned it one time after another: (Sadr-ed-Deen Zádeh:) when it is used in the former of these two senses, the term takoraArN applies to the second, and to the first [with respect to the second]: ('Ináyeh, in the early part of chap. ii.; and TA:) but its explanation as signifying the mentioning a thing one time after another is a conventional rendering of the rhetoricians: (MF:) Es-Suyootee says, that takoraArN signifies the renewing the first word or phrase; and it denotes a sort of taOokiyd [or corroboration]: but it is said to be a condition of tOkyd that the words or phrases [which are repeated] be without interruption, and occur not more than three times; and that tkrAr differs from it in both these particulars; so that the phrase in the Ḳur, [chap. lv.,] fabiOaI-i MlaMCi rab-ikumaA tukac-ibaAni is an instance of tkrAr, not of tOkyd, because it occurs [with interruptions and] more than three times; and so another phrase in the Ḳur, [chap. lxxvii.,] wayolN yawomaYicK lilomukac-ibiyna. (TA.) You say kar-ar EalaI samoEihi kacaA [He repeated, or reiterated, such a thing, or saying, to his ear, or ears, or hearing]. (A.)
5. tkr-r [It became repeated, or reiterated: and it recurred]. You say tkr-r Ealayohi [It (a saying) became repeated, or reiterated, to him]. (A.)
R. Q. 1. karokarahu: see 1: and 2.
R. Q. 2. takarokara: see 1.

hom.sense: kar-N A rope [made in the form of a hoop] by means of which one ascends a palm-tree; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) accord. to AʼObeyd, a name not applied to any other rope; and so, says Az, I have heard from the Arabs; it is made of the best of [the fibres of the palm-tree called] liyf: (TA:) or a thick rope; (Ḳ;) accord. to AO, made of liyf, and of the outer covering (qiXor) of the [portions of the racemes of the palm-tree called] Earajiyn and of the [portion of the branch called] Easiyb: (TA:) or a rope, in general: (Th, Ḳ:) and the rope [or sheet] of a sail: (Ṣ:) or the rope of a ship: or the rope by which a ship is drawn: (TA:) and a qayod [or pair of shackles, or hobbles,] made of liyf or of palm-leaves: (Ḳ:) pl. kuruwrN. (Ṣ, TA.)

The thing that connects the [two pieces of wood called] ZalifataAni of the [kind of camel's saddle called] raHol, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and that enters [or is inserted] into them: (Ṣ:) [See XajorN and XaxorN:] or the skin, or leather, into which the ZalifaAt of the raHol enter; occupying the same place in the raHol as the bidaAdaAni have in the qatab, excepting that the bdAdAn do not appear before the Zalifap: (TA:) pl. OakoraArN. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: kur-N A certain measure of capacity, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the people of El-'Irák, (Mgh, Ḳ,) for wheat; (Ṣ;) well known; (Mṣb;) consisting of six ass-loads, (Ḳ,) that is, sixty times the quantity called qafiyz, (Az, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to the people of El-'Irák, (TA,) the qfyz being eight makaAkiyk, [in the TA, six, but this is a mistake,] and the mak-uwk being a SaAE and a half, which is three kiylajaAt; so that the kur-, accord. to this reckoning, is twelve times the quantity called wasoq, (Az, Mgh, Mṣb,) each wsq being sixty times the quantity called SAE: (Az, Mgh:) in the Kitáb Kudámeh, it is said that the kur- called AlmuEad-alu is sixty times the quantity called qfyz, and the qfyz is ten OaEoXiraMC: and the kur- called Alqanoqalu is twice the quantity of the kur- muEad-al, that is, by the qfyz of the mEd-l, a hundred and twenty times the quantity of the qfyz; with this kr- are measured unripe dates and dried dates and also olives, in the districts of El-Basrah; and the qfyz used for measuring dates is twenty-five times the riTol of Baghdád; so that the kur-u Alqanoqali is three thousand times as much as the rTl: and the kur- called AlhaAXimiI-u is the third part of the mEd-l, that is, twenty times as much as the qfyz, by the measure of the mEd-l; with this kur-, rice is measured: and the kur- called AlhaAruwniI-u is equal to them two [but what these two are is not shown]: and the OahowaAziI- is equal to them two: and the maxotuwm is sixth part of the qfyz: and the qfyz is the tenth part of the jariyb: (Mgh:) or the kur- is forty times as much as the quantity called Uirodab-; (Ḳ;) by the reckoning of the people of Egypt, as ISd says: (TA:) the pl. is UikraAr. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) [It is app. connected with the Hebrew כֹּר, whence the Greek κόρος (a measure containing, accord. to Josephus, six Attic medimni,) occurring in Luke xvi. 7.]

kar-apN A return. (Mṣb.) So in the Ḳur, [ii. 162,] lawo Oan-a lanaA kar-apF [Would that there were for us] a return to the world, or former state. And so in xxvi. 102, and xxxix. 59. (Jel.) And so in the saying of Moḥammad, Qll-eha Qll-eha waQlokar-apa EalaI nabiy-ikumo Fear ye God, [fear ye God,] and return to your prophet. (Mgh.)
[Hence, The return to life;] the resurrection; the renewal of mankind, or of the creation, after perishing. (TA.)
[Hence also, A return to the fight, after wheeling away, or retiring: and simply,] a charge, or an assault, (Mgh, Ḳ,) in war; (TA;) as also kur-aI↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) pl. kar-aAtN. (Ḳ.)

[Hence also,] A time; one time; [in the sense of the French “fois”; generally repeated, or used in the pl. form, so as to denote a returning to an action, once, or more; i. e., repetition, or reiteration, thereof, agreeably with the primary signification;] syn. mar-apN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ṣ.) You say faEalahu kar-apF baEoda kar-apK [He did it time after time]. And faEalahu kar-aAtK [He did it several times]. (A.)

[Hence also,] A turn to prevail against an opposing party; victory. So in the Ḳur, [xvii. 6,] vum-a radadonaA lakumu Alkar-apa Ealayohimo [Then we gave to you the turn to prevail against them; the victory over them]. (Bḍ, Jel.)
kur-aI: see kar-apN.
kariyrN, an inf. n.: see 1.
Also, A hoarseness or roughness of the voice, occasioned by dust. (Ḳ.)
kar-aArN: see mikar-N.

kirokirapN The callosity, or callous protuberance, upon the breast of the camel, (raHaI zawori AlbaEiyri, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which, when the animal lies down, touches [and rests] upon the ground, projecting from his body, like a cake of bread; (TA;) it is one of the five vafinaAt [of which there is one at each knee and one at each stifle-joint]: (Ṣ, TA:) or the breast of any animal of which the foot is of the kind called xuf-: (Ḳ:) pl. karaAkiru. (TA.) Haz-u AlkaraAkiri [lit. The incision of the krAkr] is when a camel has a disease, so that he is not even when he lies down upon his breast; in consequence of which, a vein is gently drawn forth from the krkrp, and then he [or it] is cauterized. Hence the following, in a trad. of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr:
EaTaAWukumu lilD-aAribiyna riqaAbakumo
wanudoEaI UicaA maA kaAna Haz-u QlokaraAkiri
[Your bounty is for those who smite your necks, and we are invited when there is a difficult undertaking to be accomplished, like the incision of the krAkr:] meaning, ye invite us only when ye are distressed, because of our skill in war; and on occasions of bounty, and ampleness of the means or circumstances of life, others. (IAth.)
makar-N A place of war or fighting [where the combatants return time after time to the conflict, wheeling away and then turning back]. (Ṣ)
mikar-N One who returns often [to the fight, after wheeling away, or retiring, or being put to flight]; as also kar-aArN↓. (Ḳ)

farasN mikar-N A horse that is suitable, or fit, for returning to the fight, and for charging, or assaulting. (Ṣ.) And farasN mikar-N mifar-N A horse well trained, willing, and active, ready to return to the fight and to flee. (TA.)
naAqapN mikar-apN A she-camel that is milked twice every day. (A, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
mukar-arN [Repeated; reiterated].

Almukar-aru The letter r: (Ḳ:) because of the faltering of the tip of the tongue which is observable when one pauses after uttering it, occasioned by the reiteration with which that is done; wherefore, with respect to UimaAlap, [as an obstacle thereto,] it is reckoned as two letters. (TA.)
[mukar-arN, in the present day, also signifies Refined, as an epithet applied to sugar, &c.]

hom.sense: 1. karaba, aor. _u {yakorubu}, inf. n. kuruwbN, It was, or became, near; drew near; approached. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Compare qaruba.]
[You say] karaba Oano yakuwna, and karaba yakuwnu, He, or it, was near, or nigh, to being

. (TA.) This is one of the verbs to which one does not give as its enunciative the act. part. n. of the verb which is its proper enunciative: [so that] you do not say, karaba kaAYinFA: [in which karaba implies the pron. huwa, which is called its noun; and kAYnA is put for yakuwnu, or Oano yakuwna, its proper enunciative]. (Sb.) karaba Oano yafoEala kacaA He was near, or nigh, to doing so; he well nigh, or almost, did so. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
karabati AlX-amosu The sun was, or became, near to setting. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
krbt AljaAriyapu An tudorika The girl was near to coming of age. (TA.)
karabato HayaApu Aln-aAri The fire was near to becoming extinguished. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
karaba He bound near together the two pasterns of an ass or of a camel with a rope or with shackles. (TA.)

karaba Alqayoda He straitened, or made narrow, the shackle, or shackles, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) upon the [animal] shackled. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) ʼAbd-Allah Ibn-'Anameh Ed-Ḍabbee says,
Oazojuro HimaAraka laA yarotaEo birawoDatinaA
UicFA yurad-a waqayodu AlEayori makoruwbu
[Check thine ass: let him not pasture at large in our meadow: in that case he will be sent back with the ass's shackles straitened]: (Ṣ:) meaning Do not venture to revile us; for we are able to shackle this ass, and to prevent his acting as he pleaseth. (L.) See Ḥam, p. 290.
karaba, aor. _u {yakorubu}, He loaded a she-camel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

karabahu, (aor. _u {yakorubu}, inf. n. karobN, TA,) It (sorrow, grief, &c., Ṣ, Ḳ, or an affair, Mṣb, TA) afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, him, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so that it filled his heart with rage. (Mṣb.) See also 8.
karaba Ald-alowa, aor. _u {yakorubu}, (inf. n. karobN, TA,) and kr-bhA↓, (Ḳ,) and AkrbhA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He put or attached, a karab to the bucket. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

kariba, aor. _a {yakorabu}, The rope called karab of his bucket broke. (Ḳ.) karaba, aor. _u {yakorubu}; and kr-b↓; explained by the words TaqoTaqa Alkariyba lixaXabapi Alxab-aAzi [app. meaning, He caused the kryb (a baker's wooden implement) to make a sound, or a reiterated sound, such as is termed TaqoTaqap]. (Ḳ.)
karaba; (accord. to the Ḳ;) or kr-b↓, inf. n. takoriybN; (accord. to IM;) He sowed land such as is called kariybN. (Ḳ.)
karaba AlOaroDa, aor. _u {yakorubu}, inf. n. karobN and kiraAbN, He turned over the ground for sowing, (Ḳ,) or for cultivating. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
karaba, aor. _u {yakorubu}, He took the karab (or lower parts, or ends, of the branches) from the palm-trees. (IAạr, Ḳ.) He lopped a palmtree. (Mṣb.)
karaba, aor. _u {yakorubu}, inf. n. karobN, He twisted [a rope, &c.] (qutala: accord. to some copies of the Ḳ) or he slew (qatala: accord to other copies of the same).

entry.sense: 2. kr-b: see 1 in four places.
3. kArbh i. q. qArbh, He, or it, approached, or was or became near to, him, or it. (Ḳ.) The k is substituted for q. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Oakrbhu [He, or it, affected him with karob, i. e. sorrow, grief, distress, or affliction: occurring in the TA in several places.]
Akrb, inf. n. UikoraAbN, He filled (Ḳ) a skin. (TA.)
Akrb AlUinaACa He nearly filled the vessel: [as also Aqrbh]. (TA.)
See 1.

Akrb, inf. n. UikoraAbN, ‡ He hastened, or sped: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he ran, in the manner termed UiHoDaAr and Eadow. (AZ.) You say, xuco rijolayoka biUikoraAbK [Take up thy feet with speed,] when you order one to hasten in his pace. (Ṣ.) In this sense, Oakoraba is said of a man, but seldom; and of a horse, or other animal that runs. (Lth, Lḥ.)

entry.sense: 5. tkr-b He picked the dates called kuraAbap (Ḳ) from among the roots of the branches (TA) [after the racemes of fruit had been cut off]; and tkr-b Aln-axolapa he picked the dates that were among the roots of the branches of the palm-tree, as also taxal-alahaA. (AḤn, TA in art. xl.)
8. Aktrb He became afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, by sorrow, grief, &c., (Ḳ,) or by an affair (TA) so also kariba↓, aor. _a {yakorabu}. (TA.)

hom.sense: karobN [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]

[You say] hecahi UibilN miAYapN Oawo karobuhaA (this is the right reading; and some say that kurobuhaA↓ is correct: TA: [the latter is the reading in the CK:]) There are a hundred camels, or about that number; or nearly so. (Ḳ.) krb is syn. with qurobN. (L.)

karobN (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and kurobapN↓ (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) Grief [or distress,] that affects the breath or respiration, [lit.] that takes away the breath: (Ṣ, O, and so accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, [agreeably with present usage, see bahorN, last sentence:]) or the soul: (so [erroneously] accord. to some copies of the Ḳ) or anxiety, solicitude, or disquietude of the mind: (Mṣb:) [or grief, or anxiety, that presses heavily upon the heart:] or both signify anxiety, grief, or intense grief: (MA:) pl. of the former kuruwbN, (Ḳ,) and of the latter kurabN. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: kurobN: see karobN.

hom.sense: karabN The rope that is tied to the bucket after the maniyn, which is the first [or main] rope, so that it (the krb) remains if the mnyn break: or the rope that is tied to the middle of the cross-bars of the bucket, (and is then doubled, and then trebled, Ṣ,) so as to be that which is next the water, in order that the great rope may not rot: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but in a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ, it is said that this latter explanation properly applies to the darak; not to the krb: (IM:) pl. OakoraAbN. (TA.)

karabN [coll. gen. n.] The lower parts, or ends, of palm-branches, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which are thick and broad, (Ḳ,) like shoulderblades: (Ṣ:) or the stumps of the branches, or what remain upon the palm-tree, of the lower parts, or ends, of the branches, after the lopping, like steps: n. un. with p {karabapN}. (TA.) Hence the proverb,
mataI kaAna Hukomu Qll-ehi fiI karabi Aln-axoli
[When was the wisdom of God in the stumps, or lower ends, of palm-branches?] (Ṣ.) Said by Jereer, in reply to Es-Salatán El-'Abdee, who had pronounced El-Ferezdaḳ superior to Jereer in point of lineage, and Jereer superior to El-Ferezdaḳ as a poet. IB denies it to be a proverb; but IM contends against him that it is, [The meaning is, When was God's wisdom in husbandmen, and possessors of palm-trees? for the region of Es-Salatán's tribe abounded in palm-trees. The words are applied to a man who provokes another to a contest for excellence, being unworthy of the contest. See Freytag, Arab. Prov., ii. 628.]

entry.sense: kurobapN: see karobN.

hom.sense:
karabapN sing. of kiraAbN, which latter signifies The channels in which water flows (Ṣ) in a valley: (Ḳ:) or the upper parts (Suduwr) of valleys. (AA.)
Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, describing bees,
jawaArisuhaA taOowiI AlX-uEuwfa dawaAYibFA
watanoSab-u OalohaAbFA maSiyfFA kiraAbuhaA
[The eaters, or feeders, among them, resort to the upper parts of the mountains, busily engaged, and pour down (into) ravines with crooked water-channels]. (Ṣ.) [jwArs, XEwf, and mSyf, are explained as above in the TA: and AlhAb is said in the Ṣ and TA, art. lhb, to be here pl. of lihobN. In a copy of the Ṣ, this last is erroneously written UilohaAbFA.]
karabapN (in the TA, written karabN,) The piece of wood (zir-) in which is inserted the head of a tent-pole. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: karobaAnu A vessel nearly full: (Ṣ:) fem. karobaACu; pl. karobaI and kiraAbN. (TA.) Yaạḳoob asserts, that the k in this word is a substitute for the q in qarobaAnu; but ISd denies this. (TA.)
