krAbu UinaACK [app. kiraAb or kuraAb] What is less than jumaAmu UinaAwi; [i. e., what is nearly equal to the full, or piled-up, contents, or measure, of a vessel]. (TA.) See qiraAbN.

AlkiraAbu EalaI Albaqari [The turning over of the soil is the work of the oxen]: a proverb. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See art. kilb: [where other readings, namely AlkiraAba and AlkilaAba and AlkilaAbu, are mentioned]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: kariybN i. q. qaraAHN [Land which has neither water nor trees: or land that is cleared for sowing and planting: pl., app., kiraAbN: see an ex. near the end of the first paragraph {1} of art. xtm:] (Ḳ:) and jaAdisN [land that is not cultivated nor ploughed], that has never been sowed. (TA.) See also jariybN.
A wooden implement of a baker, or maker of bread, with which he forms the cakes of bread (yurag-ifu). (Ḳ.) [In the TA is added “in the oven”: but I doubt the propriety of this addition.]
A knot, or joint, (kaEobN), of a reed or cane. (Ḳ.)

Accord. to IAạr, i. q. XuwbaqN, which is the same as fayolakuwnN. [Xwbq is an arabicised word, from the Persian Xuwbajo, or Juwbaho, both of which signify a rolling-pin, and this meaning is given to Xwbq and Xwbk in the present day. It should be remarked, however, that karoniyb (with n), which is probably a corruption of kariybN, is a name often given in Egypt, in the present day, to a baker's peel.] In the L, kryb is explained, as on the authority of Kr, by sawiyqN; but this is probably a mistake for Xwbq. (TA.) See makoruwbN.

entry.sense: karaAbapN: see kuraAbapN

kuraAbapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and karaAbapN↓ (Ḳ), but the former is the more approved word, (TA,) Dates that are picked from among the roots of the branches (Ṣ, Ḳ) after the racemes of fruit have been cut off: (Ṣ:) the scattered dates that remain at the roots of the branches: (AḤn, TA voce xulaAlapN, which signifies the same:) pl. OakoribapN, in the formation of which, the augmentative letter (meaning the fem. p, TA,) seems to have been rejected [or disregarded]; for fuEaAlapN (this is the right reading; TA; but in some copies of the Ḳ we read fuEaAlaI, and in others fuEaAl;) does not form a pl. on the measure OafoEilapN. (Ḳ.)

AHn says, that in this verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
kaOan-amaA maDomaDato min m-aACi OakoribapK
EalaI sayaAbapi naxlK duwnahu malaqu Akrbp signifies Mountain-tops, from which the water of the mountains flows down; and that its pl. is karobapN: but ISd remarks, that this assertion is not valid; because a sing. of such a measure does not form a pl. on the measure OafoEilapN. He also says, in one place, that Akrbp is [said to be] pl. of krAbp, which signifies “dates that fall among the roots of the palm-branches;” but [that] this is a mistake: upon which ISd remarks, In like manner, [this] his saying is in my opinion a mistake. (TA.)
kariybapN A misfortune; a calamity: (Ṣ:) or a severe misfortune, or calamity: (Ḳ:) pl. karaAYibu. (Ṣ.)

Alkaruwbiy-uwna (Ḳ) and Alkar-uwbiy-uwna, or this latter is a mistake, and Alkaruwbiy-apu, (TA,) [Hebr. כְּרֻבִים Cherubim,] the chiefs, or princes, of the angels; the archangels; (Ḳ;) of whom are Jebraeel and Meekáeel and Isráfeel; who are also called Almuqar-abuwna, accord. to Abu-l-ʼÁliyeh: (TA:) the nearest of the angels to the bearers of the throne: so called from krb as signifying “nearness” or the “being near:” (L:) or from their firmness, or compactness, of make; [see mukorabN] because of their strength, and their patience in worship: or from karabN, “sorrow, &c.,” because of their fear and awe of God. (MF.) Sh quotes the following of Umeiyeh:
karuwbiy-apN minohumo rukuwEN wasuj-adN
[Archangels, among whom are (some) that bend down the body, and (some) that prostrate themselves]. (TA.)
maA biAld-aAri kar-aAbN There is not any one in the house. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: kaAribN [Becoming near; drawing near; approaching]: near; nigh. (TA.)

'Abd-Keys Ibn-Khufáf El-Burjumee says,
OabunaI-a Uin-a OabaAka kaAribu yawomihi
faUicaA duEiyta UilaI AlmakaArimi faQEojali
[O my child, verily thy father is near to his day (of death): therefore when thou shalt be called to (the performance of) generous actions, make haste]. (Ṣ.)
OamorN kaAribu An afflicting, distressing, or oppressive, affair. (TA.)
mukorabN † A joint full of sinews (Ḳ.)
† A hard hoof. (TA.)
† A firm, or compact, beast of carriage: (Ṣ:) a horse of strong and firm make: (AA:) a firm, or compact, (or strongly compacted, TA,) rope, building, joint, or horse: (Ḳ:) a strong horse. (ISd.)
mukorabu AlmafaASili, (A,) and makoruwbu↓ AlmfASl, (Lth,) ‡ An animal of firm joints. (Lth, A.)
mukorabu Alxaloqi † Of firm make. (TA.)

mukorabaAtN Camels that are brought to the doors of the tents, or dwellings, in the season of severe cold, in order that they may be warmed by the smoke: (Ḳ:) [or] i. q. muqorabaAtN: see muqorabN. (TA.)
dalowN mukorabapN A bucket having a karab attached to it. (Ṣ.)
makoruwbN and kariybN↓ Afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, by sorrow, grief, or anxiety. (Ḳ, Mṣb.)
See also mukorabN.

entry.sense: Q. 1. karobaHa He prostrated another: or, [evidently a mistake for and,] inf. n. karobaHapN, he ran heavily; (Ḳ;) as also karomaHa: (TA:) and he ran at a slower pace than that termed karodaHapN, (Ḳ,) or karodamapN, which is a pace of the ass and mule only. (L.)

kirobaAsN A coarse garment or pieces of cloth: (Mṣb:) or coarse garments or pieces of cloth: (Ṣ: [but this explanation is omitted in some copies:]) or a garment or piece of cloth of white cotton: (Ḳ:) and so kirobaAsapN: (TA:) or the latter is a more particular term: (Ṣ:) [i. e., the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is the n. un.:] a Persian word arabicized; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) originally with fet-ḥ, [karobaAs,] altered because of the rareness of the measure faEolaAlN, (Ḳ,) in the cases of words not reduplicative: (TA:) [or from כַרְפַס, (see Est. i. 6,) whence also kurofusN, and κάρπασος, and carbasus:] pl. karaAbiysu. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
karaAbiysiI-N A seller of karaAbiys: (Mṣb:) a rel. n., app. likened to OnoSaAriI-N; for otherwise, by rule, it should be kirobaAsiI-N. (Lth, Ḳ.)
kurobaqN The shop of a vintner: syn. HaAnuwt. (Aṣ, in TA, voce xS.)
sanapN kariytN A complete year. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And so a day, and a month. (TA.)

Q. 2. tkrtb EalayonaA i. q. tql-b (He turned over upon us or turned against us:) accord. to the Ḳ: but accord. to the L and other lexicons, i. q. tgl-b (He got possession of us, or obtained the mastery over us, by force). (TA.)
Q. 1. karotaHa, inf. n. karotaHapN, He (a short man) ran with short steps, and quickly; as also karodaHa. (Ṣ, art. krdH.)
Also, (TA,) and takarotaHa↓, (Ḳ,) He went quickly in his walk. (Ḳ, TA.)
Q. 2: see 1.

1. karavahu, aor. _u {yakoruvu} (and _i TA, as from the Ḳ, inf. n. karovN; TA) and Akrvhu↓; It (grief, Ṣ, and an affair, TA) pressed severely upon him; oppressed him; afflicted him; distressed him; vexed him: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) [as also qaravahu]. As rejects the first form, although Ru-beh uses the expression. [You say,] karavaniI AlOamoru The thing grieved and oppressed me: (Aṣ, in TA [but see above:]) or pained me. (AA, Skr. p. 20.)
karavahu AlOamoru The affair moved him. (A)
4: see 1.
7. Ankrv It (a rope) broke. (Ḳ.)
8. Aktrv He was oppressed, afflicted, distressed, or vexed. (Lth.)

maA Oakotarivu lahu (in some copies of the Ṣ, bihi, which is more common, MF) I care not for him, or it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or I am not moved by, and do not care for, mind, heed, or regard, him, or it: (A:) or, as some say, I turn not my face towards him, or it: like Oalotafitu. (TA.) The affirmative phrase Oakotarivu lahu is a deviation from ordinary usage. (Nh.)

hom.sense: karaAvN [coll. gen. n.] A certain kind of large trees, (Ḳ,) growing on the mountains. (AḤn.) [F mentions his having seen them on the mountains of Et-Táïf.]
And see kur-aAvN.
kariyvN: see kaArivN.

Uin-ahu lakariyvu AlOamori [Verily he is in oppressive, afflicting, or distressing, circumstances; or timid, and retiring]: said when one is timid, or cowardly, and draws back, or desists [from an affair]. (Ḳ.) And fulaAnN kariyvN Eani AlOamori Such a one is a recoiler, or shrinker, from the affair. (A in art. rbv.)

kariyvN is also syn. with makoruwvN↓ [Oppressed, afflicted, distressed, or vexed: and app. attended with difficulty: see rabiyvN] (T in art. rbv:) or kariyvN and makoruwvN↓ both signify pained. (AA, Skr, p. 20.)

entry.sense: busorN karyvaMCu, and karaAvaMCu, [in the copies of the Ḳ, both words are written without tenween; if rightly introduced here they would be with tenween,] (like qariyvaMCu and qaraAvaMCu, TA,) Good, or sweet, dates, (Ḳ.) full-grown, and ripening. (TA.) The leading lexicologists [except the author of the Ḳ] agree in mentioning kryvAC [only] in art. krv; like qryvAC in qrv: and the author of the Ḳ mentions both again in chapter v. Ibn-Esh-Sheybánee says, qryvAC and kryvAC signify a kind of date (tamor): and some say, a kind of full-grown, ripening date (busor), of a black colour, the skin of which quickly falls off: accord. to the Fṣ, a well-known kind of full-grown, green date; and said to be the best, or sweetest, kind of date in the full-grown, green state (TA.)
kar-aAvN: see kur-aAvN.

kur-aAvN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kar-aAvN↓ (Kr, Ḳ) and karaAvN↓ (Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee) [each a coll. gen. n.,] A certain herb, or leguminous plant, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well-known, of foul odour, (Mṣb, TA,) and of disagreeable juice; (TA;) [the common leek; or allium porrum of Linn; or leeks:] kur-aAvapN is a more particular term; (Mṣb;) [i. e. it is the n. un. of kar-aAvN, signifying a single leek.]
OamorN kaArivN, and kariyvN↓, An affair that presses severely upon one; that oppresses, afflicts, distresses, or vexes. (Ḳ.)
karavatohu AlkawaArivu Affairs pressed heavily upon him; or oppressed him. (A.) Alkurobu AlkawaArivu [Oppressive sorrows, or anxieties.] (Ṣ.) (See Ḥar. p. 245)
makoruwvN: see kariyvN.

Q. 1. karovaOa, [inf. n, karovaOapN;] and tkrvO↓; [like krfO and tkrfO;] It (hair, Ḳ, or a collection of clouds, TA, &c., Ḳ) became large in quantity, (Ḳ,) and intricate, or confused; in the dial. of the tribe of Asad; (TA;) and heaped up. (Ḳ.)
Q. 2: see 1.

hom.sense: kiroviYN Clouds high and piled up, one upon another. (Ḳ.)
kiroviYN An egg-shell. (Ḳ, TA.) Accord. to Sb, from krav. (TA.)

entry.sense: karoviYapN: see kiroviYapN.

hom.sense: kiroviYapN and karoviYapN↓ Dense and tangled plants. (Ḳ.)
kiroviYapN and karoviYapN↓ The froth of churned milk, when the milk of an ewe is milked upon it and it rises in consequence thereof. Accord. to Sb, from krv. (TA.)

entry.sense: busorN karaAvaMCu and kariyvaMCu: see art. krv.

1. karija, aor. _a {yakoraju}; (or karaja, inf. n. karajN, as in the L,) and Akrj↓; (Ḳ;) and kr-j↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and tkr-j↓; (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ;) It (bread) spoiled, or became bad, or corrupt, (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ,) and was overspread with greenness; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) it became mouldy or musty. (MA.)
karaja It (a thing) became corrupt. (IAạr, L.)
tkr-j↓ It (wheat, or food, TaEaAm,) became spoiled, and overspread with greenness. (L.)
2: see 1.
4: see 1.
5: see 1.

kur-ajN A muhor [lit. a horse-colt, but app. meaning a mock colt, or hobby horse,] (Ḳ,) with which one plays: (TA:) [a thing] made (yut-axacu) like a horse-colt, upon which one plays: (Lth:) an arabicized word, from kur-aho, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is the name of it in Persian. (Ṣ.) [Jereer, in two verses, mentions the jalaAjil, or little round bells, of a kr-j.]
xubozN kaArijN i. q. mukar-ajN [Bread that is spoiled, and overspread with greenness; mouldy bread]. (IAạr, L.)

hom.sense: 1. karada, (aor. _u {yakorudu}, S, L,) inf. n. karodN, He drove, (L, Ḳ,) drove away, and repelled, a people: (Ṣ, L:) accord. to some, he drove the enemy in a charge or assault: (L:) he drove away the enemy: (Ḳ:) he repelled them and drove them away with his sword. (L.)
He turned him back from his opinion. (L.)
He cut off [a thing.] (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. kArdhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mukaAradapN, (Ṣ,) He charged upon, or assaulted, or attacked, him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and repelled him, (Ḳ,) the latter doing the same. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

karodN The neck; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) a Persian word, arabicized: (Ṣ, L:) or (properly, L) the base of the neck: (L, Ḳ:) or the place where the head is set upon the neck: i. q. qarodN: (L:) the back of the neck; as also karodanN↓ and qarodanN (IAạr, T, L.)

kurodN a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is kurodapN↓, the latter signifying A maXaArap, (O, L,) i. e. channel of water for irrigation, (TA, [but see this word, and what follows here below,]) of places, [or plots] of seed-produce: (O, L, TA:)
this is what is meant in the Ḳ by the saying that Alkurodu signifies Ald-aborapu mina AlmazaAriEi, and that the n. un. is with p {kurodapN}: (TA:) an instance of agreement between the languages of the Arabs and the 'Ajam; or, as some assert, an Arabic word derived from AlmukaAradapu: (O:) or kurodN signifies a daborap, and is [originally] a Pers. word: and the pl. is kuruwdN: and kurodapN is like kurodN [in signification]: (L:) [see also daborapN, voce daborN:] or kurodapN signifies a piece of land, or of sown land, or one having a raised border; and its pl. is kuradN [app. a mistranscription for the coll. gen. n. kurodN]. (MA.)

Alkurodu A certain nation; [the Gordiæi: (Golius:) n. un. kurodiI-N:] pl. OakoraAdN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) respecting their origin authors differ: it is said that their ancestor was Kurd the son of ʼAmr Muzeykiyà the son of 'Ámir Má-es-Semà, not 'Ámir the son of Má-es-Semà, as in the Ḳ, for Má-es-Semà was a surname of 'Ámir: (TA:) or they are the remains of the people whom Beewarásf, also called Eḍ-Ḍaḥḥák, used to eat: (IḲt, MF, TA:) or their ancestor was Kurd the son of Ken'án (or Canaan) the son of Koosh (or Cush) the son of Hám (or Ḥam) the son of Nooh (or Noah): they consist of countless tribes, differing in language and condition, but all are reduced to four principal tribes, the swrAn and the kwrAn and the kulhr and the lur: (Moḥammad Efendee El-Kurdee:) or their ancestor was Kurd the son of ʼAmr the son of 'Ámir the son of Saasa'ah: (Abu-l-Yakdhán:) El-Mesʼoodee says, that some assert them to be of the descendants of Rabee'ah the son of Nizár: others, that they are of the descendants of Mudar the son of Nizár: others, that they are descended from Kurd the son of Ken'án the son of Koosh the son of Hám: and he adds, that they are apparently of the offspring of Hám, like the Persians: that among the known tribes of which they consist are the swrAny-p, the kwrAnyp, the EmAdyp, the HkAryp, the mHmwdyp, the bxtyp, the bXwyp, the jwbyp, the zrzAYyp, the mhrAnyp, the jAwdAnyp, the rDAYyp, the srwjyp, the hArwnyp, and the lryp: and that their countries are Persia, and 'Irák el-'Ajam, and Ádharbeeján, and Irbil, and El-Mósil. (Moḥammad Efendee El-Kurdee.) [Many other assertions as to the origin of this people are made by other authors.]
karodanN: see karodN.
kurodapN: see kurodN.
kurodiy-apN an appellation of certain dogs [app. belonging to the kurod]. (M voce tadomuriy-apN.)
kirodiy-apN: see kirodiydapN.
kirodiydapN A large portion of dates. (L, Ḳ.)

Also, The [kind of basket of palm-leaves called] jl-apN in which dates are put: (Seer, L, Ḳ:) or the dates remaining upon the sides in the lower part of the jul-ap: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) as also kirodiy-apN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. karaAdiydu (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and kiraAdN. (Ḳ.)
makoruwdN A mustache cut off. (Ḳ.)
Q. 1. karodaHa, inf. n. karodaHapN, He (a short man) ran with short steps, and quickly; as also karotaHa and karomaHa. (Ṣ.)
He (an ass) ran leaning on one side; as also karodama. (L.)
He went slowly. (IAạr.)
Q. 2. takarodaHa He went quickly in his walk; i. q. takarotaHa. (Ḳ.)
He, or it, rolled. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. saqaTa mina Als-aToHi fatakarodaHa He fell from the flat top, or roof, of the house, and rolled. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)
karodaHapN A quick run, (Ḳ,) with short steps. (TA.) [See also Q. 1.]
karodaHaMCu, which accord. to analogy should be karodaHFI, A kind of walk, (Ḳ,) with short steps, and quick. (TA.)
kirodaAHN Running quickly; or a quick runner; (Ḳ;) with short steps. (TA.)
krdm See arts. krbH and krdH and krmH.

kurozN The [double bag, or double sack, called] xuroj (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ) of the pastor, (Ḳ,) in which he carries his provisions and utensils, and which is also put upon the back of the [ram called] kar-aAz: (TA:) or a juwaAliq [or sack]: (A, Mṣb:) or a small jwAlq: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OakoraAzN (ISd, TA) and [of mult.] kirazapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See baTiynN.]

kar-aAzN The ram that carries the xuroj [i. e. the kuroz q. v.] of the pastor: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) he goes before the people, (TA,) and has no horns; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) because that which has horns (AlOaqoranu) diverts himself with smiting others with his horns. (Ṣ.)
2. kr-shu, (TA,) inf. n. takoriysN, (Ḳ, TA,) He put it, or placed it, namely, anything, one part upon another. (TA.)
He put it together, one part to another. (TA.)
He founded it, namely, a building. (Ḳ, TA.)

4. Akrst Ald-aAru The house had in it compacted dung and urine of camels or of sheep or goats: (Ṣ, A,* TA:) and in like manner you say of a place: (TA:) and Akrst Ald-Ab-apu The beast of carriage had upon it, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., upon its tail, (TA,) compacted dung and urine. (Ḳ, TA.) See kirosN.

hom.sense: 5. tkr-s It (anything) became put, or placed, one part upon another. (TA.)
It became compacted and cohering; (A,* TA;) as also tkArs↓. (TA.)
It (the foundation of a building) became hard and strong. (TA.)
He collected together fire-wood, &c. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 6: see 5.

hom.sense: kirosN Compacted, or caked, or a cake of, dung and urine of camels and of sheep or goats, (Ṣ,* A,* Ḳ,* TA,) in a house, and upon the traces of men's abode: (TA:) and also, compacted clay or mud: (TA:) pl. OakoraAsN. (A, TA.) [Hence,] kirosu AlHawoDi The place in which the camels stand at the watering-trough or tank, and which in consequence becomes compacted [by the mixture of their dung and urine with the soil]. (TA.)
kirosu binaMCK [The foundation, or lowest part of a building: see 2]. (TA.)

One of the OakoraAs [meaning series or strings of beads] of [the necklaces and similar ornaments called] qalaAYid and wuXuH and the like: you say, qilaAdapN caAtu kirosayoni [a necklace of two such series], and caAtu OakoraAsK valaAvapK [of three such series], when you join one part to another [in several places, by larger beads: see qilaAdapN mukorasapN, below]. (Lth, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: karisN: see mukorisN.

kurosiI-N and (sometimes, Ṣ, Mṣb) kirosiI-N (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) A throne; syn. sariyrN: (Ḳ:) a chair: (TḲ:) a seat not larger than is sufficient for one person: (Bḍ, ii. 256:) [and a stool:] pl. karaAsiI-N (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and sometimes karaAsK, agreeably with a rule mentioned by ISk. (Mṣb.) It is the place [or seat] of the king, and of the learned man: and hence, as used in the Ḳur ii. 256, it is explained as signifying ‡ Dominion: (A:) and ‡ the power of God, whereby He holds the heavens and the earth: (TA:) and ‡ knowledge: (A, Ḳ:) which last explanation is ascribed to I’Ab: but the truth is, that I’Ab explained it as there signifying the [foot-stool of God; or] place of the feet: but as to the EaroX [of God], this is immeasurable: (Az, TA:) or it signifies the sphere of the stars. (TA, art. ErX.)
[Hence, also, you say,] huwa mino Oaholi AlkurosiI-i ‡ He is of the people of science. (TḲ.) [And hence,] AlkaraAsiI-u is also used [elliptically] to signify ‡ The learned men; accord. to Ḳṭr. (A.)
Also, A prop, or support, for a wall. (TA.)
[caAtu AlkurosiI-i The Constellation Cassiopeia: see xaDiybN.]

kiroyaAsN A privy on the top of the roof of a house, (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) with a conduit from the ground, (Ḳ,) or, as in some lexicons, to the ground: one that is below is not so called: (TA:) or the privy of an upper chamber: (MF:) of the measure fiEoyaAlN, (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from kirosN, meaning, “compacted dung and urine of camels, or of sheep or goats:” (Az,* A,* Ḳ, TA:) so called because of the filth that adheres to it, and becomes compacted: (Az, TA:) incorrectly said by some to be also written kirobaAsN, with the single-pointed letter [b]: the pl. is karaAyiysu. (TA.)
kur-aAsN: see what next follows.

kur-aAsapN [A quire, or parcel, of paper, generally consisting of five sheets, forming ten leaves, of a book; also vulgarly called kar-aAsapN and kar-aAsN;] one of what are termed kur-aAsN↓ and karaAriysu; [kur-aAsN being a coll. gen. n. and karaAriysu a pl.;] (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) a portion of a SaHiyfap [i. e. book or volume]: (A, Ḳ:) so called because compacted: (TA:) or from takar-asa signifying “he collected together” fire-wood, &c. (Mṣb.) You say, fiI hecihi Alkur-aAsapi EaXoru waraqaAtK [In this quire of a book are ten leaves]. (A.) And hecaA AlkitaAbu Eid-apu karaAriysa [This book is composed of a number of quires]. (A.) And qaraOotu kur-aAsapF mino kitaAbi siybawayohi [I read a quire of the Book of Seebaweyh]. (A.) And Alt-aAjiru majoduhu fiI kiysihi waAlEaAlimu majoduhu fiI karaAriysihi [The merchant's glory is in his purse, and the learned man's glory is in his quires of books]. (A.)
mukorasN: see mukorisN.

qilaAdapN mukorasapN and mukar-asapN↓ A necklace in which the pearls or other beads are strung upon two strings, and these are joined together by divisions of large beads: so in the TṢ and Ḳ, excepting that in the latter, fiI xayoTK is erroneously put for fiI xayoTayoni. (TA.) [See kirosN, last signification.] And [in like manner], naZomN mukar-asN↓ and mutakar-isN A string of beads one above another. (TA.)

rasomN mukorisN (Ṣ) [in the L and TA mukorasN, but the former, being agreeable with the verb, (see 4,) is probably the right reading,] Traces of men's abode in which is a compacted mixture of dung and urine of camels or of sheep or goats. (Ṣ, L,* TA.* [And accord. to the second and third of these authorities, karisN↓ seems to signify the same.])
mukar-asN: see mukorasN, in two places.
mutakar-isN: see mukorasN.

hom.sense: 1. kariXa, said of skin: see 5.

kariXa Alr-ajulu, aor. _a {yakoraXu}, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. karaXN, (TA,) ‡ The man came to have a numerous family, or household, after a while. (Ṣgh.) And ‡ The man came to have an army, or a military force, after having been alone. (Ḳ, TA.)
2. kr-X inf. n. takoriyXN, He made what is termed mukar-aXap. (Az, Ḳ.) You say, kar-iXuwA lanaA mino laHomi jazuwrikumo Make ye for us a mkr-Xp of the flesh of your slaughtered camel. (TA.)

‡ He contracted his face; or contracted it much; [making wrinkles in it like the plies of a kariX:] (Ḳ, TA:) and AstkrX↓ also signifies ‡ he shrank; contracted his face; frowned, or looked sternly or austerely or morosely. (Sh, TA.)

5. tkr-X ‡ It (a man's face, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, and his skin, A, TA, or the skin of his face, or any skin, TA) contracted, or shrivelled, or shrank, (Ṣ, IF, A, Ḳ, TA,) and became like the karX: (IF, TA:) and kariXa↓, aor. _a {yakoraXu}, (A, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. karaXN, (A, TA,) signifies the same, (A, Ḳ, TA,) said of skin, (Ḳ, TA,) when touched by fire. (TA.) You say, kal-amotuhu bikalaAmK fatakar-aXa wajohuhu ‡ I spoke some words to him and his face contracted. (A, TA.)
tkr-XwA ‡ They collected, or assembled, themselves together. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 10. AstkrXt AlUinofaHapu The stomach of a sucking kid became a kariX: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. e., when he pastured upon herbage; (Ḳ;) for it is called AnfHp as long as the kid does not eat; but when he eats, it is called krX. (Ṣ.)

Also AstkrX He (a kid, and a boy,) became large in his stomach: or became hard in his palate, and wide in his belly, after he had become large: (TA:) or he (a lamb or kid or calf) became large in his belly: (IAạr:) or he (a lamb or kid) became large in his belly, and ate much: (TA:) or he (a kid, A, and a boy, Az, TA) became large in his belly, and began to eat: (Az, A, TA,) but some disapprove of its being said of a boy, asserting that one says of a boy Uisotajofara. (TA.)
See also 2.
kiroXN: see kariXN.

hom.sense: kariXN and kiroXN↓ [The stomach, or man, of any ruminant animal;] the part of any ruminant, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of the animal that has a xuf-, [here meaning of the camel,] and of such as has a divided hoof, (A, Mṣb,) that corresponds to the maEidap of a man: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [it is in most cases four-fold; consisting of the first stomach, commonly called the paunch, which is the largest, and has no rugæ upon its internal surface, but a villous coat, having innumerable blunt papillæ which give it a general roughness, and from this the food is forced back into the mouth to be ruminated, as it is also from the second; the honeycomb stomach, which is the second, and which is so called from the cells which form its internal coat; the omasum, which is the third, and smallest, stomach, by some called the millet, but commonly the manyplies, because its internal surface has many plies, or folds, and strata super strata; and the abomasum, or fourth stomach, commonly called the rennetbag, or runnet bag, and the red, or reed, which is next in size to the paunch, and has an internal villous coat like that of the human stomach, but with longer and looser inner plies, or folds, and in this alone the true digestive process takes place:] but it is only thus called after the animal has begun to eat; being previously called UinofaHapN: (Ṣ, TA:) [or, accord. to some, the term is applied to the first and second stomachs, together; for it is said that] it empties itself into the qaTinap [or third stomach], as though it were yadu jiraAbK [so in my original, but this seems to be a mistranscription for lahu jiraAbN, meaning a provisionbag for the animal]: and it also pertains to the have or rabbit, and the jerboa: and is used [tropically] for that of man (TA:) it is of the fem gender: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [of pane.] OakoraAXN (TA) and [of mult.] kuruwXN. (Mṣb, TA.)

Hence the saying, (Ṣ, TA,) Uino wajadotu UilaI celika faA kariXK, [in the CK, erroneously, faAkoriXo.] meaning, ‡ If I find to that a way; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) said by a man upon whom one has imposed a difficult task; and originating from the fact that a man divided a sheep, or goat, in pieces, and put them into its stomach to cook them; and it was said to him, “Put in the head” whereupon he replied in the above words. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, maA wajadotu Uilayohi faA kariXK ‡ I have not found to him, or it, a way. (TA.) And lawo wajadotu Uilayohi faA kariXK, and baAba kariXK, and OdonaI fiI kariXK, meaning, ‡ Had I found to him, or it, as much way as the mouth of a stomach, and the entrance of a stomach, and the least mouth of a stomach, laOatayotuhu [I had come to him, or I had done it]. (Lḥ, TA.) And it is said in a trad. of El-Hajjáj, lawo wajadotu UilaI damika faA kariXK laXaribati AlbaToHaMCu minoka, meaning, ‡ Had I found a way to [shed] thy blood [the small pebbles of the bottom of the water-course had drunk from thee]. (TA.)
[Hence also,] you say, of land (OaroD), Uigobar-ato jilodatuhaA waraq-ato kariXuhaA [lit. Its skin became dusty, and its stomach became thin]; meaning, ‡ it became sterile. (TA.)
And [hence,] ‡ A receptacle for perfumes, and for clothes: in this sense also fem.: and a place of collection of anything. (TA.)

And ‡ A man's family, or household: and his young children: (A, Ḳ:) or his family, or household, consisting of his young children. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say, jaMCa yajur-u kariXahu ‡ He came dragging along his family, or household. (A, TA.) And Ealayohi kariXN mino EiyaAlK ‡ Upon him is dependent a large family. (A,* TA, in art. bqr.) And humo, (Ṣ,) or lahu, (A,) kariXN manovuwrapN, (Ṣ, A,) ‡ They are, (Ṣ,) or he has, (A,) scattered young children. (Ṣ, A.) And tazaw-aja fulaAnapa fanavarato lahu kariXahaA, (Ṣ, A,*) and baTonahaA, (Ṣ,) ‡ He married, or took to wife, such a woman, and she bore to him many children. (Ṣ, A.) [See also art. nvr.]

Also, ‡ A company, or congregated body, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of men: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) pl. OakoraAXN. (A.) Hence the saying of Moḥammad, AlOanoSaAru kariXiI waEayobatiI (Ṣ, TA) ‡ The Ansár are my company, and my companions, whom I acquaint with my secrets, and in whom I trust, and upon whom I rely: (TA:) or the meaning is, they are my auxiliaries, from whom I derive aid; because the camel and the beast with a divided hoof draw the cud from the stomach: (TA:) or the depositories of my secrets and trusts, like as the krX is the place of the food of the beast: (A:) or the objects of my love and compassion like young children. (Mṣb.) [And hence, app.,] AlkariXaAni is an appellation applied to [the tribes of] El-Azd and ʼAbd-el-Keys. (Ṣ.)
Also, ‡ The main part, or body of a people or company of men: (A, TA:) pl. OakoraAXN and kuruwXN: or, as some say, these are pls. having no sing. [in this sense.] (TA.)
vawobu OakoraAXK [app. from some peculiarity in its colours or texture,] ‡ A kind of garment, or cloth, of the description termed buruwd of [the fabric of] El-Yemen. (Az, TA.)

entry.sense: OakoraXu ‡ A man large in the belly: or, as some say, having large property: (TA:) and [the fem.] karoXaMCu a woman large in the belly (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ *) and wide. (TA.) Also the latter, ‡ A she-ass bulky in the flanks: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or bulky in the belly and flanks. (A.) And the same applied to a foot (qadam), ‡ Having much flesh, and even in the part of the sole which is generally hollow, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and short in the toes. (Ṣ.) And the same applied to a leathern bucket (dalow), ‡ ‡ Having swollen sides: (A:) or large and with swollen sides. (TA.)
Also the fem., † Distant relationship. (Ḳ.) You say, bayonahumo raHimN karoXaMCu † Between them is a distant relationship. (TA.)
takoriyXapN What is cooked in the stomachs of ruminants. (AA, Ḳ.) See also what next follows.

mukar-aXapN [A sort of haggess; or man stuffed with flesh-meat, or flesh-meat and fat, and cooked;] a piece of the stomach of a ruminant, stuffed with flesh-meat, and fastened together with a skewer, and cooked: (A:) or a sort of food, made of flesh-meat and fat, in a piece cut out from the stomach of a camel; (Ḳ;) a sort of food of the people of the desert, made by taking flesh-meat marbled with fat (laHom OaXomaT), well cut up into small pieces, and putting with it fat cut up in like manner, then putting it into a piece cut out from the stomach of a camel, after it has been washed, and its smooth side which is without any villous substance or feces has been cleansed, and fastening its edges together with a skewer, and digging for it a hole for fire, of the size thereof, and throwing into it heated stones, and lighting a fire over them, so that they become of a red heat, like fire, when the coals are put aside from them, and the mkr-Xh is buried therein, and hot ashes are put over it; then some thick and tough firewood is kindled over it, and it is left until it is thoroughly well cooked, whereupon it is taken out, having become like one piece, the fat having melted with the flesh, and it is eaten with dates, being sweet. (Az, TA.)

kiroXab-N i. q. qiroXab-N: (Ḳ:) or the former signifies Advanced in years, and hard, gross, or coarse: and the latter, a great eater, or voracious. (T.) The k is said to be substituted for q, or viciously pronounced for the latter letter. (MF.)

dictScrap.title: krS / krD / krT / krE / krf
dictScrap.label:
[krS, krD, krT, krE and krf
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: Q. 1. karofaOati Alqidoru The pot frothed, or raised a scum, when about to boil. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
karofaWuwA They became mixed together. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Q. 2: see 1.
kirofiYN i. q. kiroviYN; (Ḳ;) Clouds high and piled up, one upon another. (Ṣ) And kirofiYapN A portion of such clouds. (Ṣ.)
kirofiYN An egg-shell. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ.) It occurs again in art. krfO. (TA.)
kirofiYapN A ceratin tree, also called Xafal-aHN. (Ḳ.)

karafosN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so written in the Bári' and the T, but in some copies of the Ṣ, karofasN, [which is wrong,] (Mṣb,) [The herb smallage; apium graveolens of Linnæus,] a well known herb, or leguminous plant, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the hottest of leguminous plants (mno OaHar-i Albuquwli, TA, [but this is probably a mistake for mino OaHoraAri Albuquwli of the leguminous plants that are eaten without being cooked, or that are slender and succulent or soft or sweet,]) the utilities of which are great; diuretic; a disperser of winds and flatulence; a cleanser of the kidneys and liver and bladder, opening obstructions thereof; a strengthener of the venereal faculty, especially its seeds pounded with sugar and clarified butter, wonderful when drunk three days, (Ḳ,) upon an empty stomach, with avoidance of hurtful things, (TA,) but injurious to the young in the womb, and to the pregnant, and to those affected with epilepsy: (Ḳ:) said by Lth to be a foreign word introduced into the Arabic language, (TA.) and thought to be so by Az: (Mṣb:) in the O said to be arabicized; and, in the language of the people of Ghazneh, called krfH [or krfj?] (TA.)
kurofusN Cotton: (Ḳ:) [like kurosufN, from which it appears to be formed by transposition: see also kirobaAsN.]
kurokubN, like kurokumN, A certain plant of sweet odour. (Ḳ.) The former word is a syn. of the latter. (TA.)

Q. 1. karomaHa, inf. n. karomaHapN, i. q. karotaHa, (Ṣ, art. krdH, and CK, and a MṢ copy of the Ḳ,) He (a short man) ran with short steps, and quickly: (Ṣ, ubi supra:) or i. q. karobaHa, the b being changed into m, (TA,) he ran at a slower pace than that termed karodamapN. (L, TA.)
karomaHonaA fiI MvaAri Alqawomi We ran heavily in the footsteps of, or after, the people, (AA, Ṣ, ubi supra, L.)
Q. 1. krnb, inf. n. karonabapN, He fed a guest with karoniyb. (Ḳ.) Ex. karonibuwA liDayofikumo faUin-ahu latoHaAnu Feed your guest with krnyb, for he is hungry. (TA.)
Also, He ate [krnyb, or] dates with milk. (Ḳ.)
AHei and others assert the n to be augmentative; but in the T, L, and Ḳ it is implied that it is radical. (MF.)

kuronubN, with damm; [so in the copies of the Ḳ in my hands, and in the O, and so accord. to the TA; but I think that the correct reading is kurunobN, as the word is written by Golius, in one place, and by Freytag; although, in the Ḳ, by the words “with damm,” in the case of a quadriliteral word, is generally meant “with damm to the first and third letters”;] and karanobN; (Ḳ;) but it is commonly pronounced with damm [app. meaning to the first and second letters: kurunob being the name now commonly given to the brassica oleracea, or cabbage; in Greek κράμβη]: (TA:) the [vegetable also called] siloqN [properly beet; for which, possibly, cabbage may have been mistaken]: (AḤn, Ḳ:) or a species thereof, (L, Ḳ,) sweeter and more tender than the qun-abiyT; of which the wild kind is bitter; and the quantity of two drachms of its roots, dried and pulverized, mixed with wine (XaraAb), is a tried antidote against the bite of a viper. (Ibn-El-Beytár, Ḳ.) It is said, by the botanists, to be a Nabathean word, arabicized. (MF.)
karoniybN and kironiybN (Ḳ) and krnAb (so in the TA) i. q. majiyEa, (Ḳ,) which is the same as kudayoraACu: (IAạr:) Dates with milk. (T.)

hom.sense: 1. kaz-a, [second pers. kazuzota,] (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yakozuzu}, (MṢ, TA,) inf. n. kazaAzapN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and kuzuwzapN, (A, Ḳ,) It dried, or dried up; or became stiff, rigid, or tough; and contracted. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, kaz-ato yaduhu His hand became dry, or stiff, rigid, or tough, and contracted. (A.)
[Hence,] kaz-ato xuTaAhu ‡ His steps were [contracted, or] near together. (A, Ḳ.)

[Hence also,] kaz-ato nafosuhu and Aktz-t↓ ‡ [His soul became contracted; meaning, he became niggardly]. (A.) And Aktz-↓ Alr-ajulu ‡ The man shrank [from giving]. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, fulaAnN laA yahotaz-u walekin-ahu yakotaz-u ‡ [Such a one does not rejoice, or is not active, or prompt, and brisk, or cheerfully excited, to give, but he shrinks from giving]. (A, TA.) [kazazN (q. v. infra) seems to be an inf. n. of which the verb is kaz-a, second pers. kazizota,, aor. _a {yakozazu}, in the sense of Aktz-↓ as explained above.]
kuz-a He (a man) shrank, or became contracted, in consequence of the cold: (Ṣ:) or he became affected by what is termed kuzaAz: (A, Ḳ:) or he became affected by a rheum. (TA.)
kaz-ahu Albarodu and Ald-aMCu [The cold, and disease, made him to shrink, or become contracted, and to be affected with a tremour]. (A.)
kaz-a AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yakozuzu}, inf. n. kaz-N, (TA,) He made the thing narrow, or strait. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kaz-ati AlmaroOapu dumolujahaA, (A, TA,) aor. _u {yakozuzu}, (TA,) ‡ The woman filled her armlet with her arm. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Akz-hu Qll-ehu God smote him, or afflicted him, with what is termed kuzaAz. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1, in three places.

kaz-N Dry, or dried up; or stiff, rigid, or tough; and contracted: (A, Ḳ:) pl. kuz-N. (Ḳ.) You say, yadN kaz-apN A dry, or stiff, rigid, or tough, and contracted, hand. (A.) And xaXabapN kaz-apN A stiff, rigid, or tough, (TA,) or hard, (A,) and crooked, piece of wood. (A, TA.) And qanaApN kaz-apN A hard and crooked spear or spear-shaft. (TA.) And qawosN kaz-apN A stiff, rigid, or tough, bow: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or a bow whereof the arrow does not go far, by reason of the narrowness of the former: (TA:) Aboo-Ziyád says, that the bow thus called is the smallest of bows: (AḤn, TA:) pl. qisiI-N kuz-aAtN. (A.) And bakorapN kaz-apN A narrow pulley-sheave, that makes a loud creaking (Ṣ, Ḳ) by reason of its narrowness. (TA.) And cahabN kaz-N Tough gold: (A:) or very hard gold. (Ḳ.) And jamalN kaz-N A hardy, strong camel. (TA.)
rajulN kaz-N, (Ṣ, A,) and kaz-N Alyadayoni, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) ‡ A niggardly man. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) of little beneficence, (TA,) and of little compliance: (A, TA:) pl. kuz-N. (Ṣ.)
wajohN kaz-N † A foul, or an ugly, face. (Ḳ.)
kazazN Hardness and crookedness in a piece of wood, or in a spear or spear-shaft. (TA.)
‡ Niggardliness, (Ḳ,) and littleness of compliance and of beneficence. (TA.) See 1.

kuzaAzN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and kuz-aAzN↓, (IAạr, A, Ḳ,) or, accord. to Az, the latter is the correct form, and the former is vulgar, (A,) A contraction and tremour arising from cold: (A:) or a tremour arising from intense cold: (IAạr, Ḳ:) or a certain disease arising from intense cold; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) being a spasmodic contraction so occasioned: or, accord. to the physicians, arising from the egress of much blood: (TA:) or a certain disease arising from cold, in consequence of which the patient trembles until he dies. (A.)
kuz-aAzN: see kuzaAzN.
makozuwzN Made narrow, or strait. (Ṣ.)
A man affected by what is termed kuzaAz: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or affected by a rheum. (TA.)
kuzobN i. q. kusobN. (Ḳ.)
[Coll. gen. n., A kind of] hard trees. (Ḳ.)
kazabN Smallness and contraction of the muXoT (or metatarsal bones) of the foot; which is a defect. (Ḳ.)
kawozabN Avaricious, or niggardly, and narrowminded. (Ḳ.)
makozuwbapN i. q. xilaAsiy-ap in colour; i. e., between black and white. (Ḳ.)

kuzoburapN, and sometimes, [in the present day commonly,] kuzobarapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Arabic, and well known, (AḤn,) [but J says] I think it is arabicized, (Ṣ,) [Chald. כּרּסְבָר, (Gol.)] One of the kinds of seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [coriander-seed: or the coriander-plant, accord. to the explanation of kusoburapN (which is said in the TA to be a dial. form of kzbrp) in the Ḳ.]

hom.sense: 1. kasaO, aor. _a {yakosaOu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. kasoCN, (TA,) He, or it, pursued, or followed, another, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as one follows a party which he has put to flight: like kasaEa. (Ṣ.)
kasaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kasoCN, (TA,) He urged on a beast of carriage. in the track, or at the heels, of another. (Ḳ.)
kasaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kasoCN, (TA,) He overcame a party in litigation or the like. (Ḳ.)
kasaOa (perhaps a mistake for kaXaOa, TA,) He smote a person with a sword. (Ḳ.)
kasoCN inf. n. of 1. q. v.
mr-a kasoCN mina All-ayoli A part of the night passed. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: kusoCN and kusuwoCN↓ The hinder, or latter, part of anything: pl. OakosaACN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kusoCN AlX-ahori, and kusuwoWuhu↓, The latter part of the month; its last ten days, or about that period. (TA.)
jaACa fiI kusoCi AlX-ahori, and EalaI kusoYihi, He came in the latter part, or end, of the month. (TA.)

jaACa EalaI kusoCi AlX-ahori, and ElI OakosaAYihi, and jiYotuka EalaI kusaAYihi↓, [in the TA written, app. by a mistake of the transcriber, ElI ksACh,] and fiI kusaAYihi, [so in the TA,] He came, and I came to thee, at the end of the month, after the whole month had passed. (TA.)
jiYotu fiI OakosaMCi Alqawomi I came among the latter of the people. (TA.)
mar-uwA fiI OakosaMCi Almunohazimiyna, and ElI OakosaAYihimo, They went at the heels of the routed party. (TA.) rakiba kusoOahu He fell upon the back of his neck, or head. (Ḳ.)
kusaMCN: see kusoCN.
kusuwoCN: see kusoCN.

1. kasaba, aor. _i {yakosibu}, inf. n. kasobN (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb) and kisobN (Ḳ), He collected [wealth, &c.]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;)
as also Aktsbhu↓. (Ṣ.) This is the original signification. (Ṣ.)
[Hence,] He gained, acquired, or earned, wealth or the like; as also Aktsb↓. (Mṣb.) kasabotu XayoYFA and Akotasabotuhu↓ are syn., [signifying I gained a thing]. (Ṣ.)

Hence [also], kasaba and Aktsb↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb) and tks-b↓ (Ḳ) He sought, sought after, or sought to gain, sustenance, or the like, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) for his family: (Mṣb:) or kasaba signifies he got, or obtained, or gained, acquired, or earned, [sustenance,, &c.]; and Aktsb↓, he applied himself with art and diligence [to get, or obtain, or gain, acquire, or earn, sustenance, &c.; he laboured to earn, or gain, sustenance]: (Sb, Ḳ:) [so] also tks-b↓ is explained by takal-afa Alkasoba he applied himself, as to a task, to gain, &c. (Ṣ.)
kasaba is also said to signify, and originally, both he sought, or sought after, [sustenance]; and he laboured in seeking, or seeking after, sustenance. (TA.)

Aktsb↓ has a more intensive signification than kasaba; and hence, in the last verse of the second chap. of the Ḳur [lahaA maA kasabato waEalayohaA maA Qkotasabato To it shall be given what reward it hath earned, and upon it shall be executed what punishment it hath drawn upon itself], the latter is used with reference to what is good; and the former, with reference to what is evil. (IJ.) You say, kasaba xayorFA ‡ [He gained, or earned, or did, good]: and Aktsb↓ Xar-FA ‡ [He gained, or earned, or did, evil]. (A.)

[This distinction, however, is not always observed: for] kasaba signifies, He did either a good or an evil deed: [because he who does so earns, or draws upon himself, reward or punishment.] (Jel in ii. 281; and iii. 24;, &c.) And Aktsb↓ He committed an act of which he was accusable. (Jel in xxxiii. 58.) kasaba UivomFA and Aktsbhu↓ signify He [committed, or] burdened himself with (taHam-ala), a sin, or crime. (Mṣb.)

kasabahu maAlFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Aksbhu↓ mAlA, (IAạr, IAth, Ḳ,) but the former is the more approved: the latter is by Fr and some others rejected: (TA:) He caused him to gain, acquire, or earn, wealth: (IAth, Mṣb:) or he assisted him to gain, acquire, or earn, wealth. (IAth.) ksbhu EilomFA He caused him to gain, or acquire, knowledge. (Mṣb.) [In like manner,] Asotakosabotu↓ AlEaboda I caused the slave to gain, or make gain; the verb having here the sense of the measure OafoEalotuhu; like as Aisotaxorajotuhu signifies Oaxorajotuhu. (Mṣb.) [See an ex. voce OadiymN.]
nahaI Eano kasobi AlUimaACi [He (Moḥammad) forbade the making female slaves to earn money, or the like, (by prostitution)]. (TA, from a trad.)
maA kasaba in the Ḳur cxi, 2, is said to signify His children. A man's children are among the things termed his kasob. (TA.)
kasabahu EajabFA It occasioned, or caused, him to wonder. (TA, voce OaEojaba.)
4: see 1.
5: see 1.
8: see 1 throughout.
kasobN inf. n. of 1. q. v.

fulaAnN Tay-ibu Alkasobi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Almakosabi↓, and Almakosibi↓, (Ḳ,) and Almakosibapi↓, and Alkisobapi↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Alkasiybapi↓, (IM,) [Such a one makes good gain: kasobN, &c. signifying gain, acquisition, or earning: and also a deed, whether good or evil].

kusobN i. q. kunjArq [or kanojaArahu], a Persian word, called by some of the people of Es-Sawád kusobaj [or kusobah; i. e., The dregs of sesamegrain, or the like, from which the oil has been expressed]; (TA;) dregs remaining after the expression of oil: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [as also kuzobN:] from the Persian kXb, (AM,) [or rather kusobah, or kusobaj]. See also tax-N.
kasobapu: see kasaAbi.
kisobap: see kasobN.
kasobiI-N: see AikotisaAbiI-N.
kasaAbi The wolf. (L, Ḳ.)

A name of a bitch: (Ṣ:) one of the names of the bitch: (ISd:) as also kasobapu↓: (Ḳ:) as kusayobN↓ is a name of the dog; i. e., of the male: (Ḳ:) names thus used as ominous of gain, [or of capturing game]: (IM:) kasaAbi, as a name of a hunting bitch, means kaAsibapN. (TA, art. brH.)

hom.sense: kasuwbN [so in the copies of the Ḳ in my hands; but by the place in which it is mentioned in the TA, it is implied that it is kas-uwbN↓: see also lasuwbN] A thing; anything. maA lahu kasuwbN He has not anything. (Ḳ.)
rajulN kasuwbN, and kas-aAbN↓, A man who makes much gain. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: kusayobN: see kasaAbi.
Uibonu Alkusayobi Bastard. (Ḳ.)
kas-aAbN: see kasuwbN.

hom.sense: kas-uwbN A certain plant. (Ḳ.)
See also kasuwbN.

entry.sense: AlkawaAsibu i. q. AljawaAriHu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) here meaning The members (either of a man or of a bird) by means of which is gained, acquired, or earned, sustenance, or the like. (MF.) [The explanation in the TA, AljawaAriHu mina AlUinosaAni waAlT-ayori, seems, at first sight, to signify preyers, whether men or birds: but this meaning I do not think to be the one intended.]
Oabuw kaAsibK The wolf. (Ḳ.)

AikotisaAbiI-N [Acquired knowledge, such as is acquired by study: as also kasobiI-N↓:] opp. to DaruwriI-N as meaning [natural or instinctive, or] such as the creature has by [Divine] appointment. (Kull p. 232.)
makosabN and makosibN and makosibapN: see kasobN.
kusoburapN and kusobarapN. The plant of the julojulaAn; (Ḳ;) [i. e., the plant of which the fruit, or produce, is called AljulojulaAn;] dial. forms of kuzoburapN and kuzobarapN, q. v. (TA.)
kusotN i. q. qusoTN (Ḳ) and kusoTN, [i. e. Costus,] with which one fumigates. (Kr.)
1. ksj, [app. kasija, aor. _a {yakosaju},] inf. n. ksj, [app. kasajN,] He had no beard grown; [was naturally beardless]. From this it would seem that kwsj is an Arabic word. (IḲooṭ, Mṣb.)
Q. Q. 1. kawosaja He was, or become, what is termed kawosajN; (Ḳ;) from which latter word the verb is derived. (Shifa el-Ghaleel.)
Q. Q. 2. mano TaAnato liHoyatuhu takawosaja Eaqoluhu † [He whose beard becometh long, his intellect becometh small.] (TA.)

kawosajN (Th, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and kuwsajN, (Fr, Ḳ,) thus pronounced by some of the Arabs agreeably with its Persian original, (Fr,) but this latter form is disapproved by Yaạḳoob and ISk and IDrst, (TA,) and AḤei says that SuwbajN and suwsanN are the only words of the measure fuwEalN, (MF,) and kuwsujN, (Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee,) a more strange form than that immediately preceding, (MF,) a word of well-known meaning, (Ḳ,) A man having no hair upon the side of his face [but only upon his chin]; (M;) i. q. OavaT-u; (M, Ṣ;) whose cheeks are clear of hair; (Expositions of the Fṣ) [used in the present day to signify having a scanty, or small, beard, and that only on the chin:] an arabicized word, (Ṣ, &c.,) originally kwsq, (Mṣb,) [or rather kuwsaho, which is Persian].

Also, Deficient in the teeth: (Aṣ, Ḳ:) from the Persian kwzh, (Sb,) [or rather kuwsaho]: [pl. kawasiju, occurring in the TA in art. vT.] A woman said to her husband Thou art kwsj: to which he replied, if I be kwsj, thou art divorced. And the matter being referred to the Imám Aboo-Ḥaneefeh, he said, Let his teeth be numbered; and if they be twenty-eight, he is kwsj, and his wife is divorced from him; but if they be thirty-two, he is not so, and she is not divorced. And they were numbered, and found to be thirty-two (MF.)

Also, [The Xiphias, or sword-fish;] a certain fish (of the sea, Ṣ) that has a snout like a saw, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and eats men; i. q. laxomN, (TA,) and jamalu AlmaMCi, (Mgh in art. jml,) or jamalu AlbaHori. (TA in that art.)
Also, A slow hackney, or nag. (A, Ḳ.)

1. kasaHa, (aor. _i {yakosiHu} K, inf. n. kasoHN, Mṣb,) He swept a house, or chamber. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [You say] kasaHati Alr-iyHu AlOaroDa The wind swept off the dust from the surface of the ground. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] kasaHa ‡ He cleaned out a well, and a canal or channel of running water, &c. (Mṣb.)
[And hence also,] ‡ He cut a thing off; destroyed it; did away with it, carried it off: (Mṣb:) [he swept it away.]
kasaHonaA baniI fulaAnK ‡ We extirpated the sons of such a one. (A.)

kasiHa, aor. _a {yakosaHu}, inf. n. kasaHN, He had a heaviness in one of his legs, and dragged it when he walked: (T:) he was crippled in the legs, and in the arms: (L, Ḳ:) mostly used in relation to the legs. (L.) [See also kusaAHN.]
8. OagaAruwA Ealayohimo faQkotasaHuwhumo ‡ They made a hostile attack, or incursion, upon them, and took all their property. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
UikotasaHonaA maAla baniI fulaAnK ‡ We took [or swept off] all the property of the sous of such a one, leaving them nothing. (L.)
[In like manner you say] kasaHa mina AlmaAli maA XaMCa [‡ He swept off what he pleased of the property]; as also kavaHa. (Ḳ, voce kavaHa.)
kasoHN Impotence, (Ḳ,) arising from a disease which attacks the hips, and weakens the leg. (TA.)
kasoHaAnu: see OakosaHu
kusaAHN (L) and kusaAHapN↓ (Ḳ) The state of being crippled (zamaAnap) in the legs, and in the arms: (L, Ḳ:) mostly used in relation to the legs. (L.) [See 1.]
kusaAHN A certain disease of camels, (L, Ḳ,) which renders them very lame, so that they cannot walk: (Aboo-Saʼeed, L.)
kasiyHN: see OakosaHu.
Also, Impotent (Ḳ) in walking, as though he swept the ground. (TA.)
kusayoHN: see OakosaHu.

hom.sense: kusaAHapN Sweepings; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) dust that is swept from a house and thrown in a heap. (Lḥ.)
See also kusaAHN.

entry.sense: OakosaHu and kasoHaAnu↓ and kasiyHN↓ (L, Ḳ) and kusayoHN↓ (Ḳ) and mukas-aHN↓ (L) Having a heaviness in one of his legs, and dragging it when he walks: (L:) crippled in the legs, and in the arms: (L, Ḳ:) also the first (as explained by some, L,) lame, by nature, or by reason of a chronic ailment: and affected by a disease which deprives one of the power of walking: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) pl. kusoHN (L) and kusoHaAnN. (L, Ḳ.) AlS-adaqapu maAlu AlkusoHaAni waAlEuwraAni (Ṣ, L) Alms are the property of the crippled and the one-eyed. (L, from a trad.)
mikosaHapN A broom, or besom, or instrument with which one sweeps (Ṣ, Ḳ) snow, &c.; (Ṣ;) as also mikosaHN. (L.)
mukas-aHN: see OkosaHN.
makosuwHN A camel severely lame, (L, Ḳ,) so that he cannot walk. (Aboo-Saʼeed, L.)
Q. 1. kasoHaba, inf. n. kasoHabapN, He walked in fear, hiding himself. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. kasada, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yakosudu}, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. kasaAdN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kusuwdN; (Ḳ;) and kasuda; (L, Ḳ;) but the former is the verb in common use; (TA;) It (a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb, a commodity, &c., L) was, or became, unsaleable, or difficult of sale, and in little demand. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) The original meaning is It was, or became, in a bad, corrupt, or unsound state. (T, Mṣb.)
kasadati Als-uwqu, (aor. _u {yakosudu}, inf. n. kasaAdN, L,) The market was, or became, stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (Ṣ,* A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) See 4.

entry.sense: 4. Aksd He (God) made a market stagnant, or dull with respect to traffic. (A, Mṣb)

He (a man) found his market to be stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, A, L, Ḳ.) [In most copies of the Ḳ, we find, wasuwqN kaAsidN waOakosadu waOakosadato suwquhumo, instead of wasuwqN kaAsidN waOakosaduwA kasadato suwquhumo, which is the right reading, as is indicated in the TA.]
kasiydN: see kaAsidN.

Also, of inferior condition; ignoble: syn. duwnN. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) So in the saying of the poet, (Ṣ, L,) Mo'áwiyeh Ibn-Málik, surnamed Mo'owwidh-el-Hukamà, (IB, L,)
Uico kul-u HaI-K naAbitN biOaruwmapK
nabota AlEiDaAhi famaAjidN wakasiydN . (Ṣ, L) meaning, Since every living man grows from a root, like the growth of the 'idáh, there is he who is noble, and he who is ignoble. (IB, L.)
kaAsidN and kasiydN↓ A thing, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or commodity, &c., (L,) unsaleable, or difficult of sale, and in little demand. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say siloEapN kaAsidapN. (Ṣ.)
suwqN kaAsidN, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) without p, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) or kaAsidapN, as in the T, (Mṣb) A market stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., caAtu kasaAdK. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. kasarahu, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) aor. _i {yakosiru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. kasorN; (Mṣb, TA;) and Aktsrhu↓: (Ḳ;) [He broke it: or the latter signifies he broke it off: or it is similar to UiqotaTaEahu and the like and signifies he broke it off for himself: for] you say Aktsrtu↓ minohu TarafFA [I broke off, or broke off for myself, from it, an extremity]. (A.) You say kasarotuhu QnokisaArFA↓ and Uinokasara kasorFA, putting each of the inf. ns. in the place of the other, because of their agreement in meaning, not in respect of being trans. and intrans. (Sb, TA.)
kusira He had his leg broken; his leg broke. (Mgh.)

fulaAnN yakosiru Ealayoka Alfuwqa, (A, Ḳ,) or AlOaroEaAZa, (Ḳ,) or yukas-iru↓, (as in the CK,* and in a MṢ copy of the Ḳ, but we find the former reading in art. rEZ in the Ḳ,) [lit., Such a one breaks against thee the notch of the arrow, or the sockets of the arrow-heads: meaning,] ‡ such a one is angry with thee: (A, Ḳ:) or is vehemently angry with thee. (Ḳ, art. rEZ, in which see further explanations.)

[kusira bayonahumo rumoHN lit., A spear was broken among them: meaning, † a quarrel occurred among them. (Reiske, cited by Freytag, but whether from a classical author is not said; and explained by him as signifying Simultas inter eos intercessit.)]
kasara AlkitaAba EalaI Eid-api OabowaAbK wafuSuwlK ‡ [He divided the book, or writing, into a number of chapters and sections]. (A.)
kasara AlX-aEora, aor. _i {yakosiru}, inf. n. kasorN, † [He broke the measure of the poetry;] he did not make the measure of the poetry correct. (TA.)
kasarotu Alqawoma, inf. n. as above, † I [broke, crushed, routed, or] defeated, the people or party. (Mṣb.)
kasarotu xaSomiI ‡ [I defeated my adversary]. (A.)
[kasara nafosahu † He broke, or subdued, his spirit.]
[† He abased, or humbled, himself.]
kasarotu mino saworatihi ‡ [I broke, or subdued, or abated, somewhat of his impetuosity, or violence, or tyranny, or anger]. (A.)
kasara Humay-aA Alxamor biQlomizaAji ‡ [He broke, or subdued, or abated, the intoxicating influence of the wine by the mixture of water]. (A.)
kasara mino barodi AlmaMCi, and Har-ihi, aor. and inf. n. as above, † He abated, or allayed, somewhat of the coldness of the water, and its heat. (TA.)
Aikosiro Ean-aA: see an ex. voce ruwbapN.
[kasara AlEaTaXa † It abated, or allayed, thirst.]
kasara mataAEahu ‡ He sold his goods by retail, one piece of cloth after another: (IAạr, Ḳ:) because, [on the contrary,] wholesale makes them to find purchasers readily. (TA)
kasarotu Alr-ajula Eano muraAdihi † I turned the man, averted him, or turned him back, from his desire. (Mṣb.)
yakosiru canabahu baEoda maA OaXaAlahu [app. † He contorts his tail after raising it], said of a camel. (Ḳ.)

kasara Alv-awoba, and Aljiloda, † He folded, and he creased, the garment, or piece of cloth, and the skin. Ex. of the former signification, [in which the pronoun refers to a tent:] mino Hayovu yukosaru jaAnibaAhu [† Where its two sides are folded]. (Ṣ.) You say also kasara AlwisaAda, meaning ‡ He folded, or doubled, the pillow, or cushion, and leaned, or reclined, upon it. (Ḳ.) See also kaAsirN.

kasara jafonahu naHowahu † [He blinked, (lit. he wrinkled his eyelid) towards him]. (Mgh. art. gmz.) You say also, riyHN HaAr-apN takosiru AlEayona Har-FA † [A hot wind, that makes the eye to blink, or contract and wrinkle the eyelids, by reason of heat]. (Ḳ, art. xwS.) And kasara Eayonahu, (A,) and kasara mino Tarofihi, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He contracted (gaD-a, q. v.,) his eye, or eyes; [so as to wrinkle the lids; in which sense the former phrase is used in the present day:] (Ḳ:) and kasara EalaI Tarofihi, accord. to Th, he contracted (gaD-a) his eye, or eyes, somewhat: (TA:) [or perhaps EalaI is here a mistake for EalaI-a, in which case we must read Tarofahu, so that the meaning would be as above with the addition at me:] and mukaAsarapu↓ AlEayonayoni signifies AlmugaADanapu [i. e. the contracting of the eyes so as to wrinkle the lids]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. gDn.)

kasara AlT-aAYiru janaAHayohi, (A, TA,) aor. _i {yakosiru}, inf. n. kasorN; (TA;) and kasara alone, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. kasorN and kusuwrN, (Ḳ,) or in this case, when the wings are not mentioned, kusuwrN [only]; which shows that a verb, when its objective complement is forgotten [or suppressed], and the inf. n. [for AlHadiyvu in my original I read AlHadavu] itself is desired [to be expressed], follows the way of an intrans. verb; (A;) [for fuEuwlN is by rule the measure of the inf. n. of an intrans. verb, of the measure faEala, such as qaEada, inf n. quEuwdN, and jalasa, inf. n. juluwsN, and faEolN of that of a trans. verb;] ‡ The bird contracted his wings, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or contracted them somewhat, (TA,) so that he might descend in his flight, (Ṣ,) or in order to alight. (A, Ḳ.)

[kasara AlHarofa, aor. _i {yakosiru}, inf. n. kasorN, He pronounced the letter with the vowel termed kesr: and he marked the letter with the sign of that vowel. A conv. phrase of lexicology and grammar.]
See also 7.

2. ks-rhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. takosiyrN, (Mṣb,) is with teshdeed to denote muchness [of the action] or multiplicity [of the objects] (Ṣ) [He broke it much, in pieces, or into many pieces: or many times, or repeatedly; or he broke it, meaning a number or collection of things.]
fulaAnN yukas-iru Ealayoka Alfuwqa, or AlOaroEaAZa: see 1.
[ks-rhu also signifies He divided it (i. e. a number, and a measure,) into fractions.]
ks-rhu AlkaraI ‡ [Drowsiness made him languid]. (A, TA in art. hyD.)
[ks-r XaEarahu, inf. n. takosiyrN, † He crimped his hair, see raT-ala.]
ks-r AlmaMCu AlwaAdiI ‡ The water made [the kusuwr, i. e.,] the turnings, bendings, or windings, (maEaATif,) of the valley, and the parts thereof eaten away by torrents, to flow with water. (Th.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1.

5. tk-sr, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) quasi-pass. of 2, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) [It broke, or became broken, much, in pieces, or into many pieces; or many times, or repeatedly; or it (a number or collection of things) broke, or became broken.]

[Said of water, and of sand, † It became rippled by the wind. And of crisp hair, † It became crimped; or became rimpled, as though crimped. (In these senses it is used in the Ṣ in art. Hbk, &c. See HibaAkN.) Also said of the skin, † It became wrinkled: see tagaD-ana. Said of a garment, or piece of cloth, and of a coat of mail, and skin, † It became folded, and it became creased, much, or in several, or many places. See an ex. below, voce kisorN.]
[And hence, as meaning, † It became contracted,] said also of the eye. (TA in art. xXE.) [See 1.]

[‡ He was, or became, languid, or loose in the joints. And † He affected languor, or languidness: a very common signification.] You say, fiyhi taxan-uvN watakas-urN † [In him is effeminacy, and affectation of languor or languidness]. (A.) And one says of an effeminate man, tks-r fiI kalaAmihi † [He affected languor, or languidness, in his speech], (IDrd, O, voce tafar-aka,) and also maXoyihi [his walk]. (Ḳ, ibid.) See also 7.
7. Anksr, quasi-pass. of 1, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [It broke, or became broken.] You say, kasarotuhu↓ QnokisaArFA and Ainokasara kasorFA. (Sb, TA. See 1.)
Anksrt Als-ihaAmu EalaI Alr-uWuwsi † The portions became fractional to the several heads; were not divisible into whole numbers. (Mṣb.)
Anksr AlX-iEoru † The poetry became [broken, or] incorrect in measure. (TA.)
[Anksr Alqawomu † The people became broken, or defeated.]
Anksr xaSomiI ‡ [My adversary became defeated.] (A.)

[Anksrt nafosuhu † His spirit became broken, or subdued: and Anksr, alone, he became broken in spirit; his sharpness of temper, vehemence of mind, or fierceness, became broken, or subdued; he became meek, gentle, or humble.]
[Anksr, said of a man, also signifies, very frequently, ‡ He became languid, or languishing. See the act. part. n., below. And see 5.] fatorapN and AinokisaArN and DaEofN are syn. (Ṣ, art. ftr.)

Anksr Eani AlX-aIoCi † He lacked power, or ability, to do, or accomplish the thing. And Anksr [alone] † He, or it, (said of anything, [man or beast,]) remitted, flagged, or became remiss, in an affair, lacking power, or ability, to perform, or accomplish, it. (TA.)

Anksr naZaru AlT-arofi † The look of the eye, or eyes, became languid, or languishing; syn. fatara. (IḲṭṭ, in TA, art. ftr.) And Anksr Tarofuhu † [His eye, or eyes, or sight, became languid, or languishing, or not sharp]. (T, Ḳ, art. ftr.)

Also Anksr, said of the coldness of water, [and of cold, absolutely, and of the heat of water,] and of heat, [absolutely,] and of anything, (TA,) for instance, of a price, and so kasara↓, (Fr. in TA, art. qT,) † It abated, or became allayed; or, [said of heat,] it became languid, or faint. (TA.)
Said of dough, † It became soft, and leavened, or good, and fit to be baked. (TA.)

[Said of a garment, or piece of cloth, and skin, † It became folded; it became creased. Ex.:] yaTowiI Alv-iyaAba Oaw-ala Tay-ihaA Hat-aI tanokasira EalaI Tab-ihi [He folds the garments, or pieces of cloth, the first time of folding them, so that they may crease agreeably with his folding]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, voce qasaAmiI-N. [In one copy of the Ṣ, I find tatakas-ara in the place of tanokasira, which latter reading I find in a better copy of the same work.])
8: see 1, first sentence.

hom.sense: kasorN: see kisorN, throughout.

‡ A fraction, or broken part of an integral, as the half, and the tenth, and the fifth; (Mṣb;) what does not amount to an integral portion: (Ḳ:) pl. kusuwrN. (A, Mṣb.) You say, Daraba AlHus-aAbu Alkusuwra baEoDahaA fiI baEoDK ‡ [The calculator multiplied the fractions together]. (A.)
Little in quantity or number: (ISd, Ḳ:) as though it were a fraction of much. (ISd.)

† A crease, wrinkle, ply plait, or fold, in skin, and in a garment or piece of cloth; (JK, Ṣ,* Ḳ,* voce gar-N, in the CK gur-; and so accord. to the explanation of the pl. in the present art. in the TA;) as also makosirN↓: (accord. to the explanations of its pl. in the Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb voce gaDonN:) pl. of the former kusuwrN: (JK, Ṣ, voce gar-N; and TA in the present art.;) and of the latter, makaAsiru. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, voce gaDonN;, &c.)
See also kusuwrN, below.
[As a conventional term in grammar, A vowel-sound, well known; the sign for which is termed kasorapN↓.]

entry.sense:
kisorN and kasorN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) the latter of which is [said to be] of higher authority (OaEolaI) than the former, [but this is doubtful, for the former is certainly the more common,] (TA,) A portion of a limb: or a complete limb: (Ḳ:)
or a limb by itself, which is not mixed with another: (TA:) or half of a bone, with the flesh that is upon it: (Ḳ:) or a bone upon which there is not much flesh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and which is broken; otherwise it is not thus called: (Ṣ) or any bone: (AHeyth:) or a limb of a camel: (TA:) or of a human being or other: (ISd. TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OakosaArN (TA) and [of mult.] kusuwrN. (Ṣ, TA.)

kisru qabiyHK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and kasoru↓ qabiyHK, (Ṣ,) The bone of the saAEid [here meaning the upper half of the arm, from the part next the middle to the elbow]. (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also qabiyHN. And ksr HasanK signifies The upper part of that bone.]

Also kisorN and kasorN↓ The side of a bayot [or tent]: (Ḳ:) or the part of [each of] the two sides thereof that descends from the TariyqataAni [app. meaning the two outer poles of the middle row]; every tent having two such, on the right and left: (TA:) or the lowest Xuq-ap [or oblong piece of cloth] of a [tent of the kind called] xibaMC: (A, Ḳ:) or the part of that Xq-h which is folded or creased (takas-ara watavan-aI) upon the ground: (Ḳ:) or the lowest Xq-p of a bayot [or tent], that is next the ground, from where its (the tent's) two sides are folded (mino Hayovu yukosaru jaAnibaAhu), on thy right hand, and thy left. (ISk, Ṣ.)

Also, (Ḳ,) or kasorN↓ [only], (TA,) [but for this limitation there appears no reason,] A side (Ḳ, TA) of anything; as, [for instance,] of a desert: (TA:) pl. OakosaArN and kusuwrN [app. in all the senses: see above]. (Ḳ.)

qidorN kisorN, and OakosaArN, (TA,) and UinaMCN OakosaArN, (IAạr,) and jafonapN OakosaArN, (Ḳ,) A cooking-pot, (TA,) and a vessel, (IAạr,) and a bowl, (Ḳ,) large, and [composed of several pieces] joined together: (IAạr, Ḳ:) because of its greatness or its oldness: as though, in the second and following phrases, the term ksr applied to every distinct part of it. (TA.)
See also kusuwrN, below.

hom.sense: kasorapN † A defeat. You say, waqaEa Ealayohimu Alkasorapu Defeat befell them. (Mṣb.)
See also kasorN.

entry.sense: kisorapN (in some copies of the Ḳ kisorN, but this is a mistake, TA,) A piece of a broken thing: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or rather a piece broken from a thing: (TA:) or a fragment, or broken piece, of a thing: (Mṣb:) pl. kisarN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, kisorapN mino Alxubozi A broken piece of bread. (Mṣb.) See also kusaArN.

kisoraI and kasoraI, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more chaste, accord. to Th and others, and it alone is allowed by Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà, (Mṣb,) A name (TA) applied to the king of the Persians, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) or a surname of the kings of the Persians, (Ṣ,) like Aln-ajaAXiI-u, a name of the king of Abyssinia, (TA), arabicized from xusorawo, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which means “possessing ample dominion,” (Ḳ,) in the Persian language: so they say: but xusorawo is itself arabicized from xuwXo ruwo, which means, in that language, “goodly in countenance”: (TA:) [but that xsrw is an arabicized word may reasonably be doubted:] accord. to IDrst, it is changed into ksrI because there is no word in Arabic having the first letter with damm and ending with w; and the x is changed into k to shew that it is Arabicized: (MF:) the pl. is OakaAsirapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) contr. to analogy, (Ṣ,) and kasaAsirapN and OakaAsiru and kusuwrN, (Ḳ,) [all of which are also] contr. to analogy: (TA:) by rule it should be kisorawona, like Eiysawona (Ṣ, Ḳ) and muwsawona. (Ṣ.)
kisoriI-N: see kisorawiI-N.

kisorawiI-N and kisoriI-N↓ Of, or relating to, kisoraI; rel. ns. from kisoraI: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and kasorawiI-N alone is the rel. n. from kasoraI. (Mṣb.) [In the TA, it is said that one should not say kasorawiI-N; but it seems that what is not allowable is kasoriI-N.]

kusaArN and kusaArapN [Fragments, or broken pieces or particles, that fall from a thing:] what breaks from a thing: (Ṣgh:) or what breaks in pieces from a thing, (Ḳ, TA,) and falls: (TA:) fragments, or broken pieces or particles, (duqaAq, ISk, Ṣ, and HuTaAm, Ṣ,) of fire-wood. (ISk, Ṣ.) You speak of the kusaAr of glass, and of a mug, and of aloes-wood. (A.)

kusuwrN † The turnings, bendings, or windings, (maEaATif, Ḳ, TA,) and parts eaten away by torrents, (jirafap, TA,) and ravines, (XiEaAb, Ḳ, TA,) of valleys, (Ḳ, TA,) and of mountains: (TA:) a pl. without a sing.: (Ḳ:) you do not say kasoru AlwaAdiI nor kisoru AlwAdI. (TA.)
OaroDN caAtu kusuwrK ‡ A land having [places of] ascent and descent. (Ṣ, A.)
See also kasorN and kisorN.

kasiyrN i. q. makosuwrN↓, [Broken,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to a thing: (Ṣ:) and so the fem., without p: (TA:) pl. kasoraI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like as maroDaI is pl. of mariyDN, (Ṣ,) and kasaAraI: (Ḳ:) [and makaAsiyru is pl. of makosuwrN:] Abu-l-Ḥasan says, that Sb mentions the pl. makaAsiyru because it is of a kind proper to substs. (TA.)

nAqp kasiyrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) i. q. makosuwrapN [lit., A broken she-camel,] (Ḳ,) is like the phrase kaf-N xaDiybN, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning maxoDuwbapN: (TA;) or a she-camel having one of its legs broken: (Mgh:) and XaApN kasiyrN a sheep, or goat, having one of its legs broken: ksyr being of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and kasiyrapN also, [app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] like naTiyHapN: (Mṣb:) kasiyrN, occurring in a trad. is explained as signifying a sheep, or goat, having a broken leg, that cannot walk; (IAth,* Mgh;) but this requires consideration. (Mgh.)

‡ Folding or doubling, and leaning or reclining upon, a pillow or cushion. Hence the following. in a trad. of ʼOmar, lA yazaAlu OaHaduhumo kaAsirFA wisaAdahu Einoda QmoraOapK mugoziyapK, meaning, ‡ Not one of them ceases to fold or double his pillow or cushion at the abode of a woman whose husband is absent in war, and to lean or recline upon it, and enter upon discourse with her. (IAth, TA.)
‡ An eagle, (A, Ḳ,) and a hawk or falcon, (A,) contracting his wings, (A, Ḳ,) or contracting them somewhat, so that he may descend in his flight, (TA,) or in order to alight. (A, Ḳ.)
AlkaAsiru↓ The eagle. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
AlUikosiyru i. q. AlkiymiyaMCu q. v. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

jamoEu Alt-akosiyri † [The broken plural;] the plural in which the composition of the singular is changed; (Ḳ;) the change being either apparent, as in rijaAlN, pl. of rajulN, or understood, as in fulokN, which is both sing. and pl., for the ḍammeh in the sing. in this case is like the ḍammeh of qufolN, and that in the pl. is like that of OsodN. (Ibn-ʼAḳeel: see Dieterici's “Alfijjah”, &c.; pp. 329 and 330.)

Also takosiyrN † [The area of a circle]: in the circle are three things: daworN [or circumference] and quTorN [or diameter] and takosiyrN [or area], which [last] is the product of the multiplication of the half of the qTr by the half of the dwr: and it is sometimes called misaAHapN. You say, maA takosiyru daAYirapK quToruhaA saboEapN wadaworuhaA QvonaAni waEiXoruwna [What is the area of a circle of which the diameter is seven and its circumference two-and-twenty?]: and the answer is vamaAniyapN wavalaAvuwna waniSofN [Eight-and-thirty and a half]. (TA.) [It is scarcely necessary to add that this is not perfectly exact.]

makosirN A place of breaking, (Ḳ, TA,) of anything. (TA.) You say, EuwdN Sulobu Almakosiri [Wood, or a piece of wood, or a branch, or twig, hard in the place of breaking,] when you know its goodness by its breaking: (Ṣ, A:) and EuwdN Tay-ibu Almakosiri [Wood,, &c., good in the place of breaking,] i. e. approved. (Ḳ.)

Hence, rajulN Sulobu Almakosiri (A, L) ‡ A man who bears up against difficulty, distress, or adversity: because one breaks a piece of wood, to try if it be hard or soft. (TA.) And of a pl. number, humo SilaAbu AlmakaAsiri. (A.) And fulaAnN haX-u Almakosiri, (TA,) and Almukas-ari↓, (TA in art. hX, q. v.,) † [Such a one is easy, or compliant, when asked], which is an expression of praise when it means [lit.] that he is not one whose wood gives only a sound when one endeavours to produce fire from it; and of dispraise when it means [lit.] that be is one whose wood is weak. (TA.) And fulaAnN Tay-ibu Almakosiri † Such a one is praised when tried, proved, or tested: (Ṣ, TA:) and radiIoCu Almakosiri [dispraised when tried,, &c.]. (TA.) [Wherefore it is said that] makosirN also signifies † The internal state; an internal, or intrinsic, quality; the intrinsic, or real, as opposed to the apparent, state, or to the aspect; syn. maxobarN. (Ḳ.)
Also makosirN The lowest part (OaSolN Ḳ, TA) of anything; and especially of a tree, where the branches are broken off. (TA.)
[Hence] it is said to be metonymically used as meaning ‡ Old property. (TA voce faroEN.)
See also kasorN.
makosuwrN: see kasiyrN.
sawoTN makosuwrN † A soft, weak, whip. (TA.)
mukas-arN pass. part. n. of 2, q. v.
See also makosirN, with which it is made synonymous.
‡ A valley whose kusuwr (q. v.) flow with water: (Ḳ:) or are made to flow: (Th:) accord. to one relation of a saying in which it occurs, it is mukosarN. (TA.)
fulaAnN mukaAsiriI, (Ṣ,) or jaAriI mukaAsiriI, (ISd, Ḳ,) Such a one is my neighbour; (Ṣ;) the kisor (q. v.) of his tent is next the kisor of my tent. (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ.)
munokasirN has for its pl. makaAsiyru, which is extr.; like masaAHiyqu, pl. of munosaHiqN. (TA in art. sHq.) raOayotuhu munokasirFA ‡ I saw him in a languid, or languishing state. (A.)
kusoTN i. q. qusoTN (Ḳ) The wood with which one fumigates; being a dial. var. of the latter. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: ksE / ksf / ksl / ksm / ksw
dictScrap.label:
[ksE, ksf, ksl, ksm and ksw
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. kaXaOa, aor. _a {yakoXaOu}, He ate cucumber. (Ṣ.)

kaXaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ.) inf. n. kaXoCN, (Ṣ,) He ate food: (TA:) or he ate food in the same manner as one eats cucumbers; (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) chewing with the extreme grinders, or filling the mouth, (xaDomFA,) as in eating cucumbers and the like. (TA.)
kaXaOa and kX-O↓, He ate flesh-meat: [the latter] only used with reference to flesh-meat. (TA.)
kaXaOa He ate a piece of kaXiIoC. (TA.) [See also 4 and 5.]
kaXiYa mina AlT-aEaAmi, aor. _a {yakoXaOu}, inf. n. kaXoCN and kaXaMCN (Ḳ) and, accord. to some, kaXaON; (TA;) and tkX-O↓; (Ḳ;) He was, or became, filled with food. (Ḳ.)
kaXaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. kaXoCN; (Ṣ;) and AkXO↓; (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ:) He roasted meat until it became dry. (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kaXiYa It (a skin for water, &c.) had its inner skin appearing through its outer; (Ḳ;) as happens when a skin has been long folded, and has dried and broken in that state. (TA)
kaXiYato yaduhu His hand chapped; or its skin became rough and corrugated. (Ḳ.)
kaXaOa He peeled a thing: (Fr, Ḳ:) used with reference to a hide. (TA.)
kaXaOa wasaTahu He smote and cut his, or its, middle with a sword. (Ḳ, TA.)
kaXaOa Inivit feminam. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4. AkXO He ate. kaXiIoC. (TA.)
And see 1.
5. tkX-O All-aHoma He ate dry meat [see kaXiY], (Ṣ,) and was filled with it. (TA.) See 1.
tkX-O It became peeled. (Ḳ.)
tkX-O AlOadiymu The hide became peeled: [i. e., its outer layer of skin, or scarf-skin, was shaven, or scraped off]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: kaXoCN inf. n. of 1, q. v.
Roughness and corrugation [or chapping] in the skin of the hand. (TA.)

hom.sense: kaXiYN and kaXiIoCN Filled with food. (Ḳ.)
kaXiIoCN Meat roasted until it becomes dry. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: kuXoOapN A vice, fault, defect, blemish, or something amiss. (Ḳ.)
1. kaXaba, aor. _u {yakoXubu}, inf. n. kaXobN; and kX-b↓, inf. n. takoXiybN; He ate flesh-meat and the like with vehemence. (Ḳ, TA.)
2: see 1.

kaXuwvN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kuXuwvN and kaXuwvaI and kaXuwvaACu (of the fem. gender, Ibn-Buzruj, in TA, voce hinodabN) and OukoXuwvN but this last is a bad word, (Ḳ,) [as also XakuwvaI and XakuwvaACu,] [A species of cuscuta, or dodder;] a certain plant that clings to the branches of trees, having no root in the earth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also AlX-ajarapu Alxabiyvapu, in art. xbv. And see Alfaqodu and sakarN.]

A poet says,
huwa AlkaXuwvu falaA OaSolN walaA waraqN
walaA nasiymN walaA Zil-N walaA vamaru
[He is the Kashooth: therefore (he has) no root nor leaves nor fragrance, nor shade nor fruit]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. kaXaHa laHu biAlEadaAwapi; and kAXHhu↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. mukaAXaHapN and kiXaAHN; (L;) signify the same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He determined, or resolved, upon enmity to him: (L:) was inimical to him, (L, Ḳ,) and broke friendship with him: (L:) hated him and was inimical to him: bore a secret enmity to him. (L.)
kaXaHa He dispersed, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and drove away, (Ṣ,) a people. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kaXaHuwA Eani AlmaMCi, and AnkXHwA↓, They (a people, Ṣ) dispersed from the water: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) they went away from it, and dispersed: (TA:) they went back from it. (T.)
kaXaHa He went back; retired. (A.)
kaXaHahu He pierced, or stabbed, him in the part called kaXoHN. (TA.)
kaXaHa; (L;) and kX-H↓, (Kr, L,) inf. n. takoXiyHN; (Ḳ;) He cauterized, (Ḳ,) or marked with a hot iron, a camel (L) in the part called kaXoHN. (L, Ḳ.)
kuXiHa, inf. n. kaXoHN, He had a pain in his kaXoHN. (L.)
Also, (inf n. as above, Ṣ,) He was cauterized for the disease called kaXaHN. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
3: see 1.
7: see 1.

hom.sense: kaXoHN The HaXaI [i. e. the flank; or part between the false ribs and the hip; also explained in the TA by the word xaASirap]: (L:) or the part between the hypochondre and the false ribs, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and from near the navel to the portion of flesh and sinew next the back-bone: (L:) the part against which the sword hangs when a man is wearing it; and the part corresponding thereto on the other side: (T:) or each of the two sides of the belly, externally and internally, [or behind and before]; and so in a horse: (M:) or the waist: [see a verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys cited voce mucal-alN:] or the part from the top, or projecting portion, of the haunch-bone to the armpit: (L:) pl. kuXuwHN. (A.)
TawaI kaXoHFA He determined upon a thing, or affair, and persevered in his determination. (T.) [See an ex. voce Oab-a.]

TawaI kaXoHahu EalaI AlOamori He determined, or resolved, upon the thing, or affair, in his mind, syn. OaDomarahu: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and hid it, or concealed it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the L, and other lexicons, he persevered in the thing, or affair. (TA.)
TawaI kaXoHahu He went away, and cut the ties of kindred. (L.)

TawaI kaXoHahu Ean-iI He cut me, or cut the tie of friendship that united him to me, and broke off from me, abandoned me, or discarded me, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and became inimical to me: (L:) he turned away from me. (L.)

kaXoHN Either side of a wiXaAH; from which the kXH of the body is said to have its name, because the former hangs against the latter: (L:) or a wiXaAH [altogether]; so called because it hangs against the kXH of the body; in like manner as an UizaAr is called HaqowN: (A:) pl. kuXuwHN (TA.)
The kind of shells called cowries, or conchæ Veneris; syn. wadaEN: pl. kuXuwHN: (Ḳ:) or a wiXaAH made of such shells: OawoXiHap were made of white shells of that kind. (Aboo-Saʼeed Es-Sukkaree.)

entry.sense: kaXaHN A certain disease (which attacks a man, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in the kaXoH, (meaning the flank, xaASirap, TA,) and for which he is cauterized: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or the pleurisy, syn. caAtu Aljanob. (Ḳ.)
kuXaAHapN, a subst., A determining, or resolving, upon enmity to another: hating enmity: secret enmity: estrangement of oneself from another. (L.)
kiXaAHN A mark made by burning with a hot iron in the part called kXH. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

kaAXiHN One who determines, or resolves, upon enmity (yuDomiruhu) to another: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) a hating enemy: (L:) a secret enemy: as though he folded up enmity in his kaXoH; or as though he turned his kaXoH towards thee, and his face from thee; (ISd, L;) or because he conceals enmity in his kaXoH, in which is his liver, which is the seat of enmity and hatred; wherefore an enemy is called Oasowadu Alkabidi, as though enmity had burned his liver: (L:) or, accord. to some, one who estranges himself from another. (Mṣb.)
makoXuwHN A man cauterized for the disease called kaXaHN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) a man cauterized with the mark called kiXaAHN, below the ribs. (L.)
A man smitten with a sword in his kaXoH. (Ḳ.)

1. kaXara Eano OasonaAnihi, (M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yakoXiru}, inf. n. kaXorN; (M, Ḳ;) [and tkX-r↓, alone; (occurring in the Ṣ, Ḳ, voce kalaHa;)] He displayed his teeth, or grinned, (M, A, Ḳ,) in laughter, and otherwise. (M, Ḳ.) You say also kaXara Eano naAbihi He (a camel) displayed his tusk: (Ṣ:) and he (a beast of prey) snarled by reason of irritation. (TA.) And kaXara Eano OanoyaAbihi He (an enemy, and a beast of prey,) displayed his dog-teeth, or tusks. (A.) And UikoXiro Eano OanoyaAbika ‡ Threaten thou. (A.)

Also kaXara, inf. n. as above, He smiled, or laughed a little without any sound, so as to display his teeth: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:*) or he displayed his teeth in smiling. (TA.) And kaXara Uilayohi He smiled to him, displaying his teeth. (A.)
And kaXara fulaAnN lifulaAnK ‡ Such a one behaved ferociously to such a one, or became changed towards him, and threatened him. (TA.)

3. kAXrhu, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. mukaAXarapN, (A,) He displayed his teeth to him, or grinned to him: (Ḳ:) or he laughed in his face; and conversed, or acted with him without shyness or aversion, boldly, or in a free and easy, or cheerful, manner (wabaAsaTahu). (TA.)
5: see 1.

kiXorapN [The act of displaying the teeth, or grinning, to another: or laughing in the face of another, and looking at him in an open or a cheerful manner:] a subst. from kaAXara, (Ḳ, TA,) like hijorapN from haAjara, and EiXorapN from EaAXara. (Az, TA.)
