1. kaXaTa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yakoXiTu}, (Mṣb, MṢ,) inf. n. kaXoTN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He removed, put off, took off, or stripped off, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a thing (Mṣb, Ḳ) from (Eano) a thing which it covered; (Ḳ;) as, for instance, the housing, or covering, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from a horse, (Ḳ,) or from the back of a horse; (Ṣ;) and the cover from a thing; (Ṣ;) and the skin from a slaughtered camel: (TA:) and qaXaTa is a dial. var. thereof; (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ;) the former being of the dial. of Kureysh, (Yaạḳoob, accord. to the TA,) or of Keys, (M in art. qXT,) and the latter of the dial. of Temeem and Asad; the k not being a substitute for the q: (Yaạḳoob, TA:) and AstkXT↓ signifies the same. (Ḥam., p. 693.) It is said in the Ḳur, [lxxxi. 11,] waUicaA Als-amaMCu kuXiTato And when the heaven shall be removed from its place, like as a roof is removed from its place; (Zj, Ḳ;) and in like manner quXiTatN, (Zj, Ṣ,*) accord. to the reading of ʼAbd-Allah [Ibn-Mesʼood]: (Ṣ:) or shall be pulled off and folded together. (Fr.) And you say also, kaXaTa AlHarofa He removed the letter from its place. (TA.) And kuXiTa rawoEuhu, (TA,) inf. n. kiXaATN, (Ḳ,* TA,) ‡ His fright, or fear, became removed; (Ḳ,* TA;) and so AnkXT↓ rwEh: (TA:) or the latter signifies ‡ his fright, or fear, went away. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And kaXaTa Ald-aAb-aha and qaXaTahaA [He removed the housing, or covering, from the beast of carriage]. (TA in art. qXT.) And kaXaTotu AlbaEiyra, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (Mṣb,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) I skinned the camel: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) you should not say salaxotu; for the Arabs, in speaking of a camel, say only kaXaTotuhu and jal-adotuhu. (Ṣ.)
5. tkX-T Als-aHaAbu fiI Als-amaMCi The clouds became dissundered and dispersed in the sky. (TA.)
7. AnkXT Alt-uraAbu [The dust became removed, or cleared away, by the wind]. (T, TA in art. jwl.) See also 1.
kuXoTN i. q. qusoTN. (AA in TA art. qsT.)

hom.sense: kiXaATN: see kuXiTa.

The stripped skin of a slaughtered camel. (Lth, Ḳ.) Sometimes the latter is covered over with it; and one says, UirofaEo EanohaA kiXaATahaA liOanoZura UilaI laHomihaA [Take thou off from it its stripped skin, that I may look at its flesh.] (Lth, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: kaX-aATN: see what next follows.
Also, [its pls.] kaXaTapN (Lth, Ḳ,) and kaAXiTuwna (M, TA) The owners of a skinned camel. (Lth, M, Ḳ.)
jazuwrN makoXuwTapN [A skinned slaughtered camel]. (Ḳ.)

dictScrap.title: kXf / kXm / kXw / kS
dictScrap.label:
[kXf, kXm, kXw and kS
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. kaZ-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yakoZuZu}, inf. n. kaZ-N, (Ṣ,) It (food, Ṣ, Ḳ, and in like manner drink, TA) affected him with kiZ-ap, q. v.; (Ṣ,) filled him so that he could not breathe: (Ḳ:) filled him, and made him heavy. (TA.)
He, or it, made him sad, or sorrowful, by reason of much eating; inf. n. kaZ-apN. (Lth.)
He filled it (namely a skin for water or milk) so as to make it stretch. (TA.)
[And hence, app.,] He made it (namely a rope) firm, or fast. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)

kaZ-a AlgayoZu Sadorahu [in the TA kaZ-ah, which is evidently a mistranscription,] † Wrath, or rage, filled his bosom: and UikotaZ-ahu↓ AlgayoZu signifies the same as kaZ-ahu † [wrath, or rage, filled him]. (TA.)

kaZ-ahu AlOamoru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yakoZuZu}, inf. n. kaZ-N (TA) and kaZaAZN and kaZaAZapN, (Ḳ,) ‡ The affair, or case, oppressed him with grief; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) distressed him; (Ḳ, TA;) filled him with grief, or disquietude, or anxiety, and burdened him. (TA.)
kaZ-a xaSomahu † He bridled his adversary so that he found no way of escape. (TA.)
See also 8.

entry.sense: 3. kaAZ-a Alqawomu baEoDuhumo baEoDFA, inf. n. mukaAZ-apN and kiZaAZN, † The people, or company of men, straitened one another, or crowded together, and clave together, in the place of fight, in war; as also tkAZ-wA↓. (TA.) kiZaAZN signifies [likewise] † Long cleaving, or holding fast, (Ḳ, TA,) notwithstanding difficulty: (TA:) and vehement striving for the mastery in war or fight; as also mukaAZ-apN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and the latter, [or both,] † the exceeding the ordinary bounds in enmity; as also takaAZ-N↓. (TA.) You say, bayonahumo kiZaAZN † [Between them is vehement striving for the mastery in fight]. (Ṣ.) And it is said in a prov., layosa Oaxuw AlkiZaAZi mano yasoOamuhu † [He who is fitted for vehement striving for the mastery is not he who turns away from it with disgust]: meaning kaAZ-ihimo maA kaAZ-uwka † [Strive thou vehemently for the mastery with them as long as they so strive with thee]; i. e. do not thou turn away from them with disgust unless they so turn away from thee. (TA.) [Meyd relates it thus: Oaxuw AlkiZaAZi mano laA yasoOamuhu † He who is fitted for vehement striving for the mastery is he who does not turn away from it with disgust.] You say also, takaAZ-a↓ Alqawomu † The people, or company of men, exceeded the ordinary bounds in enmity. (Ṣ.) See also kiZaAZN below.
6: see 3, in three places.
8. AktZ- He became filled by food so that he could not breathe, (Ḳ,) and in like manner by drink. (TA.) It is also said of the belly. (TA.)

‡ It (a water-course) became straitened by the abundance of its flow of water; (Ṣ;) as also kaZ-a↓, [aor., accord. to general rule, _i;] (TA;) and so AktZ- biAlmaMCi: (Ḳ:) and AktZ- bivajiyji AlmaMCi ‡ it (a valley) became filled by the rain and torrent. (TA.) [See also R. Q. 1 and 2.]
AktZ- Alqawomu fiI Almasojidi † The people straitened, or crowded, one another in the mosque. (TA.)
AktZ-hu AlgayoZu: see 1.

R. Q. 1. kaZokaZa, inf. n. kaZokaZapN, It (a skin for water or milk) stretched when being filled: (Lth, Ḳ:) was seen to become even [more and more] as often as water was poured into it. (O, Ḳ.) [See also 8, and R. Q. 2.]

R. Q. 2. takaZokaZa He erected himself, sitting, as often as he filled his belly, (Lth, Ḳ,) becoming filled so that he could not breathe, (Ḳ,) after being seen to be in a bending posture, (Lth,) while eating. (Ḳ.)
It (a skin for water or milk) became filled, or full. (TA.) [See also 8, and R. Q. 1.]

hom.sense: kaZ-u [originally an inf. n.]

[Used as a simple subst.,] ‡ Grief, or disquietude, or anxiety, that fills the bosom: so in the saying of ʼOmar Ibn-ʼAbd-el-'Azeez, in speaking of death, wakaZ-N layosa kaAlokaZ-i, meaning And grief,, &c., that is not like other grief,, &c., but more vehement. (TA.) [See also ganoZN.]
It is also used as an epithet: you say rajulN kaZ-N ‡ A man whom affairs oppress, or distress, and overcome, so that he is unable to perform them. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.*)
And rajulN laZ-N kaZ-N † A man, hard, or difficult, in disposition. (Ṣ, L: in some copies of the former, kaZ-N laZ-N.) ISd thinks that kZ- is here an imitative sequent. (TA in art. lZ, q. v.)

entry.sense: kiZ-apN Repletion, or the state of being much filled, with food or drink: (M, Mgh,* Ḳ:) and a thing that befalls (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) a man, (Ṣ,) or an animal, (A,) in consequence of impletion [or repletion] with food: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) pl. OakiZ-apN. (TA.) Hence the trad. of En-Nakha'ee, AlOakiZ-apu EalaI AlOakiZ-api masomanapN makosalapN masoqamapN [Repletions upon repletions are causes of fattening, rendering heavy or lazy, diseasing]. (TA.)
kiZaAZN: see 3, of which it is an inf. n.
Also, † Difficulty, or distress, and fatigue, (Ḳ, TA,) in an affair, such as takes away the breath. (TA.) And † Grief, or disquietude, or anxiety, occasioned by war, filling the heart. (L.)

hom.sense: kaZiyZN A man replete with food. (Mgh.)
A skin for water or milk filled so as to be made to stretch; as also makoZuwZN↓. (TA.)

‡ A man oppressed, or distressed [and overcome, (see kaZ-N,)] by affairs, so as to be unable to perform them; as also makoZuwZN↓ and mukaZ-aZN↓: (Ḳ:) or all these signify ‡ grieved, and full of heaviness. (TA.)
† Angry, or enraged, in the most vehement degree. (TA.)
A state of fulness, or impletion. (TA.)
† A mutual straitening, or crowding together. (TA.) You say, EalaI baAbi fulaAnK kaZiyZN ‡ At the door of such a one is a crowding together. (Ḥar, p. 341.)

entry.sense: hecaA AlT-aEaAmu makaZ-apN This food is a cause of indigestion, and heaviness of the stomach. (TA.)
mukaZ-aZN: see kaZiyZN.
makoZuwZN: see kaZiyZN, in two places.
1. kaZaba, aor. _u {yakoZubu}, inf. n. kuZuwbN, He became full of fat: (IAạr, Ḳ:) like HaZaba. (TA.)
1. kaZara Alqawosa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yakoZuru}, (TḲ,) inf. n. kaZorN, (TA,) He made to the bow a kuZor, or notch to receive the ring of the string. (Ḳ.)
kaZara Alz-anodapa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He cut in the [piece of wood called] zndp a notch [from which to produce fire]. (Ḳ.)

kuZoru Alqawosi The notch in the curved extremity of the bow, in which is the string; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) the notch of the bow, into which falls the ring of the string: (A, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OakoZaArN (A) and [of mult.] kiZaArN and kiZaArapN. (TA.)
kuZoru Alz-anodapi The notch [from which the fire is produced] in the [piece of wood called] zndp. You say Aln-aAru tasiylu mino kuZori Alz-anodapi Fire flows from the notch of the zndp. (A.)
kiZorN The piece of sinew which is tied upon the base of the notch of an arrow. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 2. kaEaba Alv-adoIu, aor. _i {yakoEibu} and _u {yakoEubu}, (it seems to be implied in one place in the Ḳ, that the aor. is _a; but this is not the case; TA,) inf. n. kuEuwbN and kiEaAbapN (by MF written kaEaAbapN) and kuEuwbapN; and kE-b↓, inf. n. takoEiybN; The girl's breast swelled, or became prominent or protuberant, (Ḳ,) and round: (TA:) [or began to swell, &c.: see kaAEibN]: or they use the term tafoliykN; then nuhuwdN; and then takoEiybN; [as applied to the successive stages of growth of the breast]. (TA.) kaEabati AljaAriyapu, aor. _u {yakoEubu}, (and _i, TA,) inf. n. kuEuwbN; and kE-bt↓; [and tkE-bt↓; (A, TA in art. Ej;)] The girl had breasts beginning to swell, or become prominent, or protuberant: (IAth, Ṣ:) [or had swelling, prominent, or protuberant, breasts: see kaAEibN].

kaEabahu, inf. n. kaEobN, He beat him on a hard, or tough, part; as the head, and the like: (TA:) [and so kE-bh↓: for it is mentioned in the TA, that a certain king was surnamed AlmukaE-ibu from his beating the protuberances of people's heads].
kaEaba, aor. _a {yakoEabu}; (Ḳ;) and kE-b↓, inf. n. takoEiybN; (TA;) He filled a vessel (Ḳ), &c. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. [kE-b It (a reed, or cane,) put forth, or produced, its jointed stem.]
[Hence the phrase:] Uin-iI OaraI AlX-ar-a kaE-aba [† Verily I see the evil to have grown, like reeds when they put forth their jointed stems.] (TA, voce nab-aba.)
kE-b lababahaA He put to her breast-band [the pronoun app. referring to daAb-ap “a beast of carriage”] edges, or borders, like kuEuwb [app. meaning play-bones, or dice, or similar things.]. (TA.)
kE-b, inf. n. takoEiybN, He folded a garment, or piece of cloth, hard, or firmly, accord. to some, in a square form. (TA.) See also mukaE-abN.
He made it square, (Ḳ,) [or rather of a cubic form].
And see 1 in four places.

4. AkEb, inf. n. UikoEaAbN, He hastened: (Ḳ:) or he went away, paying no regard to anything: (TA:) or, inf. n. kaEaAbN, he went away injuriously (muDaAr-FA [an act. part. n.]) not caring for what was behind him, [or for the people whom he left behind him]: like kal-ala. (Aboo-Saʼeed.)

hom.sense: kaEobN Any joint, juncture, or place of division, of the bones. (Ḳ.)

Also, [and more commonly, The ankle-bone, or talus;] in a man, what projects above the tarsus, where the foot is set on; (TA;) what projects above the foot; (Ḳ;) the bone that projects at the place of junction of the shank and the foot; (AA, Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb;) each foot has two bones thus termed; one on the right and the other on the left; (Mṣb;) each of the two bones that project on either side of the foot; (Ḳ, TA:) or the anklejoint, or tarsal-joint; the joint that is between the shank and the foot: (IAạr, &c., Mṣb:) Aṣ rejected the saying of the [common] people, that it is in the upper part (Zahor) of the foot: (Ṣ:) some persons say, that it is each of the two bones that are in the upper part (Zahor) of the foot: so say the Shee'ah: and in like manner Yaḥyà Ibn-El-Hárith speaks of the kiEaAb as in the middle of the foot: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OakoEubN and [of mult.] kuEuwbN and kiEaAbN. (Ḳ.)
jaAriyapN daromaACu AlkuEuwbi A girl the heads of whose bones are not big [or prominent].

Also employed with reference to any quadruped; meaning, in a horse, What is between each waZiyf and saAq: or between the bone of the wZyf and the bone of the sAq; which projects backwards: [by this is meant, not the fetlock-joint, or hind fetlock-joint, but the hock: for it has been shown, voce Euroquwb, that the term kaEob, with reference to quadrupeds, is sometimes applied to what anatomists term the tarsus]. (TA.)

kaEobN and kaEobapN↓ [An ossicle] with which one plays; [a play-bone; a cockal-bone; the superior bone of the tarsus, called by anatomists astragalus or as tali, a little bone, somewhat oblong, taken from the foot of a sheep, or the like, thrown in play, like a die:] (Lḥ, Ḳ:) the die (faS-) that is used in the game of tables, or backgammon, (Aln-arod); (TA;) [any die that is used in play]: pl. (of the former word, TA) kiEaAbN and (of the latter, TA,) kuEobN and kaEabaAtN. (Ḳ: the last so written accord. to the TA; but in the CK kaEobaAtN.) The playing with the kEb is forbidden [Ḳur v. 92]. (TA.)
A conventional term of arithmeticians [a cube]. (Ḳ.)

‡ A piece of clarified butter; (Ṣ;) such [a lump, or compact piece] as is termed kutolap, thereof: (Ḳ:) and [a lump] of dates [compacted together]: (M, voce fidorapN:) a piece of clarified butter, or of fat or grease. (TA.)
‡ What is termed a Sum-ap (or what is poured out at once, or what remains in a vessel, &c., or a small quantity,) of milk, (Ḳ,) or of clarified butter. (TA.)

‡ [A knot, or joint, of a reed or cane;] what is between each two internodal portions of a reed or cane; (Ḳ;) the prominent part that is at the extremity of each of the internodal portions of a spear [of reed or cane]: (Ṣ:) or an internodal portion, or portion that is between each two knots, or joints, of a reed or cane: (Mṣb:) pl. kuEuwbN and kiEaAbN. (TA.)

By SArwA kEAbA, in the following verse,
raOayotu AlX-aEoba mino kaEobK wakaAnuwA
mina AlX-anoMni qado SaAruwA kiEaAbaA
the poet means, they were divided and opposed in mind or opinion, so that each portion that was of one mind, or opinion, became a party by itself. (AAF.) [He seems to compare them to play-bones thrown on the ground; or to the several joints, or knots, of a reed, or cane; or to a spear not equal, or uniform, in the joints, or knots, of its cane-shaft.]
rumoHN bikaEobK waAHidK A spear with equal, or uniform, knots, or joints; not having one knot, or joint, thicker than another. (TA.)
‡ Eminence, or nobility, and glory. (Ḳ.)
rajulN EaAliI AlkaEobi A man eminent, or noble, and successful in his enterprises. (TA.)
OaEolaI Qll-ehu kaEobahu May God exalt his glory! (TA, from a trad.)
laA yazaAlu kaEobuka EaAlyFA May thy glory not cease to be exalted! See EaAlK, in art. Elw. (TA.)
EalaA kaEobuka biI Thy nobility, or glory, hath exalted me. (TA.)
This signification is taken from the kaEob of a cane: and kaEobN is applied to Anything elevated. (IAth.)

entry.sense: kuEobN A girl's or woman's, breast, (Ḳ,) that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant. (TA.) See also kaAEibN.
kaEobapN see kaEobN.
Any square [or cubic] house, or chamber, or the like. (Ḳ.)
A chamber of the kind called gurofap: (Ḳ:) thought by ISd to be so called because of its square [or cubic] form. (TA.)

AlkaEobapu The Sacred House; [the square, or cubic, building, in the centre of the Temple of Mekkeh]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) said to be so called because of its square [or cubic] form: (Ṣ:) or because of its height and its square form: also called kaEobapu Albayoti [The Kaabeh of the House (of God)]. (TA.)

AlkaEabaAtu, (Ḳ,) or cuw AlkaEabaAti, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) A house [or temple] belonging to the tribe of Rabee'ah, who used to compass it, or perform circuits round it, [as is done round the Kaabeh of Mekkeh]. (Ṣ, Ḳ: in one copy of the Ṣ, written cuw AlkaEabayoni.)
kuEobapN A girl's virginity, or maidenhead: (Ḳ:) [the virgineal membrane: as shown by a verse cited in the TA].
kuEokub-N: see kuEokub-apN.

kuEokub-apN A nuwnap of hair: this is made by a woman's disposing her hair in four plaits, and inserting them, one in another; thus they (i. e. the plaits, TA) become [what are termed] kuEokub-N↓ [a coll. gen. n., of which kEkb-p is the n. un.]. (Ḳ.)
Also, and kuEokubiy-apN, A certain mode of combing, or dressing, the hair. (Ḳ.)
[These words are inserted in this art. in the Ḳ: but I think that they should be in a separate art., as quadriliteral-radical words; being of the same class as simosaArN, &c.]
jaAriyapN kaEaAbN A virgin. (TA.) See kaAEibN.

jaAriyapN kaAEibN, (this is the most common of the epithets here mentioned, TA,) and kaEaAbN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mukaE-ibN↓, (Ḳ,) and kaAEibapN, (KL,) and, as written by some, mukaE-ibapN↓, (TA,) A girl whose breasts are beginning to swell, or become prominent, or protuberant: (IAth, Ṣ:) or having swelling, prominent, or protuberant, breasts: see 1: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. of the first kawaAEibu and [of the first or second] kiEaAbN; the latter mentioned by Th; the former occurring in the Ḳur lxxviii. 33. (TA.)

vadoIN kaAEibN. and mukaE-ibN↓, and mukaE-abN↓, (in some copies of the Ḳ, mukoEabN, in either case extr., [the forms being those of pass. part. ns., and the signification that of an act. part. n.,]) and mutakaE-ibN↓, A girl's breast that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant: (Ḳ:) [or beginning to swell, &c.,: see 1, and see also kuEobN].
mukaE-abN see kaAEibN.

A burod, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a garment, or piece of cloth, variegated, or figured, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with squares. (Lḥ, Ṣ.) Some explain it as signifying variegated, or figured, without applying it particularly to a garment, or piece of cloth, or to a brd. (TA.)
A garment, or piece of cloth, folded hard or firmly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) accord. to some, in a square form. (TA.)
wajodN mukaE-ibN A hard and projecting face. (TA.)
mukaE-abapN The kind of basket called dawoHal-apN (Ḳ) and XawogarapN and waXaxapN. (TA.)
mukaE-ibN: see kaAEibN and 1.
mutakaE-ibN: see kaAEibN.

hom.sense: 4. AkEt, (inf. n. UikoEaAtN, TA,) He went away quickly. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
He sat down. (TṢ, Ḳ.)
He mounted [his beast] swollen with anger. (TṢ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: kaEotN Short: fem. with p {kaEotapN} (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an epithet applied to a man, and, with p, to a woman. (AZ, Ṣ.)
kuEotapN The cover of a glass bottle. (Ḳ.) So in the scholia in certain of the copies of the Ṣ, relied upon for accuracy. (TṢ, L.)
kuEayotN The [bird called] bulobulN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a small bird (EuSofuwrN) called by the people of El-Medeeneh nugarN: (IAth:) pl. kiEotaAnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Q. 2. takaEovabati AlEaraArapu The ErArp (with an unpointed E meftoohah, the name of a certain plant; (TA;) in the CK, giraArap, or sack;) became collected together, and round. (Ḳ.)
rakabN kaEovabN (as also kavoEabN, TA) A large (and full and prominent, TA) pubes, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or pudendum: (TA:) a prominent, compact, pubes. (Fr.) Pudendum muliebre. (ISk.)
kaEovabN (as also kavoEabN, TA) A woman having a large (and full and prominent, TA) pubes, (Ḳ,) or pudendum. (TA.)
kaEodabN and kaEodabapN A base, unmanly, person. (Ḳ.)
kuEodubapN Bubbles that float upon the surface of water; (Ḳ;) resulting from rain: (TA:) a bubble floating upon the surface of water, &c. (TA): or a spider's web: (AA:)
Also, Stones. (TA.)
All these significations are also assigned to juEodubapN. (TA, art. jEdb, q. v.)
Q. 1. He ran (Ḳ) vehemently: like kaEoZala: (TA:) and fled: (Ḳ:) like kaEosama: (TA:) or he ran slowly: or he walked quickly: or he walked in the manner of a drunken man. (Ḳ.)
kuEokubN, &c.: see art. kEb.

hom.sense: kaEonabN Short: (Ḳ:) an epithet applied to a man. (Az.)
AlkaEonabu and AlkuEaAnibu The lion. (Ḳ.)
kaEaAnibu Knobs, or protuberances, (EujarN,) of the head. (Ḳ.) kaEonabN A man having knobs, or protuberances, (EujarN,) on his head. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: tayosN mukaEonabu Alqaroni A he-goat having the horn curved so as to resemble a ring: (Ḳ:) like muXaEonab, q. v. (TA.)

kaAgadN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and kaAgidN, (L, TA,) Paper; syn. qiroTaAsN [which seems to be properly paper made of the papyrus]: (Ḳ:) a Persian word, (L,) arabicized. (L, Ḳ.) The d is sometimes changed into c, (Mṣb, TA,) and into T. (TA.)
kaAgadiI-N [A maker, or seller, of paper.]
kaAgacN i. q. kaAgadN. (L, Ḳ.)

1. kafaOa He turned a thing over; as a man turns over a cake of bread in his band until it becomes even. yatakaf-aOu↓ occurs in a trad. respecting the Day of Resurrection, accord. to one relation, for yakofaOu, in this sense: it is said that the earth will be like a single cake of bread, which God will turn over in his hand, as a man in a journey turns over a cake of bread. (TA.) kafaOa, (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. kafNCN and kafaMCapN; (TA;) and AkfO↓, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AktfO↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) but the first word is said to be the most chaste; He inverted, or turned upside-down, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a vessel, &c. (Ṣ, TA.) [You say] kufiYato jafonatuhu [His bowl was turned upside-down; meaning] ‡ He was slain: a phrase similar to huriyqa rifoduhu. (A in art. rfd.)

kafaOa (TA) and AkfO↓, (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latte of the rare dial., accord. to Ks, and rejected by Aṣ, (TA,) He inclined, or made to turn aside or incline, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a bow, in shooting with it, and a vessel, (Ks, Ṣ,), &c. (TA.) And kafaOa (TA) and AkfO↓, (Ḳ,) and AnkfO↓ (TA) He, or it, inclined: intrans. (Ḳ, TA.)

kafaOahu Eano XaIo, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. kafoCN, (Ṣ, TA,) He turned him away, or back from a thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as from a thing that he desired to do, to another thing. (Ṣ, TA.) And kafaOa Eano XaIoCK He turned away, or back, from a thing: intrans. (TA.) [See also 4 and 7.] kafaOa Alqawumu The people turned away, or back. (Ḳ.) [See also 7.]
kafaOa He drove away a man, (Ḳ,) or camels. (L.)
kafaOa AlUibila He made an assault upon the camels, and took them away. (TA.)
kafaOa He followed, or pursued, another. (Ḳ.)
kafaOa Alganamu fiI AlX-iEobi The sheep entered the ravine. (Ḳ.)
kafaOa lawonuhu, and AkfO↓ lwnh, and tkf-O↓ lwnh, (TA,) and AnkfO↓ lwnh, (Ḳ,) (as also Ankft lwnh, TA,) ‡ His, or its, colour changed. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 3. kAfOhu EalaI XaIoCi, inf. n. mukaAfaOapu and kifaOCN, He requited, compensated, or recompensed, him for a thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
maA liI bihi qibalN walaA kifaMCN I have not power to requite him. (Ṣ.)
kAfOh, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mukaAfaOapN and kifaMCN, (TA,) He was like him; was equal to him; equalled him. (Ḳ.)
kAfOh He watched him; observed him. (Ḳ.)
kAfO, (Ḳ,) inf. n. mukaAfaOapN, (TA,) He repelled; turned, or put away; kept away, or off; withstood, or resisted. (Ḳ, TA.)
kAfO bayona faArisayoni birumoHihi He thrust this horseman, and then that, with his spear. (Ḳ, TA.)
kAfO byn AlbaEiyrayoni He stabbed this camel, and then that. (Z.)
laA mukaAfaOapa EinodiI fiI kacaA There is no concealment with me in respect of such a thing; as also lA muHaAjaApa. (TA in art. Hjw.)
4: See 1, in four places.
AkfO fiI sayorihi Eani AlqaSodi, (TA,) or kafaOa, (Ḳ,) He deviated, or turned aside, in his journey, from the object he had in view. (Ḳ,* TA.)

AkfO AlUibila kafoOatayoni He divided the camels into two equal numbers, setting apart the one half for breeding during one year, and the other half for breeding during the next. It was esteemed the best plan, by the Arabs, to leave a she-camel for one year after her breeding, without suffering the stallion to cover her; in like manner as land is left fallow for a year. (Ṣ, TA.)
The same is also said of sheep, &c. (TA.)

AkfOh Uibilahu waganamahu (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA) He assigned to him the profits, (Ḳ,) or the profits for a year, (Ṣ,) of his camels and his sheep or goats; (Ḳ, TA;) i.e., their hair and wool, milk, and young ones. (Ṣ, TA.)
AkfOt AlUibilu Many of the camels had young ones in their wombs. (Ḳ.)
AkfO Albayota, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UikofaMCN, (Ṣ,) He made for the tent a kifaMC. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

AkfO, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UikofaACN, (TA,) in poetry, accord. to a commentary on the Káfee, He used as the rawiI- two letters having their places of utterance near to each other; as T with d: [such is the signification of the verb accord. to general usage in the present day:] or, accord. to the Ahkám el-Asás, he changed the rwI- from r to l, or l to m: or he made a similar change of one letter to another having its place of utterance near to that of the former: or it has another signification, given below, accord. to the same authority: (TA:) or he used different letters in the rhymes; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) whether letters having their places of utterance near to each other, or the contrary; (TA;) or in some m and in some n and in some d, and in some T, and in some H, and in some x, &c.; as says AZ; and this is the meaning known to the Arabs: (Ṣ:)
or he used different vowels in the rwI-: (Fr, Ṣ:) or i. q. OaqowaI: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the Ahkám el-Asás, it signifies either as explained above on that authority, (TA,) or he used different final inflections in the rhymes: (Ḳ:) or he changed the final vowel in the rhyme; ending one verse with Dam-ap, and another with kasorap, [which are the two vowels that resemble each other]: (TA:) [see a verse cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. gyb:] or he impaired the end of a verse in any way. (Ḳ.) Eloquent Arabs explained the meaning of the verb in this last manner to Akh, without defining any particular kind of impairment: but one made it to consist in the use of different letters. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tkf-O It (a vessel, &c.) was inverted, or turned upside-down. (TA.) See also 1, in two places.

tkf-O (as also tk-fI, inf. n. takaf-K; but the original word is that with hemzeh;) He inclined forwards, in walking, as a ship inclines in her course. Moḥammad is said to have walked in this manner, which is indicative of strength. (TA.) [And so] tkf-Ot She (a woman) moved her body from side to side, in walking, as the tall palm-tree moves from side to side. (Ṣ.) [And] She (a ship) inclined forwards in her course. (TA.) [See an ex., voce OaEoraba, in this sense; or, as implied in the Ṣ, in the sense immediately preceding.]
6. takaAfaM They two were like, or equal, each to the other. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

tatakaAfaOu dimaAWuhumo Their blood (i. e., the blood of the Muslims,) shall be equally retaliated, or expiated: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) i. e., the noble shall have no advantage over the ignoble in the retaliation or expiation of blood. (AʼObeyd.)
7. AnkfO He turned, or was turned, away, or back, from a thing that he desired to do; (Ṣ;) [see also 1;] he returned, or went back, or reverted. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, (TA,) or kafaOa↓, (Ḳ,) It (a party) became routed, defeated, or put to flight. (Ḳ, TA.)
See 1, in two places.
8: See 1.
AktfO Oaholiyhimo waOamowaAlahumo [He carried off their families and their goods.] (TA, from a trad.; mentioned next after the explanation of kafaOa AlUibila.)
10. AstkfOh Uibilahu He asked him for a year's produce of his camels; i.e., their young ones in the womb in one year; (Ṣ, TA;) or their hair and wool, milk, and young ones, of one year. (TA.)
AstkfOh naxolapF He asked him for a year's produce of a palm-tree. (TA.)
kafoCN and kufoCN and kifoCN and kufuWN see kifaACN, and for kifoCN see also kafiIoCN.

kafoOapN and kufoOapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) The young ones in the wombs of camels, in one year: or those after the dams have not conceived for one year or more: (Ḳ:) or a year's produce of camels [&c.]; i. e., their hair and wool, and their milk, as well as their young ones. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say OaEoTiniI kfOpa naAqatika Give me the year's produce, &c., of thy she-camel. (Ṣ.)
And, both words ‡ A year's produce of a palm-tree. (Ḳ.)
‡ A year's produce of a piece of land. (Ḳ.) See also 4.
kufoOapN: see kafoOapN.
kafaMCN (Ḳ) and kafaOCapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) Likeness; equality. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kafaOCN A slight inclination, to one side, of a camel's hump, and the like. This is the slightest of faults in a camel; for when the camel grows fat, his hump becomes erect. (TA.)

hom.sense: kafaMCN, originally an inf. n. [of 3], and kufoCN↓ and kufuwoCN [&c., as in the following examples,] Like; equal; a match. (Ṣ.)

hecaA kifaAWuhu, and kafiyoYatuhu↓, and kafiyWuhu↓, and kufoWuhu↓, and kafoWuhu↓, and kifoWuhu↓, (in the CK, kafuWuhu,) and kufuwoWuhu↓, (in the CK, kufuWuhu,) This is like, or equal to, him or it: (Ḳ:) And laA kifaMCa lahu There is no one, or nothing, like, or equal, to him, or it. (Ṣ.)

Zj says, that the words of the Ḳur-án, walamo yakuno lahu kufuWFA OaHadN (cxii. 4,) may be read in four different ways: kufuWFA↓ and kufoYFA↓ and kifoYFA↓ (in which three ways the word has been read) and kifaACF (in which last way it has not been read.) Ibn-Ketheer and AA and Ibn-'Ámir and Ks read kufuWFA: Hamzeh read kufoYFA; and, in a case of pause, kufaA, without hemzeh. (TA,)
Pl. (of kufoCN and kifoCN, and kufuWN, and perhaps of kafoCN also, MF,) OakofaMCN and (of all the above forms excepting kifaMCN, MF,) kifaMCN. (Ḳ.)
kifaMCN As much as is equal to another thing. (L.)
AlHamodu lil-hi kifaMCa AlwaAjibi Praise be to God, as much as is incumbent. (Ḳ.)

kifaMCN A curtain (sutorap) extending from the top to the bottom of a tent, at the hinder part: or an oblong piece of staff at the hinder part of the kind of tent called xibaAC: or a kisaMC that is thrown upon a xbAC, so as to reach the ground: (Ḳ:) or an oblong piece of stuff, or two such pieces well sewed together, attached by the kind of wooden pin called xilaAl to the hinder part of a xbAC: (Ṣ:) or the hinder part of a tent: pl. OakofiYapN. (TA.) See miZal-apN in art. Zl.
kafiIoCu All-awoni, and makofuwoCu↓ Allwn, (Ḳ,) and makotafiYu↓ Allwn, (TA,) ‡ Changed in colour: (Ḳ:) said of the countenance and of other things: as also mukotafitu Allwn. (TA.)
Also, mukofaOu Alwajohi Changed in countenance. (TA.)
See kifaMCN.
kafiIoCN and kifoCN↓ (as in the CK and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ) or kifiIoCN (as in the TA) The bottom, or interior, or inside, (baTon,) of a valley. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: kufuwoCN: see kifaMCN.
kafaMCapN: see kafaMCN.
In marriage, Equality of the husband and wife in rank, religion, lineage house, &c. (L,)
OakofaOu, fem. kafoOaI, A camel whose hump inclines slightly to one side. (TA.)
A camel's hump inclining to one side. (ISh.)
mukofiYu AlZ-aEoni The last of the days called Oay-aAmu AlEajuwzi. (TA.) [See Ejwz.]
makofuwoCu All-wn: see kafiIoCN.
mukaAfiYN Being like, or equal to: equalling. (Ṣ.)

Also, in the following words of a trad., kaAna laA yaqobalu Alv-anaMCa Uil-aA min m-ukaAfiYi, said to signify One of known sincerity in professing himself a Muslim: (IAmb:) or one not transgressing his proper bounds, nor falling short with respect to that [religion] to which God hath exalted him- (Az.)

XaAtaAni mukaAfiYataAni, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mukaAfaOataAni. (Ḳ,) as the relaters of trads. say, (Ṣ,) in a trad. respecting the Eaqiyqap for a male child, (Ṣ, TA,) Two sheep, or goats, of equal age. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Some assign to these words meanings slightly differing from the above; as, similar, one to another: also, slaughtered, one immediately after the other: (TA:) or slaughtered, one opposite to the other. (Ṣ.)
mukotafiYu All-wn: see kafiIoCN.

hom.sense: 1. kafata, [aor. _i {yakofitu},] inf. n. kafotN, It (a thing) turned over, lit, back for belly: (Ḳ:) or, as in a copy of the L, he turned a thing over, back for belly. (TA.)
kf-thu↓ Qll-ehu God took him; syn. qabaDahu: meaning he died: and so kftp Qll-eh Alyh. (TA.)

kafatN, [aor. _i {yakofitu},] (Ṣ, Ḳ) inf. n. kafotN and kifaAtN and kafiytN and kafataAnN, (Ḳ,) He, or it, hastened, or was quick, or swift: (Ṣ:) it (a bird, &c.) hastened, or was quick, or swift, in flying, and running, and contracted itself therein: (Ḳ:) it (a solid-hoofed animal) contracted its fore-legs quickly in running: (Az:) the kind of running and flying termed kafataAnN is like a turning aside, or starting aside, (HayadaAnN) with violence, or vehemence. (TA.)
kafatahu, [aor. _i {yakofitu},] inf. n. kafotN, He drove him, or urged him on, vehemently. (Ṣ.)

kafata AlX-aIoCa Uilayohi, (aor. _i {yakofitu}, inf. n. kafotN, Ṣ,); and kf-th↓; (but the latter has an intensive signification; Ṣ;) He drew the thing together to himself, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and contracted it, grasped it, or took it. (Ḳ.) [See an ex. of the latter verb in a verse cited voce raAjilapN.]
UikofituwA SiboyaAnakumo biAll-ayoli (Ṣ) Draw together your boys, and confine them in the houses, or tents, at night. (AʼObeyd.) Said by Moḥammad.

nuhiynaA Oano nakofita Alv-iyaAba fiI AlS-alaApi We have been forbidden to draw together the clothes [that are upon us] in prayer: meaning, in the inclination of the body, and in prostration. (TA, from a trad.)

kafata Ald-iroEa biAls-ayofi, aor. _i {yakofitu}; and kf-thA↓; which latter has an intensive signification; He hung the coat of mail [i.e. the lower part of it] by means of, or upon, the sword [which he was wearing], and then drew it together to him. Zuheyr says, describing a coat of mail, of which the wearer had hung upon the sword the redundant lower portions, and drawn it together to him,
wamufaADapK kaQln-ahoIi tanosijuhu AlS-abaA
bayoDaACa kaf-ata faDolahaA bimuhan-adi
[And an ample coat of mail, like the pool which the east wind ripples in transverse directions; white; the redundant lower parts of which he had hung upon the sword of Indian steel, and which he had then drawn together to him.] (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.

hom.sense: 3. kAfthu He contended with him in running, or in a race. (Ḳ.)
maAta kifaAtFA, and mukaAfatapF, He died suddenly. (Ḳ.)
7. Ankft He turned away, or became averted, or diverted, [Eano wajohihi from his course, or design]. (Ḳ.)
He returned [En wjhh from his course, or design; and] UilaI manozilihi to his abode. (TA.)
He, or it, became contracted; (Ḳ;) and so Astkft↓. (TA in art. skf.)
It (a garment) was drawn up, or tucked up, and contracted. (TA.)
He was compact in make. (Ḳ, TA.)
He (a horse) was lean, lank, slender, light of flesh, or lank in the belly. (Ḳ.)
Ankft lawonuhu His, or its, colour changed. (TA, art. kfO.)

entry.sense: 8. Aktft AlmaAla He took the whole of the property, (Ḳ,) and drew it together to himself. (TA.)

hom.sense: kafotN and kafiytN↓ (and kafitN↓, Ks) A man quick or swift, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and light, active, or agile, and slender: (Ḳ:) so too a horse. (TA.)
EadowN kafiytN↓, and kifaAtN↓, [the latter originally an inf. n.] A quick, or swift, running: and so a passing by, or through. (L.)
[Hence] kafotN ‡ Death. (Ḳ.)
xubozN kafotN Bread without seasoning; without savoury food. (Ḳ.)
See also kifotN.

kifotN (Ṣ, Z, Ḳ, &c.) and kafotN↓ (Fr. Ḳ) and kafitN↓ (Z) A small cooking-pot. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) It is said, in a proverb, kifotN UilaI waYiy-apK [A small cooking-pot (put) next to a large one]: i.e. a calamity next to which is another calamity. (Ṣ, TA.) Applied to him who oppresses a man, and compels him to do that which is disagreeable to him, and then adds to his oppression of him. (AʼObeyd.) [See also Freytag, Arab. Prov. ii. 349.]
See kafiytN.

entry.sense: kafitN: see kafotN and kifotN.

farasN kufatN, and kufatapN, A horse that leaps, springs, or bounds, with his whole body and limbs, and so that one cannot get possession of him, or obtain the mastery over him. (Ḳ.) See also art. klt.
kft [written without the syll. points] A certain herb. (See kaf-u Alkalobi, in art. klb.)

kifaAtN A place in which a thing is drawn together, or comprehended, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and collected, or congregated. (Ḳ.) So in the words of the Ḳur [lxxvii. 25 and 26,] Oalamo najoEali QloOaroDa kifaAtFA OaHoyaACF waOamowaAtFA [Have we not made the earth a place which comprehends the living and the dead? meaning kifaAta OaHoyaACK waOamowaAtK:] (Ṣ:) EshShaabee, pointing to the houses of El-Koofeh, said, hecihi kifaAtu AlOaHoyaACX; and then, turning to its tombs, he said, hedhi kifaAtu AlOamowaAti; meaning to explain the above text of the Ḳur: but ISd thinks, that kfAtA in this text is an inf. n., and that AHyAC and AmwAtA are governed by it in the acc. case. (TA.)

hom.sense: kafiytN: see kafotN.
See kifotN.
kafiytN A traveller's provision-bag that does not lose [or suffer to escape] anything (Ḳ) of what is put into it: you say jiraAbN kfytN: (TA:) as also kifotN↓. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Alkaf-aAtu The lion. (TṢ, Ḳ.)

mukofitN One who wears two coats of mail with a garment between them: (Ḳ:) or who wears a long coat of mail, and draws together its skirt by means of hooks, or the like, to loops in its middle part, to disencumber himself of the lower part. (T.)

hom.sense: 1. kafaHahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. kafoHN; (Ṣ;) and kaAfaHahu↓, inf. n. mukaAfaHapN and kifaAHN; (Ḳ;) [the latter form of the verb the more common;] He faced him; confronted him; encountered him; met him face to face: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or he met him, or encountered him, face to face, suddenly, or unexpectedly. (T, M.) [You say] laqiytuhu kifaAHFA↓, (Ṣ,) and mukaAfaHapF↓, and kafoHFA, (TA.) I met him face to face. (TA.) [And] kal-amahu Qll-ehu kifaAHFA↓ God spoke to him face to face, without anything intervening between them. (TA from a trad.)

kafaHahaA, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yakofaHu}; (Ṣ;) and kaAfaHahaA↓, inf. n. as above; (Ḳ;) He kissed her suddenly, unexpectedly, or unawares: (Ḳ:) or he met her face to face, or encountered her, with a kiss: (Ṣ:) or he kissed her with full ability, and completely, without snatching the kiss: (T:) or he made his skin to meet, and come in contact with hers. (AʼObeyd.)

kaAfaHuwA↓ (in war) signifies They contended together with swords face to face: (L:) or kaAfaHuwhumo↓, they encountered them in war face to face, having before their faces neither shield nor anything else. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)
Also kAfH↓ Eanohu He contended for him, and defended him. (L.)
kaAfaHotu↓ Als-amuwma ‡ [I faced, or encountered, the hot wind called samuwm]. (A.)
kAfHhu↓ bimaA saMCahu ‡ [He encountered him with that which displeased or vexed him]. (A.)
kAfHhu↓, inf. n. mukaAfaHapN, ‡ He refelled him by an argument, a plea, a proof, or an evidence: as though the argument, &c. were likened to a sword, or other weapon. (MF.)

kafaHa lijaAma Ald-aAb-api, (inf. n. kafoHN, TA,) He drew, or pulled, the bridle and bit of the beast of carriage; as also OakofaHahu↓: (Ḳ:) or, as in the T and M, kafaHa Ald-aAb-apa biAlil-jaAmi he pulled the beast of carriage by the bridle and bit. (TA.) [See also 4.]

entry.sense: 3: See 1, throughout.
fulaAnN yukaAfiHu AlOumuwra ‡ Such a one superintends, manages, or conducts, affairs himself, or in his own person. (Ṣ, A.)
4. AkfH Ald-aAb-apa, inf. n. UikofaAHN, He put the bit to the mouth of the beast of carriage, striking the mouth with it, in order that the beast might take it into its mouth. (T, Ṣ.)
See also 1.
5. takaf-aHati Als-amaAYimu ‡ The hot winds called smAYm met, or encountered, one another. (L.)
6. takaAfaHuwA [They faced, confronted, or encountered, one another; or met face to face]. (A.)
takaAfaHati AlkibaAXu [The rams butted one another.] (A.)
takaAfaHati AlOamowaAju ‡ [The waves met and dashed together.] (A.)
OaSaAbahu mina Als-amuwm lafoHN wamina AlHaruwri kafoHN ‡ [A burning gust of the hot day-wind smote him, and a blast of the hot night-wind meeting him in the face]. (A.)

hom.sense: kafiyHN A husband: (Ḳ:) so called because he beholds his wife face to face. (TA.)
A bedfellow, syn. DajiyEN, (A, Ḳ,) of a woman. (TA.)
A guest coming suddenly, or unexpectedly. (Ḳ, TA.)
Like; or equal; syn. kufoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and nadiydN. (TA.)

entry.sense: mukaAfiHN ‡ One who superintends, manages, or conducts, affairs himself, or in his own person. (TA.) See 3.

hom.sense:
1. kafara AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor., in the sense first explained below _i; (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.;) [respecting which Fei observes,] ElFárábee, whom J follows, says that it is like yaDoribu, but in a trustworthy copy of the T it is written _u, and this is the proper form, because they say that kafara Aln-iEomapa [of which the aor. is _u] is borrowed from kafara AlX-aIoCa in the sense which is first explained below; (Mṣb;) and MF says, that the saying of J, following his maternal uncle Aboo-Naṣr El-Fárábee, that the aor. of this verb is _i, is doubtless a mistake; but to this, [says SM,] I reply, that it is correctly _i, as J and F and other leading lexicologists have said; though the aor. of the verb of kuforN as meaning the contr. of UiyomaAnN is _u; (TA;) [or, if this latter verb be taken from the former, the aor. of the former may have been originally _i and _u, and general usage may have afterwards applied the aor. _i {yakofiru} to one signification, while the aor. _u {yakofuru} has been applied by very few persons to that signification, but by all to the significations thence derived;] inf. n. kaforN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and kf-rhu↓, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. takofiyrN; (TA;) He veiled, concealed, hid, or covered, the thing: (Ṣ, A,* Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or he covered the thing so as to destroy it: (Az, TA:) and kafara Ealayohi, aor. [and inf. n.] as above, he covered it; covered it over. (Ḳ,) You say kafara Albacora Qlomabocuwra He covered the sown seed with earth. (TA.) And kafara Als-aHaAbu Als-amaMCa The clouds covered the sky. (A.) Lebeed says,
fiI layolapK kafara Aln-ujuwma gamaAmuhaA
In a night whereof the clouds that covered the sky concealed the stars. (Mṣb.) You say also kafarahu All-ayolu, and kafara Ealayohi, The night covered it with its blackness. (TA.) And kafarati Alr-iyHu Alr-asoma The wind covered the trace or mark [with dust.] (A.) And kafara fawoqa diroEihi He clad himself with a garment over his coat of mail. And kaf-ara↓ diroEahu bivawobK He covered his coat of mail with a garment. (TA.) And kafara mataAEahu He put his goods in a receptacle. (TA.) And kafara QlomataAEa fiI AlwiEaMCi He covered, or concealed, the goods in the receptacle. (A.) And kaf-ara↓ nafosahu biAls-ilaAHi He covered himself with the arms. (A.) And kafara Aljaholu EalaI Eilomi fulaAnK Ignorance covered over the knowledge of such a one. (TA.) wakayofa takofuruwna, [thus, with damm as the vowel of the aor.,] in the Ḳur, iii. 96, has been explained as signifying And wherefore do ye cover the familiarity and love in which ye were living? (TA.)

Hence, (Mṣb, TA,) kafara, (Ṣ,) and kafara Aln-iEomapa, and biAln-iEomapi; (Mṣb;) and kafara niEomapa Qll-ehi, and biniEomapi Qll-ehi; (Ḳ;) aor. _u {yakofuru}, (TA,) inf. n. kuforaAnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is the most common form in this case, (El-Basáïr,) and kufuwrN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and kuforN; (El-Basáïr;) He covered, or concealed, (Mṣb,) and denied, or disacknowledged, the favour or benefit [conferred upon him]; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) he was ungrateful, or unthankful, or behaved ungratefully or unthankfully; contr. of Xakara; (Ṣ;) and he denied, or disacknowledged, and concealed, or covered, the favour or benefit of God: (Ḳ:) God's favours or benefits are the signs which show to those who have discrimination that their Creator is one, without partner, and that He has sent apostles with miraculous signs and revealed scriptures and manifest proofs. (Az, TA.) walaA nakofuruka, in the prayer [termed Alqunuwtu], means walaA nakofuru niEomataka [And we will not deny, or disacknowledge, thy favour; or we will not be ungrateful, or unthankful, for it]. (Mṣb.) [The verb when used in this sense, seems, from what has been said above, to be a Haqiyqap Eurofiy-ap, or word so much used in a particular tropical sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as proper.]

And hence, kafara, inf. n. kuforaAnN, is used to signify [absolutely] He denied, or disacknowledged. (TA.) [See the act. part. n., below: and see 3. See also art. f, p. 2322 a.] You say kafara biAlS-aAniEi He denied the Creator. (Mṣb.)

Hence also, (TA.) kafara, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yakofuru}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. kufurN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is the most common form in this case, (El-Basáïr,) and kaforN (Ḳ) and kuforaAnN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and kufuwrN, (Ḳ,) He disbelieved; he became an unbeliever, or infidel; contr. of Mmana, inf. n. UiyomaAnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say kafara biQll-ehi (Ṣ, Mṣb) He disbelieved in God: (Ṣ:) because he who does so conceals, or covers, the truth, and the favours of the liberal Dispenser of favours [who is God]. (MF.) [Also, as shown above, He denied God.] It is related in a trad. of ʼAbd-El-Melik, that he wrote to El-Hajjáj, mano Oaqar-a biAlkufori faxal-i sabiylahu, meaning, Whosoever confesses the unbelief of him who opposes the Benoo-Marwán, and goes forth against them, let him go his way. (TA.) See also kuforN, below.
[He blasphemed: a signification very common in the present day.]
Also, kafara bikacaA He declared himself to be clear, or quit, of such a thing. (Mṣb.) In this sense it is used in the Ḳur xiv. 27. (Mṣb, TA.)

And kafara also signifies He was remiss, or fell short of his duty, with respect to the law, and neglected the gratitude or thankfulness to God which was incumbent on him. So in the Ḳur xxx. 43; as is shown by its being opposed to Eamila SaAliHFA. (TA.)
kafara lahu, inf. n. kaforN: see 2.
2. kf-rhu, inf. n. takofiyrN: see 1, first signification, in three places.

Hence, kaf-ara Alc-anoba It (war in the cause of God [or the like]) covered, or concealed, the crime or sin: (Mgh:) [or expiated it: or annulled it; for] tkfyr with respect to acts of disobedience is like UiHobaATN with respect to reward. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The saying in the Ḳur [v. 70.] lakaf-aronaA Eanohumo say-iYaAtihimo means, We would cover, or conceal, their sins, so that they should become as though they had not been: or it may mean, We would do away with their sins; as is indicated by another saying in the Ḳur [xi. 116,] “good actions do away with sins.” (El-Basáïr.) kaf-ara Qll-ehu Eanohu Alc-anoba signifies God effaced his sin. (Mṣb.)

And kaf-ara Eano yamiynihi [He expiated his oath;] he performed, (Mṣb,) or gave, (Ḳ,) what is termed kaf-aArap [i. e. a fast, or alms, for the expiation of his oath]: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) takofiyrN of an oath is the doing what is incumbent, or obligatory, for the violation, or breaking, thereof: (Ṣ:) kaf-ara yamiynahu is a vulgar phrase. (Mgh.)
kaf-arahu as syn. with Oakofarahu: see 4.

kaf-ara lahu, inf. n. takofiyrN, (A, Mgh, TA,) He did obeisance to him, lowering his head, or bowing, and bending himself, and putting his hand upon his breast: (Mgh:) or put his hand upon his breast and bent himself down to him: (TA:) or he made a sign of humbling himself to him; did obeisance to him: (A:) namely, an Eiloj [or unbeliever of the Persians or other foreigners] (A, Mgh) or a cim-iI- [or free non- Muslim subject of a Muslim government, i. e., a Christian, a Jew, or a Sabian] (Mgh) to the king; (A, Mgh;) or a slave to his master, or to his dihoqaAn [or chief]: (TA:) and kafara↓, [aor. _u {yakofuru}, accord. to the rule of of the Ḳ,] (TḲ,) inf. n. kaforN, (Ḳ,) he (a Persian, faArisiI-N, Ḳ, and so in the L and other lexicons, but in the TṢ faAris, without I, which is probably a mistake of copyists, TA) paid honour to his king, (Ḳ, TA,) by making a sing with his head, near to prostration: (TA:) takofiyrN is a man's humbling himself to another, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) bending himself, and lowering his head, nearly in the manner termed rukuwEN; as one does when he desires to pay honour to his friend; (TA;) or as the Eiloj does to the dihoqaAn: (Ṣ:) and the tkfyr of the people of the scriptures [or Christians and Jews, and Sabians] one's lowering his head to his friend, like the tasoliym with the Muslims: or one's putting his hand, or his two hands, upon his breast: (TA:) and tkfyr in prayer is the bending one's self much in the state of standing, before the action termed rukuwEN; the doing of which was disapproved by Moḥammad, accord. to a trad. (TA.) It is said in a trad., UicaA OaSobaHa Qbonu Mdama faUin-a AlOaEoDaMCa tukaf-iru kul-uhaA lil-isaAni When the son of Adam rises in the morning, verily all the members abase themselves to the tongue, (Mgh, TA,) and confess obedience to it, and humbly submit to its command. (TA.)
takofiyrN also signifies The crowning a king with a crown, [because] when he, or it, is seen, obeisance is done to him (UicaA ruYiIa kuf-ira lahu). (Ḳ.)
See also takofiyrN below.

entry.sense: 3. kaAfaraniI Haq-iI He denied, or disacknowledged, to me my right, or just claim. (A, Mgh, Ḳ.) Hence the saying of 'Ámir, UicaA Oaqar-a Einoda AlqaADiI biXaIoCK vum-a kaAfara [When he confesses a thing in the presence of the Kádee, then denies, or disacknowledges: kaAfara being thus used in the sense of kafara]. But as to the saying of Moḥammad [the lawyer], rjulN lahu EalaI Mxara dayonN fakaAfarahu bihi siniyna [A man who owed to another a debt, and denied to him, in the case of it, for years], he seems to have made it imply the meaning of AlmumaATalap, and therefore to have made it trans. in the same manner as AlmmATlp is trans. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: 4. Akfrhu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and kf-rhu↓, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) [the latter of which is the more common in the present day,] He called him a kaAfir [i. e. a disbeliever, an unbeliever, or an infidel]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) he attributed, or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, disbelief, or infidelity: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) or he said to him kafarota [Thou hast become an unbeliever, or infidel, or Thou hast blasphemed: in this last sense, “he said to him Thou hast blasphemed,” kf-rhu, to which alone it is assigned in the Mṣb, is very commonly used in the present day]. (Mṣb.) Hence the saying, laA tukofiro OaHadFA mino Oaholi qibolatika Do not thou attribute or impute disbelief or infidelity to any one of the people of thy kibleh; (Ṣ, TA;) i. e., do not thou call any such a disbeliever, &c.; or do not thou make him such by thine assertion and thy saying. (TA.) laA tukaf-iruwA Oahola qibolatikumo is not authorized by the relation, though it be allowable as a dial. form. (Mgh.)

[Also] Oakofarotuhu, inf. n. UikofaArN, I made him a disbeliever, an unbeliever, or an infidel; I compelled him to become a disbeliever,, &c. (Mṣb.) And Oakofara fulaAnN SaAHibahu Such a one compelled his companion by evil treatment to become disobedient after he had been obedient. (Mgh.) And Oakofara Alr-ajulu muTiyEahu The man compelled him who had obeyed him to disobey him: (T, TA:) or he made him to be under a necessity to disobey him. (TA.)
Akfr He (a man, TA) kept, or confined himself, to the kafor, (Ḳ,) i. e. qaroyap [town or village]; (TA;) as also Aktfr↓. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tkf-r biAls-ilaAHi He covered himself with the arms. And tkf-r biAlv-awobi He enveloped himself entirely with the garment. (A.)
8: see 4, last signification.

hom.sense: kaforN The darkness and blackness of night; [because it conceals things;] as also, sometimes, kiforN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also kaAfirN.] See a verse cited voce cukaMCu.
Earth, or dust; because it conceals what is beneath it. (Lḥ.)
[Hence also] A grave, or sepulchre: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. kufuwrN. (Ṣ.) Whence the saying, Oall-hum-a Qgofiro liOaholi Alkufuwri [O God, pardon the people of the graves]. (Ṣ.)

[And hence, perhaps,] A town, or village; [generally the latter;] syn. qaroyapN: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a Syriac word, and mostly used by the people of Syria [and of Egypt]: or, accord. to El-Ḥarbee, land that is far from men, by which no one passes: (TA:) pl. kufuwrN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) in the present day, it is applied in Egypt to any small qaroyap [or village] by the side of a great qaroyap [or town]: they say Alqaroyapu AlfulaAniy-apu wakaforuhaA [Such a town and its village]: and sometimes one qaroyap has a number of kufuwr. (TA.) Hence the saying of Mo'áwiyeh, Oaholu Alkufuwri humo Oaholu Alqubuwri [The people of the villages are the people of the graves]; meaning, that they are as the dead; they do not see the great towns and the performance of the congregational prayers of Friday: (Ṣ, Mgh:) by Alkfwr he meant the villages (AlquraI) remote from the great towns and from the places where the people of science assemble, so that ignorance prevails among their inhabitants, and they are most quickly affected by innovations in religion and by natural desires which cause to err. (Az, TA.) Hence also the trad. (of Aboo-Hureyreh, TA), layuxorijan-akumu Qlr-uwmu minohaA kaforFA kaforFA [The Greeks will assuredly expel you from them, town by town, or village by village]; (Ṣ,* TA;) i. e. from the furFI of Syria. (Ṣ, TA.)
kaforN EalaI kaforK also signifies One upon another; or one part upon another. (TA.)
kuforN: see 1. [As a simple subst., Ingratitude,, &c.]

[And particularly Denial, or disacknowledgment, of favours or benefits, and especially of those conferred by God: and disbelief, unbelief; infidelity.] It is of four kinds: kuforu UinokaArK the denial, or disacknowledgment, of God, with the heart and the tongue, having no knowledge of what is told one of the unity of God [&c.]: and kuforu juHuwdK the acknowledgment with the heart without confessing with the tongue: [or the disacknowledgment of God with the tongue while the heart acknowledges Him:] and kuforu AlmuEaAnadapi the knowledge of God with the heart, and confession with the tongue, with refusal to accept [the truth]: and kuforu Aln-ifaAqi the confession with the tongue with disbelief in the heart: all of these are unpardonable: (L, TA:) the greatest kufor is the denial, or disacknowledgment, of the unity [of God], or of the prophetic office [of Moḥammad and others], or of the law of God. (El-Basáïr.) [Also, Blasphemy. Its pl., as a simple subst. in all these senses, is said to be kufuwrN.]. Akh says, that kufuwrFA [in the accus. case] in the Ḳur xvii. 101, [to which may be added v. 91 of the same ch., and xxv. 52,] is pl. of kuforN, like as buruwdN is pl. of burodN. (Ṣ.)

Tar, or pitch, syn. qiyrN; with which ships are smeared; (Ḳ;) of which there are three sorts, kuforN and qiyrN and ziftN: kfr is melted, and then ships are smeared with it: [whence, app., its name, from its being a covering:] zft is used for smearing skins for wine, &c. (ISh.)

entry.sense: kiforN: see kaforN.
kafarN: see kaAfuwrN.
kaforapN: see kaAfirN.
kufar-aI, and its variations: see kaAfuwrN.
kafuwrN: see kAfr.
kaf-aArN: see kAfr.

kaf-aArapN a subst. from takofiyru Alyamiyni, (Ṣ,) or an intensive epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates; signifying [An expiation for a sin or crime or a violated oath;] an action, or a quality, which has the effect of effacing a wrong action or sin or crime; (TA;) that which covers, or conceals, sins or crimes; such as the kf-Arp of oaths [violated], and that of [the kind of divorce termed] ZihaAr, and of unintentional homicide; (T, TA;) an expiation (maA kuf-ira bihi), such as an alms-giving, and a fasting, and the like: (Ḳ:) pl. kaf-aAraAtN. (T, TA.)

hom.sense: kaAfirN A sower: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a tiller of the ground: (Mṣb:) because he covers over the seed with earth: (Ṣ, Mṣb:*) pl. kuf-aArN. (Ṣ, TA.) The pl. is said by some to be thus used in the Ḳur lvii. 19. (TA.)
Dark clouds, or a dark cloud; (Ḳ;) because it conceals what is beneath it. (TA.)
Night: (Ḳ:) or intensely black night; because it conceals everything by its darkness. (Ṣ.)
The darkness; (Ḳ;) because it covers what is beneath it; (TA;) as also kaforapN↓, accord. to the copies of the Ḳ; but in the L, kaforN, q. v. (TA.)

The sea; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) for the same reason. (TA.) Thaalabeh Ibn-So'eyr El-Mazinee says, (Ṣ, TA,) describing a male and a female ostrich and their returning to their eggs at sunset, (TA,)
fatacak-araA vaqalFA raviydFA baEodamaA
Oaloqato cukaMCu yamiynahaA fiI kaAfiri
[And they remembered goods placed side by side, after the sun had cast its right side into a sea]; i. e., the sun had begun to set: or the poet may mean [by kAfr] night: (Ṣ, TA:) but Ṣgh says, that the right reading is tacak-arato; the pronoun referring to the female ostrich. (TA.)
Also, A great river: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) used in this sense by El-Mutalemmis: (Ṣ:) and a great valley. (Ḳ.)
[A man] staying, or abiding, [in a place,] and hiding himself. (TA.) [See an ex. voce EaroXN.]

[A man] wearing arms; covered with arms: (Az, Ḳ:) as also mukaf-irN↓ (A, Ḳ) and mutakaf-irN↓ (Ṣ, A) and mukaf-arN↓: (A:) or this last signifies bound fast in iron; (Ḳ, TA;) as though covered and concealed by it: (TA:) pl. of the first, kuf-aArN. (Ḳ.) Hence the following, (Ḳ,) said by Moḥammad during the pilgrimage of valediction, (TA,) laA tarojiEuwA biEodiI kuf-aArFA yaDoribu baEoDukumo riqaAba baEoDK (Ḳ) [Do not ye become again, after me, i. e., after my death,] wearers of arms, preparing yourselves for fight, [one party of you smiting the necks of others;] as though he meant thereby to forbid war: (AM, TA:) or [do not ye become unbelievers, after me,, &c.; i. e.,] do not ye call people unbelievers, and so become unbelievers [yourselves]. (AM, Ḳ, TA.)
A coat of mail; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) because it conceals what is beneath it. (TA.)
One who has covered his coat of mail with a garment worn over it. (Ṣ.)
kaAfiru Ald-uruwEi A garment that is worn over the coat of mail. (A.)

One who denies, or disacknowledges, the favours or benefits of God: (Ḳ:) [ungrateful; unthankful; especially to God:] one who denies, or disacknowledges, the unity [of God], and the prophetic office [of Moḥammad and others], and the law of God, altogether, accord. to the common conventional acceptation: a disbeliever; an unbeliever; an infidel; a miscreant; contr. of muWominN: (El-Basáïr:) because he conceals the favours of God: (Ṣ:) or because his heart is covered; as though it were of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (IDrd, TA:) or because kufor covers his heart altogether: (Lth, TA:) i. e. having a covering to his heart: or because, when God invites him to acknowledge his unity, He invites him to accept his favours; and when he refuses to do so, he covers the favour of God, excluding it from him: (Az, TA:) fem. with p {kaAfirapN}: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. masc. kafarapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the most common pl. of kAfr in the first of the senses explained above, (El-Basáïr,) and kuf-aArN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the most common pl. of the same in the last of those senses, as contr. of mWmn, (El-Basáïr,) and kifaArN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kaAfiruwna: (Mṣb:) and pl. fem. kawaAfiru (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kaAfiraAtN: (Mṣb:) and rajulN kaf-aArN↓, and kafuwrN↓ signify the same as kaAfirN: (Ḳ:) or kafuwrN is an intensive epithet, meaning very ungrateful, or unthankful, [&c., especially to God]: so in the Ḳur xxii. 65, and xliii. 14: and kaf-aArN has a more intensive signification than kafuwrN, [meaning habitually ungrateful,, &c.:] os in the Ḳur A 23: but sometimes it is used in the sense of kafuwrN; as in the Ḳur xiv. 37: (El-Basáïr:) kafuwrN↓ is fem. as well as masc.; (TA;) and its pl. is kufurN, (Ḳ,* TA,) also both masc. and fem.; and it has no unbroken pl. (TA.)
Also, simply, Denying, or disacknowledging; a denier, or disacknowledger: followed bybi before the thing denied: pl. kaAfiruwna: (Ṣ, TA;) so in the Ḳur ii. 38, (TA,) and xxviii. 48. (Ṣ, TA.)
[Also, Blaspheming; a blasphemer.]
See also kaAfuwrN.

kaAfuwrN The spathe, or envelope of the TaloE [or spadix], (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or upper covering thereof, (TA,) of a palm-tree; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) the kim- of a palm-tree: (Mgh, Mṣb:) as also kufar-aI↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) with damm to the k and fet-ḥ to the f and teshdeed to the r, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or kufur-aI, [so in the copies of the Ḳ, and so I have found it written in other works, so that both forms appear to be correct,] and kafar-aI and kifir-aI, (Ḳ,* TA,) and kaAfirN↓ (AḤn, Ḳ) and kafarN↓: (Ḳ:) so called because it conceals what is within it: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or, accord. to AA and Fr, the TaloE [by which they probably mean the spathe, for, as is said in the Mgh, it is applied by some to the kim- (or spathe) before it bursts open]: (Ṣ:) [kfr-I↓ is sometimes masc., though more properly and commonly fem.:] IAar says, I heard Umm-Rabáh say. hecihi kfr-I and hecaA kf-rI: (TA:) the pl. of kaAfuwrN is kawaAfiyru; and the pl. of kaAfirN is kawaAfiru. (TA.)

Also ‡ The zamaE of the grape-vine; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e., the leaves which cover what is within them of the raceme; likened to the kAfwr of the TlE; (TA;) the kim- [or calyx] of the grapes, before the blossom comes forth; because they cover the unopened raceme; accord. to IF, as also kufar-aI↓: (Mṣb:) pl. kawaAfiyru and kawaAfiru, accord. to the Ḳ; but it is well known that the former is pl. of kAfwr, and the latter of kAfr. (TA.)
And, accord. to some, † The envelope [or calyx] of any plant. (TA.)

[Camphor;] a kind of perfume, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) well known, from certain trees [the laurus camphora of Linn.] in the mountains of the sea of India and China, which afford shadow to many people or creatures, (Ḳ,) by reason of its greatness and its many spreading branches, (TA,) which leopards or panthers frequent, and the wood of which is white and easily broken; the kAfwr is found within it, and is of various kinds, in colour red, and becoming white only by taSoEiyd [or sublimation]. (Ḳ.)
Accord. to the M, A mixture of perfume, composed of the spathe (kAfwr) of the spadix of the palm-tree. (TA.)

A certain spring, or fountain, in paradise. (Fr. Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur [lxxvi. 5,] Uin-a QloOaboraAra yaXorabuwna mino kaOosK kaAna mizaAjuhaA kaAfuwrFA [Verily the pious shall drink a cup of wine whereof the mixture is Káfoor]. (Fr.) IDrd says, that it should be imperfectly decl., because it is a fem. [proper] name, determinate, of more than three letters; but it is made perfectly decl. for the conformity of the ends of the verses: Th says, that it is made perfectly decl. because it is used by way of comparison; and that if it were a [proper] name of the spring, or fountain, it would be imperfectly decl.: Th means, says ISd, whereof the mixture is like kAfwr [or camphor]: and Zj says, that it may mean that the taste of perfume and kAfwr is in it, or that it is mixed with kAfwr. (TA.)

A certain plant, (Lth, Ḳ,) [which I believe to he the same as the camphorata Monspeliensis, see my “Thousand and One Nights,” ch. xxviii. note 6,] of sweet odour, (ISd, Ḳ,) the flower of which is (Lth, Ḳ) white, (Lth,) like the flower of the OuqoHuwaAn [or camomile]. (Lth, Ḳ.)
IDrd says, I do not think the kAfwr is Arabic, because they sometimes say qafuwrN and qaAfuwrN. (TA.)

entry.sense: Oakofaru [More, or most, ungrateful or unthankful, especially to God; or disbelieving or unbelieving]. (TA.)
takofiyrN, as a subst., The crown of a king. (ISd, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: mukof-arN A bird covered with feathers. (A.) See also kaAfirN: and see makofuwrN.
One who, though beneficent, is regarded, or treated, with ingratitude; (Ḳ;) a benefactor whose beneficence is not gratefully acknowledged. (A.)

entry.sense: mukaf-irN: see kaAfirN.
ramaAdN makofuwrN Ashes upon which the wind has swept the dust so that it has covered them. (Ṣ.) See also mukaf-arN.
mutakaf-irN: see kaAfirN.
Q. Q. 1. kawokaba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. kawokabapN (Ḳ) It (iron) glistened; was lustrous, or bright. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also mukawokibN.

hom.sense: kawokabN i. q. najomN, A star; an asterism; a constellation: as also kawokabapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or Alkwkbp is an appellation given to the planet Venus; and for the rest of the stars, the masc. word kwkb is used: (Az:) but Venus is called also Alkwkb. (MF.) [Pl. kawaAkibu.]

Accord. to Lth, kwkb is a quadriliteral-radical word; the w being a radical letter: it is also said to be from wkb, or from kwb; though k is not one of the letters of augmentation; so that here it must be augmentative contrary to rule. (TA.) [But I rather think that it is an arabicized word, from the Hebrew כוׄכָב; and that ignorance of its being so has caused the Arabs to dispute respecting its formation.]
cahabuwA taHota kul-i kawokabK They became dispersed [as though under every tract of heaven]. (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kawokabN † Drops [of dew] that fall upon herbage in the night, (Ḳ,) and become like stars. (TA.)
The source, or spring, of a well. (Ḳ.)
Water. (El-Muärrij, Ḳ.)
† The lustre, or brightness, or glistening, of iron. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
† A sword. (Ḳ.)
A nail: (Ḳ:) [or more probably, † its head, as in Golius]
kawokabN (AZ, Ḳ) and kawokabapN↓ (TA) † A whiteness in the eye: (Ḳ:) a whiteness in the black part of the eye, whether the sight be gone in consequence thereof, or not. (AZ.)
kawokabN A tract, such as is termed xiT-ap, differing in colour from the land in which it lies. (Ḳ.)

† A youth nearly of the age of puberty: (Ḳ:) a youth who has attained the period of adolescence, and whose face has become beautiful, is called kawokabN mumotaliYN (a full star), like as he is called badorN. (TA.) [See XaAdixN, and muTab-ixu.]
† The chief, lord, or prince, and horseman, or cavalier, of a people. (Ḳ.)
† A man with his arms; an armed man. (Ḳ.)
† What is tall of plants. (Ḳ.)
A mountain: (Ḳ [but Freytag mentions, that in some copies, for jabalN, is read xayolN, horses and horsemen, or a troop of horse:]) or the main part thereof. (TA.)
The greater part, chief part, main, gross, mass, or bulk, of a thing: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as of herbage, water, an army. (TA.)
‡ The flower, or flowers, of a garden, or meadow. (TṢ, Ḳ.)

The fuTor [toadstool, or mushroom], a well-known plant: (AḤn, Ḳ:) I do not mention it, says AḤn, from a learned man: but kwkb is [explained by lexicologists only as] the name of a well-known plant, called kwkbu AlOaroDi: (L:) perhaps a species of the fuTor. (El-Mak- disee, cited by MF.)
Vehemence of heat: (Ḳ:) the greater part of the heat. (TA.)

The medicament called Taloq, q. v., [which defends the person who is anointed therewith from the burning of fire]. (Ḳ: explained by the words AlT-aloqu mina AlOadowiyapi: in some copies of the Ḳ, mn AlOawodiyapi. [This is wrong: kawokabu AlOaroDi means Talc: see TalaqN.])
yawomN cuw kawaAkiba A day of difficulties, distresses, or calamities. (Ḳ.)
kawokabN A place of con- finement. (Ḳ.)
kawokabapN see kawokabN.
An assembly; a company; a congregated body. (Ḳ.) Said by some to be figurative in this sense.

entry.sense: daEawoA daEowapF kawokabiy-apF [They uttered an imprecation like that of Kowkebeeyeh]: a proverb. Alkawokabiy-apu was a town the people of which were oppressed by its governor, wherefore they uttered an imprecation against him, and he died immediately after it. (Ḳ.)
OamoEazu mukawokibN † A hard tract with glistening pebbles: also called DuHFI mukawokibN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. kalaOahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yakolaOu}, inf. n. kaloCN (Ḳ) and kilaMCapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kilaMCN (Ḳ) [but respecting this last see a verse of Jemeel cited below], He (i. e. God, Ṣ) guarded him, or kept him, or kept him safely. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
UicohabuwA fiI kilaMCapi Qll-ehi Go ye in the safe keeping of God. (Ṣ, TA.)

In the following verse of Jemeel,
fakuwniI bixayorK fiI kilaMCi wagiboTapK
waUino kunoti qado OazomaEoti SaromiI wabigoDatiI
[Then be thou in prosperity, in safe keeping (of God), and in happy condition, even if thou have firmly resolved to cut me and to detest me], kilaMCN may be an inf. n.; or it may be pl. of kilaOCapN; or it may be put for kilaMCapN, the p being elided by a necessary poetical licence. (Abu-l- Ḥasan.)

The verb is also used without hemzeh, thus; kalaAtu, yakoluwkumo; and kalayotu, yakolaAkumo; in the dial. of Kureysh; inf. n. kilaAyapN: as the pass. part. n. of both, makoluw-N is more commonly used than makoliI-N, which is correctly used as the pass. part. n. of kalayotu. (TA.)
kalaOa Alqawoma † He acted as a scout (rabiyoYap) for the party, or people. (TA.)
kalaOa baSarahu fiI XaIoCK, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK naZarahu,]) or OakolaOahu↓, (Ṣ,) He repeatedly turned his eye to a thing; looked at it again and again. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kalaOa Aln-ajoma ‡ He watched the star, to see when it would rise. (A.)
kalaOa Ald-ayonu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or kaluWa, inf. n. kuluwCN, act. part. n. kaAliYN, (A,) The debt, or its payment, was put off, or postponed, or delayed. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
kalaOa Eumoruhu ‡ His life came to an end: (Ḳ:) or was long, and was delayed. (A.)
kalaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kaloCN, (Aṣ,) He beat with a whip. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)
kalaOati Aln-aAqapu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AklOt↓, (Ṣ,) The she-camel ate kalaO, or herbage. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kalaOati AlOaroDu, (Ḳ,) and kaliYat, and AklOt↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UkolaMCN, (TA,) and AstklOt↓, (Ḳ,) The land contained, (Ṣ,) or abounded with, (Ḳ,) kalaO, or herbage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
2. kl-O, inf. n. takoliIoCN and takoliYapN, He brought a ship near to the bank of the river, (Ḳ,) and moored it. (TA.)
kl-O † He retained, detained, or confined, a person: (Ḳ:) app. from the verb as used with reference to a ship; and therefore tropical. (TA.)
kl-O, (Ḳ,) inf. n. takoliIoCN, (TA,) He came to a place, and stopped there. (TA.)
kl-O, inf. n. takoliYapN, He came to a place sheltered from the wind. (Ṣ)
kl-O He came to a person (Ḳ) on an affair. (TA.)
kl-O fiI OamorK ‡ He looked into, or considered attentively, a thing. (Ḳ.) See 4.
kl-Ofiyhi ‡ He regarded him attentively, and was pleased with him. (TA.)

kl-O fiI AlT-aEaAmi wagayorihi, inf. n. takoliIoCN; (Ṣ,* TA;) and AklO↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UikolaMCN; (Ṣ;) He paid in advance (Oasolama, Ḳ, and Oasolafa, Ṣ, Ḳ) for corn or other food, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [Here the original signification of postponement or delay is involved: for he who pays in advance for a thing grants a delay in the delivery thereof.] IAar cites the following verse:
famano yuHosino Uilayohimo laA yukal-iYo
UilaI jaAzK bicaAka walaA kariymi
[So that he who does a good action to them does not pay in advance to one who will recompence for that (action), nor to him who is generous]. (TA.) See 1 and 5.

entry.sense: 3. kAlO, inf. n. mukaAlaOapN, and kilaOCN, He watched, or observed. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4: See 1 in three places.
AklOt Eayonuhu ‡ His eye was sleepless, or wakeful. (A.)
AklO Eayonahu, and kl-O↓, ‡ He made his eye sleepless, or wakeful. (A.)
AklO Eumurahu ‡ He brought his life to its close. (Ḳ.) See 1.

entry.sense: 5. tkl-O; and kl-O↓, inf. n. takoliIoCN; He bought on credit. [This is the explanation given in the TḲ, and it appears to be correct. It is also there said, that takal-aOotuhu signifies Oaxacotuhu nasiyoYapF, I took it, or bought it, on credit: and kal-aOotu fiI AlT-aEaAmi, Axcth bAln-syYpi, I took, or bought, the food on credit, but the latter I render differently. (See 2, above.) In the Ḳ we read AlkaAliYu wAlkuloOapu biAlD-am-i Aln-asiyoYapu wAlEurobuwnu wtakal-aOotu wkal-aOotu takoliyoYFA Oxacotuhu. IbrD thinks that the last word should be Ox-arotu “I postponed, or delayed”: but I rather think that it should be OaxacotuhaA, meaning Oaxacotu nasiyoYapF I took, or bought, on credit. in the TA we read, AO says, takal-aOotu kuloOapF wkal-aOotu takoliyoYFA UisotanosaOotu nasiyoYapa OaIo Oaxacotuhu waAln-asiyoYapu Alt-aOoxiyru wakacelika UisotakolaOotu kuloOapF: but the words AI Axcth seem to have been added by SM; for in the Ṣ we find, on the authority of AO, takal-aOotu OaIo QsosanosaOotu nasiyoYapF wakacelika QsotakolaOotu kuloOapF biAlD-am-i wahuwa mina Alt-aOoxiyri: whence it seems, that tkl-O, (or tkl-O kuloOapF, and kl-O↓ kuloOapF, see above,) and AlstklO↓ kulOapF, signify He asked for a delay of the period of the payment of a debt.] See 8.

hom.sense: 8. AktlO minohu † He preserved, or guarded, himself from him or it; had a care of, or was cautious of, him or it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
AktlOt EayonI † My eye was wakeful, vigilant, or cautious. (Ṣ.)
AktlO kuloOapF, and tkl-OhA↓, He received a kuloOap [i. e., an earnest, or money paid in advance]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 10: see 1 and 5.

kalaON Fresh herbage; syn. EuXobN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied to the Eurowap, nSiI-, and Sil-iyaAn: (Az:) or pasture, or what cattle, &c. feed upon: (TA:) or herbage. whether fresh or dry either fresh pasture or fodder: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it comprises the naSiI-, Sil-ayaAn, Halamap, XiyH, Earofaj, the various kinds of Eurowap, and what are termed EuXob, baqol, and the like: or it is applied to the herbs called bql, and to trees: a gen. n., having no sing.; or its sing. is kalaMCN. (TA.)
kuloOapN: see 5 and kaAlYN.
OaroDN kaliYapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and makolaOopN↓, (Ḳ,) and mukoliYapN↓, (Ṣ,) A land containing, (Ṣ,) or abounding with, (Ḳ,) kalaO, or herbage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
The ↓last is also said to signify A land with the pasture of which its camels have been satiated. (TA.)
See a trad. quoted in art. faDolN.
EayonN kaluwoCN ‡ A strong eye, which sleep does not overcome. (TA.)
kaluwoCN AlEayoni ‡ A man, or a camel, (male or female,) having a strong eye, which sleep does not overcome: (Ḳ:) or, a sleepless, or wakeful, eye. (A.)
maroOapN kaluwoCu All-ayoli ‡ [A woman who is sleepless at night]. (TA.) See 4.

kal-aMCN and mukal-aON↓ A station of ships, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) near the bank of a river, or near what is called the jud-: (TA:) the former is masc. and fem.; or, accord. to Sb, it is of the measure faE-aAlN; and therefore masc., and perfectly declinable: (Ṣ:) so called because it keeps the vessels safe (yakolaWuhaA) from the wind: but accord. to Th, it is of the measure faEolaMCu; and therefore fem., [and imperfectly declinable; from kal-a;] so called because the wind there becomes slackened: or a place where ships are moored, near the bank of a river: (TA:) or a place sheltered from the wind. (Ṣ.)
Also, The bank of a river. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Dual of kl-AC, kal-aA Mni and kal-aAwaAni: pl. kal-aOuwwna. (TA.)

mano Ear-aDa Ear-aDonaA lahu wamano maXaI EalaI Alkal-aMCi OaloqayonaAhu fiI Aln-ahori, (TA,) or qacafonaAhu fiI Aln-ahori, (Ḳ in art. ErD,) or fI AlmaMCi, (TA in that art.) ‡ Him who indirectly calumniates we will treat in a similar manner; (meaning, we will inflict upon him a chastisement less than that termed AlHad-;) and him who walks upon the bank of the river (i. e., who openly calumniates, and so, as it were, embarks on the river of the Huduwd, [pl. of Had-N,]) we will cast into that river; meaning, we will inflict upon him the chastisement termed AlHad-. (TA; and Ḳ * in art. ErD.)

kaAliYN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kuloOapN↓ (Ḳ) i. q. nasiyoYapN, [app. bearing both of the two significations immediately following, and clearly shown in the Ṣ, &c. to bear the latter of them: A postponement, or delay, in the time of the payment of a debt, &c. See also nusoOapN, and kalaOa.]
[Also, both words, like nasiyoYapN, A debt of which the payment is deferred by a creditor to a future period.] (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

Ex., nahaI Eani AlkaAliYi biAlkaAliY, i. e., Aln-asiyoYap bAln-asiyoYap, He (Moḥammad) forbade [exchanging] a debt to be paid at a future time for a similar debt. (Ṣ, TA.) [See the Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer, and Mishkát el-Masábeeh, ii., 21.] What is forbidden by this is, a man's buying a thing on credit for a certain period, and, when the period of payment is come, and he finds not that wherewith to pay the debt, his saying, Sell it to me on credit for a further period, for something additional: whereupon he [thus] sells it to him: (TḲ:) or, a man's paying money for, wheat, or the like, to be given at a certain period, and, when the period comes, the debtor's saying, I have not wheat; etc.; but sell thou it to me on credit for a certain period. (AObeyd, Mṣb.) [See OajalN.] kaAlK is also used for kaAliYN. (Ṣ.) [See an ex. voce naAjizN.] The pl. of the latter is kwaAliYu. (TA.)
Also kuluOapN↓, Money paid at a period after the purchase, for food. (Ṣ.)
Also kaAliYN and kuloOapN↓, An earnest, or money paid in advance. (Ḳ.)
OakolaOu ‡ Longer, or longest; more, or most, protracted. (TA.)
balaga Qll-ehu bika OakolaOa AlEumuri (Ṣ, A) i. e. ‡ [May God cause thee to reach, or attain,] the extreme, or most distant, period of life! (Ṣ, TA.)
makolaOapN and mukoliYapN: see kaliYapN.
lloEayoni fiyhaA makoluwoCN ‡ The eye is constantly fixed upon her: [or has in her an object that is watched (by it):] as though watching her because pleased with her. (A.)
mukal-aON: see kalA-aCN.

hom.sense: 1. kaliba, aor. _a {yakolabu}, inf. n. kalabN, He (a dog) was seized with madness, in consequence of eating human flesh. (Ḳ.) See also kalabN and kalibN.

kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, He (a man) was seized with madness like that of dogs, in consequence of his having been bitten by a [mad] dog; [was seized with hydrophobia]. (Ḳ.) So also a camel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also kalabN and kalibN.
kuliba, like EaniIa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] He lost his reason by the kind of madness termed kalab. (Ḳ.) See kalaAbN.
kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, † He was angry (Ḳ) Ealayohi with him; and thus resembled one afflicted with the disease called kalab. (TA.)
kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, † He was light-witted; weak and stupid, or foolish; ignorant; deficient in intellect: syn. safiha: (Ḳ:) and thus resembled one afflicted with the disease called kalab. (TA.)

kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, † He thirsted. (Ḳ.) From kaliba signifying “he was seized with the disease of dogs, and died of thirst:” for the person afflicted with this disease thirsts, and when he sees water, is frightened at it. (TA.)
kaliba EalaI XaIoCK, (TA,) inf. n. kalabN, ‡ He was eager for, or desired with avidity, a thing. (Ḳ, TA.)
In like manner, takaAlaba↓ Aln-aAsu EalaI AlOamori ‡ The people were eager for the thing, as though they were dogs.
kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, ‡ He ate voraciously, without becoming satiated. (Ḳ.)
kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, He (a person bitten by a mad dog) cried out, [or barked]. (Ḳ.)
kaliba, inf. n. kalabN; (so accord. to the TA; but accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, kalaba;) and Astklb↓; He (a dog) had the habit of eating men. (TA.)

kalaba, aor _i (Ḳ: but in some copies, kaliba, aor. _a {yakolabu}; [which is evidently the right reading;]) and Astklb↓; He (a man in a desert place, TA,) barked, in order that dogs might hear him and bark, and that one might be guided thereby to him [to receive or direct him]. (Ḳ.)

kaliba, inf. n. kalabN and makolabapN, † He performed the office of a pimp. (Aṣ, IAạr, Ḳ.) [This office seems to be thus compared with that which a dog performs, in inviting travellers, by his bark, to enjoy his master's hospitality.]

kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, † It (a tree), not having sufficient watering, had rough leaves, without losing their moisture, so that they caught to the garments of those who passed by, thus annoying them like a dog. (ADk, Ḳ.*)
kaliba † It (a tree) became stripped of its leaves, and rugged, or scabrous, so that it caught to men's garments, and annoyed the persons passing by, like a dog. (TA.)

kalaba AlmazAdapN, aor. _u {yakolubu}, (inf. n. kalobN, TA,) He inserted a strap, thong, or strip of leather, (kalob,) between the two edges of the mzAdp, in sewing them: (Ṣ:) or Alkalobu is the action of a woman who sews a skin, when, finding the thong too short, she inserts into the hole a double thong, and puts through it [i. e. through the loop thus formed] the end of the deficient thong, and then makes it to come out [on the other side of the skin, by pulling the loop through]. (IDrd.) See kulobapN.

kalabati Als-ayori aor. _u {yakolubu}, inf. n. kalobN, She (a female sewer of skins or the like), finding the thong [with which she was sewing] too short, doubled a thong, through which she put the end of the deficient thong [in order to draw it through]: (TA:) or kalaba Als-ayora, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies he sewed the thong, or strip of leather, between two other thongs, or strips. (IAạr.)

kaliba Ealayohi Alqid-u ‡ The strap or thong of untanned hide pressed painfully upon him, by his being exposed with it to the sun or air, and its drying. (TA.) kaliba Ealayohi Ald-ahoru, inf. n. kalabN, ‡ Fortune pressed severely upon him. (TA, from a trad.) See also kaliybN, and 6.
kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, ‡ It (winter, Ṣ, Ḳ, cold, &c., Ṣ,) became severe, or intense: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he (an enemy) pressed hard, or vehemently, upon him. (TA.)
kaliba, inf. n. kalabN, It (a rope) fell between the cheek and wheel of the pulley. (Ḳ.)
kalabahu, aor. _u {yakolubu}, He struck him with a kul-aAb, or spur. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. kl-b, inf. n. takoliybN, He trained a dog to hunt: and sometimes, he trained a fahod, or a bird of prey, to take game. (L.) See the act. part. n.

hom.sense: 3. kAlbhu, inf. n. mukaAlabapN (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and kilaAbN, (TA,) † He acted in an evil manner, or injuriously, towards him; or contended against him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he straitened, or distressed, him, (Ḳ,) as dogs do, one to another, when set upon each other: (TA:) he acted with open enmity, or hostility, to him: (Mṣb:) and takaAlubN↓ (inf. n. of 6) is syn. with mukaAlabapN. (Ṣ.)
kaAlabati AlUibilu, (inf. n. mukaAlabapN, TA,) The camels fed upon kalaAliyb, i. e., the thorns of trees. (Ḳ.)
