Also sometimes signifying The camels pastured upon dry, or tough, HX [app. a mistake for xaX- “what is very rough”]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Oakolaba His camels became affected with the disease called kalabN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., with a madness like that which arises from the dog. (TA.)
6: See 3 and 1.

humo yatakaAlabuwna EalaI kacaA They leap, or rush, together upon such a thing [in an evil, or injurious, or contentious, manner]. (Ṣ.) Alt-akaAlubu is syn. with Alt-awaAvubu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and so also, accord. to the CK, is Alt-akolAabu, which I suppose to be an intensive inf. n. of kaliba].
8. Aktlb He made use of a kulobap, i. e., a thong of leather, &c. in sewing a skin, &c. [See kulobap.] (Lḥ.)

hom.sense: 10: see 1
and see 10 in art. sEl.

kalobN a word of well-known signification, [The dog:] (Ṣ:) or any wounding animal of prey: (L, Ḳ, &c.:) but whether birds [of prey] are comprised in this term is a point that requires consideration: (Esh-Shiháb El-Khafájee:) and especially applied to the barking animal [or dog]: (Ḳ:) or rather, this is its proper signification; and it admits no other: (MF:) sometimes used as an epithet; as in the ex. UimoraOapN kalobapN [A woman like a bitch; a woman who is a bitch]: (Ṣ:) pl. [of pauc.] OakolubN and (of mult., TA,) kilaAbN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kaliybN, which is a rare [form of] pl., like EabiydN, pl. of EabodN, [or rather a quasi-pl. n.,] (Ṣ,) and ( pl. of OakolubN, Ṣ,) OakaAlibu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and ( pl. of kilaAbN, TA,) kilaAbaAtN (Ḳ) and (also pl. of kilaAbN) OakaAliybu: (Mṣb:) kilaAbN is also used as a pl. of pauc.; valaAvapu kilaAbK being said for vlAvpN mina AlkilaAbi; or klAb being used in this case for OakolubK: (Sb:) kaliybN and kaAlibN↓ signify a pack, or collected number, of dogs: (Ḳ:) [both are quasi-pl. ns. in my opinion, though the former is called a pl. in the Ṣ:] accord. to some, the former, if masc., is a quasi-pl. n.; and if fem., a pl.: (MF:) the latter is like jaAmilN and baAqirN [which are both quasi-pl. ns.]. (L.) The pl. of kalobapN [the fem.] is kilaAbN and kalabaAtN. (Mṣb.)

fulaAnN biwaAdiI Alkalobi ‡ [Such a one is in the valley of the dog:] said of one whom no one cares for, and who has no place of abode or resort, but is like a dog, which one sees ever going forth into the desert.
kaf-a Eanohu kilaAbahu ‡ He left reviling him, and injuring or annoying him: [lit., restrained from him his dogs]. (A.) See also kalabN.

AlkilaAbu ElI Albaqar i, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the first word being in the nom. case as an inchoative, (TA,) and AlkilaAba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) put in the acc. case as governed by a verb understood, (TA,) or AlkiraAbu and AlkiraAba; (Kh, Ṣ, art. krb, Ḳ;) of which readings, that of AlklAb is the one generally adopted; (TA;) or they are two distinct proverbs, each having its proper meaning; (Meyd;) the former signifying, [if we read AlkilaAba,] Send the dogs against the wild oxen: i. e., leave a man and his art: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [but accord. to MF, this is the meaning if we read krAb; but if we read klAb, the signification is, as explained above, “Send the dogs, &c.,” and the proverb is applied on the occasion of instigating one set of people against another set, without caring for what may happen to them:] or it alludes to a man's having little care or solicitude for the state, or case, or affair, of his companion. (AʼObeyd.) If we read AlklAbu, the meaning is The dogs are upon, or against, the wild oxen: and in like manner, if we read AlkrAbu, the meaning is “The turning over of the soil is the work of the oxen:” if AlkrAba, “Leave the turning over of the soil to the oxen.” (MF, from expositions of the Fṣ.)
[kalobN kalibN seems also to signify A fierce, or furious, dog. See EaqanobaApN.]
kalobu Albar-i The dog of the desert; i. e. the wolf. (Ḳ, voce ciYob.)
kalobN is also especially applied to A lion. (Ḳ, TA.)
The first increase of water in a valley. (Nh, Ḳ.)
A piece of iron at the head of the pivot, or axis, of a mill. (Ḳ.)
A piece of wood by which a wall is propped, or supported. (Ḳ.)
A certain fish (Ḳ) in the form of a dog. (TA.) [kalobu AlbaHori and Alkalobu AlbaHoriI-u are appellations now applied to The shark.]
kalobN A strap, or thong, cut from an untanned skin, and mukal-abN↓ is A man bound with a kalob, i. e., with a strap, or thong, cut from an untanned skin. (TA.)
The extremity of a hill of the kind called Oakamap. (Ḳ.)

kalobN (and kul-aAbN↓, TA,) The nail that is in the hilt of a sword, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which is [fixed] the cuWaAbap [or cord or other ligature by which the hilt is occasionally attached to the guard]: (Ṣ:) or a nail in the hilt of a sword, with which is another [nail] called AlEajuwzu: (L:) and (so accord. to the Ḳ: but accord. to the TA, the [cord or ligature, itself, which is called the]) cWAbp, of a sword. (Ḳ.)
kalobN A strap, thong, or strip of leather, (or a red OaHomar [probably a mistake for Mxar, another] strap, &c., Ḳ,) which is put between the two edges of a skin (Ṣ, Ḳ) when it is sewed. (Ṣ.)
kalobu Alfarasi The line, or streak, that is in the middle of the horse's back. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
UisotawaI EalaI kalobi farasihi He sat firmly upon the line, or streak, in the middle of his horse's back. (Ṣ.)

kalobN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kal-aAbN↓ (Ḳ) An iron at the edge of a camel's saddle of the kind called raHol: (Ḳ:) a bent, or crooked, or hooked, iron, by which the traveller hangs, from the saddle (rHl), his travelling-provisions (Ṣ,) and his OadaAwiI. (TA.) See also fahodN.

kalobN Anything with which a thing is made firm, or fast, or is bound: syn. kul-umaA wuv-iqa bihi XaIoCN, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or Ouwviqa (as in others): so called because it holds fast a thing like a dog. (TA.)
kalobN i. q. XaEiyrapN [app. meaning the XEyrp of the handle of a knife, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
lisaAnu Alkalobi A certain plant; (Ḳ;) [cynoglossum, or dog's tongue].

kaf-u Alkalobi A certain spreading herb, (Ḳ,) which grows in the plain low tracts of Nejd; thus called when it has dried, in which case it is likened to the paw of a dog; but while it continues green, it is called kft. (TA.)

Oum-u kalobK A certain small thorny tree, (Ḳ,) which grows in rugged ground, and upon the mountains, having yellow leaves, and rough; when it is put in motion, it diffuses a most fetid and foul smell: so called because of its thorns, or because it stinks like a dog when rain falls upon him. (TA.)
Oum-u kalobapa Fever. (Ḳ.) So called because it keeps to a man with much tenacity, like a dog. (TA.)
laqiytu minohu Qsota Alkalobapi, a prov.: see AisotN in art. sth.
Alkalobu AlOakobaru The constellation of Canis Major: and its principal star, Sirius. (El-Ḳazweenee, &c.)
Alkalobu AlOaSogaru, also called Alklb Almutaqad-imu, The constellation of Canis Minor: and its principal star, Procyon. (El-Ḳazweenee, &c.)

Alkalobu [or kalobu Alr-aAEiI] A certain star, over against Ald-alowu (q. v.), [which is] below; in the path of which is a red star, called Alr-aAEiI: (TA:) klb AlrAEI is a name given to a star between the feet, or legs, of Cepheus; and AlrEI, to that which is upon his left foot, or leg; (El-Ḳazweenee;) [app., from their longitudes, the same two stars to which the above quotation from the TA relates: but the same two names are also given to two other stars.]

klb AlrEI is [likewise] a name given to The star which is on, or in, the head of Hercules; [for AlHAwI, an evident mistake in my MṢ. of El-Ḳazweenee, I read AljaAviI;] that in the head of Ophiuchus (AlHaw-aACu) being called AlrAEI. (El-Ḳazweenee.)

[AlkalobaAni, accord. to Freytag, A name of the two stars υ and κ which belong to Taurus: but accord. to my MṢ. of El-Ḳazweenee, the two stars that are near together on the ears of Taurus are called AlkuloyataAni.]

kilaAbu AlX-itaACi The stars, or asterisms, of the beginning of winter; namely, Alc-iraAEu and Alm-avorapu and AlT-arofu and Aljabohapu [the 7th, 8th, 9th, and 10th, of the Mansions of the Moon: so called because they set aurorally in the winter: the first so set, about the period of the commencement of the era of the Flight, in central Arabia, on the 3rd of January: see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl]. (TA.)

entry.sense: kalabN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kulaAbN↓ (Lth) Madness which affects a dog in consequence of eating human flesh. (Ḳ.)

Also, Madness like that of dogs, which affects a man in consequence of his having been bitten by a [mad] dog: (Ḳ:) [a disorder] resembling madness, or diobolical possession: (Ṣ:) a disease that befalls a man from the bite of a mad dog, occasioning what resembles madness, or diabolical possession, so that whomsoever he bites, that person also becomes in like manner affected, abstaining from drinking water until he dies of thirst: the Arabs concur in the assertion that its cure is a drop of the blood of a king, mixed with water, and given to the patient to drink. (TA.) Accord. to El-Mufaddal, it originates from a disease which befalls the standing corn, &c., and which is not removed until the sun rises upon it: if cattle eat of it before that, they die: wherefore Moḥammad forbade pasturing by night: but sometimes a camel runs away, and eats of such pasture before sunrise, and dies in consequence: then a dog comes, and eats of its flesh, and becomes mad; and if it bite a man, he also becomes mad, and when he hears the barking of a dog, answers it [by barking]. (TA.)

dimaACu Almuluwki OaXofaI mina Alkalabi [The blood of kings has cured of canine madness]: or, accord. to another reading, dimaACu Almuluwki XifaACu Alkalabi [The blood of kings is the cure for canine madness]. A proverb, explained by what is quoted from Lḥ, voce kalibN. But some reject this explanation, and assert the meaning to be, that, when a man is enraged [by desire of obtaining revenge], and takes his blood revenge, the blood is the cure of his rage, though not really drunk. (TA.) See also kalibN and kaliba.
[Also kalabN A madness like that of the dog, affecting camels. (See 4.)]

kalabN and kulobapN↓ ‡ Vehemence; severity; pressure; affliction: (Ḳ, TA:) severity, or intenseness of cold, &c.; like julobapu: (Ṣ:) severity and sharpness of winter: (Ḳ, for the former word; and TA, for the latter) also the latter, accord. to the TA, [and the former also, as appears from its verb,] severity, or pressure, of him or fortune, and of everything: (TA:) and the latter, straitness, or difficulty, (Ḳ,) of life: (TA:) and drought: (Ḳ:) or distress arising from drought or from government, &c. (AḤn.)
dafaEotu Eanoka kalaba fulaAnK ‡ I have averted from thee the evil, or mischief, and injurious conduct, of such a one. (Ṣ.) See also kalobN.
kalibN A dog or man affected with the disease called kalabN: (Ṣ, TA:)

A dog accustomed to eating human flesh, and in consequence seized with what resembles madness, or diabolical possession, so that when it wounds a man, he also becomes in like manner affected (Lth. Ṣ) by the disease called kulaAbN, barking like a dog, reading his clothes upon himself. wounding others, and at last dying of thirst, refusing to drink. (Lth.)

A man thus affected is termed kalibN and kaliybN↓: pl. of the former kalibuwna, and of the latter (or of the former accord. to the Ṣ) kalobaI. (TA.) When a man thus affected bites another, they come to a man of noble rank, and he drops for them some blood from his finger, which they give to drink to the patient, and he becomes cured. (Lḥ.) See also kalabN and kaliba.
kalibN A dog habituated to eating men. (TA.)
‡ An importunate beggar. (A.)
dahorN kalibN ‡ Fortune that presses severely and injuriously upon its subjects. (TA.)

kalibN A tree of which the leaves are rough, in consequence of its not having sufficient watering, without losing their moisture, so that they catch to the garments of those who pass by, thus annoying them like a dog. (ADk.)

hom.sense: kalobapN † A thorny tree, destitute of branches: (Ḳ:) so called because it catches to [the garments of] those who pass by it, like a dog: (TA:) a rugged tree, with branches standing out apart, and tough thorns. (TA.)

A small thorny plant, of the kind called Xiros, resembling the XkAEA [or XukaAEaI, or XukaAEap], of the description termed cukuwr: (TA:) or a certain thorny tree, (Ḳ,) of the kind called EiDaAh, having [what is termed] jrAC; (TA;) as also kalibapN↓. (Ḳ.)
kalobatAani The implement with which the blacksmith takes hold of hot iron; [his forceps]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
HadiydapN caAtu kalobatayoni [An iron with two curved ends, forming a forceps]. You also say HadiydataAni cawaAtaA klbtyn, and HadaAYidu cawaAtu klbtyn. (TA.)
kulobapN The shop of a vintner. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
The hairs that grow upon each side of the fore part of the nose and mouth of a dog or cat: (Z, Ḳ:) wrongly explained as signifying the nails of a dog. (Z.)

A thong, or a strand (TaAqap) of the fibres of the palm-tree (liyf), with which skins and the like are sewed: (Ḳ, TA:) [see UiqotafaOa:] or a thong, or [so in the O and in the TA, art. qfO; but here, in the latter, instead of “or,” “behind,” which is evidently a mistake;] a strand (TaAqap) of the fibres of the palm-tree, used in the same manner as the shoe-maker's awl that has, at its head, a perforation vaqobN [so in the O, in the TA Hjr a strange mistranscription: what is meant is doubtless an eye, like that of a needle, and it is by means of an implement with an eye at the end that the operation here described is commonly performed in the present day:] the thong, or the thread, or string, is inserted into the klbp, which is doubled: thus it enters the place [or hole] of the sewing, and the sewer introduces his hand into the UidaAwap [q.v., i. e., the vessel upon which he is employed in working], and stretches the thong of leather, or the thread, or string, (O, L, TA,) in the klbp. (L, TA.) [See kalaba.]

entry.sense: OaroDN kalibapN ‡ Land which has not sufficient watering, and of which the plants, in consequence, become dry: (Ṣ:) or rugged land, and such as is termed quf-, in which there are neither trees nor herbage, and which is not a mountain. (Aboo-Kheyreh.)
OaroDN kalibapu AlX-ajari Land upon which the rain called Alr-abiyE does not fall: (TA:) or rugged, dry, land, upon which that rain does not fall, and which does not become soft. (ADk.)
See kalobapN.
kalaAbN [perhaps inf. n. of kuliba] The departure of reason by the kind of madness termed kalab. (Ḳ.)
kulaAbN: see kalabN.
kaliybN: see kalobN and kalibN.

Respecting this word in the following verse of TaäbbataSharran,
UicaA AlHarobu Oawolatoka Alkaliyba fawal-ihaA
kaliybaka waQEolamo Oan-ahaA sawofa tanojaliI
[When war sets over thee, &c.] there are two opinions: one, that by klyb is meant mukaAlib (see 2): the other, that it is an inf. n. of kalibati AlHarobu [“The war became vehement, severe, or fierce”]: the former is the more valid. (IM.)
kal-aAbN: see kalobN and mukal-ibN.
kul-aAbN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kal-uwbN↓ (Ḳ) A spur; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the iron instrument that is in the boot of him who breaks in a horse. (Ṣ.)

kul-aAbN and kal-uwbN↓ (and kul-uwbN↓, MF, art. sbH q. v.,) [A flesh-hook;] an iron implement with which meat is taken out of the cooking-pot: pl. kalaAliybu: (Ṣ:) an iron flesh-hook, with prongs: (R, which gives this as the explanation of the latter word:) a hooked iron; like xuT-aAf: (Fr., &c.) a piece of wood at the head of which is a hook, (ʼEyn,) of the same or of iron: (T:) an iron instrument for roasting flesh-meat: syn. saf-uwd. (Lḥ.) See kalobN.
kalaAliybu ‡ The talons of a falcon: (Ḳ:) pl. of kal-uwbN. (TA.)
‡ The thorns of a tree. (Ḳ.)
kul-uwbN and kal-uwbN: see kul-aAbN.

kalotabaAnN A pimp: from kaliba, q. v., (Aṣ, IAạr, Ḳ) Sb, however, does not mention the measure faEotalaAnN. ISd thinks it most probable that kaliba is a triliteral-radical, and kltbAn a quadriliteral-radical [or rather a quasi-quadriliteral-radical], like zarima and UizoraOam-, &c. (L.) See also qaroTabaAnN and qalotabaAnN, and art. kltb.
kaAlibN: see kalobN, and mukal-ibN.
tikil-aAbapN A clamourous, very noisy, very garrulous, woman, of evil disposition. (TA, voce jal-aAbap.)

hom.sense: mukal-abN A dog trained and accustomed to hunt. (L.) See the verb.
A captive, or prisoner, (Ṣ,) having the feet shackled, or bound; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. q. mukab-alN, from which it is formed by transposition, (Ṣ,) accord. to some. (TA.)

entry.sense: mukal-ibN One who trains dogs to hunt; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also kal-aAbN↓: and sometimes signifying one who trains the fahod, and birds of prey, to take game: see Ḳur v. 6: one who possesses dogs trained to hunt, and hunts with them; (L;) as also kaAlibN↓, pl. kul-aAbN: (R:) or kaAlibN and kal-aAbN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) signify an owner, or a possessor, of dogs; (L, Ḳ;) the former being similar to taAmirN, &c. (Ṣ.)
mutakaAlibN an appellation given by the people of El-Yemen to ‡ A deputy, or an agent; because of his acting injuriously, or contentiously, towards them over whom he is appointed as such. (TA.)
kalobavN and kulaAbivN A hard and strong man. (IDrd, L.)
Also, and kulobuvN and kulabivN, Niggardly, or stingy, and contracted [in disposition]. (Ḳ.) [See also kunobuvN.]

hom.sense: 1. kalatahu, aor. _i {yakolitu}, inf. n. kalotN, (IF,) He collected it together: (IF, Ḳ:) like kaladahu. (IF.)
kalatahu fiI AlUinaACi, aor. _i {yakolitu}, He poured it into the vessel. (Az, Ḳ.)
kalata XayoYFA (or kalata bihi, Ṣgh) He threw, or cast, a thing. (Ḳ.)
kalata, [aor. _i {yakolitu},] He urged a horse to run, by striking him with his feet; syn. rakaDa. (Aboo-Mihjen, Ḳ.)
7. Anklt It (beverage, TA) poured out, or forth; or was, or became, poured out, or forth. (Ḳ.)
He (a man, TA) shrunk; or became contracted. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. Aktlthu He drank it. (Fr, Ḳ, TA.)
kulotapN A lot, portion, or set portion, of food (Ḳ), &c. (TA.)
A little; a small portion; somewhat; syn. nubocapN; (Ḳ;) of a thing. (TA.)
farasN fulatapN kulatapN A horse that leaps, springs, or bounds, with his whole body and limbs. (Ḳ, TA.)
kltp (probably a mistake for kulobapN, TA,) Vehemence; severity; pressure; affliction. (TṢ.)
UimoraOapN kaluwtN i. q. jamuwEN. (TA.)

kaliytN and kil-iytN↓ An oblong stone (resembling a biroTiyl, TA) with which the hole of a hyena is stopped up: (Ḳ:) so (yusad-u bihi) accord. to IDrd.: or, as in some copies yusobaru bh, is probed: or, as in the TṢ, yusotaru bh, is covered: after this is applied, the earth is dug away to find the hyena: mentioned by IAạr. (TA.)
farasN ful-atN kul-atN, and fulatN kulatN, A swift horse. (Ḳ.)
kil-iytN: see kaliytN.
rajulN miSolatN mikolatN A man who is sharp, acute, or penetrating, in the transacting of affairs. (TṢ, L.) [See also mikolavN.]
Q. 1. kalotaba, inf. n. kalotabapN, He acted as a pimp. (IAạr.) See kalotabaAnN.

[Freytag assigns to this verb the signification Dissimulations, astutia, usus est in rebus; as from the Ḳ, with the same inf. n.: but I do not find it in any copy of that work. See, however, the next para.]
kalotabN and kulotubN Dissimulation, or craftiness, or deceit, in affairs: (Ḳ:) [or i. q. kalovabN, q. v.]
kalotabaAnN A pimp: (Ḳ:) from Alkalabu: [see kaliba]. (TA.)
7. Anklv He advanced: preceded: syn. taqad-ama. (Ḳ.)
mikolavN A man (TA) penetrating (maADK) in affairs. (Ḳ.) See mikolatN.
kalovabN and kulaAvibN Contracted [in hand or mind]: avaricious: (Ḳ:) dissembling, or using craft, or deceit, in affairs: app. a dial. syn. of kalotabN. (TA.) See also kalobavN.

1. kalaHa, aor. _a {yakolaHu}, inf. n. kuluwHN and kulaAHN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and tlk-H↓, and AklH↓, (Ḳ,) and Aklw-H↓; (A;) He (a man, Ṣ) grinned, or displayed his teeth, (M, rendered in the Ṣ and Ḳ by takaX-ara), frowning, or contracting his face, or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
kalaHa fiI wajohihi He frightened him; namely a child, and a madman. (A.)
2. kl-H wajohahu He contracted his face much. (A.)
3. mukaAlaHapN [inf. n. of kAlHhu He contended with him for superiority in strength;] i. q. muXaAd-apN. (Ṣ.) [And so mujaAlaHapN.]
4. OakolaHahu He (or it, L) made him to grin, or display his teeth, frowning, or contracting his face, or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely. (L, Ḳ.)
See 1.
5. tkl-H ‡ He smiled: see 1. (Ḳ.)
Hence, (TA,) tkl-H Albaroqu ‡ The lightning flashed in continued succession: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) also, it continued, and became concealed, in a white cloud. (L.)
kalaHapN ‡ The mouth and parts around it. So in the phrase maA OaqobaHa kalaHatahu How ugly is his mouth with the parts around it! (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kalaAHi: see kulaAHN.

kulaAHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kalaAHi↓, the latter [indecl.] like qaTaAmi, (Ḳ,) ‡ A year of dearth, scarcity, drought, sterility, or barrenness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say OaSaAbatohumo sanapN kulaAHN A year of dearth, &c., befell them. (TA.) See kaAliHN.

hom.sense: kaAliHN, act. part. n. of 1.
Also, Having the lip withdrawn from the teeth. (Zj, L.) So in the Ḳur xxiii. 106, accord. to Zj. (L.)
dahorN kaAliHN ‡ Severe, distressing, or afflictive, fortune, or time; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also kulaAHN↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: kawolaHN Foul, unseemly, or ugly; syn. qabiyHN: (Ḳ;) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)
balaMCN mukoliHN A trial, or an affliction, which, by its severity, makes men grin and frown. (L, from a trad.)
Q. 1. kaloHabahu He struck him with a sword. (Ḳ.)

kaloHabapN: of this word, Az says, It is not known what it is: but it is related, on the authority of IAạr, that it signifies The sound, and flame, of fire; or its sounding, and flaming: (as explained in the Ḳ:) or, accord. to the RA, it signifies its sound, or sounding, in what is slender, or small, as a lamp and the like. (TA.) [See also HadomN.]
5. tkl-d He (a man) was, or became, thick and firm in flesh. (L.)
See also Q. Q. 3.
R. Q. 3. Uikolanodada: see Q. Q. 3.

Q. Q. 3. UikolanodaI He (a man, Lḥ, and a camel, Ṣ, L) was, or became, thick, big, gross, or coarse, and strong; (Lḥ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) like UiEolanodaI; (Ṣ, L;) as also Uikolanodada↓ (Lḥ, L) and takal-ada↓: (Ḳ:) he, or it, was, or became, hard; (Ḳ;) and strong; as also Uikolanodada↓. (TA.)

kaladN [a coll. gen. n.] Rugged lands: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {kaladapN}: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or [hills such as are termed] UikaAm: n. un. with p {kaladapN}: and kalanodFI↓ also signifies a hill of this kind: (Ḳ:) also, a hard place without pebbles; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also kaladapN and kalanodFI↓: (TA:) or the last two words signify a piece of rugged ground or land. (Ṣ.) The Arabs use the expression Dab-u kaladapK, because the Db- burrows only in hard ground. (L.)
Oabuw kaladapK [in some copies of the Ḳ, kalodapK] a surname of The male hyena. (L, Ḳ.)
kalanodFI: see kaladN.

mukolanodK Strong, and thick, big, gross, or coarse, as also mukolanodidN↓: (Ḳ:) and ↓the latter, hard: (Ṣ, L:) and strong in make, and big: and, the former, accord. to some, strong; applied in a general manner: or a hard and strong camel; (L;) as also the latter. (TA.)
mukolanodidN: see mukolanodK.
1. kalasa: see 2.

2. kl-s, inf. n. takoliysN, He plastered (Tar-a) a building with kilos; as also kalasa↓, inf. n. kalosN: he made smooth [with plaster]: when a thing is thickly plastered, it is termed muqaromadN. (TA.) See kilosN.
As used by the alchemists, [He calcined a substance;] he dissolved a body so that it became like kilos. (TA.)

kilosN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and by poetic licence. kil-isN↓ (IJ) i. q. SaAruwjN [i. e. Quick time, and the mixtures thereof, with which are plastered tanks, or cisterns, and baths, &c.], (Ṣ, Ḳ.) or the like thereof, (TA,) with which one builds: (Ṣ, TA:) or that with which a wall, or the inside of a palace or the like, is plastered, resembling jiS [or gypsum], without baked bricks. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, describing El-Hadr, a city between the Tigris and Euphrates, (TA,)
XaAdahu maromarFA wajal-alahu kilo
sFA falilT-ayori fiI curaAhu wukuwru
[He raised it high, of marble, and covered it with quick time, and there were nests for the birds in its tops]: or, accord. to Aṣ, the right reading is waxal-alahu kilosFA, with x, meaning, and put SArwj into the interstices of its stones; and he used to laugh at him who related it in the former manner, with j. (TA.) But see 2.
kil-isN: see kilosN.
kal-aAsN: see mukal-isN.
[kal-aAsapN A lime-kiln: so in the present day.]

kayoluwsN [Chyle; from the Greek χυλός;] a term applied by the physicians to the food when it is digested in the stomach before it departs thence and becomes blood; also called kayomuwsN. (L.) [But the latter word more properly signifies “chyme,” and in this sense is used by modern physicians.]
mukal-isN A lime-burner; (Golius, on the authority of Meyd;) [as also kal-aAsN↓: or this latter signifies a seller of quick lime.]

dictScrap.title: klE / klf / klm / klI / km
dictScrap.label:
[klE, klf, klm, klI and km
See Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. kamaOa, aor. _a {yakomaOu}, inf. n. kamoCN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AkmO↓; (Ḳ;) He fed people with [the truffles called] kamoC. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

kamiYa, aor. _a {yakomaOu}, inf. n. kamaON, He walked barefoot, and had no shoes, or sandals; HafiIa walamo takuno Ealayohi naEolN: (accord. to some copies of the Ṣ, on the authority of Ks, and so in the L: or, accord. to the Ḳ, and an excellent copy of the Ṣ, HafiIa waEalayohi naEolN, [which may signify He became thin in the feet, from much walking, though wearing shoes, or sandals:]) kamaON in the foot is the same as qasaTN; [i. e., the being naturally stiff in the tendons]. (TA.)
kamiYato ‡ It (his foot, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, or hand, A) became much cracked (Th, Ṣ, Ḳ) by reason of cold. (A.) Also written in a copy of the A kmOt; app. by a mistake of the transcriber. (TA.)
kamiYa Eani AlOaxobaAri (Ḳ) inf. n. kamoCN, (TA,) He was ignorant of, and understood not, or minded not, the news. (Ḳ.)
4. AkmO It (a place) abounded with [the truffles called] kamoC. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See 1.
OakomaOatohu Als-in-u Age rendered him a Xayox, or an old man. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5. tkm-O He gathered [the truffles called] kamoC. (Ṣ.)
tkm-O Ealayohi AlOaroDu The earth hid him [as in a grave]. (Ḳ.)
tkm-Ohu He detested him, or it; syn. takar-ahahu. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. tkAmOnA fI OaroDihimo [We, together, gathered the truffles called kamoC in their land]. (A.)

kamoCN A well-known vegetable, (Ḳ,) [the truffle,] which comes forth from the earth like the fuTor: or what is called XaHomu AlOaroDi [the fat of the earth]; and the Arabs also call it judariI-u AlOaroDi [the small-pox of the earth]: it is also said that the name of kamoOapN is given to those [truffles] that incline to dust-colour and black; and jbOp (q. v.) to those that incline to red: kuHol and tuwtiyaA are compounded with the juice of this vegetable [to apply to the eye]: Th also mentions kamaApN [as used for kamoOapN]. (TA.) The dual of kamoCN is kamoMni; (Ṣ;) the pl. (of pauc., Ṣ) OakomuWN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and [pl. of mult.] kamoOapN: (Ḳ:) this last is not a pl. of kmC, but a quasi-pl. n.: (Sb, Ḳ:) [or kamoOapN is rather a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is without the p, contr. to analogy: (see jaboCN:)] in speaking of many, you say kamoOapN, contr. to analogy: (Ṣ:) or kamoOapN is the sing., and kamoCN pl.: or [accord. to some,] kamoOapN is both sing. and pl.: (Ḳ:) AḤn mentions kamoOapN as sing., and kamoOataAni as dual, and kamoMtN as pl.: but the right opinion is that of Sb. (TA.) [kamoOapN also signifies Any kind of fungus, such as the mushroom, and toadstool. See fuTorN.]
kam-aACN One who sells, and who gathers for sale, [the truffles called] kamoC. (Ḳ.)
makomaOapN and makomuWapN A place in which [the truffles called] kamoC grow. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. kamuta, (contr. to analogy, as verbs significant of colours [if unaugmented] are generally of the measure faEilN, MF,) aor. _u {yakomutu}, inf. n. kamotN and kumotapN (in the CK kamotapN) and kamaAtapN; and Akmt↓, inf. n. UikomaAtN; (Ḳ;) and Akmt-↓, inf. n. UikomitaAtN; and AkmAt-↓, (in the CK UikomaOat-a,) inf. n. UikomiytaAtN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He (a horse, Ṣ, Ḳ, [and a camel, &c.]) was, or became, of the colour called kumayotN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kamata AlgayoZa, [aor, _u,] He concealed, or hid in his bosom, rage, or wrath. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. km-t vawobahu ‡ He dyed his garment of the colour of [fresh ripe] dates; i. e., of a red colour inclining to black. (A.)
kum-itato She was rendered artificially of the colour called kumayotN, (Ḳ,) or was dyed of that colour. (So in a copy of the Ḳ.)
4: see 1.
9: see 1.
kumotN: see Oakomatu.

kumotapN [A dark bay colour:] a red colour mixed with blackness: (Kh, Sb:) or a red colour mixed with qunuwoC, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which latter is blackness that is not pure, or clear: (see kumayotN:) or a colour between black and red: (ISd:) there are two kinds of kmtp; namely kumotapu SuforapK [yellow bay, or gilded bay,] and kumotapu HumorapK [red bay, or chestnut-bay]. (IAạr.)

kumayotN, masc. and fem., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [A bay, or dark bay, or brown, horse, &c.:] of a red colour mixed with blackness: (Kh, Sb:) or of a red colour mixed with qunuwoC, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which latter is blackness that is not pure, or clear: (TA [app. from Aṣ]:) [see kumotapN, above:] a camel is called OaHomaru if of an unmixed red; but if of a red colour mixed with qnwC, it is called kmyt: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) the difference between kmyt and OaXoqaru, as applied to horses, is in the mane and the tail: if these are red, the animal is called AXqr [i. e. sorrel]; and if they are black, it is called kmyt; (AO, Ṣ, TA;) and the warod is between these two: (AO, TA:) [all bay horses have black manes, which distinguish them from the sorrel, that have red or white manes: (Farrier's Dict., quoted in Johnson's Dict., voce “bay”:)] an epithet applied to the horse and the camel and other animals: (ISd:) you say farasN kmytN, and muhorapN kmytN, and baEiyrN kmytN, and naAqapN kmytN: (TA:) accord. to the Kh, as cited by Sb, it is of the dim. form because it denotes a colour between black and red, as though to imply that it signifies what is near to each of these two colours. (Ṣ.) In a marginal note in the Ṣ, it is said to be a foreign word arabicized. (TA.) [Perhaps from the Persian kumiyCaho: Freytag says, accord. to some from the Persian kumyth.] See also Oakomatu, and kumotapN. The Arabs say, that the kmyt is the most powerful of horses, and the strongest in the hoofs. (TA.)

tamorapN kumayotN ‡ A date of the colour called kumayotN; [or, red tinged, or mixed, with black, or of a blackish red colour]: it is one of the kinds hardest, or toughest, in liHaMC [i. e. pulp, or flesh], and sweetest to chew. (AM.)
tiynN kumayotN ‡ A fig of that colour. (AḤn.)

kumayotN ‡ a name of Wine; because there is in it blackness and redness: (Ṣ:) or wine in which is blackness and redness: (M, Ḳ:) used like a proper name, [or rather as a subst.,] though originally an epithet. (TA.)
kumayotN is also applied as an epithet to waste, or unowned, land. (ISd.)
kumayotN A long, complete, month, or year. (IAạr.)
Oaxacahu bikamiytatihi He took it by its root. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
kamaAtiI-N: see next paragraph.
[Oakomatu]

xayolN kumotN, and kamaAtiI-N↓, (Ḳ,) and kamaAtaI, of the same measure as EacaAraI, (TA,) Horses of the colour of that which is called kumayotN, (Ḳ,) kmt is a pl. formed from Oakomatu; though this sing. has not been used: (L:) and kmAtI is a pl. formed from kamotaACu [fem. of Oakomatu] regarded as a subst.; though this sing. also has not been used. (TA.)

Q. 1. kamovara, inf. n. kamovarapN, It became compact, one part of it entering into another, or parts into parts: (Ḳ: [but only the inf. n. is there mentioned:]) an obsolete verb: (TA:) whence the following word, (IDrd, Ḳ,) if it be Arabic. (IDrd.)

kum-avorFI (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a [coll.] gen. n., with tenween, and, accord. to some, kumavorFI, without teshdeed, but others disallow this, (Mṣb,) A certain kind of fruit; (T, Ṣ;) well known; [namely, the pear;] called by [some of] the vulgar Uij-aASN: (T:) [it is called by this latter name, and also UinojaAS and UinojaAs, in Syria; but in Egypt and some other countries, kum-avoraI:] n. un. kum-avoraApN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pl. kum-avorayaAtN: (Ḳ:) [here I find added in the TA, it is fem., imperfectly decl.; and in the Ḳ, “and sometimes it is masc.”: but this is evidently wrong: it is masc., and with tenween, as is shown by its n. un.; but it is sometimes made fem., and then it must be written kum-avoraI, without tenween: for it is added,] and one says, hecihi kum-avoraI waAHidapN [this is one pear: in the copies of the Ḳ in my possession erroneously written kum-avorFI]: and hecihi kum-avoraI kaviyrapN [these are many pears]. (Ḳ.) Its dim. has the following forms: kumayomivorapN, (Ḳ,) which is the most agreeable with analogy, (ISd, TA,) and kumayomivoriyapN, (Ḳ,) which is the form adopted by those who make the pl. km-avorayaAtN, (ISk, TA,) and kumayovirapN, (Ḳ,) which is the best form, (ISk, TA,) and kumayomivoraApN. (Ḳ.) Az says, I have asked a number of Arabs of the desert respecting the kmvr-I, but they knew it not. (TA.)

1. kamaHa Ald-aAb-apa, [aor. _a {yakomaHu},] (inf. n. kamoHN; M) and OakomaHahaA↓; i. q. kabaHahaA (AʼObeyd, Ḳ) and OakobaHahaA: (AʼObeyd:) or kamaHa Ald-aAb-apa biAlil-jaAmi signifies He pulled in the horse, or the like, by the bridle and bit, in order that it might stop, and not run: (M:) and AkmHhA↓, he pulled its bridle so that its head became upright, or erect. (Aṣ, Ṣ, M.)

hom.sense: 4: See 1.
AkmH Alkaromu The grape-vine became in a state of commotion preparatory to its putting forth its leaves. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AkmHt Alz-amaEapu The gem, or knot, in the place whence a bunch of grapes was about to grow forth became white, and what resembled cotton came forth upon it. (Az, on the authority of Et-Táïfee.)
See also Akmx and OuqomiHa.

entry.sense: kawomaHN (and kuwmaHN, L) A man (Ṣ) having large buttocks. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

Also kawomaHN, A man (TA) whose teeth fill his mouth so that his speech is thick: (Ḳ:) or a man whose teeth are crowded together, one upon another, so that his mouth seems to be straitened by them. (IDrd.)
famN kwmH A mouth straitened by the great number of the teeth and by the swelling of the gums. (IDrd.)

hom.sense: 1. kamaxa biOanofihi, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yakomaxu}; (Ḳ;) and Akmx↓ bAnfh; (L;) He magnified himself, or was proud; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) elevated his nose, from pride: (L:) or Akmx he elevated his head, from pride; (L;) i. q. AqmH [in the CK with x]: (Ḳ:) or he sat in the manner of him who magnifies himself (Ṣ, L) in his own mind. (L.) OakomaxuwA baOowFA They flourished and increased in self exaltation: or taraAd-uwA. (L.)

kamaxahu biAll-ijaAmi He pulled him in [i. e. a horse or the like] by the bridle and bit, in order to check or stop him; (L:) i. q. kabaHahu; (Ḳ;) [or he pulled up his head by the bridle and bit]. See kamaHa.

kamaxa bihi, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yakomaxu}, (L,) inf. n. kmoxN, (Ṣ, L,) He voided it, namely his excrement, or ordure; or voided it in a thin state; syn. salaHa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Some bread and kaAmaxN [q. v. infra] were offered to an Arab of the desert, and he knew not the latter; so it was said to him, “This is kAmx;” whereupon he said, “I know that it is kAmx;” and added, Oay-ukumo kamaxa bihi “which of you voided it?” Ay-km salaHa bh. (Ṣ.)
kamaxa bisaloHihi, aor. and inf. n. as above, He (a camel) voided his excrement, or ordure, in a thin state. (L.)
4: See 1.
Akmx It (a vine) put forth its gems when about to put forth its leaves. (AḤn.) [See also OakomaHa.]

entry.sense: kumaAxN The magnifying one's self; pride. (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, Ḳ.)

kaAmaxN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) sometimes written and pronounced kaAmixN, (Mṣb, and written in both these ways in a copy of the Ṣ) but the former is better known, and more common, (TA,) an arabicized word, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) from the Persian kaAmaho, (Mgh, Shifá el-Ghaleel,) A kind of seasoning, or condiment, eaten with bread to render it pleasant, or savoury; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [a thing used to give relish to food, or to quicken the appetite;] accord. to some, prepared with vinegar, and used to quicken the appetite; (TA;) also called mur-iI-N: (Mṣb:) or it is a bad sort of mur-iI-: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. kawaAmixu, (Mṣb,) or kawaAmiyxu. (Mgh.)
malikN kayomaxN A king having his head elevated, from pride. (L.)
1. kamida, aor. _a {yakomadu}, inf. n. kamadN, It (a thing) became changed in colour, (L,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and lost its clearness, (L, Ḳ,) the traces thereof remaining. (L.)
kamida lawonuhu His, or its, colour became changed. (L.)
kamida Alv-awobu The garment became worn-out, (A, Ḳ,) and smooth, (Ḳ,) so that its colour changed. (A.)
kamada, (aor. _u {yakomudu} K, inf. n. kamodN and kumuwdN, TA,) He (a fuller, L) beat a garment, or piece of cloth. (L, Ḳ.)

kamida, aor. _a {yakomadu}, inf. n. kamadN, ‡ He (a man) was affected with concealed grief or sorrow: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or, with grief or sorrow which he could not dispel: (L:) or, with intense grief or sorrow: (Ḳ:) or, with most intense grief or sorrow: (L:) and, with disease of the heart from intense grief or sorrow. (Ḳ.)

2. km-dhu, inf. n. takomiydN, He heated it (a limb) with a kimaAdap; (Ḳ;) heated it with rags and the like; (Ṣ, L;) applied to it a kimaAdap. (A.) kimaAdN [which see below] signifies the same as takomiydN. (Ṣ, L.)

He heated for him a garment or piece of cloth or some other thing, and applied it to a place in which he suffered pain in one of his limbs, so as to give him ease. You also say Oakomadahu↓; and makomuwdN is used as the pass. part. n. of this verb, anomalously. (L.)
4. Akmdhu He (a fuller, Ṣ, A, L, and a washer, L) failed of cleaning it, (Ṣ, A, L,) and of making it white, (A,) namely, a garment. or piece of cloth. (Ṣ, &c.)
Akmdhu He, or it, affected him with intense grief or sorrow: and, with disease of the heart from intense grief or sorrow: (Ḳ:) it (grief) rendered him sorrowful. (A.)
See 2.
kamodN: see kamadN.
kamadN (L, Ḳ) and kamodN↓ (Ḳ) and kumodapN↓, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the last a simple subst., (Mṣb,) Change of colour, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and loss of its clearness, (L, Ḳ,) the traces thereof remaining. (L.)
kamidN A thing changed in colour; (Mṣb;) see 1; and Oakomadu↓ All-awoni [the same]: (A:) and kaAmidu↓ Alwajohi [changed in countenance]. (A.)
Frowning, or contracting his face; looking sternly, austerely, or morosely; as also kaAmidN↓. (L.)
kumodapN: see kamadN.
kimaAdN (a subst. Ḳ) The act of beating a garment, or a piece of cloth, by a fuller. (L, Ḳ.*)

kimaAdN (Ḳ) and kimaAdapN (A, L, Ḳ) A greasy, (A,) or dirty, (Ḳ,) or greasy and dirty, (L,) piece of rag, which is heated, and put upon a pained part, as a means of cure, (A, L, Ḳ,) for pain (A, Ḳ) of the belly, (Ḳ,) or flatulence. (A, Ḳ.)

kimaAdN i. q. takomiydN; see 2; (Ṣ, L;) [The application of a kimaAdap;] the taking a piece of rag, and heating it with fire, and putting it upon the place of a swelling. (Sh, L.) It is said in a trad., AlkimaAdu OaHab-u UilaI-a mina AlkaI-i [The application of a kimaAdap is more pleasing to me than cauterization]. (Ṣ, L.)
kamiydN and kaAmidN: see kamidN.
makomuwdN, which is extr., being from Oakomadahu: (TA:) see 4, and kamidN.
1. kamara He (a circumciser) missed the place of circumcision [and hurt, or wounded, the glans of the penis]. (IḲṭṭ.)

kamarapN The head [or glans] of the penis; (Ḳ;) or i. q. HaXafapN: (Mṣb:) pl. kamarN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or rather, the latter is a coll. gen. n.; and the former, the n. un.] It is said in a proverb, Alkamaru OaXobaAhu Alkamari; alluding to the likeness of one thing to another. (Ḳ.)
Hence, by synecdoche, ‡ The penis, altogether. (Mṣb.)
makomuwrN A man (Ṣ) having the head [or glans] of his penis, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the extremity of the head of his penis, (Ṣ,) hurt, or wounded, by the circumciser. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

kayomuwsN [Chyme; from the Greek χυμός;] a term applied by the physicians to the food when it is digested in the stomach before it departs thence and becomes blood; also called kayoluwsN: (L, TA:) [but the latter word more properly signifies “chyle,” and in this sense is used by modern physicians:] a certain mixture or humour (xiloTN): a Syriac word: (Ḳ:) [or Greek, as mentioned above:] Az says, that kayomuwsaAtN, as used by the physicians, signifies the four humours; and is not Arabic, but ancient Greek. (TA.)
kayomuwsiy-apN Want, or requirement, of food, or nourishment. Occurring in a trad. of Kuss, where it is said to be not an attribute of God. (ISd, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. kamuXato, aor. _u {yakomuXu}, inf. n. kamaAXapN, She (a woman) was, or became, small in the breast. (TA.)
kamuXati AlxuSoyapu, inf. n. kumuwXapN, [The testicle, or the scrotum,] was, or became, short, and cleaving to the inner skin. (TA.) See also 5.

kamuXa, inf. n. kamaAXapN, He (a man) was, or became, quick; (Ḳ;) as also tkm-X↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and AnkmX↓; (Ḳ, TA;) and AkmX↓, in relation to pace and to work: (IḲṭṭ:) or quick and sharp or vigorous or effective: (Ṣ:) or determined or resolute, and sharp or vigorous or effective, (A, TA,) and quick, in his affairs: (TA:) or courageous. (Sb, ISd.) You say, AnkmX↓ fiI saEoyihi and tkm-X↓ [He was quick,, &c., in his walking, or running, or working]. (A.) And AnkmX↓ Alfarasu fiI sayorihi [The horse was quick,, &c., in his going, or pace.] (A.) And AnkmX↓ fiI Oamorihi He hastened, or was sharp or vigorous or effective, in his affair. (Aṣ.) And AnkmX↓ fiI AlHaAjapi He was quick and vigorous in executing the needful affair; syn. AjotamaEa fiyhaA. (TA.)
And kamuXa He determined, resolved, or decided, upon an affair; as also kamiXa, [aor. _a {yakomaXu}] inf. n. kamaXN. (TA.)
2. km-X cayolahu, (A, TA,) inf. n. takomiyXN, (TA,) He contracted, or tucked up, his skirt. (A, TA.)
km-Xhu, (inf. n. as above, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He hastened him; made him quick; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) [and so app. AkmXhu↓: see Xam-ara.]
And km-X, (Ḳ,) or km-X AlUibila, inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a man singing to camels to urge or excite them) was vigorous in driving [so that he made the camels quick]. (Ḳ, TA.)
4. AkmX: see 1.
AkmXhu: see 2.
AkmX biAln-aAqapi He bound all the teats of the camel with the SiraAr, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5. tkm-X It (skin) contracted, or shrank, (A, Ḳ,) and became drawn together; (Ḳ;) and so AnkmX↓, said of a garment, or piece of cloth, after washing; (Ḳ, art. qlS;) and of an udder. (TA.) See also 1.
See again 1, in two places.
7. AnkmX: see 5.
See also 1, in five places.
kamoXN Short and small; applied to an udder: and [the fem.] with p {kamoXapN}, applied to a testicle, or a scrotum, (xuSoyap) short, and cleaving to the inner skin. (TA.)

Applied to a horse, Small in the veretrum; as also kamiyXN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or short therein: [contr. of saAbigN:] pl. [of mult.] kimaAXN and [of pauc.] OakomaAXN: (AʼObeyd:) or, applied to a beast of carriage, short and small therein: (ʼEyn:) but when applied to a female, having a small udder; as also kamiyXN↓, (Ḳ,) or kamiyXapN, so applied, (ʼEyn,) and kamoXapN, applied to a she-camel, (Ks, Ṣ,) and kamuwXN↓, thus applied: (TA:) or kamiyXapN [so in the Ḳ accord. to the TA, but in some copies of the Ḳ kamiXapN↓,] and kamuwXN have this signification when applied to a ewe or she-goat: (Ḳ:) or the former of these two epithets, (Aṣ,) or each of them, (Ḳ,) thus applied, signifies short in the teat, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) so as to be milked only with the ends of three fingers, or with the thumb and forefinger: (Aṣ:) and kamoXapN, applied to a woman, having a small breast. (TA.)

Also, and kamiyXN↓, applied to a man, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) Quick: (A, Ḳ:) or quick and sharp or vigorous or effective: (Ṣ:) or determined or resolute, and sharp or vigorous or effective, (A, TA,) and quick in his affairs: (TA:) and kamiXN↓ [app. applied to a man, being the part. n. of kamiXa, q. v.] is syn. with kamoXN: (TA:) or kamiyXN↓ signifies courageous. (Sb, ISd.)

entry.sense: kamiXN: fem. with p {kamiXapN}: see above, in two places.
kamuwXN: see above, in three places.
kamiyXN: fem. with p {kamiyXapN}: see above, passim.
rajulN kamiyXu AlUizaAri [lit.] A man having his AzAr [or waist-wrapper] tucked up; (Ḳ, TA;) [meaning,] vigorous, laborious, or sedulous, in his affair. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: kmE / kml / kmn / kmh / kmI / kn
dictScrap.label:
[kmE, kml, kmn, kmh, kmI and kn
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: 1. kanaba, aor. _u {yakonubu}, inf. n. kunuwbN; and Aknb↓; He, or it, was, or became, gross; thick, coarse; or rough: syn. galuZa. (Ḳ.) See 4.
kanaba He was, or became, possessed of plenty, or riches: syn. AisotagonaI. (Ḳ.)
kanabahu fiI jiraAbihi, aor. _i {yakonibu}, inf. n. kanobN, He stowed it, or deposited it, in his provision-bag. (Ḳ.)

4. Oakonabato yaduhu; and kanibato↓, aor. _a {yakonabu}, inf. n. kanabN; (Ḳ;) or the former verb only is used; not the latter; (Aṣ, Ṣ;) His hand was, or became, callous, or hard, (Ṣ,) or coarse, or rough, (Ḳ,) by reason of work. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See 1.
Aknb lisaAnuhu His tongue was impeded, or tied up. (Ḳ.)
Aknb Ealayohi baTonuhu His belly [meaning its contents] oppressed him, or gave him pain: syn. UiXotad-a. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: kanabN Callousness, or hardness, of the hand, resulting from work: (Ṣ:) or coarseness, or roughness, of the foot, and of the hoof, and of the camel's foot, and of the hand: or of the hand only, resulting from work. (Ḳ.)
See kanibN.

entry.sense: kanibN, of the same measure as katifN, (Ḳ,) or kanabN↓, (as in the copies of the Ṣ in my hands) A certain plant: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a certain tree: (Lth:) AḤn says, It resembles the qataAd growing in our country, where, sometimes, sandals or shoes are sewed with its bark, and thereof are twisted ropes which endure moisture, day-dew, or rain: and in one place he says, I asked one of the Arabs of the desert respecting the knb, and he shewed me a scattered, small, thorny plant, with white twigs or branches, abounding with thorns, having, at the extremities, baraAEiym [or calyxes, or flowers, or flower-buds,] from each of which grew forth three thorns. (TA.)
kinaAbN i. q. XimoraAxN [i. e. the fruit-stalk of the raceme of a palm tree]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kaniybN What is dry, of trees: or having its thorns broken. (Ḳ.)
kunotubN and kunaAtibN Short: (Ḳ:) or thick, or coarse, and short: (TA:) or hard and strong: (see kunotvubN:) but the v is augmentative, (TA,) [and therefore the proper art. is knb].
kaAnibN Full to satiety; glutted with food. (Ḳ.)
mukonabN and mikonabN: see next paragraph.
mukonibN and mikonabN↓ A coarse, or rough, hoof; (IAạr, Ḳ;) and the same words, and mukonabN↓, the same as applied to a camel's foot. (IAạr)
mukonaYib-N Thick, or coarse, and strong, and short. (Ḳ)
Q. 2. takanobata He (a man) became contracted [in disposition; or niggardly, or stingy]. (L, as from IDrd.) But see art. knbv. (TA.)
kunobubN, (or this should be kunovubN, TA) A hard, strong, robust, man. (L.) But see kunobuvN. (TA.)
Also, and kunaAbitN, A man contracted [in disposition]; niggardly, or stingy. (L.) But see art. knbv. (TA.)
Q. 2: see Q. 1.
kunobuvN and kunobuwvN↓ and kunaAbivN↓ Hard (L, Ḳ) and strong. (L.) [Epithets applied to a man.]
Also, all the three words, Contracted [in disposition], and niggardly, or stingy. (Ḳ.)
Mentioned before in art. kbv; and like kulobuvN. (TA.)
[Accord. to the L, these epithets seem also to apply to a man Contracted in make: the first and third being expl. by the words tadaAxala baEoDuhu fiI baEoDK.]
kunobuwvN: see kunobuvN.
kunaAbivN: see kunobuvN and art. knvb.

hom.sense: 1. kanata fiI xaloqihi, (aor. _u {yakonutu}, inf. n. kanotN, TḲ,) He (a man) was strong in his make. (IAạr, TṢ, Ḳ.)

kanita, aor. _a {yakonatu}, It (a skin, TA) became foul with the grease of milk [and so retained the water, or milk, well]; syn. HaXina: (TṢ, and SM's copy of the Ḳ: in the CK and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, xaXuna: in another copy of the Ḳ, Hasuna.)

entry.sense: 8. Aktnt He was lowly; humble; submissive. (Ḳ.) [See Aiqotanata.]
He was content, or well pleased; acquiesced. (Ḳ.)
kunotN: see kunotiI-N.
siqaACN kaniytN [as also qaniytN] A skin that retains [the water, or milk,] well. (Ḳ.)

kunotiI-N Strong; robust. (Ibn-Buzruj, Ḳ.) An epithet applied to a man. (Ibn-Buzruj.) Formed from kunotu “I was” because an old man speaks of himself in time past saying kunotu kacaA wakunotu kacaA. (MF.)

Also, [and kunotN↓, as implied in the TA, and in the Ṣ in art., Ejn,] and kunotuniI-N↓, i. q. kabiyrN [app. Great in age; old: aged]. (AZ, Ḳ.) A poet says,
wamaA kunotu kunotiy-FA wamaA kunotu EaAjinFA
waXar-u Alr-ijaAli AlkunotuniI-u waEaAjinu
[And I was not old, nor was I one who raised himself from the ground by the help of his hands: and the worst of men is the old, and one who raises himself so]. (TA.)
kunotaniI-N: see kunotiI-u.
kunotubN and kunaAtibN: see art. knb.

kunovapN A nawarodjap (in the TA, nawarodaHap, with H unpointed,) made of myrtle, and of the branches of the [kind of willow called] xilaAf (spread out, TA), upon which sweet-smelling plants are arranged, or disposed, in regular series, and which is then folded: (Lth, Ḳ:) the Nabathean word is knvA. (L.) It is a circular thing (daAYirap) of myrtle, and of branches of willow, upon which sweet-smelling plants are disposed, or arranged, and which is then folded like a volume, or roll, and made in the form of a basket: the damsels prepare this for ornament in the days of the springseason, and amuse themselves with it. nwrdjp is an arabicized word, from the Persian nawarodho, pass. part. n. of nawarodiydano, and meaning “folded,” or “twisted” (TḲ, [as explained to me by a very learned Turk, who, however, thinks the words not very clear.])
kanovabN and kunovubN and kunaAvibN Hard and strong: (Ḳ:) but the v in this case is corrupted from t: see kunotubN in art. knb. (TA.)
kinovaAbN [in the TA written knAbv] Sand pouring down. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
1. kanada, (Ṣ, &c.), aor. _u {yakonudu}, (A, MṢ,) or _i, (El-Basáïr,) or kanada niEomapF, (TA,) inf. n. kunuwdN, (Ṣ. Ḳ, &c.) He was ungrateful; he disacknowledged a benefit. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
Uino saOalotahu nakada waUino OaEoTayotahu kanada If thou ask of him, he refuseth; and if thou give him. he is ungrateful. (A.)
kanada OabaAhu Aln-iEomap (Ḳ) He disacknowleged his father's beneficence. (TA.)
kanacuhu, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. kanodN, (Ḳ,) He cut, or severed, it. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
kunadN: see kanuwdN.
kinodapN A portion of a mountain. (Ḳ.)

kanuwdN Ungrateful; who disacknowledges benefits; (El-Kelbee, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) as also kan-aAdN↓: (L, Ḳ;) or a denier: (L:) the former applied also to a woman; and so kunudN↓: (Ṣ, A, L:) an unbeliever: (Zj, L:) a blamer of his Lord, (El-Ḥasan, L, Ḳ,) who takes account of evil accidents and forgets benefits: (El-Ḥasan, L:) rebellious. or disobedient, (Ḳ,) in the dial. of Kindeh: (TA:) niggardly; tenacious; avaricious; (Ḳ;) in the dial. of the Benoo-Málik: (TA:) who eats alone, and withholds his drinking-bowl (rifodahu), and beats his slave: (Kh, L, Ḳ:) all these meanings are assigned to it in the verse [6 of ch. c.] of the Ḳur-án, Uin-a QloUinosaAna lirab-ihi lakanuwdN: but of the last, ISd remarks, that he knows no foundation for it in the classical language, and that it is not easily admissible coupled with lrb-h. (L, TA.)
A woman ungrateful for friendship, and for loving communion, commerce, or intercourse; (Aṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also kunudN↓. (Aṣ, L.)
OaroDN kanuwdN ‡ Land that produces nothing. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
kan-aAdN: see kanuwdN.
Also, One who cuts, or severs; who is wont to do so. (Ṣ, L.)
kunoduvN and kunaAdivN Hard and strong: (Ḳ, L:) [as also kunobuvN and kunotubN, &c.].

kunodurN [Greek χόνδρος λιβανωτοῦ, or λιβάνου χόνδρος] i. q. lubaAnN [q. v., i. e. Frankincense], (Ṣ, in art. kdr; TA;) accord. to the physicians; (TA;) a kind of Eilok [or resin], very useful for stopping phlegm, (Ḳ,) and a dispeller of forgetfulness, and having other properties: n. un. with p {kunodurapN}. (TA.)

1. kanaza AlmaAla, aor. _i {yakonizu}, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and, accord. to MF, _u also, but the former is that which commonly obtains, (TA,) inf. n. kanozN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) He buried the property, or treasure, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in the earth: (TA:) he collected the property together, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and treasured it, hoarded it, laid it up, reposited it, stowed it, or stored it, in secret: (Mṣb:) and Aktnz↓ AlmaAla signifies the same as kanazahu. (TA.)
kanaza AlX-aIoCa, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yakonizu}, inf. n. kanozN, (TA,) He pressed the thing, meaning anything, (Ḳ,) with his hand or foot, (TA,) in a receptacle, or in the earth. (Ḳ.)

kanazaAlt-amora, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yakonizu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kanozN, (Mṣb, TA,) and, accord. to Az, kanaAzN and kinaAzN, [but see the former of these two words below,] (Mṣb,) He stowed, or packed, the dates, (TA,) fiI AlwiEaMCi in the receptacle, (A, Mṣb,) or fiI AljilaAli in the large receptacles of palm-leaves, [pl. of jul-ap,] by throwing [the contents of] a bag (jiraAb) into the bottom of the jul-ap and pressing them with the feet until they became compacted, or commixed in a mass, and then bag after bag until the jl-p was pressed full, when it was sewed up with palm-leaf cord. (TA.)
kanaza Albur-a fiI AljiraAbi [He stored up, or packed, the wheat in the bag]. (TA.) [See an ex. of the pass. part. n. voce dar-N.]
kanaza AljiraAba He filled the bag very full. (A.) And kanaza Als-iqaMCa He filled the skin of milk or water. (TA.) And Xad-a kanoza Alqirobapi He filled the water-skin. (TA.)
kanaza Alr-NmoHa, (Ṣgh, TA,) inf. n. kanozN, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) He stuck the spear into the ground. (Ṣgh, Ḳ,* TA.)

hom.sense: 8. Aktnz It (a thing, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) became collected together, or compacted; and full. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Aktnz Alt-amoru [The dates became closely packed, or pressed together so as to be compact or commixed in a mass: see 1]. (TA; and Ḳ in art. wjO;, &c.) The like is also said of wheat. (TA.)
Aktnz All-aHomu The flesh became compact, or hard. (From an explanation of the part. n. in the A;, &c.)
Aktnz AljiraAbu The bag became very full. (A.) And Aktnz Als-iqaMCu The skin of milk or water became full. (TA.)
Aktnz AlmaAla: see 1.
kanozN Treasure; property buried (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) in the earth: (TA:) an inf. n. used as a subst.: pl. kunuwzN. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
Hence, (TA,) it is applied in a trad. to ‡ Any property whereof the portion that should be given in alms is not given. (Ṣ, TA.)
Property that is preserved in a receptacle. (TA.)
Anything abundant, collected together, that is desired with emulation. (Sh, TA.)
Gold: and silver. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., OuEoTiytu Alkanozayoni mina AlOaHomari waAlOaboyaDi I have been given gold and silver. (TA.)

‡ [A treasure of knowledge or science]. You say, maEahu kanozN mino kunuwzi AlEilomi ‡ [With him is a treasure of the treasures of knowledge or science]. (A, TA.) In the Ḳur, xviii. 81, it is said to be used in a similar manner, as signifying not gold nor silver, but ‡ Science and books. (TA.) And it is said in like manner in a trad., OalaA OuEal-imuka kanozFA mino kunuwzi Aljan-api laA Hawola walaA quw-apa Uil-aA biQll-ehi ‡ [Ho! I will teach thee a treasure of the treasures of paradise: There is no power nor strength but in God]: meaning, that a reward is stored up [in paradise] for him who says this, and who describes himself thereby, like as a treasure is stored up. (TA.)

Aboo-ʼAlee El-Ḳálee says, that it is used in a verse of 'Alkamah, which he does not quote, as signifying ‡ Fat; as a subst.; and adds, that it is the only instance known to him of its being thus used. (TA.)

Also, That in which property is preserved, or guarded: (Ḳ,* TA:) and makonizN↓ [or rather both] that in which property is buried, treasured, hoarded, laid up, reposited, or stored, in secret: pl. of the latter, makaAnizu. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: kanizN: see mukotanizN.

kanaAzN and kinaAzN↓: see kanaza Alt-amora. [Accord. to Az, they are inf. ns.; but some seem to regard them as simple substs.] You say, hecaA zamanu AlkanaAzi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.*) and AlkinaAzi↓, (Ḳ,) This is the time of packing the dates. (Ḳ,* TA.) And El-Umawee says, Oatayotuhumo Einoda AlkanaAzi, and AlkinaAzi↓, I came to them when they were packing the dates. (TA.) ISk says, that it has been heard only with fet-ḥ; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) but some say, that it is like jadaAdN and jidaAdN, and SaraAmN and SiraAmN. (Ṣ.)
Also, sometimes, [The storing, or packing,] of wheat. (TA.)

hom.sense: kinaAzN: see kanaAzN:
and see also mukotanizN, throughout.

entry.sense: kaniyzN Dates packed in [the receptacles called] qawaASir [pl. of qawoSar-apN] (Ḳ, TA) and jilaAl [pl. of jul-apN]. (TA,) for winter; (Ḳ, TA;) as also makonuwzN↓. (TA.) See kanaza Alt-amora.
See also mukotanizN.
kan-aAzN One who takes extraordinary pains in treasuring, or hoarding, gold and silver. (TA.)
makonizN: see kanozN.
makonuwzN: see kaniyzN:
and mukotanizN.

mukotanizu All-aHomi, and kaniyzuhu↓, (A, TA,) and kanizahu↓, and makonuwzuhu↓, (TA,) Compact, or hard, in flesh: (A:) and [in like manner] kinaAzN↓ compact and strong in flesh. (TA.) You say, naAqapN kinaAzN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or kinaAzu All-aHomi, (A,) and jaAriyapN kinaAzN, (Ḳ,) and hanN kinaAzN, (TA,) A she-camel, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and a girl, (Ḳ,) and a woman's pudendum, (TA,) compact, (mukotanizap, Ṣ, or kaniyzap, or, as in the Ḳ, abundant, kaviyrap, TA,) in flesh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and hard, or firm: (Ḳ:) pl. kunozN and kinaAzN; the latter being like the sing.; (Ḳ;) but the two vowels [namely the two kesrehs] and the two alifs are regarded as different; for the word is not, as some assert, of the same class as junubN, since it has a dual form, namely kinaAzaAni. (TA.)
kitaAbN mukotanizN biAlfawaAYidi ‡ [A book, or writing, stored with useful things]. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. kanasa, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yakonusu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or _i, (Mgh,) inf. n. kanosN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He swept (Mgh, TA) a house, or chamber, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) or place, (TA,) with a mikonasap [or broom]. (A, Mgh.)
mar-uwA bihimo fakanasuwhumo ‡ They passed by them and swept them away, or destroyed them; syn. kasaHuwhumo. (A, TA.)

kanasa, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yakonisu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or _u, (Mgh,) inf. n. kunuwsN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) He (an antelope) entered his kinaAs, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e., his covert, or hiding-place, among trees; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or abode; (Mṣb;) or cave; (TA;) as also tkn-s↓ (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ) and Aktns↓; (A, TA;) which two verbs are likewise said of a wild bull or cow, in the same sense. (TA.) [Hence,] tkn-s↓ also signifies ‡ He (a man, TA) entered the tent: (Ḳ:) or hid himself, and entered the tent. (TA.) And tkn-st↓ ‡ She (a woman) entered the hawodaj [or camel-litter]: (Ḳ:) app. taken from the saying of Lebeed, fatakan-asuwA quTonFA, meaning, and they entered hawaAdij [or camel-litters] covered with cloths of cotton. (TA.)

[Hence also,] kanasati Aln-ujuwmu, (Zj,) aor. _i {yakonisu}, (AO, Zj, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. kunuwsN, (Lth, Zj,) ‡ The stars hid themselves in their place, or places, of setting, (AO, Zj, Ṣ, Ḳ,*) like antelopes in their kunus [or coverts]: (Ḳ:) [or] continued in their courses and then departed, returning: (Zj:) or the stars [here meaning planets] became stationary in their circuiting or revolving. (Lth.) See kaAnisN.

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in four places.
8: see 1.

kinaAsN A gazelle's covert, or hiding-place, among trees: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because he sweeps (ykns) the sand, or in the sand, [accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,] until he reaches the soil, or moist earth: (Ḳ,* TA:) or his abode: (Mṣb:) or cave: (TA:) and [in like manner] makonisN↓ a place into which a gazelle or a wild bull or cow enters to protect itself therein from the heat: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OakonisapN (TA) and [of mult.] kunusN and kun-asN (Ḳ) and [pl. pl., i. e., pl. of kunusN,] kunusaAtN. (TA.)
kunaAsapN Sweepings; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the dust of a house that is swept and thrown into a heap. (Lḥ.)
Also, The place of sweepings; (Mgh;) the place where sweepings are thrown. (TA.)

hom.sense: kaniysapN A place of worship (Ḳ) of the Christians; [a Christian church:] (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or of the Jews; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) i. e., of the Jews only: [a Jewish synagogue;] that of Christians being called biyEapN: (Ṣgh:) [Chald כְניִשָה: (Golius:)] or both; (Mgh, Mṣb;) being sometimes applied to the former [in classical times, as it is in the present day, as well as to the latter]: (Mṣb:) or of unbelievers, (Ḳ,) absolutely: (TA:) an arabicized word, [from the Chaldee mentioned above, or] from [the Persian word] kunisoto (Az, Mgh) or kanasoto (TA) [signifying “a firetemple”]: pl. kanaAYisu. (A, Mṣb.)

A thing resembling [the kind of camel-litter called] a hawodaj, composed of twigs, or branches, stuck in a maHomil or a raHol, with a cloth thrown over them, in which the rider sits in the shade and conceals himself: (Mgh, Mṣb:) of the measure faEiylapN from kunuwsN [an inf. n. of kanasa]: (Mgh:) pl. as above. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: kan-aAsN One who sweeps HuXuwX [meaning privies]. (A, TA.)

kaAnisN An antelope, (Ṣ, A, TA,) and a wild bull, (TA,) entering his kinaAs, (Ṣ, A, TA,) i. e., his covert, or hiding-place, among trees: (Ṣ:) fem. with p {kaAnisapN}}: (Zj:) pl. kun-asN, both of the masc. and fem., (Zj,) and kawaAnisu, of the masc., (A,) [and of the fem. also accord. to rule,] and kunuwsN. (TA.)

[Hence,] Alkun-asu, (Ṣ,) or AljawaAriI Alkun-asu, (Ḳ,) [in the Ḳur, lxxxi. 16,] ‡ The stars; because they hide themselves in their place of setting: (AO, Ṣ:) or the stars that rise running their course, and hide themselves in their places of setting: (Zj:) or all the stars; because they appear by night and lie hidden by day: (Ḳ:) or i. q. Alxun-asu, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., Als-ay-aArapu, (TA,) or Als-ay-aAraAtu, (Bḍ,) or Alxun-asu Als-ay-aArapu, (Ṣ,) the five stars, [or planets,] Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Venus, and Mercury; (TA;) because they hide themselves in their place of setting, like antelopes in their kunus [or coverts]; (Ḳ;) or because they become hidden beneath the light of the sun: (Bḍ:) or the stars [meaning plants] that become hidden in their courses, and run their courses and become stationary in their places of circuiting, and then circuit [again]; every star [of those thus named] having a circuit in which it becomes stationary, and [then] revolves [again], and then it departs, returning: (Lth:) or the angels: (Ḳ:) or the wild bulls or cows, and the wild antelopes, (Zj, Ḳ,) that enter their kunus [or coverts] when the heat is vehement. (Zj.)
makonisN: [pl. makaAnisu:] see kinaAsN.
[Hence,] makaAnisu Alr-ayobi † The places of suspicion. (TA.)
mikonasapN A broom; a thing with which one sweeps: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) pl. makaAnisu. (A, TA.)
mukan-isN A maker of brooms. (Golius, from Meyd.)
kanoEatN. A species of fish; (AO, TṢ, L, Ḳ;) as also kanoEadN; from which it appears to be formed by the substitution of t for d. (TṢ, L.)
Q. 2. takanoEava It (a thing) became collected together. (L.)
kanoEadN A kind of sea-fish; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also kanoEatN, in which the t seems to be a substitute for the d. (L.)
kunofuvN and kunaAfivN Short. (Ḳ.)
1. kahiba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and kahuba, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kahabN and kuhobapN, (TA,) He (a camel, Ṣ,) was, or became, of the colour called kuhobap. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Q. Q. 4. UikohaOab-a lawonuhu His complexion was, or became, changed, [or darkened by the sun, &c.]. (TA.)
kahobN A buffalo (or camel, A; and so in the CK;) advanced in years. (Ḳ.)
kahabN: see kuhobapN

kuhobapN The colour which is also called quhobap: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or that which is called duhomap: or dust-colour intermixed, or tinged over, with black: (Ḳ:) used absolutely, (TA,) or only with reference to camels, (Ḳ,) i. e., to their colours: (TA:) or a colour not purely red, but applied specially to a red colour: (AA, Ṣ:) or any colour inclining to that of dust: (Yaạḳoob, who does not particularize anything [to which it is applied] exclusively: TA): Az says, I have not heard khbp as a colour of camels on the authority of any one but Lth; and perhaps it is used as a colour of clothes: (TA:) it is also said that kahabN↓ signifies the colour of the buffalo. (IAạr, cited by Az.)
banuw kuhayobapa, an expression used by the poet Hassán Ibn-Thábit, meaning ‡ Sons of a base, or an ignoble, woman: khybp being thus used as though it were a proper name. (RA.)
kaAhibN: see Oakohabu.
Oakohabu (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ) and kaAhibN↓ (Ḳ) A camel (Az, Ṣ) of the colour called kuhobap: (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ) fem. of the former kahobaACN, (Az) [and pl. kuhobN].
rajulN Oakohabu All-awoni ‡ A man whose complexion is changed, [or darkened by the sun, &c.]. (TA.)
1. kahada, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yakohidu}, inf. n. kahodN (Ḳ) and kahadaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He was quick; made haste; (L, Ḳ;) in his pace: (L:) he (an ass) ran; syn. EadaA. (Ṣ, L.)
kahada and Akhd↓ He was quick in service. (TA.)
kahada He was importunate, persevering, or urgent, in petitioning, or seeking, or desiring. (Ḳ.)
kahada and Akhd↓ He was, or became, fatigued, tired, or weary. (Ḳ.)
kahada and Akhd↓ He became jaded, harassed, or fatigued, by labour, or toil: as also kadaha and Oakodaha. (L.)
kahadotuhu (so in the copies of the Ḳ; but differently in the Ṣ: [see 4:] TA:) I made him to be quick, or to hasten. (Ḳ.)
4. Oakohadotuhu I made him (an ass) to run. (Ṣ, L.) See also 1.
Akhd He fatigued, tired, or wearied, (L, Ḳ,) his companion. (L.)
Q. Q. 4. Uikowahad-a It (a young bird) trembled, or fluttered, before its mother, that she might feed it: (Ṣ, L:) and he (an old man) trembled: (L:) i. q. Uiqomahad-a. (Ḳ.)
kahodN Distress; trouble; fatigue; weariness; i. q. jahodN. (TA.) You say OaSaAbahu jahodN wakahodN [Distress, &c., befell him]. (L, Ḳ.)
kahodaMCu A female slave: (Ḳ:) so called because of her quickness in service. (TA.)
kahuwdu Alyadayoni A she-ass quick in the fore legs. (L, Ḳ.)
kaAhidN and mukohadN↓ Fatigued; tired; weary. (L.)
kawohadN One who trembles by reason of old age. (Ḳ.)
mukohadN: see kaAhidN.
kahodabN A heavy, or dull, man: syn. vaqiylN waxomN. (Ḳ.)
1. kaharahu, aor. _a {yakoharu}, inf. n. kahorN, He chid him with rough speech, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) to show him contempt. (TA.)
He reviled him. (Az, TA.)
He encountered him with a frowning face, (Ḳ,) to show him contempt: (TA:) or he frowned at him. (TA.)

He oppressed him; i. q. qaharahu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur, [xciii. 9,] faOam-aA Qloyatiyma falaA tkoharo [Therefore, as to the orphan, thou shalt not oppress him]; accord. to the reading of Ibn-Mesʼood. (Ks, Ṣ.) Yaạḳoob says, that the k in kaharahu is a substitute for the q in qaharahu. (TA.)
kahokabN and kahokamN i. q. baAcinojaAnN [The eggplant, or melongena]. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.) Mentioned in the T in art. khkm; whence it seems that the b is a substitute for m. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: khl / khm / khn / khI
dictScrap.label:
[khl, khm, khn and khI
See Supplement.]

entry.sense: 1. kaAba, aor. yakuwbu; and AktAb↓; He drank with a kuwb, the kind of mug or cup so called. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
2. kw-b, inf. n. yakowiybN, He pounded, or brayed, a thing with a fihor [or kuwbap, q. v.] (Ḳ.)
8: see 1.

kuwbN A mug, or drinking-cup, (kuwzN,) without a handle: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or one (with a round top, TA,) that has no spout: (Ḳ:) or a vessel, (Bḍ in lvi. 18,) or drinking-cup, (Jel. ibid.) having neither handle nor spout: (Bḍ, Jel. ibid.:) pl. OakowaAbN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kawabN Slenderness of the neck with bigness of the head. (L, Ḳ.)
kawobapN A sighing, or grief, or regret, for something that has past, or escaped one. (Ḳ.) Probably formed from the mahmooz word [kaOobapN]. (TA.) [Perhaps an inf. n.]

kuwbapN, occurring in a trad., in which it is forbidden, (TA,) The game called narod; (Ḳ;) an appellation given to that game by the people of El-Yemen: (AʼObeyd, on the authority of Moḥammad Ibn-Ketheer; and IAth) or that called XiToranoj: (Ḳ:) or a small drum, slender in the middle: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to some, (TA,) the musical instrument called barobaT; (Ḳ;) as occurring in a trad. of ʼAlee, in which a command is given to break the thing thus called. (TA.)
Also, i. q. fihorN; (Ḳ;) i. e., A small stone, such as fills the hand. (TA.)
kuwtiI-N Short: (Ḳ:) or a short and deformed or ill-shapen man. (So in a marginal note in two copies of the Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 2. kw-v, inf. n. takowiyvN, It (growing corn or the like) became composed of four leaves, and of five. (En-Naḍr, Ḳ.)
kw-v bigaAYiTihi, inf. n. takowiyvN, He voided his excrement [in form] resembling the heads of hares, or rabbits. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: kaAvN i. q. kaAv-N, [q. v. in art. kv]. (Ḳ.)
kawovN A qafoX, or kind of short boot: (AM, Ḳ:) app. an arabicized word. (AM, L.)

hom.sense: kawovapN What is composed of four leaves, and of five: referring to growing corn and the like: n. un. of kawovN. (TA.)

kawovapN, or kuwvapN↓, [as in different copies of the Ḳ, the latter being the reading in the TA, which mentions kwyvp as another reading,] Abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; plenty; fruitfulness. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: kuwovapN: see kawovapN.
kuwiviI-N Short: like kuwtiI-N [q. v.]. (T.)

1. kaAHahu, [aor. yakuwHu,] inf. n. kawoHN; and kw-Hhu↓, and AkAHhu↓, and kAwHhu↓; He fought with him and overcame him: (Ḳ:) so Az, explains kAwHhu, inf. n. mukaAwaHapN: or, accord. to the M, kAwHhu↓ signifies he fought with him; and kAHh, he overcame him; (TA;) and kw-Hhu↓, inf. n. takowiyHN, also has this last signification; (IAạr, Ṣ, TA;) and so AkAHhu↓, inf. n. UikaAHapN. (IAạr, TA.)
2: See 1.
Also kw-Hhu, (inf. n. takowiyHN, TA,) He abased him; rendered him abject; syn. Oacal-ahu. (Ḳ.)
It (the nose-rein) rendered him (a camel) submissive, or tractable. (TA.)
3: See 1.
Also kAwHhu He reviled him, or vilified him, mutually; and treated him in an open manner (Ṣ, Ḳ) with opposition or altercation. (TA.)
4. AkAHhu He destroyed him. (T, in this art; and Ḳ in art. kyH.) See 1.
6. takaAwaHaA They two laboured, or strove, each with the other, to do evil, or mischief. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

kaAHN and kiyHN↓ The foot, or base, (EuroD,) of a mountain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or] its face, or part facing the spectator, above its foot, or base; syn. sanadu jabalK: (Ṣ:) or its foot, or base, (ErD) and most rugged part: or its safoH [i. q. EuroD]; and the foot, or base, of its face; syn. safoHu sanadihi: or kiyHN signifies the side (naAHiyap) of a mountain: and any rugged face of a mountain, above its foot, or base: and in some cases, the side of a valley, when it is rugged, but not unless consisting of the hardest and roughest of stones: (Aṣ, TA:) pl. of kaAHN, OakowaAHN; (M;) and (of kiyHN↓, TA,) OakoyaAHN and koyuwHN (Ḳ) and kiyaHapN. (Aṣ, T.)

kiyHN↓ OakoyaHu A rough or rugged [foot, or base, or face above the foot or base, &c., of a mountain]; an expression similar to yawomN Oayowamu; (Ḳ, art. kyH;) the latter word being a corroborative; for the sanad of a mountain is called kyH only because of its ruggedness and roughness. (TA.)
kyHN: see kaAHN.
kaAxN: see kuwxN.

kuwxN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) a Persian word, (L,) and kaAxN↓, (Ḳ,) A house [or hut] with a gibbous roof: (L, TA:) a house [or hut] of reeds or canes, (with a gibbous roof, Ḳ,) without an aperture for the admission of light: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) any place which a husbandman or a gardener prepares in which to guard his growing corn or his garden: and the people of Marw give the name of kAx↓ to a pavilion (qaSor) made in a garden or other place: (L:) pl. OakowaAxN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kuwxaAnN and kiyxaAnN and kiwaxapN: (Ḳ, TA:) [the last, in the CK, written kuwaxapN].

1. kaAda yafoEalu kacaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*, &c.,) [originally kawida,] first pers. kidotu, accord. to the usage of most of the Arabs, (IḲṭṭ,) aor. yakaAdu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) the form used by all the Arabs, (IḲṭṭ.) or yakuwdu [is also used, by some of those who make the pret. to be originally kawuda], (Lth,) inf. n. kawodN (Lth, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.) and kaAdN (M, IḲṭṭ) and makaAdapN (Lth, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.) and makaAdN; (Lth, M, Ḳ;) and kaAda, originally kawuda, deviating from constant rule, (MF,) first pers. kudotu, (Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, MF,) in the dial. of the Benoo-'Adee, (MF,) mentioned by Sb as heard from some of the Arabs, (Ṣ,) aor. yakaAdu, (IḲṭṭ,) deviating from constant rule, (MF,) [and yakuwdu, mentioned above, agreeably with rule;] as also kaAda, (Mṣb, Ḳ, art. kyd,) originally kayida, first pers. kidotu, aor. yakaAdu, (Mṣb, art. kyd,) inf. n. kayodN; (L, art. kyd;) and kiyda, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) a form mentioned by Abu-l-Khattáb to Sb, as used by some of the Arabs, who in like manner said maA ziyla yafoEalu kacaA, for kaAda and zaAla; (Ṣ;) He was near to doing so; he nearly, well nigh, or almost, did so; he wanted but little of doing so; (Akh, Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.;) he purposed, or intended, doing so; (Lth, M, IḲṭṭ;) but did it not, [or did it not immediately]. (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) kaAda is applied to signify the being near to doing a thing whether it be [afterwards] done or not done. (Ṣ.) Without a negative, it enunciates the negation of the action; and coupled with a negative, it enunciates the happening of the action. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [This will be explained in the course of the following observations.] It is (as Es-Suyootee says in the Itkán) an incomplete [i. e. a non-attributive] verb, of which only the pret. and aor. are used. It has a noun as the subject, in the nom. case; and an aor., [generally] without Oano, as the predicate. (TA.) Sometimes they introduce Oano after it, likening it to EasaI; as, for ex., in the saying of Ru-beh,
qado kaAda mino Tuwli AlbilaI Oano yamoSaHaA
[It had nearly come to nought from length of wear]. (Ṣ.) Used affirmatively, it is affirmative of the being near [to doing a thing, &c.]; and used negatively, it is negative thereof. It is a well-known opinion of many, that, used affirmatively, it is negative; and used negatively, it is affirmative: so that kaAda zayodN yafoEalu means [Zeyd was near to doing; but] he did not [or did not immediately]; as is shown by the expression [in the Ḳur xvii. 75, where Uino is a contraction of Uin-a,] waUino kaAduwA layafotinuwnaka [And verily they were near to seducing thee]: and maA kaAda yafoEalu means [He was not near to doing; but] he did; as is shown by the expression [in the Ḳur ii. 66,] wamaA kaAduwA yafoEaluwna [And they were not near to doing (it); but they afterwards did (it)]. I'Ab is related to have said, that wherever kaAda and OakaAdu and yakaAdu occur in the Ḳur-án, they denote a thing's never happening. Some say, that kaAda [with a negative] denotes an action's happening with difficulty. Some, again, say, that the pret. preceded by a negative is affirmative [of the action, &c.]; as is shown by the expression wamaA kaAduwA yafoEaluwna [quoted above]: and that the aor. preceded by a negative is negative; as is shown by the expression [in the Ḳur xxiv, 40,] lamo yakado yaraAhaA [He is not near to seeing it]; meaning that he sees not anything: [though this phrase is said to bear a different meaning, which see below]. But the correct opinion is the one first mentioned; that, used affirmatively, it is affirmative [of the being near to do a thing, &c.]; and used negatively, it is negative [thereof]: so that kaAda yafoEalu signifies He was near to doing; but did not [or did not immediately]: and maA kaAda yafoEalu He was not near to doing; much less did he do [or do immediately]; the denial of the action [or of the immediate performance of the action] being necessarily understood from the denial of the being near to do it. As to the expression in the Ḳur, wamaA kaAduwA yafoEaluwna [quoted above], it enunciates the state of the people to whom it relates in the beginning of their case; for they were far from sacrificing the cow; and the affirmation of the action is understood only from the [preceding] expression facabaHuwhaA. And as to the expression [in the Ḳur xvii. 76,] laqado kidt-a tarokanu Uilayohimo [Thou hadst certainly been near to inclining to them], the Prophet's not inclining to them little or much is understood from lawolaA [preceding], which requires this inference. (TA.) [Often, however, or (as some say) generally, with a negative preceding or following it, it is affirmative of the action's happening, but only after difficulty, or delay.] Aboo-Bekr says, that maA kaAda fulaAnN yaquwmu means [Such a one hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, rose; like lamo yakado yaquwmu, and kaAda laA yaquwmu; waqado qaAma being understood; or] he rose after being slow, or tardy: (L:) and accord. to Az and others, maA kidotu OafoEalu means [I hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, did; or] I did after being slow, or tardy: but sometimes it means I was not near to doing. (Mṣb, art. kyd.) It is said, that kaAda is sometimes a [mere redundant] connective (Silap) of the members of a sentence; (Kutr, Akh, AḤát, Ḳ;) as in lamo yakado yaraAhaA [quoted above], meaning, He does not see it: (Ḳ:) or this means he is not near to seeing it: or, as some say, he sees it after his having been not near to seeing it by reason of the intenseness of the darkness: [or he hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, sees it:] and Fr says, with reference to the verse in which this phrase occurs, that it is allowable to say lamo yakado yaquwmu [meaning, He hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, rose] when one has risen after difficulty. (TA.) [Thus it appears, that, maA kaAda yafoEalu and lamo yakado yafoEalu sometimes signify He hardly, or scarcely, or tardily, did: and sometimes, he was not near to doing; he never did; he did not at all: so that it may be rendered he hardly or scarcely, or nowise or in nowise or never, did: or he could hardly do, or he could not at all, or could not nearly, or he could nowise or in nowise, do.]
As asserts his having heard certain of the Arabs say, laA OafoEalu celika walaA kawodFA [I will not do that, nor will I be near to doing it]. (Ṣ.)

kaAda also signifies He desired; syn. OaraAda. (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the verse
kaAdato wakidotu watiloka xayoru UiraAdapK
lawo EaAda mino lahowi AlS-abaAbapi maA maDaI
[She desired, and I desired; and that were the best of desire, if what hath passed, of the diverting delight of tender love, returned]. (Akh, Ṣ.) So, too, in the saying in the Ḳur [xx. 15,] OakaAdu OuxofiyhaA I desire (Ṣ, Ḳ) to conceal it: or, to manifest it: (Beyd:) for, like as it is allowable to put Ouriydu in the place of OakaAdu, as in the saying in the Ḳur [xviii. 76,] jidaArFA yuriydu Oano yanoqaD-a, so it is to use AkAd [in the place of Aryd]: Akh says, that the words of the verse in question mean I will conceal it, OuxofiyhaA: and some say, that the meaning is I will manifest it: (TA:) but most hold, that AkAd should here be rendered in its original sense. (MF, TA.) Some of the Arabs make kAd to denote certainty; like Zan-a, which primarily denotes doubt, and secondarily certainty. (L, art. kyd.)
Earafa maA yukaAdu minohu [is in like manner explained] He hath become acquainted with that which is desired of him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

You say to him who seeks of you a thing, when you do not desire to give him it, laA walaA makaAdapa walaA maham-apa, (Lth, Ṣ,* L, Ḳ,*) and laA kawodFA walaA ham-FA, and laA makaAdFA walaA maham-FA, (Lth, L,) i. e. laA OakaAdu walaA Oahum-u [No, nor do I desire, nor do I purpose, or intend]. (Lth, L, Ḳ.)
You also say, in the same sense, laA maham-apa liI walaA makaAdapa [I have no purpose or intention, nor any desire]. (Ṣ)
See also kaAda in art. kyd.
2. kw-c, inf. n. takowiycN, It (an UizaAr [or a wrapper for the lower part of the body and the thighs]) reached to the part called the kaAcap (L, Ḳ) only. (L.)
He (a man in the act of concubitus) thrust against the sides of the pubes. (Ḳ.)
He beat or struck, with a staff, or stick, upon the posteriors, (Ḳ,) between the thigh and the hip. (TA.)

kaAcapN What surrounds the vulva, of the exterior of the two thighs: (L, Ḳ:) or the portion of flesh of the inner side of the thigh; the two together are called the kaAcataAni: (Aṣ, L:) or the flesh of the hinder part of the thigh: (L, Ḳ:) or the part of the thigh which is the place that is cauterized in the hinder part of the thigh of the ass; so in a man, &c.: (L:) or the kaAcataAni are two compact portions of flesh in the upper part of each thigh of an ass, the place that is cauterized, between the thigh and the haunch: (T, L:) or the flesh of the outer sides of the two thighs, below the jaAEirataAni; (AHeyth, T, L;) and this is the correct signification: (T, L:) or the prominent flesh in the upper parts of the thigh: (Ṣ, L:) pl. kaAcaAtN and [quasi-pl., or coll. gen. n.,] kaAcN. (L.)
mukaw-icN An UzaAr [or a wrapper for the lower part of the body and the thighs] reaching to the part called the kaAcap (L, Ḳ) only; or, to the kaAcataAni, when it is put on. (L.)
