hom.sense: 1. kaAra AlEimaAmapa EalaI raOosihi, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,*) aor. yakuwru, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. kaworN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He wound round the turban upon his head; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also kw-rhA↓, inf. n. takowiyrN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or the latter has an intensive signification [app. meaning he wound it round many times upon his head; or in many folds]: and hence you say, kw-r↓ AlX-aIoCa he wound the thing in a round form. (Mṣb.)

Hence the saying, HaAra baEoda maA kaAra, (Zj, in TA, art. Hwr,) † He became in a bad state of affairs after he had been in a good state: or he became in a state of defectiveness after he had been in a state of redundance. (TA, art. Hwr.) See also kaworN, below.
kaAra, (TA,) inf. n. kaworN, (Ḳ,) He carried a kaArap, q. v., (Ḳ, TA,) upon his back; (TA;) as also AstkAr↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
2: see 1, in two places.

UicaA AlX-amosu kuw-irato, in the Ḳur [lxxxi. 1,] When the sun shall be wound round [with darkness] like a turban: (AO, Ṣ:) or shall be wrapped up and effaced: (AO accord. to the Ṣ, or Akh accord. to the TA:) or shall be wrapped up and have its light taken away: (Jel:) or shall have its light collected together and wrapped up like as a turban is wrapped: (TA:) or shall be folded up like as a sijil- [or scroll] is folded up: (Mṣb:) or shall lose its light: (Fr, Ḳatádeh, Ṣ:) or shall be divested of its light: (ʼIkrimeh:) or shall be blinded; syn. Eaw-irato: (I’Ab, Ṣ:) or shall pass away and come to nought: or shall be collected together and cast down into the depth below; syn. duhowirato: (both of which are explanations given by Mujáhid:) or shall be cast away. (Er-Rabeea Ibn-Kheythem.)

yukaw-iru Qll-ayola EalaI Qln-ahaAri (Ḳur xxxix. 7) He maketh the night to be a covering upon the day: or He addeth of the night to the day: (Ṣ:) or He maketh the night to overtake the day: (TA:) or He bringeth in the night upon the day: (Ḳ:) from kaw-ara AlEimaAmapa: all of which meanings are nearly alike. (TA.)
kw-r AlmataAEa, (A, Ḳ:) inf. n. takowiyrN, (Ṣ,) He collected together the goods and bound or tied them: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he put the goods one upon another. (A.)
TaEanahu fakaw-arahu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He smote and pierced him [with his spear], and threw him down gathered together, or in a heap. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.*)
Darabaha fakaw-arahu He smote him, and threw him down prostrate: (Ḳ,* TA:) [like jaw-arahu:] or kw-rhu signifies he prostrated him, whether he smote him or not. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tkw-r He fell upon his side, and drew himself together; syn. taqaT-ara wataXam-ara: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he wrapped himself up, and tucked up his garment, or skirt, or the like; syn. talaf-afa wataXam-ara. (TA.)
He fell; fell down. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He became prostrated; as also UikotaAra↓: (Ḳ:) or AktAr signifies he prostrated a thing, one part upon another. (TA.)

hom.sense: 8. AktAr He turbaned himself; attired himself with a turban. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
See also 5.

entry.sense: 10: see 1, last signification.

hom.sense: kaworN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) an inf. n. used as a subst., (Mṣb,) or kuwrN↓, (ISh, T, A,) A turn, or twist, of a turban: (ISh, T, A, Mṣb:) pl. OakowaArN. (A, Mṣb.) You say, AlEimaAmapu EiXoruwna kuwrFA [The turban is composed of twenty turns], and EaXarapu OakowaArK [ten turns]. (A.)

Increase; or redundance. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.) Hence the saying, naEuwcu biQll-ehi mina AlHawori baEoda Alkawori (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) We have recourse to God for preservation from decrease, or defectiveness, after increase, or redundance: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or, as it is also related, baEoda Alkawoni, which means the same: or the meaning is, from return to disobedience after obedience: (Mṣb:) or from return after pursuing a right course. (TA.) See also HaworN.
kuwrN: see kaworN.

A camel's [saddle of the kind called] raHol: (Ḳ, TA:) as also makowarN↓ (Ḳ) and mukowar-N↓, the latter with damm to the m and teshdeed to the r: (TṢ, L:) or a raHol with its apparatus: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) pronounced by many kaworN; but this is a mistake: (IAth:) pl. [of pauc.] OakowaArN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OakowurN, (Ḳ,) and (of mult., TA) kiyraAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kuwraAnN and kuWuwrN, which last, says ISd, is extr. as a pl. form of a sing. such as kwr with an infirm letter. (TA.)

A blacksmith's fire-place; (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb;) his majomarap; (Ḳ;) constructed of clay: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:*) and also said to signify the skin [with which he blows his fire]: (Mṣb, TA:) or this latter is called [only] kiyrN: (A, in the present art.; and Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, art. kyr:) an arabicized word. (Mṣb.)

[A hornets', or bees', nest;] the place, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or structure, (TA,) of hornets: (Alz-anaAbiyr, Ṣ, Ḳ [in the CK, Ald-anaAniyr, which is a mistake:]) or of bees: (accord. to a trad. cited in the TA:) pl. OakowaArN. (TA.) See also kuwaArapN.

entry.sense: kaArapN A bundle (HaAlN) which a man carries on his back: or a bundle (EikomN) of clothes, put in one piece of cloth [and tied up]: such is that of the qaS-aAr [or beater and washer and whitener of clothes]: (TA:) or the kArp is what is carried on the back, [being a bundle] of clothes: (Ṣ:) or what are put together and tied up [in a wrapper] of clothes: (Mṣb:) or a certain quantity of wheat; (Ḳ, TA;) which a man carries on his back: (TA:) pl. kaAraAtN. (A, Mṣb.) [See also EajalapN.]

kuwrapN A province, district, or tract of country; a quarter, or region; syn. SuqoEN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a mixolaAf [q. v.] of a country; i. e., a qaroyapN [which properly signifies a town or village] of the qurFI of El-Yemen: (M, TA:) [but mxlAf is generally used in the first of the senses here assigned to kwrp:] and also a city: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or a provincial city: but the first of these significations is the most common, as is implied in the Mṣb: see also banodN:] pl. kuwarN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as gurafN is pl. of gurofapN. (Mṣb.) IDrd says, I do not think it Arabic. (TA.) [Perhaps from the Greek χώρα.]
kiwaArN and kiwaArapN: see kuwaArapN.

kuwaArapu naHolK, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and kuw-aArap↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) written in both these ways in the T, in explanation of the word EamiyrapN, (Mgh,) and kiwaArap↓, (T, TṢ, L, Ḳ,) and kiwaAr↓, (T, TṢ, L, Mṣb,) A bee-hive; or habitation of bees; syn. xaliy-apN: (Mṣb:) or a bee-hive, when made of clay: (El-Ghooree, in Mgh:) or a bee-hive, or habitation of bees, when containing honey: (Mṣb:) or a thing made for bees, of twigs, (T, Mgh, TṢ,) or of clay, (TṢ, Ḳ,) or of twigs and clay, accord. to most copies of the Ḳ, or of twigs only, accord. to most of the lexicologists, (TA,) like a qiroTaAlap [an asses' pannier], (T, Mgh, TṢ,) narrow at the head, (T, Mgh, TṢ, Ḳ,) in which they make their honey: (TA:) or the honey of bees in the wax: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or kuw-aAraAtN↓ [pl. of kuw-aArapN] signifies domestic bee-hives; as also kawaAYirN. (AḤn, Ḳ.) [Of the latter pl., it is said in the TA, that ISd holds it to be pl., not of kwArp, but, of kuw-arap: but the passage seems to be corrupt.]
kuw-aArapN: see kuwaArapN.
makowarN: see kuwrN.
mikowarN and mikowarapN↓ and mikowaArapN↓ A turban. (IAạr, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
mukowar-N: see kuwrN.
mikowarapN: see mikowarN.
mikowaArapN: see mikowarN.

hom.sense: 1. kaAza, aor. yakuwzu, (TA,) inf. n. kawozN, (Ḳ,) He collected a thing. (Ḳ *, TA.)
He drank with a kuwz; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also AktAz↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tkw-zwA They collected themselves together. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
8. AktAzhu He ladled it out (namely water, Ṣ, A) with a kuwz. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
See also 1.

kuwzN A kind of vessel, (TA,) well-known, (A, Ḳ,) [namely, a mug, or drinking-cup,] with a handle: (IAạr, TA:) AḤn says, that it is a Persian word; but ISd denies this, and asserts it to be genuine Arabic: it is said to be from kaAza “he collected:” (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OakowaAzN, and [of mult.] kiyzaAnN and kiwazapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kaw-aAzapN [app. A stand, or a shelf, upon which mugs (kiyzaAn) are placed: see bar-aAdapN]. (Lth, T, art. brd.)
rajulN mukaw-azu Alr-aOosi A man having a long head. (A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. kaAsa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yakuwsu, inf. n. kawosN, (Mṣb, TA,) He (a camel) walked upon three legs, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) being hamstrung: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or raised one of his legs, and jumped upon the rest. (TA.) Thus you say of a quadruped: but when said of another, it means, He went upon one leg. (TA.)
kaAsa, (Ṣ, A, TA,) aor. yakuwsu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. kawosN, (A, TA,) He (a man) became turned upside down, (Ṣ, TA,) head downwards; (Ṣ;) as also tkw-s↓. (Ḳ.)
He (a poor man) fell upon his head. (A,* TA.)

kaAsa fulaAnFA, (Ḳ,) aor. yakuwsuhu, inf. n. kawosN, (TA,) He prostrated such a one; (Ḳ;) as also AkAshu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UikaAsapN; (TA;) which latter verb is the more chaste: (Ṣgh:) or he threw him down upon his head; as also kw-shu↓: (TA:) or this last, which is said of God, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. takowiysN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) signifies He turned him upside down, (Ḳ,) or head downwards, (Ṣ,) or upon his head, (A,) fiI Aln-aAri in the fire [of Hell]: (Ṣ, A:) and you say also, kaw-asotuhu↓ EalaI raOosihi, meaning, I turned him over upon his head. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in three places.
4. AkAs AlbaEiyra, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UikaAsapN, (TA,) He made the camel to walk upon three legs, by hamstringing him. (Ḳ.)
See also 1.
5: see 1.
kaAsN: see kaOosN.

hom.sense: kuwsN A drum: said to be an arabicized word [from the Persian kuwsN, pronounced “kós,” but in Arabic “koos,” and applied in the present day to a kettle-drum; accord. to Golius, a kettle-drum that used to be beaten in the camps and palaces of kings]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [The modern pl. is kuwsaAt.]
Hence, A farosax [or parasang, or league, in which sense also it is of Persian origin]: because this is the utmost distance at which may be heard the beating of the kws. (TA.)
Also, A triangular piece of wood with which a carpenter measures the squareness of wood. (Lth, A,* Ḳ.) It is [in this sense likewise] a Persian word. (TA.)

entry.sense: kawokabN, &c.: see art. kkb.

1. kaMCa Eani AlOamori, first pers. kiYotu, aor. yakiIoCu, inf. n. kaIoCN and kayoYapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) and kaMCa Eanohu, first pers. kuWotu, aor. yakuwoCu, inf. n. kawoCN and kaMCN and kaOowN, this last formed by transposition; (Ḳ;) He abstained from the thing through timidity: (TA:) or he dreaded the thing, and abstained from it through cowardice: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or his eye reverted from the thing, and he desired it not. (TA.)
kaACa Eanohu He retired from him through fear. (TA.) [Accord. to the TA, it seems that OakaMCahu↓ also has this signification.]

4. AkACh, inf. n. UikaMCN and UikaMCapN, He came upon him suddenly, when he (the latter) was about to do a thing, and caused him to abstain from it through fear or cowardice. (Ḳ, TA.) But some say that this is correctly OakaOahu; like kataba, inf. n. kitaAbN and kitaAbapN. (TA, art. OakO.)
See 1.
kaMCN and kaMCapN and kaIoCN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and kayoYapN (Ḳ) A weak-hearted, cowardly, man: (Ḳ, TA:) like kaE-N and kaAE-N. (Ṣ.)
kaIoCN and kayoYapN: see kaMCN.
2. ky-t, inf. n. takoyiytN, He stuffed, or filled, a bag or other receptacle for travelling-provisions or for goods or utensils, &c. (En-Nawádir, TṢ, Ḳ.)

Also, He made his travelling-apparatus light, or easy of conveyance; syn. yas-ara. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) A poet says,
kay-ito jihaAzaka Uim-aA kunota murotaHilFA
Uin-iI OaxaAfu EalaI OacowaAdika Als-abuEaA
[Make thy travelling apparatus light, when thou art departing on a journey; for I fear for thy droves, or troops, of camels, on account of the beast of prey]. (Ṣ.)

OakoyaAtN i. q. OakoyaAsN, [pl. of kay-isN:] (Ḳ:) the Rájiz says,
gayor OaEif-aACi walaA OakoyaAti
[Not such as abstain from things unlawful and unbecoming, nor ingenious, or acute in mind, &c.]. (TA.) See art. s p. 1281 a. Some say, that it it is a word mispronounced: others, that it is formed by the change of s into t, as in the case of Tas-N and TasotN. (TA.)

kaAna mina AlOamori kayota wakayota, and kayot wakayoti, (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) and kyotu wakayotu, (IAth, ISd, IḲṭṭ,) i. e. kacaA wakacaA, [Some of the circumstances of the case were thus and thus; or so and so; or such and such things]. (Lth, Ḳ.) The t in kyt is originally p; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as in the case of cayot; these two words being originally kay-ap and cay-ap: (TA:) or the t in kyt and cyt is substituted for I: they are originally kay-ap and cay-ap; and the p is elided, and the I which is the last radical letter is changed into t: so accord. to AḤei; and most of the leading authorities on inflexion assert the same. (MF. voce cayota.) See cyt.

hom.sense:
1. kaAdahu, aor. yakiydu, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) inf. n. kayodN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and makiydapN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and kAydhu↓, (A,) inf. n. mukaAyadapN; (Ṣ;) or this implies reciprocation; (TA;) [and AktAdhu↓, which see below. app. signifies the same as kaAdahu like as AixotadaEahu signifies the same as xadaEahu;] He deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him or he deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him; and desired to do him a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, clandestinely, or without his knowing whence it proceeded; i. q. makara bihi (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and xadaEahu: (Mṣb:)
or, accord. to some, mkrbh implies the feigning of the contrary of one's real intentions; whereas kAdh does not: or this latter signifies he did him harm, or mischief; and the former, he did so clandestinely. (MF.)
kaAda, aor. yakiydu, (L,) inf. n. kayodN and makiydapN, (L, Ḳ,) [or the latter is a simple subst.,] He acted deceitfully, mischievously, or wickedly. (L, Ḳ.)

Also, inf. n. kayodN, He practised an evasion or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice, or artful contrivance or device, a plot, a stratagem, or an expedient; or he exercised art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, in the management or ordering of affairs,, with excellent consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage with subtilty according to his own free will; syn. AixotaAla; (L:) and of the inf. n., HiylapN. (L, Ḳ.)

kaAdahu He taught him Alkayod [i. e., to deceive, beguile, or circumvent, &c., or, to act deceitfully, mischievously, or wickedly; or, to practise modes, or means, of evading or cluding, &c.]. So some explain it in the Ḳur xii. 76. (TA.)

It is said in a trad., maA qawoluka fiI EuquwlK kaAdahaA xaAliquhaA What sayest thou of intellects to which their Creator hath desired to do evil? (L.) So some explain the verb in the Ḳur xxi. 58. (TA.)

yakiyduwna kayodFA waOakiydu kayodFA [Ḳur lxxxvi. 16, They practise an artful device, and I will practise an artful device]. kayodu Qll-ehi lilokuf-aAri [God's practising an artful device towards the unbelievers] means his taking them unawares, so that they do not reckon upon it; bestowing upon them enjoyments in which they delight, and on which they place their reliance, and with which they become familiar so as not to be mindful of death, and then taking them in their most heedless state; UisotidoraAjuhumo mino Hayovu laA yaEolamuwna. (Zj, L.)

kaAda, aor. yakiydu, inf. n. kayodN, He contrived, devised, or plotted, a thing, whether wrong or right. Ex. fulaAnN yakiydu OamorF maA OadoriI maA huwa Such a one contrives, devises, or plots, a thing: I know not what it is. (L.)

kaAda, aor. yakiydu, He worked, or laboured, at, or upon, anything; he laboured, took pains, applied himself vigorously, exerted himself, strove, or struggled, to do, execute, or perform, or to effect, or accomplish, or to manage, or treat, anything; he laboured, strove, or struggled, with anything, to prevail, or overcome, or to effect an object; syn. EaAlaja. (Ṣ, L.)

kaAda, inf. n. kayodN, He strove, or laboured; exerted himself, or his power or ability; employed himself vigorously, laboriously, sedulously, or earnestly; was diligent; took extraordinary pains. (L.)
kaAda, inf. n. kayodN, He (a raven or crow) exerted himself in his croaking. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kaAda binafosihi, (Ḳ,) aor. yakiydu, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. kayodN, (L,) ‡ He gave up his spirit: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) endured distress in giving up the ghost. (A.)
kaAda, (Ḳ,) inf. n. kayodN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He vomited. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kaAda, inf. n. kayodN, It (a zanod) emitted fire. (L, Ḳ.)
kaAdato, (L, Ḳ,) aor. takiydu, inf. n. kayodN, (L,) She had the menstrual flux. (L, Ḳ.)
laA OafoEalu celika walaA kayodFA walaA ham-FA I will not do that, nor do I desire, nor do I purpose, or intend. (Ḳ,* TA.) See kaAda in art. kwd.

kaAda yafoEalu kacaA, (L. Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally kayida, first pers. kidotu, aor. yakaAdu; (L, Mṣb;) and kiyda: (L, Ḳ:) see art. kwd. [It is mentioned in arts. kwd and kyd in the L, Ḳ: in the former only in the Ṣ: and in the latter only in the Mṣb.]

entry.sense: 3: see 1.

6. humaA yatakaAyadaAni (L, Ḳ) They two deceive, beguile, or circumvent, each other; or do so, each desiring to do to the other a foul, abominable, or evil, action clandestinely. (TḲ.) See 1. You should not say yatakaAwadaAni. (L, Ḳ.)
8. AktAd is of the measure AfotaEala from Alkayodu; (Ḳ;) and AktAdhu signifies UHotaAlahu [or rather UiHotaAla Ealayohi]. (TḲ.) See 1.

hom.sense: kayodN: see 1.

‡ War: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because of the stratagems employed therein. (TA.) One says, gazaA fulaAnN falamo yaloqa kayodFA ‡ Such a one went on a hostile expedition and found not war: (Ṣ, L:) i. e., did not fight. (A.)
kayodN caAtu gadorK ‡ A war characterized by perfidy. kyd is here made fem. because meaning HarobN. (L, from a trad.)
kayodN Vomit. (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ.*) balaEa Alkayoda. He swallowed vomit. (L, from a trad.)

entry.sense: makiydapN: see 1.

As a simple subst., Deceit, guile, or circumvention, and desire to do a foul, an abominable, or an evil, action, to another clandestinely: (Mṣb:) [and an evasion, or elusion, a shift, a wile, an artifice,, &c.: see 1 as intrans.:] pl. makaAYidu. (A.)

kiyrN [A blacksmith's bellows;] a blacksmith's [skin, of the kind called] ziq-, into which he blows: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or a blacksmith's skin (ziq-), with which he blows [his fire]: (Mṣb:) also, (Mṣb,) composed of a thick skin (jilod, Ṣ, Mṣb, or ziq-, Ṣ), with HaAfaAt [or edges, forming a wide mouth, which being opened and closed by means of two pieces of wood to which the edges are sewed, the skin becomes filled with air, which is then forced out through a pipe at the end opposite the mouth: such, at least, is the most common kind of bellows used by the Arabs of the present day with which I am acquainted]: but the thing constructed of clay [in which the blacksmith kindles his fire] is called kuwrN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) so ISk says he heard AA say: (Mṣb:) [but see kuwrN: and see a verse cited in the last paragraph of art. Ewr:] the pl. [of pauc.] is OakoyaArN, and [of mult.] kiyarapN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and kiyraAnN; (Ḳ;) the last on the authority of Th; but doubtful; for it is not known in the lexicons, and is [properly] pl. of kuwrN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. kaAsa, aor. yakiysu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. kayosN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kiyaAsapN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and kuwsaI, with w put in the place of I, [originally kuyosaI,] (Seer [mentioned by him as syn. with kayosN]) He (a boy, Ṣ [but often said of a man also,]) was, or became, acute, or sharp, or quick, in intellect; shrewd; clever; ingenious; skilful; knowing; intelligent: kayosN being the contr. of HumoqN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and i. q. ZarofN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and xiq-apN, and tawaq-udN, (TA,) and fiTonapN, (Mṣb, TA,) and fiqohN, (TA,) and EaqolN. (IAạr, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

kaAsahu, aor. yakiysuhu, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) inf. n. kayosN, (A, TA,) He overcame him, or surpassed him, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) in kiyaAsap (A, Ḳ) or kayos (A, Nh) [i. e. acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect;, &c.: see above]. So in the following words of a trad., (Ḳ,) said by the prophet to Jábir Ibn-ʼAbd-Allah El-Anṣáree, (TA,) OataraAniI Uin-amaA kisotuka liMxuca jamalaka laka Alv-amanu walaka Aljamalu [Dost thou think me to have only overcome thee in acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect,, &c., in order that I might take thy camel? Thine be the price, and thine be the camel]: (Ḳ,* TA:) or, according to another relation, xuco jamalaka wamaAlaka [Take thou thy camel and thy property]: and accord. to another, Uin-amaA maA kasotuka [that I have only acted in a niggardly manner with thee], from AlmikaAsu. (TA.)
kayisa, [aor. yakoyasu,] inf. n. kayasN, is also mentioned by IḲṭṭ as a dial. form of kaAsa in the sense of He overcame or surpassed [in acuteness, &c.] (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. ky-shu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. takoyiysN, (TA,) He (God, TḲ) made him acute or sharp or quick in intellect; shrewd; clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent; (Ḳ, TA;) and well educated, or well bred. (TA.)

3. kAyshu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. mukaAyasapN, (TA), He vied, or contended, with him in kayos [i. e. acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect;, &c.: see 1]. (Ḳ.) You say, kaAyasotuhu fakisotuhu [I vied, or contended, with him in acuteness,, &c., and] I overcame, or surpassed, him (Ṣ, A) [therein, i. e.] in kayos. (A.) And kaAyasahu fiI AlbayoEi (Ṣ, A) [He vied, or contended, with him in acuteness,, &c., in selling; as seems to be indicated in the Ṣ: or] he jested, or joked, with him (laAgaAhu) in selling. (A, TA.)

4. Oakoyasa and OakaAsa He (a man, Ṣ) had born to him children acute or sharp or quick in intellect; shrewd; clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he begot a child acute, &c. (IḲṭṭ.) And Oakoyasato and OakaAsato She brought forth children acute, &c. (A.) A poet says,
falawo kunotumo limikoyasapK OakaAsato
wakayosu AlOum-i yuEorafu fiI AlbaniynaA
[But if ye belonged to one who most generally brought forth children acute in intellect, she had brought forth such children; for the acuteness of intellect of the mother is known in the sons]. (Ṣ.)

5. tky-s He affected acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect, shrewdness, cleverness, ingeniousness, skilfulness, knowledge, or intelligence: [see taEaq-ala:] or did so, not having it: syn. taZar-afa: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) he feigned, or made a show of, kayos [i. e. acuteness or sharpness or quickness of intellect;, &c.]. (TA.)
See also 1.
6: see 1.

hom.sense: kayosN: see 1:
and see also kay-isN.

entry.sense: kiysN [A purse;] a well known receptacle; (TA;) a thing made of pieces of rag sewed together; (Mṣb;) for money, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and for pearls and sapphires: (TA:) [so called] because it comprises them: (Ḳ, TA:) [a remark that seems to indicate a signification of kaAsa or some other word from the same root which I do not find elsewhere pointed out: but the more probable derivation is from the Persian kiysaho:] that which is tied up, of leather, and of pieces of rag, is not called thus, but is called xariyTapN: (Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OakoyaAsN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kiyasapN. (Ḳ.)
Hence, (TA,) ‡ The membrane that encloses a child in the womb; syn. maXiymapN. (Ḳ, TA.)
[Hence also, † The scrotum.]

kay-isN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and kayosN↓, (TA,) [like hiy-inN and hayonN, &c.,] Acute, or sharp, or quick, in intellect; clever; ingenious; skilful; knowing; intelligent: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) fem. kay-isapN: (Ṣ, A:) and kiysaI↓, applied to a woman, is syn with kay-isapN, and is, as also kuwsaI, [each originally kuyosaI,] fem. of Oakoyasu: (Ṣ:) [whence it appears that this last word is accord. to J syn. with kay-isN; i. e., a simple epithet, like its contr. OaHomaqu: but it has another signification, for which see below:] or, accord. to Kr, kiysaI and kuwsaI are pls. of kay-isapN; and there are no similar instances except DiyqaI and DuwqaI, pls. of Day-iqapN, and TuwbaI, pl. of Tay-ibapN: but ISd holds them to be fems. of the measure OafoEalu: (TA: [see DuwqaI in art. Dyq:]) the pl. of kay-isN is OakoyaAsN (A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA) and kayosaIi, (A, Ḳ, TA [in the CK, erroneously, kiysI,]) like HamoqaI, (A,) having this latter form in order that it may resemble its contr., HamoqaI: (TA:) and kiyaAsN is pl. of kay-isapN, (A, TA,) [and OakaAyiysu is app. pl. of kiyaAsN: see an ex. voce TiX-apN.] You also say, rajulN kay-isN mukay-asN↓, meaning, A man acute or sharp or quick in intellect,, &c.: (Ṣ:) or [acute, &c., and] described as being so; or having the attribute of kayos ascribed to him: (A:) or rajulN mukay-asN↓ signifies, as also kay-isN, a man known as possessing kayos [or acuteness, &c.]. (TA.) And UimoraOapN kay-isapN A woman well educated, or well bred. (TA.) And rajulN kay-isu AlfiEol A man good in action or conduct. (TA.) And banaI daArFA kay-isapF (A) ‡ He built an elegant house; syn. ZariyfapF. (TA.) [The dim. kuway-isN, more properly kuyay-isN or kiyay-isN, is much used in the present day as signifying ‡ Elegant, pretty, or beautiful.]
kuwsaI: see Oakoyasu: and kay-isN, in two places.
kiysaI: see Oakoyasu: and kay-isN, in two places.
kayosaAnu ‡ a proper name for Perfidy; (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also Oabuw kayosaAna: (IAạr:) of the dial. of Teiyi: and derived from kayosN. (Kr.) You say, rakiba kayosaAna ‡ He acted perfidiously. (A.)

OakoyasN [More, and most, acute or sharp or quick in intellect; more, and most, shrewd, clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent]: (Lth, ISd, A:) fem. kiysaI (ISd) and kuwsaI: (Lth, ISd:) [in the CK, and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, and in the text of the Ḳ as given in the TA, kiysaI and kuwsaI, each of which is originally kuyosaI, are said to be fems. of Oakowasu; but this is evidently a mistake for Oakoyasu:] pl. kuwsN, [originally kuyosN,] which is applied to women, [as well as men,] and kuwsayaAtN, which is applied to women only. (Lth.) You say, hecaA AlOakoyasu [This is the more, or most, acute, &c.]. (Lth.) And OaI-u AlmuWominiyna Oakoyasu Which of the believers is the most intelligent? (TA.) And it is said in a proverb, Oakoyasu mino qiX-apK (A) [‡ More acute, &c. than] a little female ape or monkey. (TA, art. qX.) And in a trad., Oakoyasu Alkayosi Alt-uqaI waOaHomaqu AlHumoqi Alfujuwru ‡ [The most acute of acuteness is piety, and the most foolish of foolishness, or the most stupid of stupidness, is vice]. (A.)
See also kay-isN.

mukiysapN A woman who brings forth children acute or sharp or quick in intellect; shrewd, clever, ingenious, skilful, knowing, or intelligent: (TA:) and mikoyaAsN↓, who does so usually; contr. of miHomaAqN: (A:) [and mikoyasapN↓, who does so most generally: see an ex. of this under 4.]
mikoyasapN: see mukiysapN and 4.
mukay-asN: see kay-isN.
mikoyaAsN: see mukiysapN.

dictScrap.title: kyS / kyf / kyl / kyn
dictScrap.label:
[kyS, kyf, kyl and kyn
See Supplement.]
